member.name: M:UnityEditor.EditorWindow.ShowUtility
member.summary: Show the EditorWindow as a floating utility window.
member.remarks: Utility windows will always be in front of normal windows, and will be hidden when user switches to another application. Note: You dont need to use EditorWindow.GetWindow() before using this function to show the window.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.EditorWindow.wantsMouseMove
member.summary: Does the GUI in this editor window want MouseMove events?
member.remarks: If set to true, the window recieves an OnGUI call whenever the mouse is moved over the window. Note: This function does not trigger Repaint() Automatically.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.ExportPackageOptions
member.summary: Export package option. Multiple options can be combined together using the | operator.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ExportPackageOptions.Default
member.summary: Default mode. Will not include dependencies or subdirectories nor include Library assets unless specifically included in the asset list.
member.remarks: The export process will happen synchronously, ie. the ExportPackage function will not return until the package is fully exported.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ExportPackageOptions.IncludeDependencies
member.summary: In addition to the assets paths listed, all dependent assets will be included as well.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ExportPackageOptions.IncludeLibraryAssets
member.summary: The exported package will include all library assets, ie. the project settings located in the Library folder of the project.
member.remarks: This is useful for exporting an entire project in a single unitypackage:

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ExportPackageOptions.Interactive
member.summary: The export operation will be run asynchronously and reveal the exported package file in a file browser window after the export is finished.
member.remarks: Note. When interactive mode is enabled, ExportPackage will return immediately before the package file has been created.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ExportPackageOptions.Recurse
member.summary: Will recurse through any subdirectories listed and include all assets inside them.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.FileUtil
member.summary: Lets you do move, copy, delete operations over files or directories.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.FileUtil.CopyFileOrDirectory(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Copies a file or a directory.
member.remarks: This function's path can be relative to the project root folder or be an absolute path. All file separators should be forward ones "/". Make sure to include the name of the files or directories at the end of the "to" argument.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.FileUtil.CopyFileOrDirectoryFollowSymlinks(System.String,System.String)
member.remarks: Copies from from path to the destination, to, path. In presence of symbolic links (OS X only), the actual files to which symbolic links point to are copied, not the symbolic links themselves.See Also: FileUtil.CopyFileOrDirectory.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.FileUtil.DeleteFileOrDirectory(System.String)
member.summary: Deletes a file or a directory given a path.
member.remarks: This function's path is relative to the project root folder but it can also accept absolute paths. All file separators should be forward ones "/" (Unix style).

member.name: M:UnityEditor.FileUtil.GetUniqueTempPathInProject
member.summary: Returns a unique path in the Temp folder within your current project.
member.remarks: The returned path is relative to the project folder. The returned path is of a form Temp/UnityTempFile- uniqueID, where uniqueID is guaranteed to be unique over space and time. You can use it to create temporary files/folders and be sure that you are not overriding somebody else's files, plus you don't have to keep track of the unique IDs yourself.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.FileUtil.MoveFileOrDirectory(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Moves a file or a directory from a given path to another path.
member.remarks: This function's path is relative to the project root folder but it can also accept absolute paths. All file separators should be forward ones "/". Make sure to include the name of the files or directories at the end of the "to" argument.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.FileUtil.ReplaceDirectory(System.String,System.String)
member.remarks: Replaces the directory located at dst with the directory located at src. if dst doesnt exists it copies the file. If dst exists then it deletes it and copies the directory at src to dst See Also: FileUtil.ReplaceFile.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.FileUtil.ReplaceFile(System.String,System.String)
member.remarks: Replaces the file located at dst with the file located at src. if dst doesnt exists it just copies the file. If dst exists then it deletes it and copies the file at src to dst See Also: FileUtil.ReplaceDirectory.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.FontRenderingMode
member.summary: Font rendering mode constants for TrueTypeFontImporter.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.FontRenderingMode.HintedRaster
member.summary: Use hinted font rendering without anti-aliasing. This is the crispest font rendering option, and may be most readable for small.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.FontRenderingMode.HintedSmooth
member.summary: Use Anti-Aliased Font rendering with hinting. This forces character lines to run along pixel boundaries, and generally produces.
member.remarks: A crisper output then FontRenderingMode.Smooth, more similar to the font rendering used on Windows. It is slower to render textures then when using smooth mode, but may be easier to read for small font sizes.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.FontRenderingMode.OSDefault
member.summary: Use the OS default font rendering mode. This selects either FontRenderingMode.HintedSmooth or.
member.remarks: FontRenderingMode.HintedRaster on Windows, and either FontRenderingMode.Smooth or FontRenderingMode.HintedRaster on Mac OS X, depending on the system preferences. This mode is only available for dynamic fonts, as static fonts are generated at build time.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.FontRenderingMode.Smooth
member.summary: Use Anti-Aliased Font rendering. When using dynamic fonts, this is the mode which is fastest in rendering font textures.
member.remarks: This mode looks very similar to the font rendering on Mac OS X.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.FontTextureCase.ASCIILowerCase
member.summary: Only import lower case ASCII character set.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.FontTextureCase.ASCIIUpperCase
member.summary: Only import upper case ASCII character set.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.FontTextureCase.Dynamic
member.summary: Render characters into font texture at runtime as needed.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.FontTextureCase.Unicode
member.summary: Import a set of Unicode characters common for latin scripts.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.Handles
member.summary: Custom 3D GUI controls and drawing in the scene view.
member.remarks: Handles are the 3D controls that Unity uses to manipulate items in the scene view. There are a number of built-in Handle GUIs, such as the familiar tools to position, scale and rotate an object via the Transform component. However, it is also possible to define your own Handle GUIs to use with custom component editors. Such GUIs can be a very useful way to edit procedurally-generated scene content, "invisible" items and groups of related objects, such as waypoints and location markers. You can also supplement the 3D Handle GUI in the scene with 2D buttons and other controls overlaid on the scene view. This is done by enclosing standard Unity GUI calls in a Handles.BeginGUI / EndGUI pair within the / OnSceneGUI / function. You can use HandleUtility.GUIPointToWorldRay and HandleUtility.WorldToGUIPoint to convert coordinates between 2D GUI and 3D world coordinates.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Handles.matrix
member.remarks: To make all Handle routines work in an Object's local coordinate space, set this to Transform.localToWorldMatrix.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Handles.PositionHandle(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Quaternion)
member.summary: Make a 3D Scene view position handle.
member.returns: The new position. If the user has not performed any operation, it will return the same value as you passed it in postion. Use HandleUtility.GetHandleSize where you might want to have constant screen-sized handles.
member.remarks: This will behave like the built-in move tool in Unity. If you have assigned something to Undo.SetSnapshotTarget, it will work fully with Undo. If you have assigned a non-null value to ignoreRaycastObjects, the center handle will support full raycast placement. To control the orientation of the handle, set Handles.matrix prior to calling this function.And the Script attached to this handle:
member.example: //Create a position handle that always looks at "lookAtPoint" in LookAtPoint.js @CustomEditor (LookAtPoint) class PositionHandleJS extends Editor { function OnSceneGUI () { target.lookAtPoint = Handles.PositionHandle (target.lookAtPoint, Quaternion.identity); if (GUI.changed) EditorUtility.SetDirty (target); } } // LookAtPoint.js // This Script has to be outside of the editor folder. // // Usage: Just Place this script on the object you want to work the handle with. @script ExecuteInEditMode() var lookAtPoint = Vector3.zero; function Update () { transform.LookAt (lookAtPoint); }
member.param: Center of the handle in 3D space.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Handles.RadiusHandle(UnityEngine.Quaternion,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Make a Scene view radius handle.
member.returns: The modified radius Use HandleUtility.GetHandleSize where you might want to have constant screen-sized handles.
member.remarks: And the Script attached to this handle:
member.example: // Simple script that draws and controls a float var on any GameObject that has the // ColliderRadius.js script attached. @CustomEditor (ColliderRadius) class RadiusHandleJS extends Editor { function OnSceneGUI () { target.areaOfEffect = Handles.RadiusHandle (Quaternion.identity, target.transform.position, target.areaOfEffect); if (GUI.changed) EditorUtility.SetDirty (target); } } // Place this script where you want to see the RadiusHandler working on. var areaOfEffect : float = 1;
member.param: Center of the handle in 3D space.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Handles.RadiusHandle(UnityEngine.Quaternion,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Make a Scene view radius handle.
member.returns: The modified radius Use HandleUtility.GetHandleSize where you might want to have constant screen-sized handles.
member.remarks: And the Script attached to this handle:
member.example: // Simple script that draws and controls a float var on any GameObject that has the // ColliderRadius.js script attached. @CustomEditor (ColliderRadius) class RadiusHandleJS extends Editor { function OnSceneGUI () { target.areaOfEffect = Handles.RadiusHandle (Quaternion.identity, target.transform.position, target.areaOfEffect); if (GUI.changed) EditorUtility.SetDirty (target); } } // Place this script where you want to see the RadiusHandler working on. var areaOfEffect : float = 1;
member.param: Center of the handle in 3D space.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Handles.RotationHandle(UnityEngine.Quaternion,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Make a Scene view rotation handle.
member.returns: The modified rotation Use HandleUtility.GetHandleSize where you might want to have constant screen-sized handles.
member.remarks: This will behave like the built-in rotation tool in Unity. If you have assigned something to Undo.SetSnapshotTarget, it will work fully with Undo.And the script attached to this handle:
member.example: //Create a rotation handle at (0,0,0) and rotate any object that has "RotateAtPoint.js" // attached from 0,0,0. @CustomEditor (RotateAtPoint) class RotationHandleJS extends Editor { function OnSceneGUI () { target.rot = Handles.RotationHandle (target.rot, Vector3.zero); if (GUI.changed) EditorUtility.SetDirty (target); } } // RotateAtPoint.js // This Script has to be outside of the editor folder. // // Usage: Just Place this script on the object you want to work the handle with. // And control the Object's rotation from the handle that appears at 0,0,0 when // This object is selected. @script ExecuteInEditMode() var rot : Quaternion = Quaternion.identity; function Update () { transform.rotation = rot; }
member.param: Center of the handle in 3D space.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Handles.ScaleHandle(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Quaternion,System.Single)
member.summary: Make a Scene view scale handle.
member.returns: The new scale vector. Use HandleUtility.GetHandleSize where you might want to have constant screen-sized handles.
member.remarks: This will behave like the built-in scale toolAnd the script Attached to this Handle:
member.example: // Creates a "Big" (5 times size) Scale handle that will be present whenever // you select the target GameObject @CustomEditor (ScaleAtPoint) class ScaleHandleJS extends Editor { function OnSceneGUI () { target.sc = Handles.ScaleHandle (target.sc, target.transform.position, target.transform.rotation, 5.0); Debug.Log(target.sc); if (GUI.changed) EditorUtility.SetDirty (target); } } // ScaleAtPoint.js // Usage: Place this script on the GameObject you want to use the // editor-created scale handle. @script ExecuteInEditMode() var sc : Vector3 = Vector3(1,1,1); function Update () { transform.localScale = sc; }

member.name: T:UnityEditor.HandleUtility
member.summary: Helper functions for Scene View style 3D GUI.
member.remarks: These are mainly mathematical functions that assist in converting between the 3D scene space and the 2D GUI. The functions are used in the construction of the Unity editor itself and so using them is a good way to make your own Handle GUIs consistent with Unity's.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.acceleration
member.summary: Get standard acceleration for dragging values (Read Only).
member.remarks: Normal acceleration is 1.0. When Shift is pressed, it is 4.0; when Alt is pressed, acceleration is 0.25. See Also: niceMouseDelta.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.AddControl(System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Record a distance measurement from a handle.
member.remarks: All handles call this with their controlID during layout, then use nearestControl to check if they got the mouseDown.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.AddDefaultControl(System.Int32)
member.summary: Add the ID for a default control. This will be picked if nothing else is.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.CalcLineTranslation(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Map a mouse drag onto a movement along a line in 3D space.
member.remarks: Certain types of Handles (such as arrows) involve movement along a line in 3D space. For example, the Transform's position arrows move the object along its local X, Y or Z axis as the mouse is dragged. The CalcLineTranslation function converts the movement of the mouse into constrained movement along a 3D line in the familiar way used by Unity's built-in tools.
member.param: The source point of the drag.
The destination point of the drag.
The 3D position the dragged object had at src ray.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.ClosestPointToArc(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Get the point on an arc (in 3D space) which is closest to the current mouse position.
member.remarks: This function takes the arc defined by its parameters and "flattens" it into screen space. The closest point between the flattened arc and the current mouse position (also in screen space) is then found and converted back into a 3D point on the original 3D arc. This is useful for Handle GUIs that involve rotation of an object around the center of the arc; the 2D mouse movements are converted into 3D space in the familiar way used by Unity's built-in tools.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.ClosestPointToDisc(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Get the point on an disc (in 3D space) which is closest to the current mouse position.
member.remarks: This function takes the disc defined by its parameters and "flattens" it into screen space. The closest point between the flattened disc and the current mouse position (also in screen space) is then found and converted back into a 3D point on the original 3D disc. This is useful for Handle GUIs that involve rotation of an object around the center of the disc; the 2D mouse movements are converted into 3D space in the familiar way used by Unity's built-in tools.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.ClosestPointToPolyLine(UnityEngine.Vector3[])
member.summary: Get the point on a polyline (in 3D space) which is closest to the current mouse position.
member.remarks: A polyline is simply a zigzag line defined by a set of points connected in sequence. The ClosestPointToPolyLine function takes the polyline defined by a point array and "flattens" it into screen space. The closest point between the flattened line and the current mouse position (also in screen space) is then found and converted back into a 3D point on the original 3D polyline. This is useful for Handle GUIs that involve manipulating an arbitrary 3D shape using the mouse; the 2D mouse movements are converted into 3D space in the familiar way used by Unity's built-in tools. An example of where this might be used is a racetrack defined by a set of waypoints - a position along the track line could be selected via the mouse using ClosestPointToPolyLine.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.DistancePointBezier(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Calculate distance between a point and a Bezier curve.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.DistancePointLine(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Calculate distance between a point and a line.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.DistancePointToLine(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Distance from a point p in 2d to a line defined by two points a and b.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.DistancePointToLineSegment(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Distance from a point p in 2d to a line segment defined by two points a and b.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.DistanceToArc(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Pixel distance from mouse pointer to a 3D section of a disc.
member.remarks: Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the disc section at given world space position with the given radius and normal. The disc section is defined by from vector and the angle in degrees. Uses the current camera to determine the distance. See Also: DistanceToDisc, DistanceToCircle.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.DistanceToCircle(UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Pixel distance from mouse pointer to camera facing circle.
member.remarks: Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the circle at given world space position with the given radius. The circle is assumed to be facing the camera. Uses the current camera to determine the distance. See Also: DistanceToDisc.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.DistanceToDisc(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Pixel distance from mouse pointer to a 3D disc.
member.remarks: Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the disc (circle) at given world space position with the given radius and normal. Uses the current camera to determine the distance. See Also: DistanceToCircle.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.DistanceToLine(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Pixel distance from mouse pointer to line.
member.remarks: Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the line between p1 and p2 world space points. Uses the current camera to determine the distance.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.DistanceToPolyLine(UnityEngine.Vector3[])
member.summary: Pixel distance from mouse pointer to a polyline.
member.remarks: Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the multi segment line that goes through the given world space points. Uses the current camera to determine the distance. See Also: DistanceToLine.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.DistanceToRectangle(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Quaternion,System.Single)
member.summary: Pixel distance from mouse pointer to a rectangle on screen.
member.remarks: Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the rectangle. Uses the current camera to determine the distance.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.GetHandleSize(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Get world space size of a manipulator handle at given position.
member.remarks: Uses the current camera to calculate suitable size.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.GUIPointToWorldRay(UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Convert 2D GUI position to a world space ray.
member.remarks: Uses the current camera to calculate the ray. See Also: WorldToGUIPoint, RaySnap.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.niceMouseDelta
member.summary: Get nice mouse delta to use for dragging a float value (Read Only).
member.remarks: This will autodetect the users preference for X / Y axis dragging and give you back a float that is measured accordingly. This also handles modifier keys correctly, i.e. the delta is already multiplied by acceleration. See Also: acceleration, niceMouseDeltaZoom.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.niceMouseDeltaZoom
member.summary: Get nice mouse delta to use for zooming (Read Only).
member.remarks: This will autodetect the users preference for X / Y axis dragging and give you back a float that is measured accordingly. This also handles modifier keys correctly, i.e. the delta is already multiplied by acceleration. See Also: acceleration, niceMouseDelta.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.PickGameObject(UnityEngine.Vector2,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Pick GameObject closest to specified position.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.PickRectObjects(UnityEngine.Rect)
member.summary: Pick GameObjects that lie within a specified screen rectangle.
member.remarks: This is useful for implementing multi-select tools that allow the user to drag a rectangle around the desired objects.
member.param: An screen rectangle specified with pixel coordinates.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.PickRectObjects(UnityEngine.Rect,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Pick GameObjects that lie within a specified screen rectangle.
member.remarks: This is useful for implementing multi-select tools that allow the user to drag a rectangle around the desired objects.
member.param: An screen rectangle specified with pixel coordinates.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.PointOnLineParameter(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns the parameter for the projection of the point on the given line.
member.remarks: The return value can be negative if the projected point is in negative lineDirection relative to the linePoint See Also: ProjectPointLine.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.PopCamera(UnityEngine.Camera)
member.remarks: A call to PopCamera will retrieve the most recently stored Camera settings added to a "stack" structure by PushCamera. This allows for easy saving and restoration of temporary camera changes.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.ProjectPointLine(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.remarks: See Also: DistancePointLine. See Also: PointOnLineParameter.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.PushCamera(UnityEngine.Camera)
member.remarks: The camera settings will be added to a so-called "stack" list, where they will stay until retrieved by a call to PopCamera. The settings will be stored in the reverse of the order in which they were added, so a call to PopCamera will retrieve the most recently stored Camera data and then remove it from the stack. A subsequent call to PopCamera will then retrieve the next most recently pushed data and so on.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.RaySnap(UnityEngine.Ray)
member.summary: Casts ray against the scene and report if an object lies in its path.
member.returns: A boxed RaycastHit, null if nothing hit it.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.WorldPointToSizedRect(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.GUIContent,UnityEngine.GUIStyle)
member.summary: Calculate a rectangle to display a 2D GUI element near a projected point in 3D space.
member.remarks: This function is useful when 3D objects need labels or other 2D controls that follow them around in 3D space as the camera moves.
member.param: The content to make room for.
The style to use. The style's alignment.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.WorldToGUIPoint(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Convert world space point to a 2D GUI position.
member.remarks: Uses the current camera to calculate the projection. See Also: GUIPointToWorldRay, RaySnap.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.Highlighter
member.summary: Use this class to highlight elements in the editor for use in in-editor tutorials and similar.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Highlighter.active
member.summary: Is there currently an active highlight?

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Highlighter.activeRect
member.summary: The rect in screenspace of the current active highlight.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Highlighter.activeText
member.summary: The text of the current active highlight.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Highlighter.activeVisible
member.summary: Is the current active highlight visible yet?
member.remarks: If the element to be highlighted is inside a scrollview, the scrollview automatically scrolls to reveal the element. Once it is within view, activeViisble will be true.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Highlighter.Highlight(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Highlights an element in the editor.
member.returns: if the requested element was found; otherwise.
member.remarks: This function will highlight the specified element in the specified window. If the element could not be found, the function returns false. If the element is inside a scrollview and is not currently visible, the scrollview will first automatically scroll to reveal the element and then highlight it. Once the element is highlighted it will stay highlighted until either the Highlighter.Stop function is called, or the element disappears from view. The element could disappear from view if the user scrolls away from it, the window is closed, the section of the GUI with the element in it is collapsed or otherwise hidden, or when starting or stopping Play Mode. Most EditorGUI controls can be highlighted using their label as identifier.Any control that uses the SerializedProperty system can be highlighted using its SerializedProperty.propertyPath .Any element with text in it can be highlighted using that text as identifier, which is for example useful for buttons.See the HighlightSearchMode enum for more details on identifying elements. See Also: Highlighter.Stop, Highlighter.HighlightIdentifier.
member.param: The title of the window the element is inside.
The text to identify the element with.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Highlighter.Highlight(System.String,System.String,UnityEditor.HighlightSearchMode)
member.summary: Highlights an element in the editor.
member.returns: if the requested element was found; otherwise.
member.remarks: This function will highlight the specified element in the specified window. If the element could not be found, the function returns false. If the element is inside a scrollview and is not currently visible, the scrollview will first automatically scroll to reveal the element and then highlight it. Once the element is highlighted it will stay highlighted until either the Highlighter.Stop function is called, or the element disappears from view. The element could disappear from view if the user scrolls away from it, the window is closed, the section of the GUI with the element in it is collapsed or otherwise hidden, or when starting or stopping Play Mode. Most EditorGUI controls can be highlighted using their label as identifier.Any control that uses the SerializedProperty system can be highlighted using its SerializedProperty.propertyPath .Any element with text in it can be highlighted using that text as identifier, which is for example useful for buttons.See the HighlightSearchMode enum for more details on identifying elements. See Also: Highlighter.Stop, Highlighter.HighlightIdentifier.
member.param: The title of the window the element is inside.
The text to identify the element with.
Optional mode to specify how to search for the element.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Highlighter.HighlightIdentifier(UnityEngine.Rect,System.String)
member.summary: Call this method to create an identifiable rect that the Highlighter can find.
member.remarks: If you want a custom rect in an EditorWindow or custom Editor to be highlightable, you can call this method to specify the rect and the identifier text for that rect. That will make it possible for the Highlighter to highlight the rect.
member.param: The identifier text of the rect.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.HighlightSearchMode
member.summary: Used to specify how to find a given element in the editor to highlight.
member.remarks: Let's consider various approaches to highlighting the Scale control in the Transform component. Using the HighlightSearchMode.PrefixLabel mode you can specify the label text "Scale" as the identifier to highlight the entire Scale control with both label and all three number fields included. This mode can't be used if you want to only highlight the X component of the Scale control. Since the label text of the X component is simply "X", you would get the X component of the Position control instead if you attempted that. The HighlightSearchMode.PrefixLabel mode works for any control that uses EditorGUI.PrefixLabel or EditorGUI.HandlePrefixLabel. If you use the HighlightSearchMode.Content mode to seach for the text "Scale", only the label itself will be highlighted. This mode can highlight what corresponds to a single GUIStyle.Draw call and hence cannot highlight composite controls. It is particularly useful for highlighting buttons. The HighlightSearchMode.Identifier mode searches for rects explicitly marked to be highlightable using the Highlighter.HighlightIdentifier function. This is for example done for all controls that uses the SerializedProperty system, using the SerializedProperty.propertyPath as the identifier. This means you could use this mode to highlight the X component of the Scale control by searching for "m_LocalScale.x". The HighlightSearchMode.Auto mode searches using all the above modes and can be used in most cases. Searching for "Scale" using this mode will highlight the entire Scale control rather than just the label, since the PrefixLabel handling is hit before the GUIStyle.Draw call of the label. See Also: Highlighter.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.HighlightSearchMode.Auto
member.summary: Highlights the first element found using any of the search modes.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.HighlightSearchMode.Content
member.summary: Highlights an element containing text using the text as identifier.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.HighlightSearchMode.Identifier
member.summary: Highlights an element with a given identifier text.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.HighlightSearchMode.PrefixLabel
member.summary: Highlights an entire editor control using its label text as identifier.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ImportAssetOptions.DontDownloadFromCacheServer
member.summary: Force a full reimport but don't download the assets from the cache server.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ImportAssetOptions.ForceSynchronousImport
member.remarks: By default some assets can be imported asynchronously (e.g. scripts can be compiled in the background). In some cases all importing needs to be synchronous; use this flag then. For example, when importing a scripts + prefabs, scripts have to be fully compiled before prefab is serialized, otherwise it might get old variables. See Also: AssetDatabase.ImportAsset, AssetDatabase.Refresh.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ImportAssetOptions.ForceUncompressedImport
member.summary: Forces asset import as uncompressed for edition facilities.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ImportAssetOptions.ForceUpdate
member.remarks: This should be passed when asset import is caused by the user (e.g. by clicking Reimport). Non-user initiated import happens when the asset modification time changes. See Also: AssetDatabase.ImportAsset, AssetDatabase.Refresh.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ImportAssetOptions.ImportRecursive
member.summary: When a folder is imported, import all its contents as well.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.InitializeOnLoadAttribute
member.summary: Allow an editor class to be initialized when Unity loads without action from the user.
member.remarks: See Also: Running Editor Code on Launch.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.iOSTargetOSVersion.Unknown
member.summary: Unknown iOS version, managed by user.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.LightmapBakeQuality.High
member.summary: High quality bake for final renderings.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.LightmapBakeQuality.Low
member.summary: Low quality bake for preview renderings.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings
member.remarks: The bake can be started via Lightmapping class. See Also: Lightmapping.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.aoAmount
member.summary: Controls how much Ambient Occlusion to blend into the Final Gather solution.
member.remarks: Can be used to get more contrast in your lighting. Set to a value greater than 0 for AO to be calculated.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.aoContrast
member.summary: Controls the look of the transition from black to white.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.aoMaxDistance
member.summary: Beyond this distance a ray is considered to be unoccluded.
member.remarks: Can be used to avoid full occlusion in closed scenes.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.bounceBoost
member.summary: Boosts indirect light (Beast's diffuseBoost property, pow(colorComponent, (1.0 / diffuseBoost))).
member.remarks: It can be used to increase the amount of bounced light within a scene and it's cheaper than setting the number of bounces to high values.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.bounces
member.summary: Number of light bounces in the global illumination computation (with 0 meaning direct light only).

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.finalGatherContrastThreshold
member.summary: Contrast threshold between neighbouring surface points.
member.remarks: Above that value new final gather sample points will be created - it tells the algorithm to place points where they are really needed, so in areas where the light changes quickly. In other words, it adaptively controls the number of points.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.finalGatherGradientThreshold
member.summary: Controls how the irradiance gradient is used in the interpolation.
member.remarks: Each point stores its irradiance gradient which can be used to improve the interpolation. However in some situations using the gradient can result in white halos and other artifacts. Setting the threshold to a lower value can be used to reduce those artifacts.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.finalGatherInterpolationPoints
member.summary: The number of final gather points to interpolate between.
member.remarks: Higher values give smoother results, but can also smooth out details in the lighting.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.finalGatherRays
member.summary: Number of rays used in the final gather integrator.
member.remarks: Since lower number of rays leads to creating points of higher variance (so a higher contrast difference), you will probably need a higher setting for finalGatherContrastThreshold to prevent points from clumping together.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.lastUsedResolution
member.summary: Last used lightmap resolution (i.e. resolution of the lightmaps currently in the scene) in texels per world unit.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.lockAtlas
member.summary: If enabled, Beast atlasing won't be run and lightmap indices, tiling and offset won't be modified on Mesh Renderers.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.maxAtlasHeight
member.summary: The maximum height of an individual lightmap texture.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.maxAtlasWidth
member.summary: The maximum width of an individual lightmap texture.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.quality
member.remarks: Controls Beast's final gather and anti-aliasing settings (some of which are also exposed in Unity).

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.resolution
member.summary: Lightmap resolution in texels per world unit.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.skyLightIntensity
member.remarks: Sky light can give very good results in outdoor scenes but also significantly increases bake time. Value of 0 disables sky light.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.LightmapEditorSettings.textureCompression
member.summary: Whether to use DXT1 compression on the generated lightmaps.
member.remarks: Compression is recommended to improve lightmap rendering performance and lower the memory footprint, but might introduce visible artifacts in scenes without high-detail texturing that would mask-out the issues.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.Lightmapping
member.summary: Allows to control the lightmapping job.
member.remarks: Before starting the job the bake settings can be set via LightmapEditorSettings. See Also: LightmapEditorSettings.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Lightmapping.Bake
member.remarks: Returns when the lightmapping has finished.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Lightmapping.BakeAsync
member.remarks: The progress can be monitored via isRunning property.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Lightmapping.BakeLightProbesOnly
member.summary: Starts a synchronous bake job, but only bakes light probes.
member.remarks: Returns when the lightmapping has finished.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Lightmapping.BakeLightProbesOnlyAsync
member.summary: Starts an asynchronous bake job, but only bakes light probes.
member.remarks: The progress can be monitored via isRunning property.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Lightmapping.BakeSelected
member.summary: Stars a synchronous bake job for the selected objects.
member.remarks: Returns when the lightmapping has finished.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Lightmapping.BakeSelectedAsync
member.summary: Starts an asynchronous bake job for the selected objects.
member.remarks: The progress can be monitored via isRunning property.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Lightmapping.Cancel
member.summary: Cancels the currently running asynchronous bake job.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Lightmapping.Clear
member.summary: Deletes all lightmap assets and makes all lights behave as if they weren't baked yet.
member.remarks: Only those assets are deleted that are in the folder with the same name as the scene name AND their name follows the pattern LightmapFar-#.exr or LightmapNear-#.exr. If LightmapEditorSettings.lockAtlas is disabled, it will also clear the lightmaps array and clear lightmap indices on all objects. Baked light probes are cleared as well.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Lightmapping.isRunning
member.summary: Returns true when the bake job is running, false otherwise (Read Only).

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Lightmapping.Tetrahedralize(UnityEngine.Vector3[],System.Int32[]@,UnityEngine.Vector3[]@)
member.summary: Calculates a Delaunay Tetrahedralization of the 'positions' point set - the same way the lightmapper.
member.remarks: Tetrahedralizes the space for Light Probes. outIndices index into the array of outPositions and every four indices correspond to a tetrahedron. During the tetrahedralization any position duplicates withing some tolerance are removed (the first element is kept, subsequent are removed), so outPositions might have fewer elements than positions.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.LODUtility.CalculateLODGroupBoundingBox(UnityEngine.LODGroup)
member.summary: Recalculate the bounding region for the given LODGroup.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.MacFullscreenMode
member.remarks: This defines how fullscreen mode is handled on Mac OS X Standalones.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.MacFullscreenMode.CaptureDisplay
member.remarks: In this mode Unity will capture the display and change the hardware resolution to the requested mode. No other UI content can appear, and it is not possible to switch to other applications while in fullscreen mode.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.MacFullscreenMode.FullscreenWindow
member.remarks: In this mode, Unity will create a window which is covering the whole screen. It will always run at desktop resolution, and other requested resolutions will be scaled up. OS UI will correctly show on top of the fullscreen window (such as IME input windows, GameCenter or Mac App Store UI, Battery warnings, etc). On OS X 10.7 and newer, it is possible to switch to other Applications using trackpad swipes or Cmd-Tab.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.MacFullscreenMode.FullscreenWindowWithDockAndMenuBar
member.summary: Fullscreen window with Dock and Menu bar.
member.remarks: Same as Fullscreen window mode, but Unity will also show the Menu bar and Dock if the cursor moves to the edges of the screen, like other OS X fullscreen Apps. It is possible to switch between fullscreen and windowed modes using the fullscreen button in the window title bar (or in the menu bar in fullscreen mode).

member.name: T:UnityEditor.MaterialPropertyDrawer
member.summary: Base class to derive custom material property drawers from.
member.remarks: Use this to create custom UI drawers for your material properties, without having to write custom MaterialEditor classes. This is similar to how PropertyDrawer enables custom UI without writing custom inspectors. In shader code, C#-like attribute syntax can be used in front of shader properties to add drawers to them. Unity has several built-in drawers, and you can write your own. Here's a shader code snippet demonstrating the syntax:The built-in MaterialPropertyDrawers are: ToggleDrawer, EnumDrawer, KeywordEnumDrawer, PowerSliderDrawer. In shader code, the "Drawer" suffix of the class name is not written; when Unity searches for the drawer class it adds "Drawer" automatically. Toggle displays a float as a toggle. The property value will be 0 or 1, depending on the toggle state. When it is on, a shader keyword with the uppercase property name +"_ON" will be set, or an explicitly specified shader keyword.Enum displays a popup menu for a float property. You can supply either an enum type name (preferably fully qualified with namespaces, in case there are multiple types), or explicit name/value pairs to display. Up to 7 name/value pairs can be specified.KeywordEnum displays a popup menu for a float property, and enables corresponding shader keyword. This is used with "#pragma multi_compile" in shaders, to enable or disable parts of shader code. Each name will enable "property name" + underscore + "enum name", uppercased, shader keyword. Up to 9 names can be provided.PowerSlider displays a slider with a non-linear response for a Range shader property.Note that for performance reasons, EditorGUILayout functions are not usable with MaterialPropertyDrawers. See Also: MaterialProperty class, MaterialHelper class.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.MaterialPropertyDrawer.Apply(UnityEditor.MaterialProperty)
member.summary: Apply extra initial values to the material.
member.remarks: This function is called in all property drawers when a new material is created, or a shader is changed on an existing material. This lets the property drawers apply any extra values to the materials, for example to setup shader keywords. Note that if you change a property by assigning a value to it, Apply() is not called automatically. If you have any extra setup you need it to do, you should call it yourself.
member.param: The MaterialProperty to apply values for.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.MaterialPropertyDrawer.GetPropertyHeight(UnityEditor.MaterialProperty,System.String,UnityEditor.MaterialEditor)
member.summary: Override this method to specify how tall the GUI for this property is in pixels.
member.remarks: The default is one line high.
member.param: The MaterialProperty to make the custom GUI for.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.MaterialPropertyDrawer.OnGUI(UnityEngine.Rect,UnityEditor.MaterialProperty,System.String,UnityEditor.MaterialEditor)
member.summary: Override this method to make your own GUI for the property.
member.param: Rectangle on the screen to use for the property GUI.
The MaterialProperty to make the custom GUI for.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.MenuCommand
member.summary: Used to extract the context for a MenuItem. MenuCommand objects are passed to custom menu item functions defined using the MenuItem attribute.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.MenuCommand.context
member.summary: Context is the object that is the target of a menu command.
member.remarks: Usually the context is the current selection or the item under the mouse when invoking a context menu.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.MenuCommand.userData
member.summary: An integer for passing custom information to a menu item.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.MenuItem
member.summary: The MenuItem attribute allows you to add menu items to the main menu and inspector context menus.
member.remarks: The MenuItem attribute turns any static function into a menu command. Only static functions can use the MenuItem attribute. To create a hotkey you can use the following special characters: % (ctrl on Windows, cmd on OS X), # (shift), & (alt), _ (no key modifiers). For example to create a menu with hotkey shift-alt-g use "MyMenu/Do Something #&g". To create a menu with hotkey g and no key modifiers pressed use "MyMenu/Do Something _g". Some special keyboard keys are supported as hotkeys, for example "#LEFT" would map to shift-left. The keys supported like this are: LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN, F1 .. F12, HOME, END, PGUP, PGDN. A hotkey text must be preceded with a space character ( "MyMenu/Do_g" won't be interpreted as hotkey, while "MyMenu/Do _g" will).

member.name: M:UnityEditor.MeshUtility.Optimize(UnityEngine.Mesh)
member.summary: Optimizes the mesh for GPU access.
member.remarks: This operation might take a while but will make the geometry displayed be faster. You should use it if you generate a mesh from scratch procedurally and you want to trade better runtime performance against higher load time. Internally it converts the mesh to triangle list and optimizes the triangles and vertices for both pre and post transform cache locality. For imported models you should never call this as the import pipeline already does it for you.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.MeshUtility.SetPerTriangleUV2(UnityEngine.Mesh,UnityEngine.Vector2[])
member.summary: Will insert per-triangle uv2 in mesh and handle vertex splitting etc.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.ModelImporter

member.remarks: Settings of this class match the ones exposed in Mesh Import Settings.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.addCollider
member.summary: Add mesh colliders to imported meshes.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.animationCompression
member.remarks: Compressing animations saves space in the built game, but more compression introduces more artifacts in the animation data. See Also: ModelImporterAnimationCompression.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.animationPositionError
member.summary: Allowed error of animation position compression.
member.remarks: Allowed error is defined in distance (in percents) between compressed and original positions on a curve. This settings used only when animation keyframe reduction is enabled. See Also: animationCompression, ModelImporterAnimationCompression.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.animationRotationError
member.summary: Allowed error of animation rotation compression.
member.remarks: Allowed error is defined in angle (in degrees) between compressed and original quaternions on a curve. This settings used only when animation keyframe reduction is enabled. See Also: animationCompression, ModelImporterAnimationCompression.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.animationScaleError
member.summary: Allowed error of animation scale compression.
member.remarks: Allowed error is defined in distance (in percents) between compressed and original scale on a curve. This settings used only when animation keyframe reduction is enabled. See Also: animationCompression, ModelImporterAnimationCompression.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.animationWrapMode
member.summary: The default wrap mode for the generated animation clips.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.clipAnimations
member.summary: Animation clips to split animation into.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.generateSecondaryUV
member.summary: Generate secondary UV set for lightmapping.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.importMaterials
member.remarks: When set to false ModelImporter will use default material (Default-Diffuse.mat) instead of imported materials, otherwise it will find existing or create new materials based on materialName and materialSearch options. See Also: materialName, materialSearch options.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.isBakeIKSupported
member.summary: Is Bake Inverse Kinematics (IK) supported by this importer.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.isReadable
member.summary: Are mesh vertices and indices accessible from script?
member.remarks: Making a mesh readable will keep two copies of it in memory, one for rendering and one in system memory for script access. Setting isReadable to false therefore saves memory. Scaling a mesh with different amounts along the three axes (i.e. non-uniform scaling) requires the mesh to be readable for correct lighting. In the Unity editor access is always permitted when not in play mode.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.isTangentImportSupported
member.summary: Is import of tangents supported by this importer.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.isUseFileUnitsSupported
member.summary: Is useFileUnits supported for this asset.
member.remarks: UseFileUnits is supported only on .max files. See Also: useFileUnits.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.materialName
member.remarks: When importing new model Unity will generate material name based on this setting and then it will try to locate existing material with such name, if no such material exists Unity will create a new material by that name. See Also: ModelImporterMaterialName, materialSearch, importMaterials.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.materialSearch
member.remarks: When importing new model Unity will try to find existing materials in a set of folders based on this setting. See Also: ModelImporterMaterialSearch, materialName, importMaterials.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.meshCompression
member.remarks: Compressing meshes saves space in the built game, but more compression introduces more artifacts in vertex data. See Also: ModelImporterMeshCompression.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.normalSmoothingAngle
member.remarks: How sharp the edge has to be to be turned into a hard edge when calculating normals. This setting is only used when normalImportMode is set to Calculate. See Also: normalImportMode.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.optimizeMesh
member.remarks: The vertices and indices will be reordered for better GPU performance. Techniques that require strict vertex ordering like mesh morphing or special particle mesh emitter effects should have this option disabled.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.referencedClips

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.secondaryUVAngleDistortion

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.secondaryUVPackMargin

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.splitTangentsAcrossSeams
member.summary: Should tangents be split across UV seams.
member.remarks: This setting is only used when tangentImportMode is set to Calculate. See Also: tangentImportMode.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.swapUVChannels
member.summary: Swap primary and secondary UV channels when importing.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.transformPaths
member.summary: Generates the list of all imported Transforms.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.ModelImporter.useFileUnits
member.summary: Detect file units and import as 1FileUnit=1UnityUnit, otherwise it will import as 1cm=1UnityUnit.
member.remarks: This setting is used only for .max files. It was introduced for backwards compatibility: there is a bug in some FBX 2011 plugins - they fail to pick up file units and export everything as 1unit=1cm. We fixed that problem by setting the units manually, but that breaks projects which were built with FBX 2011 plugins already, so useFileUnits was introduced as a solution. Set it to false if you want to default to centimeters in FBX exporter. See Also: isUseFileUnitsSupported.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ModelImporterMaterialSearch.Everywhere
member.remarks: Unity will search for the material in all folders of Unity project. See Also: ModelImporter.materialSearch.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ModelImporterMaterialSearch.Local
member.remarks: Unity will try to locate the material in local Materials folder, i.e. in path modelFilePath/Materials. For example: if model is Assets Model MyModel.fbx, then it will try to locate the material in Assets Model Materials folder. See Also: ModelImporter.materialSearch.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ModelImporterMaterialSearch.RecursiveUp
member.remarks: Unity will perform a recursive-up search for the material in all Materials folders up to the Assets folder. For example: if model is Assets Model MyModel.fbx, then it will try to locate the material in these folders in this order: Assets Model Materials, Assets/Materials. See Also: ModelImporter.materialSearch.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.ModelImporterMeshCompression
member.remarks: Compressing meshes saves space in the built game, but more compression introduces more artifacts in vertex data. See Also: ModelImporter.meshCompression.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ModelImporterMeshCompression.High
member.remarks: Vertex positions, normals/tangents and UVs will be quantized to respectively 10, 6, 8 bits per component. Skinning information will be compressed. See Also: ModelImporter.meshCompression.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ModelImporterMeshCompression.Low
member.remarks: Vertex positions, normals/tangents and UVs will be quantized to respectively 20, 8, 16 bits per component. Skinning information will be compressed. See Also: ModelImporter.meshCompression.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ModelImporterMeshCompression.Medium
member.remarks: Vertex positions, normals/tangents and UVs will be quantized to respectively 16, 8, 10 bits per component. Skinning information will be compressed. See Also: ModelImporter.meshCompression.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ModelImporterTangentSpaceMode.Calculate
member.remarks: It is recommended to use Import mode as long as you can - use Calculate only if you don't have normals/tangents in your file. See Also: ModelImporter.normalImportMode, ModelImporter.tangentImportMode.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.ModelImporterTangentSpaceMode.None
member.remarks: If normals/tangents are not needed by all shaders, this can be a simple way to reduce build size a little. See Also: ModelImporter.normalImportMode, ModelImporter.tangentImportMode.

member.remarks: Most platforms support viewing icons in multiple sizes so Unity lets you specify multiple icon textures for each platform. Each texture in the returned array correspond to the corresponding entry in the list of icon sizes returned by GetIconSizesForTargetGroup.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.GetIconSizesForTargetGroup(UnityEditor.BuildTargetGroup)
member.summary: Returns a list of icon sizes for the specified platform.
member.remarks: Most platforms support viewing icons in multiple sizes so Unity lets you specify multiple icon textures for each platform. Use this function to get the sizes to use for the specified platform, where each size specifies both the width and height in pixels.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.GetScriptingDefineSymbolsForGroup(UnityEditor.BuildTargetGroup)

member.name: P:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.gpuSkinning
member.summary: Enable GPU skinning on capable platforms.
member.remarks: DX11, OpenGL ES 3.0 and Xbox 360 can do mesh skinning on the GPU.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.HasAspectRatio(UnityEditor.AspectRatio)
member.summary: Returns whether or not the specified aspect ratio is enabled.
member.remarks: Aspect Ratios selectable in the Resolution Dialog will be monitor-supported resolutions of enabled items from this list.

member.remarks: Set this to change how fullscreen mode is handled in Mac OS X standalone games. See MacFullscreenMode for description on the possible modes.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.ps3BootCheckMaxSaveGameSizeKB
member.summary: PS3 Bootcheck maximum savegame size ( as per TRC R224 ). This should include the total estimated size for the savegames (including icon sizes).

member.summary: Use resizable window in standalone player builds.
member.remarks: By default standalone Windows, Mac and Linux builds use a non-resizable game window. Enabling this makes the window resizable.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.SetAspectRatio(UnityEditor.AspectRatio,System.Boolean)
member.remarks: Aspect Ratios selectable in the Resolution Dialog will be monitor-supported resolutions of enabled items from this list.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.SetIconsForTargetGroup(UnityEditor.BuildTargetGroup,UnityEngine.Texture2D[])
member.summary: Assign a list of icons for the specified platform.
member.remarks: Most platforms support viewing icons in multiple sizes so Unity lets you specify multiple icon textures for each platform. The list will only be assigned if it has the same length as the list of icon sizes returned by GetIconSizesForTargetGroup and if the specified platform is supported in this editor.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.SetScriptingDefineSymbolsForGroup(UnityEditor.BuildTargetGroup,System.String)
member.summary: Set user-specified symbols for script compilation for the given build target group.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.statusBarHidden
member.summary: Should status bar be hidden. Shared between iOS & Android platforms.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.stripPhysics
member.summary: Remove Physics code from player to save build size (Flash and NaCl only).

member.name: P:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.stripUnusedMeshComponents
member.summary: Should unused Mesh components be excluded from game build?
member.remarks: When this setting is on, Mesh components (e.g. tangent vectors, vertex colors etc.) that are not in use will be removed. This is good for game data size and runtime performance. However, be aware of this flag if you're switching shaders on some objects at runtime. For example, if a mesh uses a simple Diffuse shader when building the game, Unity will remove tangent vectors since they are not needed. If you'd want to switch to a bumpmapped shader on this mesh at runtime, you will not get proper tangent data since it was removed!

member.name: P:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.useAnimatedAutorotation
member.summary: Let the OS autorotate the screen as the device orientation changes.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.useDirect3D11
member.summary: Should Direct3D 11 be used when available?

member.name: P:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.useMacAppStoreValidation
member.summary: Enable receipt validation for the Mac App Store.
member.remarks: This enables receipt validation for the Mac App Store. If this is enabled, your game will only run when it contains a valid receipt from the Mac App Store. Use this when submitting games to Apple for publishing on the App Store. This prevents people from running the game on any computer then the one it was purchased on. Note that this feature does not implement any strong copy protection. In particular, any potential crack against one Unity game would work against any other Unity content. For this reason, it is recommended that you implement your own receipt validation code on top of this using Unity's plugin feature. However, since Apple requires plugin validation to initially happen before showing the screen setup dialog, you should still enable this check, or Apple might reject your submission.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.PlayerSettings.usePlayerLog
member.summary: Write a log file with debugging information.
member.remarks: This is useful to find out what happened if there are problems with your game. When publishing games for Apple's Mac App Store, it is recommended to turn this off, because Apple may reject your submission otherwise.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.PreferenceItem
member.summary: The PreferenceItem attribute allows you to add preferences sections to the Preferences Window.
member.remarks: The PreferenceItem attribute turns any static function into an OnGUI callback. Only static functions can use the PreferenceItem attribute.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.PropertyDrawer
member.summary: Base class to derive custom property drawers from. Use this to create custom drawers for your own Serializable classes or for script variables with custom PropertyAttributes.
member.remarks: PropertyDrawers have two uses: - Customize the GUI of every instance of a Serializable class. - Customize the GUI of script members with custom PropertyAttribute s. If you have a custom Serializable class, you can use a PropertyDrawer to control how it looks in the Inspector. Consider the Serializable class Ingredient in the script below:Using a custom PropertyDrawer, every appearance of the Ingredient class in the Inspector can be changed. Compare the look of the Ingredient properties in the Inspector without and with a custom PropertyDrawer:The other use of PropertyDrawer is to alter the appearance of members in a script that have custom PropertyAttribute s. Say you want to limit floats or integers in your script to a certain range and show them as sliders in the Inspector. Using the built-in PropertyAttribute called RangeAttribute you can do just that:You can make your own PropertyAttribute as well. We'll use the code for the RangeAttribute as an example. The attribute must extend the PropertyAttribute class. If you want, your property can take parameters and store them as public member variables.Now that you have the attribute, you need to make a PropertyDrawer that draws properties that have that attribute. The drawer must extend the PropertyDrawer class, and it must have a CustomPropertyDrawer attribute to tell it which attribute it's a drawer for.Note that for performance reasons, EditorGUILayout functions are not usable with PropertyDrawers. See Also: PropertyAttribute class, CustomPropertyDrawer class.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.PropertyDrawer.attribute
member.summary: The PropertyAttribute for the property. Not applicable for custom class drawers. (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEditor.PropertyDrawer.fieldInfo
member.summary: The reflection FieldInfo for the member this property represents. (Read Only)
member.remarks: For advanced uses, this allows you to get information about the member the property represents using reflection, such as the type of the property and which attributes it might have. Most PropertyDrawers will not need to make use of the FieldInfo.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.PropertyDrawer.GetPropertyHeight(UnityEditor.SerializedProperty,UnityEngine.GUIContent)

member.remarks: The default is one line high.
member.param: The SerializedProperty to make the custom GUI for.

member.summary: Override this method to make your own GUI for the property.
member.param: Rectangle on the screen to use for the property GUI.
The SerializedProperty to make the custom GUI for.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.ScriptableWizard
member.summary: Derive from this class to create an editor wizard.
member.remarks: Editor wizards are typically opened using a menu item.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.ScriptableWizard.DisplayWizard(System.String,System.Type)
member.example: // C# // Simple Wizard that clones an object. using UnityEngine; using UnityEditor; using System.Collections; public class ScriptableWizardDisplayWizard : ScriptableWizard { public GameObject ObjectToCopy = null; public int numberOfCopies = 2; [MenuItem ("Example/Show DisplayWizard usage")] static void CreateWindow() { // Creates the wizard for display ScriptableWizard.DisplayWizard("Copy an object.", typeof(ScriptableWizardDisplayWizard), "Copy!"); } void OnWizardUpdate() { helpString = "Clones an object a number of times"; if(!ObjectToCopy) { errorString = "Please assign an object"; isValid = false; } else { errorString = ""; isValid = true; } } void OnWizardCreate () { for(int i = 0; i < numberOfCopies; i++) Instantiate(ObjectToCopy, Vector3.zero, Quaternion.identity); } }
member.param: The title shown at the top of the wizard window.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.ScriptableWizard.DisplayWizard(System.String,System.Type,System.String)
member.example: // C# // Simple Wizard that clones an object. using UnityEngine; using UnityEditor; using System.Collections; public class ScriptableWizardDisplayWizard : ScriptableWizard { public GameObject ObjectToCopy = null; public int numberOfCopies = 2; [MenuItem ("Example/Show DisplayWizard usage")] static void CreateWindow() { // Creates the wizard for display ScriptableWizard.DisplayWizard("Copy an object.", typeof(ScriptableWizardDisplayWizard), "Copy!"); } void OnWizardUpdate() { helpString = "Clones an object a number of times"; if(!ObjectToCopy) { errorString = "Please assign an object"; isValid = false; } else { errorString = ""; isValid = true; } } void OnWizardCreate () { for(int i = 0; i < numberOfCopies; i++) Instantiate(ObjectToCopy, Vector3.zero, Quaternion.identity); } }
member.param: The title shown at the top of the wizard window.
The text shown on the create button.

member.example: // C# // Simple Wizard that clones an object. using UnityEngine; using UnityEditor; using System.Collections; public class ScriptableWizardDisplayWizard : ScriptableWizard { public GameObject ObjectToCopy = null; public int numberOfCopies = 2; [MenuItem ("Example/Show DisplayWizard usage")] static void CreateWindow() { // Creates the wizard for display ScriptableWizard.DisplayWizard("Copy an object.", typeof(ScriptableWizardDisplayWizard), "Copy!"); } void OnWizardUpdate() { helpString = "Clones an object a number of times"; if(!ObjectToCopy) { errorString = "Please assign an object"; isValid = false; } else { errorString = ""; isValid = true; } } void OnWizardCreate () { for(int i = 0; i < numberOfCopies; i++) Instantiate(ObjectToCopy, Vector3.zero, Quaternion.identity); } }

member.name: T:UnityEditor.Selection
member.summary: Access to the selection in the editor.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Selection.activeGameObject
member.summary: Returns the active GameObject. (The one shown in the inspector).
member.remarks: It will also return GameObjects that might be prefabs or non-modifyable objects.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Selection.activeInstanceID
member.summary: Returns the instanceID of the actual object selection. Includes prefabs, non-modifyable objects.
member.remarks: When working with objects that are primarily in a scene, it is strongly recommended to use Selection.activeTransform instead.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Selection.activeObject
member.summary: Returns the actual object selection. Includes prefabs, non-modifyable objects.
member.remarks: When working with objects that are primarily in a scene, it is strongly recommended to use Selection.activeTransform instead.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Selection.activeTransform
member.summary: Returns the active transform. (The one shown in the inspector).
member.remarks: This will never return prefabs or non-modifyable objects.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Selection.Contains(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns whether an object is contained in the current selection.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Selection.Contains(UnityEngine.Object)
member.summary: Returns whether an object is contained in the current selection.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Selection.gameObjects
member.summary: Returns the actual GameObject selection. Includes prefabs, non-modifyable objects.
member.remarks: When working with objects that are primarily in a scene, it is strongly recommended to use Selection.transforms instead.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Selection.GetFiltered(System.Type,UnityEditor.SelectionMode)
member.summary: Returns the current selection filtered by type and mode.
member.remarks: For a selected GameObject that has multiple Components of type, only the first one will be included in the results. if type is a subclass of Component or GameObject the full SelectionMode is supported. if type does not subclass from Component or GameObject (eg. Mesh or ScriptableObject ) only SelectionMode.ExcludePrefab and SelectionMode.Editable are supported.
member.param: Only objects of this type will be retrieved.
Further options to refine the selection.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Selection.GetTransforms(UnityEditor.SelectionMode)
member.summary: Allows for fine grained control of the selection type using the SelectionMode bitmask.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Selection.instanceIDs
member.summary: The actual unfiltered selection from the Scene returned as instance ids instead of objects.
member.remarks: Only objects from the Scene or Hierarchy will be returned, not from the Project View. You can also assign objects to the selection. The instance ID of an object is always guaranteed to be unique. See Also: Selection.objects, Object.GetInstanceID.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Selection.objects
member.summary: The actual unfiltered selection from the Scene.
member.remarks: Only objects from the Scene or Hierarchy will be returned, not from the Project View. You can also assign objects to the selection. See Also: Selection.instanceIDs.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.Selection.transforms
member.summary: Returns the top level selection, excluding prefabs.
member.remarks: This is the most common selection type when working with scene objects.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.SelectionMode
member.summary: SelectionMode can be used to tweak the selection returned by Selection.GetTransforms.
member.remarks: The default transform selection mode is: SelectionMode.TopLevel | SelectionMode.ExcludePrefab | SelectionMode.Editable.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.SelectionMode.Assets
member.summary: Only return objects that are assets in the Asset directory.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.SelectionMode.Deep
member.summary: Return the selection and all child transforms of the selection.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.SelectionMode.DeepAssets
member.summary: If the selection contains folders, also include all assets and subfolders within that folder in the file hierarchy.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.SelectionMode.Editable
member.summary: Excludes any objects which shall not be modified.
member.remarks: This will filter generated prefabs from an imported fbx file but not user created prefabs.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.SelectionMode.ExcludePrefab
member.summary: Excludes any prefabs from the selection.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.SelectionMode.TopLevel
member.summary: Only return the topmost selected transform. A selected child of another selected transform will be filtered out.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.SerializedObject
member.summary: SerializedObject and SerializedProperty are classes for editing properties on objects in a completely generic way that automatically handles undo and styling UI for prefabs.
member.remarks: SerializedObject is used in conjunction with SerializedProperty and Editor classes. See Also: SerializedProperty class, Editor class.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.SerializedObject.CopyFromSerializedProperty(UnityEditor.SerializedProperty)
member.summary: Copies a value from a SerializedProperty to the same serialized property on this serialized object.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.SerializedObject.FindProperty(System.String)
member.remarks: You can use this to find a specific property in the target object. See Also: GetIterator, SerializedProperty.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.SerializedObject.GetIterator
member.remarks: You can use this to go over all properties of the target object. See Also: FindProperty, SerializedProperty.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.SerializedObject.isEditingMultipleObjects
member.summary: Does the serialized object represents multiple objects due to multi-object editing? (Read Only)

member.name: M:UnityEditor.SerializedObject.SetIsDifferentCacheDirty
member.summary: Update hasMultipleDifferentValues cache on the next /Update()/ call.
member.remarks: Normally, you should not need to call this, as the SerializedProperty setters take care of this. However, when you change an object bypassing the SerializedProperty class, you will need to manually call this to force the difference cache to be updated.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.SerializedObject.targetObject
member.remarks: When multi-object editing, the targetObject property will just return the first of the edited objects. To get all the objects, use the targetObjects property instead.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.SerializedObject.targetObjects
member.remarks: The serialized object can represent multiple objects simultaneously when multi-object editing.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.SerializedObject.UpdateIfDirtyOrScript
member.summary: Update serialized object's representation, only if the object has been modified since the last call to Update or if it is a script.
member.remarks: In which case it is not safe to assume that SetDirty has been called.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.SerializedProperty
member.summary: SerializedProperty and SerializedObject are classes for editing properties on objects in a completely generic way that automatically handles undo and styling UI for prefabs.
member.remarks: SerializedProperty is used in conjunction with SerializedObject and Editor classes. See Also: SerializedObject class, Editor class.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.SerializedProperty.Copy
member.summary: Returns a copy of the SerializedProperty iterator in its current state. This is useful if you want to keep a reference to the current property but continue with the iteration.
member.remarks: Note that if you keep a reference to an array property and that array is subsequently resized then the stored reference is no longer reliable and should not be used.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.SerializedProperty.CountRemaining
member.remarks: This is useful for allocating height for drawing this property and all the following ones.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.SerializedProperty.DeleteCommand
member.remarks: The serialized property can't be used anymore after calling this function. A new iterator must be created in that case.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.SerializedProperty.depth

member.name: M:UnityEditor.SerializedProperty.DuplicateCommand

member.remarks: It's the first property that's not a child or grandchild of this property. The end property can be used to iterate over all children of a property by using EqualContents.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.SerializedProperty.GetEndProperty(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Retrieves the SerializedProperty that defines the end range of this property.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.TextureImporter.isReadable
member.summary: Is texture data readable from scripts.
member.remarks: Texture has to be set as "readable" in order for Texture2D.GetPixel, Texture2D.GetPixels and similar functions to work. Textures are not set as readable by default. When texture is not readable, it consumes much less memory, because a system-memory copy does not have to be kept around after texture is uploaded to the graphics API.
