member.name: M:UnityEditor.TrueTypeFontImporter.GenerateEditableFont(System.String)
member.summary: Create an editable copy of the font asset at path.
member.remarks: Use this function if you want to modify the font generated by the TrueTypeFontImporter, with a custom texture or otherwise. It will create a copy of the font asset at path with an accompanying png Texture file and a Material, which you can all modify to meet your needs. A reference to the newly created editable Font is returned.

member.name: P:UnityEditor.TrueTypeFontImporter.includeFontData
member.summary: If this is enabled, the actual font will be embedded into the asset for Dynamic fonts.
member.remarks: When you disable this, the user must have the font installed in his system to use it.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.Undo
member.summary: Lets you register undo operations on specific objects you are about to perform changes on.
member.remarks: The Undo system stores delta changes in the undo stack. Undo operations are automatically combined together based on events Eg. mouse down events will split undo groups. Undo operations store either per property or per object state. This way they scale well with any scene size. The most important operations are outlined below. Modifying a single property:Adding a component :Creating a new GameObject:Destroying a GameObject or component:Changing transform parenting:

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.ClearUndo(UnityEngine.Object)
member.summary: Removes aall Undo operation for the identifier object registered using Undo.RegisterCompleteObjectUndo from the undo stack.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.CollapseUndoOperations(System.Int32)
member.summary: Collapses all undo operation up to group index together into one step.
member.remarks: This is used by the color picked to combine all color modifications into a single step once the color picker is closed, while they are seperate operations when the color picker is still open.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.DestroyObjectImmediate(UnityEngine.Object)
member.summary: Destroys the object and records an undo operation so that it can be recreated.
member.remarks: Destroys the object with the same behaviour as DestroyImmediate (objectToUndo, true); Also stores all destroyed objects in the undo buffer so that they can be fully recreated.
member.param: The object that will be destroyed.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.GetCurrentGroup
member.summary: Unity automatically groups undo operations by the current group index.
member.remarks: The current group index is automatically increased on mouse down, clicking on menu items and other operations. See Also: Undo.RevertAllDownToGroup.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.IncrementCurrentGroup
member.summary: Unity automatically groups undo operations by the current group index.
member.remarks: The current group is automatically incremented based on events eg. mouse down events, executing a menu item increments the current group. But sometimes it is necessary to manually group undo operations.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.PerformRedo
member.remarks: This performs a redo operation. It is the same as clicking on the Edit->Redo menu. See Also: PerformUndo.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.PerformUndo
member.remarks: This performs a undo operation. It is the same as clicking on the Edit->Undo menu. See Also: PerformRedo.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.RecordObject(UnityEngine.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Records any changes done on the object after the RecordObject function.
member.remarks: Almost all property changes can be recorded with this function. The transform parent, AddComponent, object destruction can not be recorded with this function, for that you should use the dedicated functions. Internally this will create a temporary copy of the objects state and at the end of the frame Unity will diff the state and thus detect what exactly has changed. The changed properties are then recorded on the undo stack. If nothing has actually changed (Binary exact comparison is used for all properties), no undo operation will be stored on the stack.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.RecordObjects(UnityEngine.Object[],System.String)
member.summary: Records multiple undoable objects in a single call. This is the same as calling Undo.RecordObject multiple times.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.RegisterCreatedObjectUndo(UnityEngine.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Register an undo operations for a newly created object.
member.remarks: When the undo is performed the object will be destroyed. All newly created objects that are part of undoable state should be registered with this function.
member.param: The name of the action to undo. Think "Undo ...." in the main menu.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.RevertAllDownToGroup(System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs all undo operations up to the group index without storing a redo operation in the process.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.RevertAllInCurrentGroup
member.summary: Performs the last undo operation but does not record a redo operation.
member.remarks: This is useful when you want to simply revert the last performed action. In Unity the escape is commonly used to execute this function.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Undo.SetTransformParent(UnityEngine.Transform,UnityEngine.Transform,System.String)
member.summary: Sets the parent of transform to the new parent and records an undo operation.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to calling transform.parent = newParent, but it additionally records the undo operation.

member.summary: A newer version of the asset is available on the version control server.

member.summary: The asset is up to date.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.VersionControl.Asset+States.Updating
member.summary: The state of the asset is currently being queried from the version control server.

member.name: T:UnityEditor.VersionControl.Message+Severity
member.summary: Severity of a version control message.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.VersionControl.Message+Severity.Info
member.remarks: This can include information such as who else is accessing an asset.

member.name: F:UnityEditor.VersionControl.Message+Severity.Verbose
member.remarks: This includes intermediate query results and other info from the version control plugins.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AccelerationEvent
member.summary: Structure describing acceleration status of the device.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AccelerationEvent.deltaTime
member.summary: Amount of time passed since last accelerometer measurement.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ADBannerView
member.summary: ADBannerView is a wrapper around the ADBannerView class found in the Apple iAd framework and is only available on iOS.
member.remarks: It provides a view that displays banner advertisements to the user.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ADBannerView.IsAvailable(UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Type)
member.summary: Checks if the banner type is available (e.g. MediumRect is available only starting with ios6).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ADBannerView.layout
member.summary: Specifies how banner should be layed out on screen.
member.remarks: Please note that Traditional Banner and Rect Banner (introduced in ios6) use different enum values. If you use "wrong" enum value for current ad type: for Traditional Banner Top* and Center* will be considered Top, and Bottom* will be considered Bottom* for Rect Banner Top will be considered TopLeft and Bottom - BottomLeft.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ADBannerView.loaded
member.summary: Checks if banner contents are loaded.
member.remarks: You should hide banner if it is not loaded to avoid showing blank view.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ADBannerView.position
member.summary: The position of the banner view.
member.remarks: It uses unity GUI coords and convention, so it is top-left corner coords. If you change it, banner will become manually layed-out automatically. Please note that for Traditional Banner x component is ignored.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ADBannerView.size
member.summary: The size of the banner view.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ADBannerView.visible
member.summary: Banner visibility. Initially banner is not visible.
member.remarks: Please note that if you hide banner, ads might not be reloaded with time, so if you no longer need banner it is better to delete it completely.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+BannerWasClickedDelegate
member.summary: Will be fired when banner was clicked.
member.remarks: Please note, that app will loose focus on banner click, so the delegate will be called on first frame after ad was shown.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+BannerWasLoadedDelegate
member.summary: Will be fired when banner loaded new ad.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout
member.remarks: You can set manual layout to move banner around yourself.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout.Bottom
member.summary: Traditional Banner: align to screen bottom.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout.BottomCenter
member.summary: Rect Banner: align to screen bottom, placing at the center.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout.BottomLeft
member.summary: Rect Banner: place in bottom-left corner.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout.BottomRight
member.summary: Rect Banner: place in bottom-right corner.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout.Center
member.summary: Rect Banner: place exactly at screen center.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout.CenterLeft
member.summary: Rect Banner: align to screen left, placing at the center.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout.CenterRight
member.summary: Rect Banner: align to screen right, placing at the center.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout.Top
member.summary: Traditional Banner: align to screen top.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout.TopCenter
member.summary: Rect Banner: align to screen top, placing at the center.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout.TopLeft
member.summary: Rect Banner: place in top-left corner.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Layout.TopRight
member.summary: Rect Banner: place in top-right corner.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Type
member.summary: The type of the banner view.
member.remarks: Please check availability of banner type with ADBannerView.IsAvailable. Traditional banner is always available, though.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ADBannerView+Type.Banner
member.summary: Traditional Banner (it takes full screen width).

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AddComponentMenu
member.summary: The AddComponentMenu attribute allows you to place a script anywhere in the "Component" menu, instead of just the "Component->Scripts" menu.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ADInterstitialAd
member.summary: ADInterstitialAd is a wrapper around the ADInterstitialAd class found in the Apple iAd framework and is only available on iPad.
member.remarks: It provides full-screen advertisements that your iPad application can display to the user.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ADInterstitialAd.isAvailable
member.summary: Checks if InterstitialAd is available (it is iPad-only and was added in iOS 4.3).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ADInterstitialAd.loaded
member.summary: Has the interstitial ad object downloaded an advertisement? (Read Only)

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ADInterstitialAd.ReloadAd
member.remarks: Call it when you are done with current one (if you want more ads downloaded).

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ADInterstitialAd+InterstitialWasLoadedDelegate
member.summary: Will be called when ad is ready to be shown.

member.summary: Call a static Java method on a class.Call a static Java method on a class.

member.remarks: Used in conjunction with using() { } See Also: IDisposable Interface (MSDN)

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AndroidJavaProxy
member.summary: This class can be used to implement any java interface. Any java vm method invocation matching the interface on the proxy object will automatically be passed to the c# implementation.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AndroidJavaProxy.Invoke(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Called by the java vm whenever a method is invoked on the java proxy interface. You can override this to run special code on method invokation, or you can leave the implementation as is, and leave the default behavior which is to look for c# methods matching the signature of the java method.
member.param: Name of the invoked java method.
Arguments passed from the java vm - converted into AndroidJavaObject, AndroidJavaClass or a primitive.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AndroidJavaProxy.Invoke(System.String,UnityEngine.AndroidJavaObject[])
member.summary: Called by the java vm whenever a method is invoked on the java proxy interface. You can override this to run special code on method invokation, or you can leave the implementation as is, and leave the default behavior which is to look for c# methods matching the signature of the java method.
member.param: Name of the invoked java method.
Arguments passed from the java vm - all objects are represented by AndroidJavaObject, int for instance is represented by a java.lang.Integer object.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AndroidJavaProxy.javaInterface
member.summary: Java interface implemented by the proxy.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AndroidJavaRunnable
member.summary: AndroidJavaRunnable is the Unity representation of a java.lang.Runnable object.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Animation
member.summary: The animation component is used to play back animations.
member.remarks: You can assign animation clips to the animation component and control playback from your script. The animation system in Unity is weight based and supports: Animation Blending, Additive animations, Animation Mixing, Layers and full control over all aspects of animation playback. For an overview of animation scripting in Unity please read this introduction. To play a simple animation use Animation.Play To cross-fade between animations use Animation.CrossFade To change how animations wrap (Loop, Once, PingPong) change the WrapMode of the respective AnimationClips in their import settings, or use AnimationState.wrapMode to change it at runtime. AnimationState can be used to change the layer of an animation, modify playback speed, and for direct control over blending and mixing. Animation also supports enumerators so you can loop through all AnimationStates like this:See Also: An overview of animation scripting in Unity is here.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animation.AddClip(UnityEngine.AnimationClip,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a clip to the animation with name newName.Adds clip to the only play between firstFrame and lastFrame. The new clip will also be added to the animation with name newName.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animation.AddClip(UnityEngine.AnimationClip,System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds a clip to the animation with name newName.Adds clip to the only play between firstFrame and lastFrame. The new clip will also be added to the animation with name newName.

member.summary: Adds a clip to the animation with name newName.Adds clip to the only play between firstFrame and lastFrame. The new clip will also be added to the animation with name newName.
member.param: Should an extra frame be inserted at the end that matches the first frame? Turn this on if you are making a looping animation.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Animation.animatePhysics
member.summary: When turned on, animations will be executed in the physics loop. This is only useful in conjunction with kinematic rigidbodies.
member.remarks: An animated platform can apply velocity and friction to rigid bodies sitting on top of it. In order to use this, animatePhysics must be enabled and animated object must be a kinematic rigid body.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animation.Blend(System.String)
member.summary: Blends the animation named animation towards targetWeight over the next time seconds.
member.remarks: Playback of other animations will not be affected.

member.summary: Blends the animation named animation towards targetWeight over the next time seconds.
member.remarks: Playback of other animations will not be affected.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animation.Blend(System.String,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Blends the animation named animation towards targetWeight over the next time seconds.
member.remarks: Playback of other animations will not be affected.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animation.CrossFade(System.String)
member.summary: Fades the animation with name animation in over a period of time seconds and fades other animations out.
member.remarks: If mode is PlayMode.StopSameLayer, animations in the same layer as animation will be faded out while animation is faded in. if mode is PlayMode.StopAll, all animations will be faded out while animation is faded in. If the animation is not set to be looping it will be stopped and rewinded after playing.Another example:

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animation.CrossFade(System.String,System.Single)
member.summary: Fades the animation with name animation in over a period of time seconds and fades other animations out.
member.remarks: If mode is PlayMode.StopSameLayer, animations in the same layer as animation will be faded out while animation is faded in. if mode is PlayMode.StopAll, all animations will be faded out while animation is faded in. If the animation is not set to be looping it will be stopped and rewinded after playing.Another example:

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animation.CrossFade(System.String,System.Single,UnityEngine.PlayMode)
member.summary: Fades the animation with name animation in over a period of time seconds and fades other animations out.
member.remarks: If mode is PlayMode.StopSameLayer, animations in the same layer as animation will be faded out while animation is faded in. if mode is PlayMode.StopAll, all animations will be faded out while animation is faded in. If the animation is not set to be looping it will be stopped and rewinded after playing.Another example:

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animation.CrossFadeQueued(System.String)
member.summary: Cross fades an animation after previous animations has finished playing.
member.remarks: For example you might play a specific sequence of animations after each other. The animation duplicates itself before playing thus you can fade between the same animation. This can be used to overlay two same animations. For example you might have a sword swing animation. The player slashes two times quickly after each other. You could rewind the animation and play from the beginning but then you will get a jump in the animation. The following queue modes are available: If queue is QueueMode.CompleteOthers this animation will only start once all other animations have stopped playing. If queue is QueueMode.PlayNow this animation will start playing immediately on a duplicated animation state. After the animation has finished playing it will automatically clean itself up. Using the duplicated animation state after it has finished will result in an exception.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animation.CrossFadeQueued(System.String,System.Single)
member.summary: Cross fades an animation after previous animations has finished playing.
member.remarks: For example you might play a specific sequence of animations after each other. The animation duplicates itself before playing thus you can fade between the same animation. This can be used to overlay two same animations. For example you might have a sword swing animation. The player slashes two times quickly after each other. You could rewind the animation and play from the beginning but then you will get a jump in the animation. The following queue modes are available: If queue is QueueMode.CompleteOthers this animation will only start once all other animations have stopped playing. If queue is QueueMode.PlayNow this animation will start playing immediately on a duplicated animation state. After the animation has finished playing it will automatically clean itself up. Using the duplicated animation state after it has finished will result in an exception.

If queue is QueueMode.PlayNow this animation will start playing immediately on a duplicated animation state. After the animation has finished playing it will automatically clean itself up. Using the duplicated animation state after it has finished will result in an exception.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Animation.localBounds
member.summary: AABB of this Animation animation component in local space.
member.remarks: By default it is computed based on animation states (i.e. attached animation clips), unless user overrides it by setting value to localBounds. You can switch back to precomputed bounds by setting cullingType to AnimationCullingType.BasedOnClipBounds. Value of localBounds is undefined when cullingType is not set to AnimationCullingType.BasedOnClipBounds or AnimationCullingType.BasedOnUserBounds. When setting localBounds cullingType will be set to AnimationCullingType.BasedOnUserBounds automatically. See Also: AnimationClip.localBounds property, cullingType, AnimationCullingType.BasedOnClipBounds.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animation.Play
member.remarks: Play() will start animation with name animation, or play the default animation. The animation will be played abruptly without any blending. If mode is PlayMode.StopSameLayer then all animations in the same layer will be stopped. If mode is PlayMode.StopAll then all animations currently playing will be stopped. If the animation is already playing, other animations will be stopped but the animation will not rewind to the beginning. If the animation is not set to be looping it will be stopped and rewinded after playing. Play() will return false if animation can't be played (no animation clip or no default animation).For a specific animation, you can call the animation with play as well.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Animation.wrapMode
member.summary: How should time beyond the playback range of the clip be treated?
member.remarks: WrapMode.Default: Read's the wrap mode from the clip (default for a clip is Once). WrapMode.Once: Stops the animation when time reaches the end. WrapMode.Loop: Starts at the beginning when time reaches the end. WrapMode.PingPong: Ping Pong's back and forth between beginning and end. WrapMode.ClampForever: Plays back the animation. When it reaches the end, it will keep sampling the last frame.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AnimationClip
member.remarks: AnimationClip is used by Animation to play back animations.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AnimationClip.AddEvent(UnityEngine.AnimationEvent)
member.summary: Adds an animation event to the clip.
member.remarks: Note that events added with AddEvent will only persist until play mode is exited of player is quit. If you want to add an event to a clip persistently, use AnimationUtility.SetAnimationEvents from the Unity editor. See Also: AnimationEvent, AnimationUtility classes.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AnimationClip.ClearCurves
member.summary: Clears all curves from the clip.
member.remarks: See Also: SetCurve function, AnimationCurve class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationClip.frameRate
member.summary: Frame rate at which keyframes are sampled. (Read Only)
member.remarks: This is the frame rate that was used in the animation program you used to create the animation or model.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationClip.localBounds
member.summary: AABB of this Animation Clip in local space of Animation component that it is attached too.
member.remarks: It is precomputed on import for imported models/animations based on the meshes that this animation clip affects. This bounding box is specific to the mesh(es) that this clip is attached to during import, i.e. this means that it is calculated based on the file that is part of and on the "Model" file if you're using Model@Animation notation.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AnimationClip.SetCurve(System.String,System.Type,System.String,UnityEngine.AnimationCurve)
member.summary: Assigns the curve to animate a specific property.
member.remarks: If curve is null the curve will be removed. If a curve already exists for that property, it will be replaced. Common names are: "localPosition.x", "localPosition.y", "localPosition.z", "localRotation.x", "localRotation.y", "localRotation.z", "localRotation.w" "localScale.x", "localScale.y", "localScale.z" .Material properties can be animated using the property name exported in the shader. Common property names are: "_MainTex", "_BumpMap", "_Color", "_SpecColor", "_Emission". How to animate different material property types: Float properties: "PropertyName" __ Vector4 properties:__ "PropertyName.x", "PropertyName.y", "PropertyName.z", "PropertyName.w" __ Color properties:__ "PropertyName.r ", "PropertyName.g", "PropertyName.b", "PropertyName.a" UV Rotation properties: "PropertyName.rotation" UV Offset and scale: "PropertyName.offset.x", "PropertyName.offset.y", "PropertyName.scale.x", "PropertyName.scale.y" To index into multiple materials on the same renderer you can prefix the attribute like this: "[1]._MainTex.offset.y" See Also: ClearCurves function, AnimationCurve class.
member.param: Path to the GameObject this curve applies to. relativePath is formatted similar to a pathname, e.g. "rootspineleftArm". If relativePath is empty it refers to the GameObject the animation clip is attached to.
The class type of the component that is animated.
The name or path to the property being animated.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationClip.wrapMode
member.summary: Sets the default wrap mode used in the animation state.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AnimationClipPair
member.summary: This class define a pair of clip used by See Also: AnimationSet.
member.remarks: Each original clip from the controller can be overriden with another clip.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AnimationClipPair.originalClip
member.summary: The original clip from the controller.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AnimationClipPair.overrideClip
member.remarks: Can be null if no override is define.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AnimationCullingType
member.summary: This enum controlls culling of Animation component.
member.remarks: When culling is enabled, Unity might stop animating if it thinks that the results of the animation won't be visible to the user. This could save you some performance if you have things animating outside of the viewport, whose animation is only important when the user can actually see the thing that is being animated. When Animation component is culled it won't do anything: it won't update animation states, execute events or sample animations.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AnimationCullingType.AlwaysAnimate
member.summary: Animation culling is disabled - object is animated even when offscreen.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AnimationCullingType.BasedOnClipBounds
member.summary: Animation is disabled when Animation.localBounds are not visible.
member.remarks: When this type of culling is used Animation.localBounds will be based on bounds of attached clips which are precalculated on import. This culling method works better than BasedOnRenderers, because animation can push itself into the camera frustum. See Also: BasedOnUserBounds, Animation.localBounds property, AnimationClip.localBounds property.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AnimationCullingType.BasedOnRenderers
member.summary: Animation is disabled when renderers are not visible.
member.remarks: This culling method is more suitable when you have renderers attached after import - it will take renderers (like mesh renderers, particle renderers and so on) attached to this gameObject or children of this GameObject.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AnimationCullingType.BasedOnUserBounds
member.summary: Animation is disabled when Animation.localBounds are not visible.
member.remarks: Animation.localBounds can be set by user, when culling is set to BasedOnUserBounds. This culling method works better than BasedOnRenderers, because animation can push itself into the camera frustum. See Also: BasedOnClipBounds, Animation.localBounds property.

Note that the array is "by value", i.e. getting keys returns a copy of all keys and setting keys copies them into the curve. See Also: Keyframe struct, AddKey, RemoveKey functions.

member.summary: Removes the keyframe at index and inserts key.
member.remarks: If a keyframe already exists at /key.time/ the time of the old keyframe's position /key[index].time/ will be used instead. This is the desired behaviour for dragging keyframes in a curve editor. Returns the index of the keyframe after moving it.

member.summary: The behaviour of the animation after the last keyframe.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationCurve.preWrapMode

member.summary: Smooth the in and out tangents of the keyframe at index.
member.remarks: A weight of 0 evens out tangents.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AnimationEvent
member.summary: AnimationEvent lets you call a script function similar to SendMessage as part of playing back an animation.
member.remarks: Animation events support functions that take zero or one parameter. The parameter can be a float, a string, an object reference, or an AnimationEvent.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationEvent.animationState
member.summary: The animation state that fired this event (Read Only).
member.remarks: Returns null when the method is called outside of an animation event callback.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationEvent.floatParameter
member.summary: Float parameter that is stored in the event and will be sent to the function.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationEvent.functionName
member.summary: The name of the function that will be called.
member.remarks: This is the same as calling gameObject.SendMessage(animationEvent.functionName, animationEvent).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationEvent.intParameter
member.summary: Int parameter that is stored in the event and will be sent to the function.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationEvent.messageOptions
member.remarks: If options are set to SendMessageOptions.RequireReceiver (default), an error is printed when the message is not picked up by any component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationEvent.objectReferenceParameter
member.summary: Object reference parameter that is stored in the event and will be sent to the function.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationEvent.stringParameter
member.summary: String parameter that is stored in the event and will be sent to the function.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationEvent.time

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationInfo.weight
member.summary: The weight of the animation clip.
member.remarks: The weight is the concatenation of the blendtree weight and the transition weight.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AnimationState
member.summary: The AnimationState gives full control over animation blending.
member.remarks: In most cases the Animation interface is sufficient and easier to use. Use the AnimationState if you need full control over the animation blending any playback process. The AnimationState interface allows you to modify speed, weight, time and layers while any animation is playing. You can also setup animation mixing and wrapMode. The Animation.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AnimationState.AddMixingTransform(UnityEngine.Transform)
member.summary: Adds a transform which should be animated. This allows you to reduce the number of animations you have to create.
member.remarks: For example you might have a handwaving animation. You might want to play the hand waving animation on a idle character or on a walking character. Either you have to create 2 hand waving animations one for idle, one for walking. By using mixing the hand waving animation will have full control of the shoulder. But the lower body will not be affected by it, and continue playing the idle or walk animation. Thus you only need one hand waving animation. If recursive is true all children of the mix transform will also be animated. If you don't call AddMixingTransform, all animation curves will be used.Another example using a path:

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AnimationState.AddMixingTransform(UnityEngine.Transform,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds a transform which should be animated. This allows you to reduce the number of animations you have to create.
member.remarks: For example you might have a handwaving animation. You might want to play the hand waving animation on a idle character or on a walking character. Either you have to create 2 hand waving animations one for idle, one for walking. By using mixing the hand waving animation will have full control of the shoulder. But the lower body will not be affected by it, and continue playing the idle or walk animation. Thus you only need one hand waving animation. If recursive is true all children of the mix transform will also be animated. If you don't call AddMixingTransform, all animation curves will be used.Another example using a path:

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationState.blendMode
member.summary: Which blend mode should be used?

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationState.clip
member.summary: The clip that is being played by this animation state.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationState.enabled
member.remarks: For the animation to take any effect the weight also needs to be set to a value higher than zero. If the animation is disabled, time will be paused until the animation is enabled again.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationState.length
member.summary: The length of the animation clip in seconds.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationState.normalizedSpeed
member.remarks: This is most commonly used to synchronize playback speed when blending between two animations. In most cases it is easier and better to use animation.SyncLayer instead.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationState.normalizedTime
member.summary: The normalized time of the animation.
member.remarks: A value of 1 is the end of the animation. A value of 0.5 is the middle of the animation.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AnimationState.RemoveMixingTransform(UnityEngine.Transform)
member.summary: Removes a transform which should be animated.
member.remarks: You can only pass transforms that have been added through AddMixingTransform function. If transform has been added as recursive, then it will be removed as recursive. Once you remove all mixing transforms added to animation state all curves become animated again. See Also: AddMixingTransform function.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationState.speed
member.summary: The playback speed of the animation. 1 is normal playback speed.
member.remarks: A negative playback speed will play the animation backwards.See Also: AnimationState.time, AnimationState.wrapMode properties and WrapMode enum.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationState.time
member.summary: The current time of the animation.
member.remarks: If the time is larger than length it will be wrapped according to wrapMode. The value can be larger than the animations length. In this case playback mode will remap the time before sampling. This value usually goes from 0 to infinity.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationState.weight
member.remarks: This calculates the blend weights for one curve. Weights are distributed so that the top layer gets everything. If it doesn't use the full weight then the next layer gets to distribute the remaining weights and so on. Once all weights are used by the top layers, no weights will be available for lower layers anymore Unity uses fair weighting, which means if a lower layer wants 80% and 50% have already been used up, the layer will NOT use up all weights. instead it will take up 80% of the 50%. Example: a upper body which is affected by wave, walk and idle a lower body which is affected by only walk and idle.- Blend weights can change per animated value because of mixing. Even without mixing, sometimes a curve is just not defined. Still you want the blend weights to add up to 1. Most of the time weights are similar between curves.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AnimationState.wrapMode
member.remarks: By default wrapMode is initialized to the value set in the Animation component's wrap mode.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.GetIKPosition(UnityEngine.AvatarIKGoal)
member.summary: Gets the position of an IK goal.
member.remarks: An IK goal is a target position and rotation for a specific body part. Unity can calculate how to move the part toward the target from the starting point (ie, the current position and rotation obtained from the animation). This function gets the current position of the specified goal in world space. See Also: GetIKPositionWeight, SetIKPosition.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.GetIKPositionWeight(UnityEngine.AvatarIKGoal)
member.summary: Gets the translative weight of an IK goal (0 = at the original animation before IK, 1 = at the goal).
member.remarks: An IK goal is a target position and rotation for a specific body part. Unity can calculate how to move the part toward the target from the starting point (ie, the current position and rotation obtained from the animation). The point calculated by the IK is also influenced by a weight value in the range 0..1 that determines how far between the start and the goal to aim. This function returns the current weight value for the position of the goal. See Also: GetIKPosition, SetIKPosition.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.GetIKRotation(UnityEngine.AvatarIKGoal)
member.summary: Gets the rotation of an IK goal.
member.remarks: An IK goal is a target position and rotation for a specific body part. Unity can calculate how to move the part toward the target from the starting point (ie, the current position and rotation obtained from the animation). This function gets the current rotation of the specified goal in world space. See Also: GetIKRotationWeight, SetIKRotation.
member.param: The AvatarIKGoal that is is queried.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.GetIKRotationWeight(UnityEngine.AvatarIKGoal)
member.summary: Gets the rotational weight of an IK goal (0 = rotation before IK, 1 = rotation at the IK goal).
member.remarks: An IK goal is a target position and rotation for a specific body part. Unity can calculate how to move the part toward the target from the starting point (ie, the current position and rotation obtained from the animation). The rotation calculated by the IK is also influenced by a weight value in the range 0..1 that determines how far between the start and the goal to aim. This function returns the current weight value for the rotation of the goal. See Also: GetIKRotation, SetIKRotation.

The rotation in which we want the body part to be.
The body part that is involved in the match.
Structure that contains weights for matching position and rotation.
Start time within the animation clip (0 - beginning of clip, 1 - end of clip).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.MatchTarget(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Quaternion,UnityEngine.AvatarTarget,UnityEngine.MatchTargetWeightMask,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Automatically adjust the gameobject position and rotation so that the AvatarTarget reaches the matchPosition when the current state is at the specified progress.
member.remarks: Target matching only works on the base layer (index 0).
member.param: The position we want the body part to reach.
The rotation in which we want the body part to be.
The body part that is involved in the match.
Structure that contains weights for matching position and rotation.
Start time within the animation clip (0 - beginning of clip, 1 - end of clip).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Animator.playbackTime
member.summary: Sets the playback position in the recording buffer.
member.remarks: When in playback mode (see StartPlayback ), this value is used for controlling the current playback position in the buffer (in seconds). The value can range between recordingStartTime and recordingStopTime See Also: StartPlayback, StopPlayback.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Animator.recorderStartTime
member.summary: Start time of the first frame of the buffer relative to the frame at which StartRecording was called.
member.remarks: For example, if we started recording at frame 10, and the buffer is 5 frames long. If the buffer is not initialized ( StartRecording is not called), the value of this property will be -1. See Also: recorderStopTime.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Animator.recorderStopTime
member.summary: End time of the recorded clip relative to when StartRecording was called.
member.remarks: For example, if we started recording at second 10, and ended recording at second 15, then this will have a value of 5. If the buffer is not initialized ( StartRecording is not called), the value of this property will be -1. See Also: recorderStartTime.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.SetIKPosition(UnityEngine.AvatarIKGoal,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Sets the position of an IK goal.
member.remarks: An IK goal is a target position and rotation for a specific body part. Unity can calculate how to move the part toward the target from the starting point (ie, the current position and rotation obtained from the animation). This function sets the position of the ultimate goal in world space; the actual point in space where the body part ends up is also influenced by a weight parameter that specifies how far between the start and the goal the IK should aim (a value in the range 0..1).See Also: SetIKPositionWeight, SetIKRotation.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.SetIKPositionWeight(UnityEngine.AvatarIKGoal,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the translative weight of an IK goal (0 = at the original animation before IK, 1 = at the goal).
member.remarks: An IK goal is a target position and rotation for a specific body part. Unity can calculate how to move the part toward the target from the starting point (ie, the current position and rotation obtained from the animation). This function sets a weight value in the range 0..1 to determine how far between the start and goal positions the IK will aim. The position itself is set separately using SetIKPosition .See Also: SetIKPosition, SetIKRotationWeight.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.SetIKRotation(UnityEngine.AvatarIKGoal,UnityEngine.Quaternion)
member.summary: Sets the rotation of an IK goal.
member.remarks: An IK goal is a target position and rotation for a specific body part. Unity can calculate how to move the part toward the target from the starting point (ie, the current position and rotation obtained from the animation). This function sets the rotation of the ultimate goal in world space; the actual rotation where the body part ends up is also influenced by a weight parameter that specifies how far between the start and the goal the IK should aim (a value in the range 0..1).See Also: SetIKRotationWeight, SetIKPosition.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.SetIKRotationWeight(UnityEngine.AvatarIKGoal,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the rotational weight of an IK goal (0 = rotation before IK, 1 = rotation at the IK goal).
member.remarks: An IK goal is a target position and rotation for a specific body part. Unity can calculate how to move the part toward the target from the starting point (ie, the current position and rotation obtained from the animation). This function sets a weight value in the range 0..1 to determine how far between the start and goal rotations the IK will aim. The goal itself is set separately using SetIKRotation .See Also: SetIKRotation, SetIKPositionWeight.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Animator.speed
member.summary: The playback speed of the Animator. 1 is normal playback speed.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Animator.stabilizeFeet
member.summary: Automatic stabilization of feet during transition and blending.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.StartPlayback
member.summary: Sets the animator in playback mode.
member.remarks: In this mode, the animator is not updated from game logic and is controlled instead by setting time value. Note that time will not automatically progress here, you have to manipulate it explicitly from playbackTime. PlaybackRecordedFrame should be used to playback recorded data.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.StartRecording(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the animator in recording mode, and allocates a circular buffer of size frameCount.
member.remarks: After this call, the recorder starts collecting up to frameCount frames in the buffer. Note it is not possible to start playback until a call to StopRecording is made. See Also: StopRecording, recordingStartTime, recordingStopTime, StartPlayback, StopPlayback, playbackTime.
member.param: The number of frames (updates) that will be recorded. If frameCount is 0, the recording will continue until the user calls StopRecording. The maximum value for frameCount is 10000.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.StopPlayback
member.summary: Stops the animator playback mode. When playback stops, the avatar resumes getting control from game logic.
member.remarks: See Also: StartRecording, StopRecording, recordingStartTime, recordingStopTime, StartPlayback, , playbackTime.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.StopRecording
member.remarks: A call to StopRecording will lock the recording buffer's contents in its current state. The data get saved for subsequent playback with StartPlayback. See Also: StartRecording, recordingStartTime, recordingStopTime, StartPlayback, StopPlayback, playbackTime.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Animator.StringToHash(System.String)
member.summary: Generates an parameter id from a string.
member.remarks: Ids are used for optimized setters and getters on parameters.
member.param: The string to convert to Id.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Animator.targetRotation

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AnimatorCullingMode.AlwaysAnimate
member.summary: Always animate the entire character. Object is animated even when offscreen.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AnimatorCullingMode.BasedOnRenderers
member.summary: Animation is disabled when renderers are not visible.
member.remarks: The statemachine and root motion will always be evaluated. Thus you will always receive the OnAnimatorMove callbacks. All other animation will be skipped if the character is not visible. Specifically evaluation of bone animation, IK, OnAnimatorIK will be skipped.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.absoluteUrl
member.summary: The absolute path to the web player data file (Read Only).
member.remarks: Application.absoluteURL and Application.srcValue allow you to detect if your unityWeb data file was moved to another location or is being linked to. You might want to protect against both to prevent piracy of your data files.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.backgroundLoadingPriority
member.remarks: Lets you control how long it takes to load data asynchronously vs. performance impact on the game while loading in the background.See Also: ThreadPriority enum.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.CancelQuit
member.summary: Cancels quitting the application. This is useful for showing a splash screen at the end of a game.
member.remarks: This function only works in the player and does nothing in the web player or editor. IMPORTANT: This function has no effect on iPhone. Application can not prevent termination under iPhone OS.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.CaptureScreenshot(System.String)
member.summary: Captures a screenshot at path filename as a PNG file.
member.remarks: If the file exists already, it will be overwritten. This function does nothing if used from inside the web player. On mobile platforms the filename is appended to the persistent data path. When superSize parameter is larger than 1, a larger resolution screenshot will be produced. For example, passing 4 will make the screenshot be 4x4 larger than it normally would. This is useful to produce screenshots for printing.
member.param: Pathname to save the screenshot file to.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.CaptureScreenshot(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Captures a screenshot at path filename as a PNG file.
member.remarks: If the file exists already, it will be overwritten. This function does nothing if used from inside the web player. On mobile platforms the filename is appended to the persistent data path. When superSize parameter is larger than 1, a larger resolution screenshot will be produced. For example, passing 4 will make the screenshot be 4x4 larger than it normally would. This is useful to produce screenshots for printing.
member.param: Pathname to save the screenshot file to.
Factor by which to increase resolution.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.dataPath
member.summary: Contains the path to the game data folder (Read Only).
member.remarks: The value depends on which platform you are running on: Unity Editor: path to project folder >/Assets Mac player: path to player app bundle >/Contents iPhone player: path to player app bundle >/ AppName.app >/Data Win player: path to executablename_Data folder > Web player: The absolute url to the player data file folder (without the actual data file name) Flash: The absolute url to the player data file folder (without the actual data file name) Note that the string returned on a PC will use a forward slash as a folder separator.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.ExternalCall(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Calls a function in the containing web page (Web Player only).
member.remarks: This will call JavaScript function functionName in the web page that contains the web player, passing given arguments to it. Supported argument types are the primitive types (string, int, float, char) and arrays of them. Any other objects are converted to string (using ToString method) and passed as strings. The function is called non-blocking, i.e. ExternalCall immediately returns without waiting for the function that was called to complete. The number of passed arguments can be varying:The functions to be called are just declared in the HTML page using standard syntax, for example:See Also: Browser to Unity communication, Application.ExternalEval.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.ExternalEval(System.String)
member.summary: Evaluates script snippet in the containing web page (Web Player only).
member.remarks: This will execute JavaScript snippet script in the web page that contains the web player.See Also: Browser to Unity communication, Application.ExternalCall.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.HasUserAuthorization(UnityEngine.UserAuthorization)
member.summary: Check if the user has authorized use of the webcam or microphone in the Web Player.
member.remarks: This is used to check the result of a previous call to Application.RequestUserAuthorization. Explicit user consent to use features is only needed in the Web Player. In other build targets, this function will always return true.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.internetReachability
member.summary: Returns the type of Internet reachability currently possible on the device.
member.remarks: This property is mostly useful on handhelds to distinguish fast and cheap WiFi connection from carrier networking. Note: Do not use this property to determine the actual connectivity. E.g. the device can be connected to a hot spot, but not have the actual route to the network. Non-handhelds are considered to always be capable of NetworkReachability.ReachableViaLocalAreaNetwork.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.isEditor
member.summary: Are we running inside the Unity editor? (Read Only)
member.remarks: Returns true if the game is being run from the Unity editor; false if run from any deployment target.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.isLoadingLevel
member.summary: Is some level being loaded? (Read Only)
member.remarks: LoadLevel and LoadLevelAdditive don't happen immediately - a new level is loaded after the current game frame finishes. isLoadingLevel returns true if a level load was requested this frame already. See Also: LoadLevel, LoadLevelAdditive.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.isPlaying
member.summary: Returns true when in any kind of player (Read Only).
member.remarks: Returns true in the Unity editor when in play mode.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.isWebPlayer
member.summary: Are we running inside a web player? (Read Only)
member.remarks: Returns true if the game is being run from the Unity web player.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.levelCount
member.summary: The total number of levels available (Read Only).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.loadedLevel
member.summary: The level index that was last loaded (Read Only).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.loadedLevelName
member.summary: The name of the level that was last loaded (Read Only).
member.remarks: Note that this value is set only by Application.LoadLevel and Application.LoadLevelAsync. The Additive versions add content to the current level.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.LoadLevel(System.Int32)
member.summary: Loads the level by its name or index.
member.remarks: Before you can load a level you have to add it to the list of levels used in the game. Use File->Build Settings... in Unity and add the levels you need to the level list there. MonoBehaviour.OnLevelWasLoaded is called on all active GameObjects after the level has been loaded.When loading a new level all GameObjects that have been loaded before are destroyed. If you want to let an object survive when loading a new level, use Object.DontDestroyOnLoad. Calling LoadLevel will update Application.loadedLevel and Application.loadedLevelName. See Also: Application.LoadLevelAsync, Application.LoadLevelAdditive, Application.LoadLevelAdditiveAsync.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.LoadLevel(System.String)
member.summary: Loads the level by its name or index.
member.remarks: Before you can load a level you have to add it to the list of levels used in the game. Use File->Build Settings... in Unity and add the levels you need to the level list there. MonoBehaviour.OnLevelWasLoaded is called on all active GameObjects after the level has been loaded.When loading a new level all GameObjects that have been loaded before are destroyed. If you want to let an object survive when loading a new level, use Object.DontDestroyOnLoad. Calling LoadLevel will update Application.loadedLevel and Application.loadedLevelName. See Also: Application.LoadLevelAsync, Application.LoadLevelAdditive, Application.LoadLevelAdditiveAsync.
member.param: The name of the level to load.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.LoadLevelAdditive(System.Int32)
member.remarks: Unlike LoadLevel, LoadLevelAdditive does not destroy objects in the current level. Objects from the new level are added to the current scene. This is useful for creating continuous virtual worlds, where more content is loaded in as you walk through the environment.See Also: AsyncOperation, Application.backgroundLoadingPriority, Application.LoadLevelAdditiveAsync, Application.LoadLevel, Application.LoadLevelAsync.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.LoadLevelAdditive(System.String)
member.remarks: Unlike LoadLevel, LoadLevelAdditive does not destroy objects in the current level. Objects from the new level are added to the current scene. This is useful for creating continuous virtual worlds, where more content is loaded in as you walk through the environment.See Also: AsyncOperation, Application.backgroundLoadingPriority, Application.LoadLevelAdditiveAsync, Application.LoadLevel, Application.LoadLevelAsync.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.LoadLevelAdditiveAsync(System.Int32)
member.summary: Loads the level additively and asynchronously in the background.
member.remarks: Unlike LoadLevelAsync, LoadLevelAdditiveAsync does not destroy objects in the current level. Objects from the new level are added to the current scene. This is useful for creating continuous virtual worlds, where more content is loaded in as you walk through the environment. Unity will completely load all assets and all objects in the scene in a background loading thread. This allows you to create a completely streaming world where you constantly load and unload different parts of the world based on the player position, without any hiccups in game play. isDone variable from the resulting AsyncOperation can be used to query if the level load has completed. The result of a LoadLevelAdditiveAsync can also be used to yield in a coroutine. When building a player Unity automatically optimizes assets in such a way that LoadLevelAdditiveAsync will load them from disk linearly to avoid seek times. Note that background loading performance in the Unity Editor is much lower than in the web player or standalone build. In the Editor you might also get more loading hiccups than in the player. This function requires Unity Pro .See Also: AsyncOperation, Application.backgroundLoadingPriority, Application.LoadLevelAdditive, Application.LoadLevel, Application.LoadLevelAsync.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.LoadLevelAdditiveAsync(System.String)

member.remarks: Unlike LoadLevelAsync, LoadLevelAdditiveAsync does not destroy objects in the current level. Objects from the new level are added to the current scene. This is useful for creating continuous virtual worlds, where more content is loaded in as you walk through the environment. Unity will completely load all assets and all objects in the scene in a background loading thread. This allows you to create a completely streaming world where you constantly load and unload different parts of the world based on the player position, without any hiccups in game play. isDone variable from the resulting AsyncOperation can be used to query if the level load has completed. The result of a LoadLevelAdditiveAsync can also be used to yield in a coroutine. When building a player Unity automatically optimizes assets in such a way that LoadLevelAdditiveAsync will load them from disk linearly to avoid seek times. Note that background loading performance in the Unity Editor is much lower than in the web player or standalone build. In the Editor you might also get more loading hiccups than in the player. This function requires Unity Pro .See Also: AsyncOperation, Application.backgroundLoadingPriority, Application.LoadLevelAdditive, Application.LoadLevel, Application.LoadLevelAsync.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.LoadLevelAsync(System.Int32)
member.summary: Loads the level asynchronously in the background.
member.remarks: Unity will completely load all assets and all objects in the scene in a background loading thread. This allows you to load new levels while still playing the current one, show a progress bar or create a completely streaming world where you constantly load and unload different parts of the world based on the player position, without any hiccups in game play. isDone variable from the resulting AsyncOperation can be used to query if the level load has completed. The result of a LoadLevelAsync can also be used to yield in a coroutine. When building a player Unity automatically optimizes assets in such a way that LoadLevelAsync will load them from disk linearly to avoid seek times. Note that background loading performance in the Unity Editor is much lower than in the web player or standalone build. In the Editor you might also get more loading hiccups than in the player. This function requires Unity Pro .See Also: AsyncOperation, Application.backgroundLoadingPriority, Application.LoadLevel, Application.LoadLevelAdditive, Application.LoadLevelAdditiveAsync.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.LoadLevelAsync(System.String)
member.summary: Loads the level asynchronously in the background.
member.remarks: Unity will completely load all assets and all objects in the scene in a background loading thread. This allows you to load new levels while still playing the current one, show a progress bar or create a completely streaming world where you constantly load and unload different parts of the world based on the player position, without any hiccups in game play. isDone variable from the resulting AsyncOperation can be used to query if the level load has completed. The result of a LoadLevelAsync can also be used to yield in a coroutine. When building a player Unity automatically optimizes assets in such a way that LoadLevelAsync will load them from disk linearly to avoid seek times. Note that background loading performance in the Unity Editor is much lower than in the web player or standalone build. In the Editor you might also get more loading hiccups than in the player. This function requires Unity Pro .See Also: AsyncOperation, Application.backgroundLoadingPriority, Application.LoadLevel, Application.LoadLevelAdditive, Application.LoadLevelAdditiveAsync.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.OpenURL(System.String)
member.summary: Opens the url in a browser.
member.remarks: In the editor or standalone player this will open a new page in the default browser with the url. It will also bring the browser application to the front. When executed in the web player, the page the plugin is contained in will be redirected to the url.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.persistentDataPath
member.summary: Contains the path to a persistent data directory (Read Only).
member.remarks: The value is a directory path where data expected to be kept between runs can be stored. When publishing on iOS and Android, persistentDataPath will point to a public directory on the device. Files in this location won't be erased with each update of the App. However, you should bear in mind that this is not foolproof against users' actions. For example, removing the SD Card would make data stored on it inaccessible. Note that when you build the app, a GUID will be generated based on the Bundle Identifier, and this GUID will be part of persistentDataPath. If you keep the same Bundle Identifier in future versions then the app will continue accessing the same location on every update.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.platform
member.summary: Returns the platform the game is running (Read Only).
member.remarks: Use this property if you absolutely need to do some platform dependent work. See Also: RuntimePlatform.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.Quit
member.summary: Quits the player application. Quit is ignored in the editor or the web player.
member.remarks: IMPORTANT: In most cases termination of application under iOS should be left at the user discretion. Consult Apple's Technical Q&A qa1561 page for further details: http://developer.apple.com iphone library qa qa2008/qa1561.html.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.RegisterLogCallback(UnityEngine.Application+LogCallback)
member.summary: Register a delegate to be called on log messages.
member.remarks: Pass null to remove log handler.See Also: Application.LogCallback, LogType.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.RegisterLogCallbackThreaded(UnityEngine.Application+LogCallback)
member.summary: Register a delegate to be called on log messages.
member.remarks: The only difference between this function and RegisterLogCallback is that this function gets called from a different thread. Note: You should *only* use this function if you know what you are doing, else just use Application.RegisterLogCallback. See Also: Application.LogCallback, Application.RegisterLogCallback, LogType.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Application.RequestUserAuthorization(UnityEngine.UserAuthorization)
member.summary: Request authorization to use the webcam or microphone in the Web Player.
member.remarks: For security reasons (to avoid implementing a web player spying on users), we require you to have the user explicitly allow these features in the web player. To do so, you need to call Application.RequestUserAuthorization, which shows a dialog box to the user, and wait for operation to complete before being able to use these features. Use Application.HasUserAuthorization to query the result of the operation.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.runInBackground
member.summary: Should the player be running when the application is in the background?
member.remarks: Default is false (application pauses when it is in background).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.srcValue
member.summary: The path to the web player data file relative to the html file (Read Only).
member.remarks: Actually this is whatever path is written in the html file as a src parameter to object and embed tags. So if it's the absolute URL, srcValue will have the absolute path. Application.absoluteURL and Application.srcValue allow you to detect if your unityWeb data file was moved to another location or is being linked to. You might want to protect against both to prevent piracy of your data files.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.streamedBytes
member.summary: How many bytes have we downloaded from the main unity web stream (Read Only).
member.remarks: In the webplayer this returns the number of compressed bytes downloaded so far. In standalone player or the editor this always returns zero. See Also: GetStreamProgressForLevel function.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.streamingAssetsPath
member.summary: Contains the path to the StreamingAssets folder (Read Only).
member.remarks: If you have a "StreamingAssets" folder in the Assets folder of your project, it will be copied to your player builds and be present in the path given by Application.streamingAssetsPath. Note that on some platforms it is not possible to directly access the StreamingAssets folder because there is no file system access in the web platforms, and because it is compressed into the .apk file on Android. On those platforms, a url will be returned, which can be used using the WWW class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.systemLanguage
member.summary: The language the user's operating system is running in.
member.remarks: You can use this to automatically pick a localization for your content based on the user's system language.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.targetFrameRate
member.summary: Instructs game to try to render at a specified frame rate.
member.remarks: Setting targetFrameRate to -1 (the default) makes standalone games render as fast as they can, and web player games to render at 50-60 frames/second depending on the platform. Note that setting targetFrameRate does not guarantee that frame rate. There can be fluctuations due to platform specifics, or the game might not achieve the frame rate because the computer is too slow. If vsync is set in quality setting, the target framerate is ignored, and the vblank interval is used instead. The vBlankCount property on qualitysettings can be used to limit the framerate to half of the screens refresh rate (60 fps screen can be limited to 30 fps by setting vBlankCount to 2) targetFrameRate is ignored in the editor.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.temporaryCachePath
member.summary: Contains the path to a temporary data / cache directory (Read Only).
member.remarks: The value is a directory path where temporary data can be stored.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.unityVersion
member.summary: The version of the Unity runtime used to play the content.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Application.webSecurityEnabled
member.summary: Indicates whether Unity's webplayer security model is enabled.
member.remarks: In the web player, this will always return true. In the Unity editor, it will return true if web security emulation is enabled (Menu->Edit->Project Settings->Editor) and false if the emulation is disabled. On all other platforms, this will return false; This property can only be read.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Application+LogCallback
member.summary: Use this delegate type with RegisterLogCallback to monitor what gets logged.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AssetBundle
member.summary: AssetBundles let you stream additional assets via the WWW class and instantiate them at runtime. AssetBundles are created via BuildPipeline.BuildAssetBundle.
member.remarks: Note that bundles are not fully compatible between platforms. A bundle built for any of the standalone platforms (including webplayer) can be loaded on any of those platforms but not on iOS or Android. Furthermore, a bundle built for iOS is not compatible with Android and vice versa. See Also: WWW.assetBundle, Loading Resources at Runtime, BuildPipeline.BuildAssetBundle.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AssetBundle.Contains(System.String)
member.summary: Check if an AssetBundle contains a specific object.
member.remarks: Returns true if an object referred to by name is contained in the AssetBundle, false otherwise.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AssetBundle.CreateFromFile(System.String)
member.summary: Loads an asset bundle from a disk.
member.remarks: Only uncompressed asset bundles are supported by this function. This is the fastest way to load an asset bundle.
member.param: Path of the file on disk See Also: WWW.assetBundle, WWW.LoadFromCacheOrDownload.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AssetBundle.CreateFromMemory(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Asynchronously create an AssetBundle from a memory region.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AssetBundle.Load(System.String)
member.summary: Loads object with name from the bundle.Loads object with name of a given type from the bundle.

member.summary: Loads all objects contained in the asset bundle that inherit from type.Loads all objects contained in the asset bundle.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AssetBundle.LoadAsync(System.String,System.Type)
member.summary: Asynchronously loads object with name of a given type from the bundle.
member.remarks: Asynchronous loading requires Unity Pro. See Also: AssetBundleRequest.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AssetBundle.mainAsset
member.summary: Main asset that was supplied when building the asset bundle (Read Only).
member.remarks: This is a convenience function that makes it easy to find the primary asset of a bundle. For example you might want to have a prefab of a character and include all textures, materials, meshes and animations files with it. But the fully rigged prefab of the character would be your mainAsset and can easily be accessed.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AssetBundle.Unload(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Unloads all assets in the bundle.
member.remarks: Unload frees all the memory associated with the objects inside the bundle. When unloadAllLoadedObjects is false, compressed file data for assets inside the bundle will be unloaded, but any actual objects already loaded from this bundle will be kept intact. Of course you won't be able to load any more objects from this bundle. When unloadAllLoadedObjects is true, all objects that were loaded from this bundle will be destroyed as well. If there are GameObjects in your scene referencing those assets, the references to them will become missing.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AssetBundleCreateRequest
member.summary: Asynchronous create request for an AssetBundle.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AssetBundleCreateRequest.assetBundle
member.remarks: Note that accessing asset before isDone is true will stall the loading process.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AssetBundleRequest
member.summary: Asynchronous load request from an AssetBundle.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AssetBundleRequest.asset
member.remarks: Note that accessing asset before isDone is true will stall the loading process.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AsyncOperation
member.remarks: You can yield until asynchronous operation continues, or manually check whether it's done ( isDone ) or progress ( progress ). See Also: Application.LoadLevelAsync, Application.LoadLevelAdditiveAsync, AssetBundle.LoadAsync.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AsyncOperation.allowSceneActivation
member.summary: Allow scenes to be activated as soon as it is ready.
member.remarks: When used in combination with LoadLevelAsync & LoadLevelAsyncAdditive it allows you to delay the actual activation of the scene. (And unloading of the previous scene).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AsyncOperation.priority
member.summary: Priority lets you tweak in which order async operation calls will be performed.
member.remarks: When multiple asynchronous operations are queued up, the operation with the higher priority will be executed first. Once an operation has been started on the background thread, changing the priority will have no effect anymore.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioChorusFilter
member.summary: The Audio Chorus Filter takes an Audio Clip and processes it creating a chorus effect.
member.remarks: The chorus effect modulates the original sound by a sinusoid low frequency oscillator (LFO). The output sounds like there are multiple sources emitting the same sound with slight variations - resembling a choir. Note: This filter is only available on the PRO version.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioChorusFilter.delay
member.summary: Chorus delay in ms. 0.1 to 100.0. Default = 40.0 ms.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioChorusFilter.dryMix
member.summary: Volume of original signal to pass to output. 0.0 to 1.0. Default = 0.5.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioChorusFilter.rate
member.summary: Chorus modulation rate in hz. 0.0 to 20.0. Default = 0.8 hz.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioChorusFilter.wetMix1
member.summary: Volume of 1st chorus tap. 0.0 to 1.0. Default = 0.5.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioChorusFilter.wetMix2
member.summary: Volume of 2nd chorus tap. This tap is 90 degrees out of phase of the first tap. 0.0 to 1.0. Default = 0.5.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioChorusFilter.wetMix3
member.summary: Volume of 3rd chorus tap. This tap is 90 degrees out of phase of the second tap. 0.0 to 1.0. Default = 0.5.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioClip
member.remarks: An AudioClip stores the audio file either compressed as ogg vorbis or uncompressed. AudioClips are referenced and used by AudioSources to play sounds. See Also: AudioClip component in the Components Reference.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioClip.Create(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a user AudioClip with a name and with the given length in samples, channels and frequency.
member.remarks: Set your own audio data with SetData. Use the PCMReaderCallback and PCMSetPositionCallback delegates to get a callback whenever the clip reads data and changes the position. If stream is true, Unity will on demand read in small chunks of data. If it's false, all the samples will be read during the creation.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioClip.Create(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,UnityEngine.AudioClip+PCMReaderCallback)
member.summary: Creates a user AudioClip with a name and with the given length in samples, channels and frequency.
member.remarks: Set your own audio data with SetData. Use the PCMReaderCallback and PCMSetPositionCallback delegates to get a callback whenever the clip reads data and changes the position. If stream is true, Unity will on demand read in small chunks of data. If it's false, all the samples will be read during the creation.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioClip.Create(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,UnityEngine.AudioClip+PCMReaderCallback,UnityEngine.AudioClip+PCMSetPositionCallback)
member.summary: Creates a user AudioClip with a name and with the given length in samples, channels and frequency.

If stream is true, Unity will on demand read in small chunks of data. If it's false, all the samples will be read during the creation.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioClip.GetData(System.Single[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Fills an array with sample data from the clip. The samples are floats ranging from -1.0f to 1.0f. The sample count is determined by the length of the float array.
member.remarks: Use offsetSamples to start the read from a random position in the clip. If the read length from the offset is longer than the clip length, the read will wrap around and read the remaining samples from the start of the clip.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioClip.isReadyToPlay
member.summary: Is a streamed audio clip ready to play? (Read Only)
member.remarks: If the AudioClip is downloading from a web site, this returns if enough data has been downloaded so playback should be able to start without interruptions. For AudioClips not associated with a web stream, this value always returns true.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioClip.length
member.summary: The length of the audio clip in seconds. (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioClip.samples
member.summary: The length of the audio clip in samples. (Read Only)

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioClip.SetData(System.Single[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Set sample data in a clip. The samples should be floats ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f (exceeding these limits will lead to artifacts and undefined behaviour).
member.remarks: The sample count is determined by the length of the float array. Use offsetSamples to write into a random position in the clip. If the length from the offset is longer than the clip length, the write will wrap around and write the remaining samples from the start of the clip.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioClip+PCMReaderCallback
member.summary: Delegate called each time AudioClip reads data.
member.param: Array of floats containing data read from the clip.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioClip+PCMSetPositionCallback
member.summary: Delegate called each time AudioClip changes read position.
member.param: New position in the audio clip.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioEchoFilter

member.remarks: The repetitions based on the Decay Ratio. Note: This filter is only available on the PRO version.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioEchoFilter.decayRatio

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioEchoFilter.delay
member.summary: Echo delay in ms. 10 to 5000. Default = 500.

member.summary: Volume of original signal to pass to output. 0.0 to 1.0. Default = 1.0.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioEchoFilter.wetMix

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioHighPassFilter.cutoffFrequency
member.summary: Highpass cutoff frequency in hz. 10.0 to 22000.0. Default = 5000.0.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioHighPassFilter.highpassResonaceQ
member.summary: Determines how much the filter's self-resonance isdampened.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioListener

member.remarks: This class implements a microphone-like device. It records the sounds around it and plays that through the player's speakers. You can only have one listener in a scene. See Also: AudioSource, AudioListener component in the Components Reference.
