member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioListener.pause
member.summary: The paused state of the audio system.
member.remarks: If set to true, all AudioSources playing will be paused. This works in the same way as pausing the game in the editor. While the pause-state is true, the AudioSettings.dspTime will be frozen and further AudioSource play requests will start off paused. If you want certain sounds to still play during the pause, you need to set the ignoreListenerPause property on the AudioSource to true for these. This is typically menu item sounds or background music for the menu. Any scheduled play requests will be frozen in time, so that if you scheduled a sound to play after 3 seconds and paused the audio system 1 second after this, the scheduled sounds will start playing 2 seconds after unpausing.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioListener.velocityUpdateMode
member.summary: This lets you set whether the Audio Listener should be updated in the fixed or dynamic update.
member.remarks: Make sure this is set to update in the same update loop as the Audio Listener is moved in if you are experiencing problems with Doppler effect simulation. The default setting will automatically set the listener to be updated in the fixed update loop if it is attached to a rigidbody, and dynamic otherwise.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioListener.volume
member.summary: Controls the game sound volume (0.0 to 1.0).

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioLowPassFilter
member.summary: The Audio Low Pass Filter filter passes low frequencies of an.
member.remarks: AudioSource, or all sound reaching an AudioListener, and attenuates frequencies higher than the Cutoff Frequency. Note: This filter is only available on the PRO.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioLowPassFilter.cutoffFrequency
member.summary: Lowpass cutoff frequency in hz. 10.0 to 22000.0. Default = 5000.0.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioLowPassFilter.lowpassResonaceQ
member.summary: Determines how much the filter's self-resonance is dampened.
member.remarks: Higher Lowpass Resonance Q indicates a lower rate of energy loss i.e. the oscillations die out more slowly. Lowpass resonance Q value goes from 1.0 to 10.0. Default = 1.0.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioReverbFilter

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioReverbPreset

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AudioReverbPreset.Off
member.remarks: All the values are disabled and the sound is the default without any modifications.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AudioReverbPreset.User
member.remarks: Select this preset if you want to change manually the values of your preset.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioReverbZone
member.summary: Reverb Zones are used when you want to create location based ambient effects in the scene.
member.remarks: As the Audio Listener moves into a Reverb Zone, the ambient effect associated with the zone is gradually applied. At the max distance there is no effect and at the min distance the effect is fully applied. For example you can gradually change your character's footsteps sounds and create the feeling like you where entering into a cavern, going trough a room, swimming underwater, etc. You can always mix reverb zones to have combined effects. For more info check Reverb Zones in the manual.

member.summary: High-frequency to mid-frequency decay time ratio.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioReverbZone.decayTime
member.summary: Reverberation decay time at mid frequencies.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioReverbZone.density
member.summary: Value that controls the modal density in the late reverberation decay.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioReverbZone.diffusion
member.summary: Value that controls the echo density in the late reverberation decay.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioReverbZone.maxDistance

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioReverbZone.minDistance
member.summary: The distance from the centerpoint that the reverb will have full effect at. Default = 10.0.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioSettings
member.summary: Controls the global audio settings from script.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSettings.driverCaps
member.summary: Returns the speaker mode capability of the current audio driver. (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSettings.dspTime
member.summary: Returns the current time of the audio system.
member.remarks: This is a value specified in seconds and based on the actual number of samples the audio system processes and is therefore much more precise than the time obtained via the Time.time property.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSettings.GetDSPBufferSize(System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Get or set the mixer's buffer size in samples.
member.remarks: Note that setting a new buffersize will reset the audio system (all audio will stop). For mobiles (iOS devices and Android) the is also settable from the menu 'Audio Settings->Mobile DSP Buffer size'. The software mixer mixes to a ringbuffer. The size of this ringbuffer is determined here. It mixes a block of sound data every 'bufferlength' number of samples, and there are 'numbuffers' number of these blocks that make up the entire ringbuffer. Adjusting these values can lead to extremely low latency performance (smaller values), or greater stability in sound output (larger values). Warning! The 'buffersize' is generally best left alone. Making the granularity smaller will just increase CPU usage (cache misses and DSP network overhead). Making it larger affects how often you hear commands update such as volume pitch pan changes. Anything above 20ms will be noticable and sound parameter changes will be obvious instead of smooth. Unity chooses the most optimal size by default for best stability, depending on the output type, and if the drivers are emulated or not (for example DirectSound is emulated using waveOut on NT). It is not recommended changing this value unless you really need to. You may get worse performance than the default settings chosen by Unity.
member.param: Is the length of each buffer in the ringbuffer.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSettings.outputSampleRate
member.summary: Get and set the mixer's current output rate.
member.remarks: Note that setting a new samplerate will reset the audio system (all audio will stop).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSettings.SetDSPBufferSize(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get or set the mixer's buffer size in samples.
member.remarks: Note that setting a new buffersize will reset the audio system (all audio will stop). For mobiles (iOS devices and Android) the is also settable from the menu 'Audio Settings->Mobile DSP Buffer size'. The software mixer mixes to a ringbuffer. The size of this ringbuffer is determined here. It mixes a block of sound data every 'bufferlength' number of samples, and there are 'numbuffers' number of these blocks that make up the entire ringbuffer. Adjusting these values can lead to extremely low latency performance (smaller values), or greater stability in sound output (larger values). Warning! The 'buffersize' is generally best left alone. Making the granularity smaller will just increase CPU usage (cache misses and DSP network overhead). Making it larger affects how often you hear commands update such as volume pitch pan changes. Anything above 20ms will be noticable and sound parameter changes will be obvious instead of smooth. Unity chooses the most optimal size by default for best stability, depending on the output type, and if the drivers are emulated or not (for example DirectSound is emulated using waveOut on NT). It is not recommended changing this value unless you really need to. You may get worse performance than the default settings chosen by Unity.
member.param: Is the length of each buffer in the ringbuffer.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSettings.speakerMode
member.summary: Sets or gets the current speaker mode. Default is 2 channel stereo.
member.remarks: Be aware that the audio system is restarted when a new speaker mode is set. This means that playback on all AudioSources is stopped; any sounds that should be continuous (such as music) will need to be started again after the speaker mode is changed. If a speaker mode is set beyond the drivers capability, the audio behaviour is undefined. Use AudioSettings.driverCaps to get the capabilities of the current driver.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioSource
member.summary: A representation of audio sources in 3D.
member.remarks: An AudioSource is attached to a GameObject for playing back sounds in a 3D environment. In order to play 3D sounds you also need to have a AudioListener. The audio listener is normally attached to the camera you want to use. Whether sounds are played in 3D or 2D is determined by AudioImporter settings. You can play a single audio clip using Play, Pause and Stop. You can also adjust its volume while playing using the volume property, or seek using time. Multiple sounds can be played on one AudioSource using PlayOneShot. You can play a clip at a static position in 3D space using PlayClipAtPoint. See Also: AudioListener, AudioClip, AudioSource component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.bypassEffects
member.summary: Bypass effects (Applied from filter components or global listener filters).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.dopplerLevel

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.loop

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.maxDistance
member.summary: (Logarithmic rolloff) MaxDistance is the distance a sound stops attenuating at.
member.remarks: (Linear rolloff) MaxDistance is the distance where the sound is completely inaudible.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.minDistance
member.summary: Within the Min distance the AudioSource will cease to grow louder in volume.
member.remarks: Outside the min distance the volume starts to attenuate.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.mute
member.summary: Un- / Mutes the AudioSource. Mute sets the volume=0, Un-Mute restore the original volume.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.pan
member.summary: Sets a channels pan position linearly. Only works for 2D clips.
member.remarks: -1.0 to 1.0. -1.0 is full left. 0.0 is center. 1.0 is full right. Only sounds that are mono or stereo can be panned. Multichannel sounds (ie >2 channels) cannot be panned.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.panLevel
member.summary: Sets how much the 3d engine has an effect on the channel.
member.remarks: Useful for morphing an AudioSource from 3D(1.0f) to 2D(0.0f).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.pitch
member.summary: The pitch of the audio source.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSource.Play
member.summary: Plays the clip with an optional certain delay.
member.remarks: The delay parameter is deprecated, please use the newer PlayDelayed function instead which specifies the delay in seconds. Note: To obtain sample accuracy with an AudioClip with a different samplerate (than 44.1 khz) you have to do the math yourselves. Delaying an audiosource with an attached AudioClip with samplerate of, say, 32 khz, with 16k samples(.5 sec) is done by Play(22050). ((44100/32000) * 16000 = 22050). Note: The AudioSource.PlayScheduled API will give you more accurate control over when the audio clip is played.See Also: Stop, Pause, clip and PlayScheduled functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSource.Play(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Plays the clip with an optional certain delay.
member.remarks: The delay parameter is deprecated, please use the newer PlayDelayed function instead which specifies the delay in seconds. Note: To obtain sample accuracy with an AudioClip with a different samplerate (than 44.1 khz) you have to do the math yourselves. Delaying an audiosource with an attached AudioClip with samplerate of, say, 32 khz, with 16k samples(.5 sec) is done by Play(22050). ((44100/32000) * 16000 = 22050). Note: The AudioSource.PlayScheduled API will give you more accurate control over when the audio clip is played.See Also: Stop, Pause, clip and PlayScheduled functions.
member.param: Delay in number of samples, assuming a 44100Hz sample rate (meaning that Play(44100) will delay the playing by exactly 1 sec).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSource.PlayClipAtPoint(UnityEngine.AudioClip,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Plays an AudioClip at a given position in world space.
member.remarks: This function creates an audio source but automatically disposes of it once the clip has finished playing.
member.param: Position in world space from which sound originates.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSource.PlayClipAtPoint(UnityEngine.AudioClip,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Plays an AudioClip at a given position in world space.
member.remarks: This function creates an audio source but automatically disposes of it once the clip has finished playing.
member.param: Position in world space from which sound originates.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSource.PlayDelayed(System.Single)
member.summary: Plays the clip with a delay specified in seconds. Users are advised to use this function instead of the old Play(delay) function that took a delay specified in samples relative to a reference rate of 44.1 kHz as an argument.
member.remarks: Note: This function replaces the Play(delay) function when called with the delay-argument. In that function the delay had to be specified as samples relative to a reference rate of 44100. This is inconvenient when the engine is running on a different sample rate and the source sound has an even different rate. Working with delays specified in seconds makes this independent of these.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.playOnAwake
member.summary: If set to true, the audio source will automatically start playing on awake.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSource.PlayOneShot(UnityEngine.AudioClip)
member.summary: Plays an AudioClip, and scales the AudioSource volume by volumeScale.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSource.PlayOneShot(UnityEngine.AudioClip,System.Single)
member.summary: Plays an AudioClip, and scales the AudioSource volume by volumeScale.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSource.PlayScheduled(System.Double)
member.summary: Plays the clip at a specific time on the absolute time-line that AudioSettings.dspTime reads from.
member.remarks: This is the preferred way to stitch AudioClips in music players because it is independent of the frame rate and gives the audio system enough time to prepare the playback of the sound to fetch it from media where the opening and buffering takes a lot of time (streams) without causing sudden CPU spikes.The example at AudioSource.SetScheduledEndTime shows how you can play two audio clips without pops or clicks between the clips. The approach is to have two AudioSources with clips attached, and queue up each clip using its AudioSource. See Also: SetScheduledStartTime.
member.param: Time in seconds on the absolute time-line that AudioSettings.dspTime refers to for when the sound should start playing.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.priority
member.summary: Sets the priority of the AudioSource.
member.remarks: Unity is virtualizing AudioSources, when there's more AudioSources playing than available hardware channels. The AudioSources with lowest priority (and audibility) is virtualized first. Priority is an integer between 0 and 255. 0=highest priority, 255=lowest priority.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.rolloffMode
member.summary: Sets/Gets how the AudioSource attenuates over distance.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSource.SetScheduledEndTime(System.Double)
member.summary: Changes the time at which a sound that has already been scheduled to play will end. Notice that depending on the timing not all rescheduling requests can be fulfilled.
member.remarks: Note that the time specified is still a time on the absolute time-line, meaning that the sound will stop when reaching that time, regardless of when it was started. So if you have a 5 second long sound and want it to play at time T and stop after 3 seconds (i.e. silencing the last 2 seconds of the sound), you need to specify the end time to be T+3. This function is useful in music systems to overcome the discontinuities in signals that frame-based lossy codecs cause.Note: If possible create clips that overlap, and use the scheduled end time for the first, and AudioSource.time for the second to trim out the overlapped part, as the example above shows.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.AudioSource.SetScheduledStartTime(System.Double)
member.summary: Changes the time at which a sound that has already been scheduled to play will start.
member.remarks: Notice that depending on the timing not all rescheduling requests can be fulfilled. One interesting use case for this is stinger sound effects that are initiated by game events, but that you also want to be synchronized to specific beats in music. Then this function can be used to defer the stinger until the next musical transition. Note: In general it is better to use PlayScheduled to cue up audio. Only use SetScheduledStartTime if you have scheduled an audio clip to play in the future and you need to change the time at which it starts. Calling SetScheduledStartTime will not cause an un-scheduled audio clip to play. See Also: AudioClip.PlayScheduled.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.spread
member.summary: Sets the spread angle a 3d stereo or multichannel sound in speaker space.
member.remarks: 0 = all sound channels are located at the same speaker location and is 'mono'. 360 = all subchannels are located at the opposite speaker location to the speaker location that it should be according to 3D position. Default = 0.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.time
member.remarks: Use this to read current playback time or to seek to a new playback time. Be aware that: On a compressed audio track position does not necessary reflect the actual time in the track Compressed audio is represented as a set of so-called packets. The length of a packet depends on the compression settings and can quite often be 2-3 seconds per packet. See Also: timeSamples variable.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.timeSamples
member.remarks: Use this to read current playback time or to seek to a new playback time in samples, if you want more precise timing than what time variable allows. See Also: time variable.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.velocityUpdateMode
member.summary: Whether the Audio Source should be updated in the fixed or dynamic update.
member.remarks: Make sure this is set to update in the same update loop as the Audio Source is moved in if you are experiencing problems with Doppler effect simulation for this source. The default setting will automatically set the source to be updated in the fixed update loop if it is attached to a rigidbody, and dynamic otherwise.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.AudioSource.volume
member.summary: The volume of the audio source (0.0 to 1.0).

member.name: T:UnityEngine.AudioSpeakerMode
member.summary: These are speaker types defined for use with AudioSettings.speakerMode.
member.remarks: Your project's default speaker mode can be set in the Audiomanager through Edit->Project Settings->Audio. See Also: AudioSettings, Audio Manager.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AudioSpeakerMode.Mode5point1
member.summary: Channel count is set to 6. 5.1 speaker setup. This includes front left, front right, center, rear left, rear right and a subwoofer.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AudioSpeakerMode.Mode7point1
member.summary: Channel count is set to 8. 7.1 speaker setup. This includes front left, front right, center, rear left, rear right, side left, side right and a subwoofer.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AudioSpeakerMode.Mono
member.summary: Channel count is set to 1. The speakers are monaural.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AudioSpeakerMode.Prologic
member.summary: Channel count is set to 2. Stereo output, but data is encoded in a way that is picked up by a Prologic/Prologic2 decoder and split into a 5.1 speaker setup.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AudioSpeakerMode.Quad
member.summary: Channel count is set to 4. 4 speaker setup. This includes front left, front right, rear left, rear right.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AudioSpeakerMode.Stereo
member.summary: Channel count is set to 2. The speakers are stereo. This is the editor default.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AudioSpeakerMode.Surround
member.summary: Channel count is set to 5. 5 speaker setup. This includes front left, front right, center, rear left, rear right.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.AudioType.AUDIOQUEUE

member.remarks: How many bones affect each vertex. See Also: QualitySettings.blendWeights.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.BoneWeight
member.summary: Skinning bone weights of a vertex in the mesh.
member.remarks: Each vertex is skinned with up to four bones. All weights should sum up to one. Weights and bone indices should be defined in the order of decreasing weight. If a vertex is affected by less than four bones, the remaining weights should be zeroes. See Also: Mesh.boneWeights variable.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Bounds
member.summary: Represents an axis aligned bounding box.
member.remarks: An axis-aligned bounding box, or AABB for short, is a box aligned with coordinate axes and fully enclosing some object. Because the box is never rotated with respect to the axes, it can be defined by just its center and extents, or alternatively by min and max points. Bounds is used by Collider.bounds, Mesh.bounds, Renderer.bounds.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Bounds.min

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Bounds.SetMinMax(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Sets the bounds to the min and max value of the box.
member.remarks: Using this function is faster than assigning min and max separately.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Bounds.size

member.remarks: size.x is the width, size.y is the height and size.z is the depth of the box.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.BoxCollider2D.center

member.name: P:UnityEngine.BoxCollider2D.size
member.summary: The width and height of the rectangle.
member.remarks: The X coordinate of the vector represents the width while the Y represents the height. These values are specified relative to a center point, so the distance from the center to the left edge is actually width/2. See Also: center.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Caching
member.summary: The Caching class lets you manage cached AssetBundles, downloaded using WWW.LoadFromCacheOrDownload.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Caching.Authorize(System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.remarks: Enables a dedicated, application-specific WebPlayer cache (Dedicated WebPlayer caches require a paid license from Unity Technologies). If you have a dedicated cache license, call this function at WebPlayer application startup with the license information provided to you. Starting with the release of Unity 3.2, all WebPlayer applications have access to a 50 MiB shared cache; calling the Authorize() function is not necessary. Starting with the release of Unity 3.4, PC/Mac Standalone players and iOS/Android players have access to a 4 GiB dedicated cache for each application; calling the Authorize() function is not necessary.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Caching.Authorize(System.String,System.String,System.Int64,System.String)
member.remarks: Enables a dedicated, application-specific WebPlayer cache (Dedicated WebPlayer caches require a paid license from Unity Technologies). If you have a dedicated cache license, call this function at WebPlayer application startup with the license information provided to you. Starting with the release of Unity 3.2, all WebPlayer applications have access to a 50 MiB shared cache; calling the Authorize() function is not necessary. Starting with the release of Unity 3.4, PC/Mac Standalone players and iOS/Android players have access to a 4 GiB dedicated cache for each application; calling the Authorize() function is not necessary.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Caching.Authorize(System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String)
member.remarks: Enables a dedicated, application-specific WebPlayer cache (Dedicated WebPlayer caches require a paid license from Unity Technologies). If you have a dedicated cache license, call this function at WebPlayer application startup with the license information provided to you. Starting with the release of Unity 3.2, all WebPlayer applications have access to a 50 MiB shared cache; calling the Authorize() function is not necessary. Starting with the release of Unity 3.4, PC/Mac Standalone players and iOS/Android players have access to a 4 GiB dedicated cache for each application; calling the Authorize() function is not necessary.

If you have a dedicated cache license, call this function at WebPlayer application startup with the license information provided to you. Starting with the release of Unity 3.2, all WebPlayer applications have access to a 50 MiB shared cache; calling the Authorize() function is not necessary. Starting with the release of Unity 3.4, PC/Mac Standalone players and iOS/Android players have access to a 4 GiB dedicated cache for each application; calling the Authorize() function is not necessary.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Caching.CleanCache
member.summary: Delete all AssetBundle content that has been cached by the current application.
member.returns: True when cache cleaning succeeded, false if cache was in use.
member.remarks: This function is not available to WebPlayer applications that use the shared cache.
member.example: if (GUILayout.Button("Uninstall Game")) Caching.CleanCache ();

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Caching.enabled
member.remarks: WebPlayer users may disable Caching for all WebPlayer applications by right-clicking on the WebPlayer content, selecting "Setup...", and checking the 'Disable all caching' checkbox. If caching is disabled, WWW.LoadFromCacheOrDownload() will continue to function, but will never cache downloaded AssetBundles. Caching is always enabled for PC/Mac Standalone and iOS/Android player builds.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Caching.expirationDelay
member.summary: The number of seconds that an AssetBundle may remain unused in the cache before it is automatically deleted.
member.remarks: This value defaults to 150 days (12,960,000 seconds). Lower values will cause the cache to be cleaned more aggressively in order to minimize disk storage usage. The delay cannot be set greater than 12,960,000 seconds.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Caching.IsVersionCached(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Checks if an AssetBundle is cached.
member.returns: True if an AssetBundle matching the and parameters has previously been loaded using WWW.LoadFromCacheOrDownload() and is currently stored in the cache. Returns false if the AssetBundle is not in cache, either because it has been flushed from the cache or was never loaded using the Caching API.
member.remarks: When using the default shared cache, the URL of the WebPlayer application bundle is automatically prepended to the url parameter; this prevents filename collisions with identically-named AssetBundles used by other developers' WebPlayer applications. WebPlayer applications that use a dedicated cache do not experience this behavior. This function can be utilized to enable AssetBundle preloading. First, call Caching.IsVersionCached() to see if the current version of an AssetBundle is already cached. If the AssetBundle is not cached, it can be preloaded in the background so that it is immediately available for loading into memory when requested.
member.example: if (Caching.IsVersionCached("http://myserver.com/bla.unity3d", 3)) GUILayout.Button("Load Level");

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Caching.MarkAsUsed(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Bumps the timestamp of a cached file to be the current time.
member.remarks: This allows you to keep files in the cache even if you are not explicitly loading them. Returns true if the url is cached.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Caching.maximumAvailableDiskSpace
member.summary: The total number of bytes that can potentially be allocated for caching.
member.remarks: This value can be set to a smaller number in order to limit the amount of disk space used by cached AssetBundles. The WebPlayer shared cache allows up to 50 MiB of cached AssetBundles. PC/Mac Standalone applications and iOS/Android applications have a limit of 4 GiB. WebPlayer applications that make use of a dedicated cache are limited to the number of bytes specified in the Caching license agreement. This property does not account for total available disk space. If a user's computer has less available disk space on the drive where the cache is located than maximumAvailableDiskSpace, the full amount of maximumAvailableDiskSpace will not be usable. Cache storage is allocated on an as-needed basis in order to minimize disk space usage.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Caching.spaceFree
member.summary: The number of currently unused bytes in the cache.
member.remarks: When the cache is empty, this value equals maximumAvailableDiskSpace. As AssetBundles are stored in the cache, this value will decrease. Caching manages cached content based on a Least Recently Used (LRU) algorithm. If insufficient space is available in the cache to store a requested AssetBundle, the oldest AssetBundles in the cache will be iteratively removed until enough space is free for the new AssetBundle. This property does not account for total available disk space. If a user's computer has less available disk space on the drive where the cache is located than spaceFree, the full amount of spaceFree will not be usable.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Caching.spaceOccupied
member.remarks: Initially this is 0. As you download files to the cache, this will increment. If insufficient space is available in the cache to store a requested AssetBundle, the least-recently-used AssetBundles in the cache will be iteratively removed until enough space is available for the new AssetBundle.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CalendarIdentifier.RepublicOfChinaCalendar
member.summary: Identifies the Republic of China (Taiwan) calendar.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CalendarUnit.Quarter
member.summary: Specifies the quarter of the calendar.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Camera
member.summary: A Camera is a device through which the player views the world.
member.remarks: A screen space point is defined in pixels. The bottom-left of the screen is (0,0); the right-top is ( pixelWidth, pixelHeight ). The z position is in world units from the camera. A viewport space point is normalized and relative to the camera. The bottom-left of the camera is (0,0); the top-right is (1,1). The z position is in world units from the camera. A world space point is defined in global coordinates (eg. Transform.position). See Also: camera component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.allCameras
member.summary: Returns all enabled cameras in the scene.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.aspect
member.summary: The aspect ratio (width divided by height).
member.remarks: By default the aspect ratio is automatically calculated from the screen's aspect ratio, even if the camera is not rendering to full area. If you modify the aspect ratio of the camera, the value will stay until you call camera.ResetAspect(); which resets the aspect to the screen's aspect ratio. See Also: camera component, Screen class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.backgroundColor
member.summary: The color with which the screen will be cleared.
member.remarks: Only used if clearFlags are set to CameraClearFlags.SolidColor (or CameraClearFlags.Skybox but the skybox is not set up).See Also: camera component, Camera.clearFlags property.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.cameraToWorldMatrix
member.summary: Matrix that transforms from camera space to world space (Read Only).
member.remarks: Use this to calculate where in the world a specific camera space point is. Note that camera space matches OpenGL convention: camera's forward is the negative Z axis. This is different from Unity's convention, where forward is the positive Z axis.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.clearFlags
member.summary: How the camera clears the background.
member.remarks: Can be CameraClearFlags.Skybox, CameraClearFlags.SolidColor, CameraClearFlags.Depth or CameraClearFlags.Nothing.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.CopyFrom(UnityEngine.Camera)
member.summary: Makes this camera's settings match other camera.
member.remarks: This will copy all camera's variables (field of view, clear flags, culling mask, ...) from the other camera. It will also set this camera's transform to match the other camera, as well as this camera's layer to match the layer of the other camera. This can be useful if you want one camera to match the other camera's setup, when doing custom rendering effects. For example when using RenderWithShader.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.cullingMask
member.summary: This is used to render parts of the scene selectively.
member.remarks: If the GameObject 's layerMask AND the camera's cullingMask is zero then the GameObject will be invisible from this camera. See Layers for more information. See Also: camera component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.current
member.summary: The camera we are currently rendering with, for low-level render control only (Read Only).
member.remarks: Most of the time you will want to use Camera.main instead. Use this function only when implementing one of the following events: MonoBehaviour.OnRenderImage, MonoBehaviour.OnPreRender, MonoBehaviour.OnPostRender.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.depth
member.summary: Camera's depth in the camera rendering order.
member.remarks: Cameras with lower depth are rendered before cameras with higher depth. Use this to control the order in which cameras are drawn if you have multiple cameras and some of them don't cover the full screen. See Also: camera component, Camera.rect property.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.depthTextureMode
member.summary: How and if camera generates a depth texture.
member.remarks: A camera can build a screen-space depth texture. This is mostly useful for image post-processing effects. Note that generating the texture incurs a performance cost. See Also: DepthTextureMode.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.eventMask
member.summary: Mask to select which layers can trigger events on the camera.
member.remarks: Just as the camera's cullingMask determines if the camera is able to see the GameObject, the event mask determines whether the GameObject is able to receive mouse events. Only objects visible by the camera and whose layerMask overlaps with the camera's eventMask will be able to receive OnMouseXXX events. Setting this mask to zero will improve performance and is recommended if you don't use OnMouseXXX events. See Layers for more information. See Also: MonoBehaviour.OnMouseEnter See Also: MonoBehaviour.OnMouseExit See Also: MonoBehaviour.OnMouseOver See Also: MonoBehaviour.OnMouseDown See Also: MonoBehaviour.OnMouseOver See Also: MonoBehaviour.OnMouseUp See Also: MonoBehaviour.OnMouseDrag See Also: MonoBehaviour.OnMouseUpAsButton.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.fieldOfView
member.summary: The field of view of the camera in degrees.
member.remarks: This is the vertical field of view; horizontal FOV varies depending on the viewport's aspect ratio. Field of view is ignored when camera is orthographic (see orthographic ). See Also: camera component .Another example using specifically the main camera:

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.hdr
member.remarks: Should this camera use HDR rendering?

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.layerCullDistances
member.remarks: Normally Camera skips rendering of objects that are further away than farClipPlane. You can set up some Layers to use smaller culling distances using layerCullDistances. This is very useful to cull small objects early on, if you put them into appropriate layers. When assigning layerCullDistances, you need to assign float array that has 32 values. Zero values in cull distances means "use far plane distance". By default, per-layer culling will use a plane aligned with the camera. You can change this to a sphere by setting layerCullSpherical on the Camera to true.See Also: farClipPlane. See Also: layerCullSpherical.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.layerCullSpherical
member.summary: How to perform per-layer culling for a Camera.
member.remarks: Normally this type of culling is performed by moving the Camera's far plane closer to the eye. By setting this value to true, the culling is instead based on spherical distance. The benefit is that rotating on the same spot does not affect which objects are visible. See Also: layerCullDistances.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.main
member.summary: The first enabled camera tagged "MainCamera" (Read Only).
member.remarks: Returns null if there is no such camera in the scene.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.orthographic
member.summary: Is the camera orthographic (true) or perspective (false)?
member.remarks: When ortho is true, camera's viewing volume is defined by orthographicSize. When orthographic is false, camera's viewing volume is defined by fieldOfView. See Also: camera component, transparencySortMode .Specifically for the main camera:

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.orthographicSize
member.summary: Camera's half-size when in orthographic mode.
member.remarks: This is half of the vertical size of the viewing volume. Horizontal viewing size varies depending on viewport's aspect ratio. Orthographic size is ignored when camera is not orthographic (see orthographic ). See Also: camera component .Using specifically the main camera:

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.pixelHeight
member.summary: How tall is the camera in pixels (Read Only).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.pixelRect
member.summary: Where on the screen is the camera rendered in pixel coordinates.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.pixelWidth
member.summary: How wide is the camera in pixels (Read Only).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.projectionMatrix
member.remarks: If you change this matrix, the camera no longer updates its rendering based on its fieldOfView. This lasts until you call ResetProjectionMatrix. Use a custom projection only if you really need a non-standard projection. This property is used by Unity's water rendering to setup an oblique projection matrix. Using custom projections requires good knowledge of transformation and projection matrices.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.rect
member.summary: Where on the screen is the camera rendered in normalized coordinates.
member.remarks: The values in rect range from zero (left/bottom) to one (right/top).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.Render
member.remarks: This will render the camera. It will use the camera's clear flags, target texture and all other settings. The camera will send OnPreCull, OnPreRender & OnPostRender to any scripts attached, and render any eventual image filters. This is used for taking precise control of render order. To make use of this feature, create a camera and disable it. Then call Render on it. You are not able to call the Render function from a camera that is currently rendering. If you wish to do this create a copy of the camera, and make it match the original one using CopyFrom. See Also: RenderWithShader.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.RenderToCubemap(UnityEngine.Cubemap)
member.summary: Render into a static cubemap from this camera.Render into a cubemap from this camera.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.RenderToCubemap(UnityEngine.RenderTexture)
member.summary: Render into a static cubemap from this camera.Render into a cubemap from this camera.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.RenderToCubemap(UnityEngine.Cubemap,System.Int32)
member.summary: Render into a static cubemap from this camera.Render into a cubemap from this camera.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.RenderToCubemap(UnityEngine.RenderTexture,System.Int32)
member.summary: Render into a static cubemap from this camera.Render into a cubemap from this camera.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.RenderWithShader(UnityEngine.Shader,System.String)
member.summary: Render the camera with shader replacement.
member.remarks: See Rendering with Replaced Shaders page for details. This will render the camera. It will use the camera's clear flags, target texture and all other settings. The camera will not send OnPreCull, OnPreRender or OnPostRender to attached scripts. Image filters will not be rendered either. This is used for special effects, e.g. rendering screenspace normal buffer of the whole scene, heat vision and so on. To make use of this feature, usually you create a camera and disable it. Then call RenderWithShader on it. You are not able to call the Render function from a camera that is currently rendering. If you wish to do this create a copy of the camera, and make it match the original one using CopyFrom. See Also: Rendering with Replaced Shaders, SetReplacementShader, Render.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.ResetAspect
member.summary: Revert the aspect ratio to the screen's aspect ratio.
member.remarks: Call this to end the effect of setting aspect.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.ResetProjectionMatrix
member.summary: Make the projection reflect normal camera's parameters.
member.remarks: Call this to end the effect of setting projectionMatrix.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.ResetReplacementShader
member.remarks: Call this to end the effect of setting SetReplacementShader.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.ResetWorldToCameraMatrix
member.summary: Make the rendering position reflect the camera's position in the scene.
member.remarks: Call this to end the effect of setting worldToCameraMatrix.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.ScreenPointToRay(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns a ray going from camera through a screen point.
member.remarks: Resulting ray is in world space, starting on the near plane of the camera and going through position's (x,y) pixel coordinates on the screen (position.z is ignored). Screenspace is defined in pixels. The bottom-left of the screen is (0,0); the right-top is ( pixelWidth, pixelHeight ).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.ScreenToViewportPoint(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Transforms position from screen space into viewport space.
member.remarks: Screenspace is defined in pixels. The bottom-left of the screen is (0,0); the right-top is ( pixelWidth, pixelHeight ). The z position is in world units from the camera. Viewport space is normalized and relative to the camera. The bottom-left of the camera is (0,0); the top-right is (1,1). The z position is in world units from the camera.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.ScreenToWorldPoint(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Transforms position from screen space into world space.
member.remarks: Screenspace is defined in pixels. The bottom-left of the screen is (0,0); the right-top is ( pixelWidth, pixelHeight ). The z position is in world units from the camera.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.SetReplacementShader(UnityEngine.Shader,System.String)
member.summary: Make the camera render with shader replacement.
member.remarks: See Rendering with Replaced Shaders page for details. After calling this function, camera will render its view with shader replacement. Call ResetReplacementShader to reset it back to normal rendering. See Also: Rendering with Replaced Shaders, ResetReplacementShader, RenderWithShader.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.SetTargetBuffers(UnityEngine.RenderBuffer,UnityEngine.RenderBuffer)
member.summary: Sets the Camera to render to the chosen buffers of one or more RenderTextures.
member.param: The RenderBuffer to which color information will be rendered.
The RenderBuffer to which depth information will be rendered.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.SetTargetBuffers(UnityEngine.RenderBuffer[],UnityEngine.RenderBuffer)
member.summary: Sets the Camera to render to the chosen buffers of one or more RenderTextures.
member.param: The RenderBuffer to which color information will be rendered.
The RenderBuffer to which depth information will be rendered.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.transparencySortMode
member.remarks: By default, perspective cameras sort objects based on distance from camera position to the object center; and orthographic cameras sort based on distance along the view direction. If you're making a 2D game with a perspective camera, you might want to use TransparencySortMode.Orthographic sort mode so that objects are sorted based on distance along the camera's view.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.useOcclusionCulling
member.summary: Whether or not the Camera will use occlusion culling during rendering.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.velocity
member.summary: Get the world-space speed of the camera (Read Only).
member.remarks: This camera's motion in units per second as it was during the last frame.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.ViewportPointToRay(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns a ray going from camera through a viewport point.
member.remarks: Resulting ray is in world space, starting on the near plane of the camera and going through position's (x,y) coordinates on the viewport (position.z is ignored). Viewport coordinates are normalized and relative to the camera. The bottom-left of the camera is (0,0); the top-right is (1,1).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.ViewportToScreenPoint(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Transforms position from viewport space into screen space.
member.remarks: Viewport space is normalized and relative to the camera. The bottom-left of the camera is (0,0); the top-right is (1,1). The z position is in world units from the camera. Screenspace is defined in pixels. The bottom-left of the screen is (0,0); the right-top is ( pixelWidth, pixelHeight ). The z position is in world units from the camera.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.ViewportToWorldPoint(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Transforms position from viewport space into world space.
member.remarks: Viewport space is normalized and relative to the camera. The bottom-left of the camera is (0,0); the top-right is (1,1). The z position is in world units from the camera. Note that it transforms a x-y screen position, into a x-y-z position in 3D space. You provide the function with a vector where the x-y components of the vector are the screen coordinates and the z component is the distance of the resulting plane from the camera.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Camera.worldToCameraMatrix
member.summary: Matrix that transforms from world to camera space.
member.remarks: Use this to calculate the camera space position of objects or to provide custom camera's location that is not based on the transform. Note that camera space matches OpenGL convention: camera's forward is the negative Z axis. This is different from Unity's convention, where forward is the positive Z axis. If you change this matrix, the camera no longer updates its rendering based on its Transform. This lasts until you call ResetWorldToCameraMatrix.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.WorldToScreenPoint(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Transforms position from world space into screen space.
member.remarks: Screenspace is defined in pixels. The bottom-left of the screen is (0,0); the right-top is ( pixelWidth, pixelHeight ). The z position is in world units from the camera.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Camera.WorldToViewportPoint(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Transforms position from world space into viewport space.
member.remarks: Viewport space is normalized and relative to the camera. The bottom-left of the camera is (0,0); the top-right is (1,1). The z position is in world units from the camera.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CameraClearFlags
member.summary: Values for Camera.clearFlags, determining what to clear when rendering a Camera.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CameraClearFlags.Depth
member.remarks: This will leave colors from the previous frame or whatever was displayed before. See Also: Camera.clearFlags property, camera component.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CameraClearFlags.Nothing
member.remarks: This will leave colors and depth buffer from the previous frame or whatever was displayed before. See Also: Camera.clearFlags property, camera component.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CameraClearFlags.Skybox
member.remarks: If a skybox is not set up, the Camera will clear with a backgroundColor. See Also: Camera.clearFlags property, camera component, Render Settings.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CameraClearFlags.SolidColor
member.remarks: See Also: Camera.clearFlags property, camera component, Camera.backgroundColor property.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CapsuleCollider
member.remarks: Capsules are cylinders with a half-sphere at each end. See Also: BoxCollider, SphereCollider, PhysicMaterial, Rigidbody.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CapsuleCollider.center
member.summary: The center of the capsule, measured in the object's local space.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CapsuleCollider.direction
member.remarks: 0 -> Capsule height is along the x-axis. 1 -> Capsule height is along the y-axis. 2 -> Capsule height is along the z-axis.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CapsuleCollider.height
member.summary: The height of the capsule meased in the object's local space.
member.remarks: The capsule's height will be scaled by the transform's scale. Note that the height is the actual height including the half-spheres at each end.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CapsuleCollider.radius
member.summary: The radius of the sphere, measured in the object's local space.
member.remarks: The capsule's radius will be scaled by the transform's scale.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CharacterController
member.summary: A CharacterController allows you to easily do movement constrained by collisions without having to deal with a rigidbody.
member.remarks: A CharacterController is not affected by forces and will only move when you call the Move funtion. It will then carry out the movement but be constrained by collisions. See Also: Character Controller component and Character animation examples

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterController.center
member.summary: The center of the character's capsule relative to the transform's position.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterController.collisionFlags
member.summary: What part of the capsule collided with the environment during the last CharacterController.Move call.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterController.detectCollisions
member.summary: Determines whether other rigidbodies or character controllers collide with this character controller (by default this is always enabled).
member.remarks: This method does not affect collisions detected during the character controller's movement but rather decides whether an incoming collider will be blocked by the controller's collider. For example, a box collider in the scene will block the movement of the controller, but the box may still fall through the controller if detectCollisions is false. This property is useful to disable the character controller temporarily. For example, you might want to mount a character into a car and disable collision detection until it exits the car again.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterController.height
member.summary: The height of the character's capsule.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterController.isGrounded
member.summary: Was the CharacterController touching the ground during the last move?

member.name: M:UnityEngine.CharacterController.Move(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: A more complex move function taking absolute movement deltas.
member.remarks: Attempts to move the controller by motion, the motion will only be constrained by collisions. It will slide along colliders. CollisionFlags is the summary of collisions that occurred during the Move. This function does not apply any gravity.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterController.radius
member.summary: The radius of the character's capsule.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.CharacterController.SimpleMove(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.remarks: Velocity along the y-axis is ignored. Speed is in meters/s. Gravity is automatically applied. Returns if the character is grounded. It is recommended that you make only one call to Move or SimpleMove per frame.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterController.slopeLimit
member.summary: The character controllers slope limit in degrees.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterController.stepOffset
member.summary: The character controllers step offset in meters.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterController.velocity
member.summary: The current relative velocity of the Character (see notes).
member.remarks: This allows you to track how fast the character is actually walking for example when he is stuck at a wall this value will be the zero vector. Note: The velocity returned is simply the difference in distance for the current timestep before and after a call to CharacterController.Move or CharacterController.SimpleMove. The velocity is relative because it won't track movements to the transform that happen outside of the CharacterController (e.g. character parented under another moving Transform, such as a moving vehicle).

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CharacterInfo
member.summary: Info how to render a character from the font texture. See /Font.characterInfo/.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CharacterInfo.flipped
member.remarks: Unity may flip the U and V coordinates of characters in font textures it generates to make more efficient use of texture space.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CharacterInfo.size
member.summary: The size of the character or 0 if it is the default font size.
member.remarks: Only used with characters generated at runtime for dynamic fonts).

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CharacterInfo.style
member.remarks: Only used with characters generated at runtime for dynamic fonts).

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CharacterInfo.uv
member.summary: UV coordinates for the character in the texture.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CharacterInfo.vert
member.summary: Screen coordinates for the character in generated text meshes.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CharacterInfo.width
member.summary: How for to advance between the beginning of this charcater and the next.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CharacterJoint
member.summary: Character Joints are mainly used for Ragdoll effects. They are an extended ball-socket joint which allows you to limit the joint on each axis.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterJoint.highTwistLimit
member.summary: The upper limit around the primary axis of the character joint.
member.remarks: The limit is relative to the angle the two rigidbodies started the simulation out with.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterJoint.lowTwistLimit
member.summary: The lower limit around the primary axis of the character joint.
member.remarks: The limit is relative to the angle the two rigidbodies started the simulation out with.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterJoint.swing1Limit
member.summary: The limit around the primary axis of the character joint.
member.remarks: The limit is symmetric. Thus a value of eg. 30 will limit the rotation between -30 and 30. The limit is relative to the angle the two rigidbodies started the simulation out with.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterJoint.swing2Limit
member.summary: The limit around the primary axis of the character joint.
member.remarks: The limit is symmetric. Thus a value of eg. 30 will limit the rotation between -30 and 30. The limit is relative to the angle the two rigidbodies started the simulation out with.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CharacterJoint.swingAxis
member.summary: The secondary axis around which the joint can rotate.
member.remarks: CharacterJoint.swing1Limit are the limits of the rotation allowed around this axis.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CircleCollider2D
member.summary: Collider for 2D physics representing an circle.
member.remarks: See Also: BoxCollider class, PolygonCollider2D class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CircleCollider2D.center
member.summary: Center point of the circle in local space.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Cloth
member.summary: Base class used to simulate cloth physics - shared by both InteractiveCloth and SkinnedCloth.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cloth.bendingStiffness
member.remarks: Must be between zero and one. Setting the value to zero disables bending stiffness simulation. In many cases, when you want a cloth to be more stiff, actually reducing the number of vertices will get you better results - and performance.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cloth.damping
member.remarks: Set this to damp the motions of a cloth instance. Must be between zero and one. Setting this to zero will disable cloth damping.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cloth.enabled
member.remarks: This is the same as the checkbox next to the component label in the inspector. A disabled cloth component will not update it's physics simulation, so you can use this to suspend the simulation of cloth objects when they are not needed, as cloth simulation is a very CPU-intensive task.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cloth.externalAcceleration
member.summary: A constant, external acceleration applied to the cloth.
member.remarks: Use this to simulate constant forces on the cloth, such as wind waving a flag. See Also: Cloth.randomAcceleration, InteractiveCloth.AddForceAtPosition.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cloth.normals
member.summary: The current normals of the cloth object.
member.remarks: This gives you read access to the normals of the cloth object, so you can analyse it's current simulation state. Note that the normal indices may not necessarily correspond to the indices of the source mesh - especially when triangle stripping or UV seams are used in the source mesh (ie, multiple indices for the same vertex), cloth vertices will be different, as the cloth simulation only uses a single index for each vertex.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cloth.randomAcceleration
member.summary: A random, external acceleration applied to the cloth.
member.remarks: Use this to simulate randomly changing forces on the cloth, such as wind turbulences waving a flag. See Also: Cloth.externalAcceleration, InteractiveCloth.AddForceAtPosition.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cloth.selfCollision
member.summary: Will the cloth collide with itself?
member.remarks: Enable this only where needed, as it has a big impact on cloth performance.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cloth.stretchingStiffness
member.remarks: Must be greater than zero and smaller or equal to one. In many cases, when you want a cloth to be more stiff, actually reducing the number of vertices will get you better results - and performance.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cloth.thickness
member.summary: The thickness of the cloth surface.
member.remarks: This is the distance kept between any cloth vertex and and other collider (or other cloth vertex if self-collision is enabled). Any object closer then this distance will collide with the cloth. If this value is too low, you may see the edges of objects intersecting the cloth surface. If this value is too high, you may see noticable distance between the cloth surface and colliding objects or stiffness in cloth motion if self-collision is enabled. Must be larger then zero.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cloth.useGravity
member.summary: Should gravity affect the cloth simulation?

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cloth.vertices
member.summary: The current vertex positions of the cloth object.
member.remarks: This gives you read access to the vertex positions of the cloth object, so you can analyse it's current simulation state. Note that the vertex indices may not necessarily correspond to the indices of the source mesh - especially when triangle stripping or UV seams are used in the source mesh (ie, multiple indices for the same vertex), cloth vertices will be different, as the cloth simulation only uses a single index for each vertex.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ClothRenderer
member.summary: The ClothRenderer component is used together with the InteractiveCloth component, to visualize a cloth object in the scene.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ClothRenderer.pauseWhenNotVisible
member.summary: Pause the cloth simulation, when the ClothRenderer is not currently visible.
member.remarks: If this is enable, the cloth will only be simulated, while the cloth is visible to any camera. This can improve performance of the physics simulation.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ClothSkinningCoefficient
member.summary: The ClothSkinningCoefficient struct is used to set up how a SkinnedCloth component is allowed to move with respect to the SkinnedMeshRenderer it is attached to.
member.remarks: This is set using the SkinnedCloth.coefficients property on the SkinnedCloth component, which is a per-vertex array of ClothSkinningCoefficient structs. Typically, you will not set these values from code, but instead, set them up in the editor which shows up when you look at the SkinnedCloth component in the inspector.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ClothSkinningCoefficient.collisionSphereDistance
member.summary: Definition of a sphere a vertex is not allowed to enter. This allows collision against the animated cloth.
member.remarks: The pair (collisionSphereRadius, collisionSphereDistance) define a sphere for each cloth vertex. The sphere's center is located at the position constrainPosition - constrainNormal * (collisionSphereRadius + collisionSphereDistance) and its radius is collisionSphereRadius, where constrainPosition and constrainNormal are the vertex positions and normals generated by the SkinnedMeshRenderer. The SkinnedCloth makes sure that the cloth vertex does not enter this sphere. As a typical usecase, set collisionSphereDistance to zero and collisionSphereRadius to a large value w.r.t. the triangle size. In this setup, the cloth collides against the skinned mesh. Default: 0.0 Range: [0,inf).

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ClothSkinningCoefficient.collisionSphereRadius
member.summary: Definition of a sphere a vertex is not allowed to enter. This allows collision against the animated cloth.
member.remarks: The pair (collisionSphereRadius, collisionSphereDistance) define a sphere for each cloth vertex. The sphere's center is located at the position constrainPosition - constrainNormal * (collisionSphereRadius + collisionSphereDistance) and its radius is collisionSphereRadius, where constrainPosition and constrainNormal are the vertex positions and normals generated by the SkinnedMeshRenderer. The SkinnedCloth makes sure that the cloth vertex does not enter this sphere. As a typical usecase, set collisionSphereDistance to zero and collisionSphereRadius to a large value w.r.t. the triangle size. In this setup, the cloth collides against the skinned mesh. Default: 0.5 Range: [0,inf).

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ClothSkinningCoefficient.maxDistance
member.summary: Distance a vertex is allowed to travel from the skinned mesh vertex position.
member.remarks: The SkinnedCloth component makes sure that the cloth vertices stay within maxDistance from the skinned mesh vertex positions. If maxDistance is zero, the vertex is not simulated but set to the skinned mesh vertex position. This behavior is useful for attaching the cloth vertex to the skin of an animated character. Default: 0.2 Range: [0, inf).

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ClothSkinningCoefficient.maxDistanceBias
member.summary: Distorts the sphere defined by the maxDistance based on skinned mesh normals.
member.remarks: The feature is disabled for a value of 0.0 (default). In this case the max distance sphere is undistorted. Decreasing the maxDistanceBias towards -1.0 reduces the distance the vertex is allowed to travel in the tangential direction. For -1.0 the vertex has to stay on the normal through the skinned mesh vertex position and within maxDistance to the skinned mesh vertex position. Increasing maxDistanceBias towards 1.0 reduces the discance the vertex is allowed to travel in the normal direction. At 1.0 the vertex can only move inside the tangental plane within maxDistance from the skinned mesh vertex position. Default: 0.0 Range: [-1.0, 1.0].

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Collider
member.summary: A base class of all colliders.
member.remarks: See Also: BoxCollider, SphereCollider, CapsuleCollider, MeshCollider, PhysicMaterial, Rigidbody. If the object with the Collider needs to be moved during gameplay then you should also attach a Rigidbody component to the object. The Rigidbody can be set to be kinematic if you don't want the object to have physical interaction with other objects.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collider.attachedRigidbody
member.summary: The rigidbody the collider is attached to.
member.remarks: Returns null if the collider is attached to no rigidbody. Colliders are automatically connected to the rigidbody attached to the same GameObject or attached to any parent GameObject.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collider.bounds
member.summary: The world space bounding volume of the collider.
member.remarks: Note that this will be an empty bounding box if the collider is disabled or the GameObject is inactive.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Collider.ClosestPointOnBounds(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: The closest point to the bounding box of the attached collider.
member.remarks: This can be used to calculate hit points when applying explosion damage.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collider.enabled
member.summary: Enabled Colliders will collide with other colliders, disabled Colliders won't.
member.remarks: This is shown as the small checkbox in the inspector of the Colliders.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collider.isTrigger
member.remarks: A trigger doesn't collide with rigid bodies. Instead it sends OnTriggerEnter, OnTriggerExit and OnTriggerStay message when a rigidbody enters or exits the trigger.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collider.material
member.summary: The material used by the collider.
member.remarks: If material is shared by colliders, it will duplicate the material and assign it to the collider.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Collider.Raycast(UnityEngine.Ray,UnityEngine.RaycastHit@,System.Single)
member.summary: Casts a Ray that ignores all Colliders except this one.
member.returns: True when the ray intersects any collider, otherwise false.
member.remarks: Same as above using /ray.origin/ and /ray.direction/ instead of origin and direction.
member.example: // pragma below is needed due to a UnityJS issue #pragma strict function Update(){ var ray : Ray = Camera.main.ScreenPointToRay (Input.mousePosition); var hit : RaycastHit; if (collider.Raycast (ray, hit, 100.0)) { Debug.DrawLine (ray.origin, hit.point); } }
member.param: The starting point and direction of the ray.
If true is returned, hitInfo will contain more information about where the collider was hit (See Also: RaycastHit).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collider.sharedMaterial
member.summary: The shared physic material of this collider.
member.remarks: Modifying this material will change the surface properties of all colliders using the material. In most cases you want to modify Collider.material instead.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Collider2D
member.summary: Parent class for collider types used with 2D gameplay.
member.remarks: See Also: BoxCollider2D class, CircleCollider2D class, PolygonCollider2D class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collider2D.attachedRigidbody
member.summary: The Rigidbody2D attached to the Collider2D's GameObject.
member.remarks: This property will be null if no Rigidbody2D is attached. See Also: Rigidbody2D::ref::

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collider2D.isTrigger
member.summary: Is this collider configured as a trigger?

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Collider2D.OverlapPoint(UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Check if a collider overlaps a point in space.
member.remarks: This will always return false when used on a EdgeCollider2D.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collider2D.shapeCount
member.summary: The number of separate shaped regions in the collider.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collider2D.sharedMaterial
member.summary: The PhysicsMaterial2D that is applied to this collider.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Collision
member.remarks: Collision information is passed to Collider.OnCollisionEnter, Collider.OnCollisionStay and Collider.OnCollisionExit events. See Also: ContactPoint.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision.collider
member.remarks: To find all colliders that were hit in detail you have to iterate the contact points ( contacts property).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision.contacts
member.summary: The contact points generated by the physics engine.
member.remarks: Every contact contains a contact point, normal and the two colliders that collided (see ContactPoint ). From inside OnCollisionStay or OnCollisionEnter you can always be sure that contacts has at least one element.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision.gameObject
member.summary: The GameObject whose collider we are colliding with. (Read Only).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision.relativeVelocity
member.summary: The relative linear velocity of the two colliding objects (Read Only).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision.rigidbody
member.summary: The Rigidbody we hit (Read Only). This is null if the object we hit is a collider with no rigidbody attached.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision.transform
member.summary: The Transform of the object we hit (Read Only).
member.remarks: If we collided against a collider with a Rigidbody, the transform will be the transform attached to the rigidbody. If we collided against a collider without a rigidbody, the transform will be the transform attached to the collider.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Collision2D
member.summary: Information returned by a collision in 2D physics.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision2D.collider
member.summary: The incoming Collider2D involved in the collision.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision2D.contacts
member.summary: The specific points of contact with the incoming Collider2D.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision2D.gameObject
member.summary: The incoming GameObject involved in the collision.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision2D.relativeVelocity
member.summary: The relative linear velocity of the two colliding objects (Read Only).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision2D.rigidbody
member.summary: The incoming Rigidbody2D involved in the collision.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Collision2D.transform
member.summary: The Transform of the incoming object involved in the collision.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CollisionDetectionMode
member.summary: The collision detection mode constants used for Rigidbody.collisionDetectionMode.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CollisionDetectionMode.Continuous
member.summary: Continuous collision detection is on for colliding with static mesh geometry.
member.remarks: Collisions will be detected for any static mesh geometry in the path of this Rigidbody, even if the collision occurs between two FixedUpdate steps. Static mesh geometry is any MeshCollider which does not have a Rigidbody attached. This also prevent Rigidbodies set to ContinuousDynamic mode from passing through this Rigidbody.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CollisionDetectionMode.ContinuousDynamic
member.summary: Continuous collision detection is on for colliding with static and dynamic geometry.
member.remarks: Prevent this Rigidbody from passing through static mesh geometry, and through other Rigidbodies which have continuous collision detection enabled, when it is moving fast. This is the slowest collision detection mode, and should only be used for selected fast moving objects.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CollisionDetectionMode.Discrete
member.summary: Continuous collision detection is off for this Rigidbody.
member.remarks: This is the default collision detection mode, and it is the fastest mode. Collisions for this collider will only be checked at the content's Time.fixedDeltaTime.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CollisionDetectionMode2D
member.summary: Options for the detection mode used by a Rigidbody2D.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CollisionDetectionMode2D.Continuous
member.summary: The Rigidbody2D estimates its position between physics updates.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CollisionDetectionMode2D.None
member.summary: No collision detection is used on the Rigidbody2D.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CollisionFlags
member.summary: CollisionFlags is a bitmask returned by CharacterController.Move.
member.remarks: It gives you a broad overview of where your character collided with any other objects.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CollisionFlags.Above
member.summary: CollisionFlags is a bitmask returned by CharacterController.Move.
member.remarks: It gives you a broad overview of where your character collided with any other objects.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CollisionFlags.Below
member.summary: CollisionFlags is a bitmask returned by CharacterController.Move.
member.remarks: It gives you a broad overview of where your character collided with any other objects.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CollisionFlags.None
member.summary: CollisionFlags is a bitmask returned by CharacterController.Move.
member.remarks: It gives you a broad overview of where your character collided with any other objects.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CollisionFlags.Sides
member.summary: CollisionFlags is a bitmask returned by CharacterController.Move.
member.remarks: It gives you a broad overview of where your character collided with any other objects.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Color
member.remarks: This structure is used throughout Unity to pass colors around. Each color component is a floating point value with a range from 0 to 1. Components ( r, g, b ) define a color in RGB color space. Alpha component ( a ) defines transparency - alpha of one is completely opaque, alpha of zero is completely transparent.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Color.gamma
member.summary: A version of the color that has had the gamma curve applied.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Color.grayscale
member.summary: The grayscale value of the color. (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Color.grey
member.summary: English spelling for gray. RGBA is the same (0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Color.Lerp(UnityEngine.Color,UnityEngine.Color,System.Single)
member.summary: Interpolates between colors a and b by t.
member.remarks: t is clamped between 0 and 1. When t is 0 returns a. When t is 1 returns b.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Color.linear
member.summary: A version of the color that has had the inverse gamma curve applied.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Color.ToString
member.summary: Returns a nicely formatted string of this color.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Color.ToString(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a nicely formatted string of this color.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Color.yellow
member.summary: Yellow. RGBA is (1, 0.92, 0.016, 1), but the color is nice to look at!

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Color32
member.summary: Representation of RGBA colors in 32 bit format.
member.remarks: Each color component is a byte value with a range from 0 to 255. Components ( r, g, b ) define a color in RGB color space. Alpha component ( a ) defines transparency - alpha of 255 is completely opaque, alpha of zero is completely transparent.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Color32.Lerp(UnityEngine.Color32,UnityEngine.Color32,System.Single)
member.summary: Interpolates between colors a and b by t.
member.remarks: t is clamped between 0 and 1. When t is 0 returns a. When t is 1 returns b.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Color32.ToString
member.summary: Returns a nicely formatted string of this color.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Color32.ToString(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a nicely formatted string of this color.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ColorSpace.Gamma
member.summary: Lightmap has been baked for gamma rendering.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ColorSpace.Linear
member.summary: Lightmap has been baked for linear rendering.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CombineInstance
member.summary: Struct used to describe meshes to be combined using Mesh.CombineMeshes.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CombineInstance.transform
member.summary: Matrix to transform the mesh with before combining.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Compass.enabled
member.summary: Used to enable or disable compass. Note, that if you want Input.compass.trueHeading property to contain a valid value, you must also enable location updates by calling Input.location.Start().

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Compass.magneticHeading
member.summary: The heading in degrees relative to the magnetic North Pole. (Read Only)
member.remarks: The value in this property is always measured relative to the top of the screen in its current orientation. The heading of magnetic north is not exactly the same as true geographical north - to get the exact heading, use the trueHeading property.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Compass.rawVector
member.summary: The raw geomagnetic data measured in microteslas. (Read Only)
member.remarks: The compass is actually a magnetometer that measures the magnetic field in the device's XYZ coordinates - in the absence of a stronger magnet, it will measure the Earth's field from which the compass heading can be found. This property can be used if you want to make non-standard use of the compass (eg, find the heading from the X or Z axis of the device).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Compass.timestamp
member.summary: Timestamp (in seconds since 1970) when the heading was last time updated. (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Compass.trueHeading
member.summary: The heading in degrees relative to the geographic North Pole. (Read Only)
member.remarks: The value in this property is always measured relative to the top of the screen in its current orientation. Note, that if you want this property to contain a valid value, you must also enable location updates by calling Input.location.Start(). (Read Only)

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Component
member.summary: Base class for everything attached to GameObjects.
member.remarks: Note that your code will never directly create a Component. Instead, you write script code, and attach the script to a GameObject. See Also: ScriptableObject as a way to create scripts that do not attach to any GameObject.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Component.animation
member.summary: The Animation attached to this GameObject (null if there is none attached).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Component.audio

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Component.BroadcastMessage(System.String)
member.summary: Calls the method named methodName on every MonoBehaviour in this GameObject or any of its children.
member.remarks: The receiving method can choose to ignore parameter by having zero arguments. if options is set to SendMessageOptions.RequireReceiver an error is printed when the message is not picked up by any component.
member.param: Name of the method to call.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Component.BroadcastMessage(System.String,System.Object)

member.remarks: The receiving method can choose to ignore parameter by having zero arguments. if options is set to SendMessageOptions.RequireReceiver an error is printed when the message is not picked up by any component.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Component.SendMessage(System.String)

member.remarks: The receiving method can choose to ignore the argument by having zero arguments. if options is set to SendMessageOptions.RequireReceiver an error is printed when the message is not picked up by any component. Note that messages will not be sent to inactive objects (ie, those that have been deactivated in the editor or with the GameObject.SetActive function).
