member.name: T:UnityEngine.ComputeBuffer
member.summary: Data buffer to hold data for compute shaders.
member.remarks: ComputeShader programs often need arbitrary data to be read & written into memory buffers. ComputeBuffer class is exactly for that - you can create & fill them from script code, and use them in compute shaders or regular shaders. Compute shaders need a fairly modern GPU and are only available when using DirectX 11 right now. On shader side, ComputeBuffers map to StructuredBuffer and RWStructuredBuffer in HLSL. See Also: SystemInfo.supportsComputeShaders, ComputeShader class, Shader.SetGlobalBuffer, Material.SetBuffer, Compute Shaders.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ComputeBuffer.CopyCount(UnityEngine.ComputeBuffer,UnityEngine.ComputeBuffer,System.Int32)
member.remarks: Compute buffer data can be filled from an aribrary array of value types (simple types like ints or floats; or struct types like Vector3 or Color). Read buffer data. Reads buffer data into an aribrary array of value types (simple types like ints or floats; or struct types like Vector3 or Color). Note that reading data back from the buffer can be quite slow, as the CPU will have to wait for GPU to finish any pending operations and read the data back to system memory. Copy counter value of append/consume buffer into another buffer. CopyCount takes an append or consume buffer as src, and copies its "counter" value into dst buffer at given byte offset. This is most commonly used in conjunction with Graphics.DrawProceduralIndirect, to render arbitrary number of primitives without reading their count back to the CPU.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ComputeBuffer.count
member.summary: Number of elements in the buffer (Read Only).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ComputeBuffer.GetData(System.Array)
member.summary: Read data values from the buffer into an array.
member.param: An array to receive the data.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ComputeBuffer.SetData(System.Array)
member.summary: Set the buffer with values from an array.
member.param: Array of values to fill the buffer.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ComputeBuffer.stride
member.summary: Size of one element in the buffer (Read Only).

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ComputeBufferType.Append
member.remarks: Allows a buffer to be treated like a stack in compute shaders.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ComputeBufferType.Default
member.remarks: A simple structured buffer in DX11.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ComputeBufferType.Raw
member.remarks: Buffer that allows raw unstructured access; underlying DX11 format is typeless R32.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ComputeShader
member.remarks: Compute shaders are programs that run on the GPU outside of the normal rendering pipeline. They correspond to compute shader assets in the project (.compute files). Compute shaders need a fairly modern GPU and are only available when using DirectX 11 right now. See Also: SystemInfo.supportsComputeShaders, ComputeBuffer class, Compute Shaders.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ComputeShader.Dispatch(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.remarks: This functions "runs" the compute shader, with the given work size as indicated by threadsX, threadsY, threadsZ parameters. See Also: FindKernel, Compute Shaders.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ComputeShader.FindKernel(System.String)
member.remarks: A single compute shader can contain many "kernels" (functions that do the computation); FindKernel returns kernel index given the name. If name is not found, -1 is returned.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ComputeShader.SetBuffer(System.Int32,System.String,UnityEngine.ComputeBuffer)
member.summary: This function can either set an input or output compute buffer.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ComputeShader.SetFloats(System.String,System.Single[])
member.summary: Set multiple consecutive float parameters at once.
member.remarks: This function can be used to set float vector, float array or float vector array values. For example, float4 myArray[4] in the compute shader can be filled by passing 16 floats.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ComputeShader.SetInts(System.String,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Set multiple consecutive integer parameters at once.
member.remarks: This function can be used to set int vector, int array or int vector array values. For example, int4 myArray[4] in the compute shader can be filled by passing 16 integers.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ComputeShader.SetTexture(System.Int32,System.String,UnityEngine.Texture)
member.remarks: This function can either set a regular texture that is read in the compute shader, or an output texture that is written into by the shader. For an output texture, it has to be a RenderTexture with random write flag enabled, see RenderTexture.enableRandomWrite. See Also: FindKernel, RenderTexture.enableRandomWrite.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint
member.summary: The configurable joint is an extremely flexible joint giving you complete control over rotation and linear motion.
member.remarks: You can build all other joints with it and much more but it is also more complicated to setup. It gives you control over motors, drives and joint limits for each rotation axis and and linear degree of freedom.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.angularXDrive
member.summary: Definition of how the joint's rotation will behave around its local X axis. Only used if Rotation Drive Mode is Swing & Twist.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.angularXMotion
member.summary: Allow rotation around the X axis to be Free, completely Locked, or Limited according to Low and High Angular XLimit.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.angularYLimit
member.summary: Boundary defining rotation restriction, based on delta from original rotation.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.angularYMotion
member.summary: Allow rotation around the Y axis to be Free, completely Locked, or Limited according to Angular YLimit.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.angularYZDrive
member.summary: Definition of how the joint's rotation will behave around its local Y and Z axes. Only used if Rotation Drive Mode is Swing & Twist.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.angularZLimit
member.summary: Boundary defining rotation restriction, based on delta from original rotation.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.angularZMotion
member.summary: Allow rotation around the Z axis to be Free, completely Locked, or Limited according to Angular ZLimit.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.configuredInWorldSpace
member.summary: If enabled, all Target values will be calculated in world space instead of the object's local space.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.highAngularXLimit
member.summary: Boundary defining upper rotation restriction, based on delta from original rotation.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.linearLimit
member.summary: Boundary defining movement restriction, based on distance from the joint's origin.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.lowAngularXLimit
member.summary: Boundary defining lower rotation restriction, based on delta from original rotation.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.projectionAngle
member.summary: Difference in angle from the Connected Body that must be exceeded before the object snaps back to an acceptable position.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.projectionDistance
member.summary: Distance from the Connected Body that must be exceeded before the object snaps back to an acceptable position.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.projectionMode
member.summary: Properties to track to snap the object back to its constrained position when it drifts off too much.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.rotationDriveMode
member.summary: Control the object's rotation with either X & YZ or Slerp Drive by itself.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.secondaryAxis
member.remarks: Together, secondary and primary axes define the joint's coordinate space.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.slerpDrive
member.summary: Definition of how the joint's rotation will behave around all local axes. Only used if Rotation Drive Mode is Slerp Only.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.swapBodies
member.summary: If enabled, the two connected rigidbodies will be swapped, as if the joint was attached to the other body.
member.remarks: Prior to Unity 3.4, this was wrongfully applied to all ConfigurableJoints with the configuredInWorldSpace property set. If you want to restore the behaviour of older Unity versions and you are using configuredInWorldSpace, enable this property.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.targetAngularVelocity
member.summary: This is a Vector3. It defines the desired angular velocity that the joint should rotate into.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.targetPosition
member.summary: The desired position that the joint should move into.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.targetRotation
member.summary: This is a Quaternion. It defines the desired rotation that the joint should rotate into.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.targetVelocity
member.summary: The desired velocity that the joint should move along.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.xDrive
member.summary: Definition of how the joint's movement will behave along its local X axis.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.xMotion
member.summary: Allow movement along the X axis to be Free, completely Locked, or Limited according to Linear Limit.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.yDrive

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConfigurableJoint.yMotion

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ConstantForce
member.remarks: This is a small physics utility class used to apply a continous force to an object. Rigidbody.AddForce applies a force to the Rigidbody only for one frame, thus you have to keep calling the function. ConstantForce on the other hand will apply the force every frame until you change the force or torque to a new value. See Also: Rigidbody.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConstantForce.force
member.summary: The force applied to the rigidbody every frame.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConstantForce.relativeForce
member.summary: The force - relative to the rigid bodies coordinate system - applied every frame.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConstantForce.relativeTorque
member.summary: The torque - relative to the rigid bodies coordinate system - applied every frame.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ConstantForce.torque
member.summary: The torque applied to the rigidbody every frame.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ContactPoint
member.summary: Describes a contact point where the collision occurs.
member.remarks: Contact points are stored in Collision structure. See Also: Collision, Collider.OnCollisionEnter, Collider.OnCollisionStay, Collider.OnCollisionExit.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ContactPoint2D
member.summary: Details about a specific point of contact involved in a 2D physics collision.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ContactPoint2D.collider
member.summary: The collider attached to the object receiving the collision message.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ContactPoint2D.normal
member.summary: Surface normal at the contact point.
member.remarks: This is the normal vector (ie, the vector perpendicular to the surface) of the incoming Collider2D at the contact point. See Also: Collider2D class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ContactPoint2D.otherCollider
member.summary: The incoming collider involved in the collision at this contact point.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ContactPoint2D.point
member.summary: The point of contact between the two colliders in world space.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ContextMenu
member.summary: The ContextMenu attribute allows you to add commands to the context menu.
member.remarks: In the inspector of the attached script. When the user selects the context menu, the function will be executed. This is most useful for automatically setting up scene data from the script. The function has to be non-static.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ControllerColliderHit
member.summary: ControllerColliderHit is used by CharacterController.OnControllerColliderHit to give detailed information about the collision and how to deal with it.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ControllerColliderHit.collider
member.summary: The collider that was hit by the controller.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ControllerColliderHit.controller
member.summary: The controller that hit the collider.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ControllerColliderHit.gameObject
member.summary: The GameObject that was hit by the controller.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ControllerColliderHit.moveDirection
member.summary: Approximately the direction from the center of the capsule to the point we touch.
member.remarks: This can be used to find a reasonable direction to apply forces to touched rigidbodies.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ControllerColliderHit.moveLength
member.summary: How far the character has travelled until it hit the collider.
member.remarks: Note that this can is different from what you pass to CharacterController.Move, because all movement is constrained by collisions.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ControllerColliderHit.normal
member.summary: The normal of the surface we collided with in world space.
member.remarks: Note: When the CharacterController is colliding with an edge or a corner rather than a flat surface, the reported normal may be different when colliding with BoxColliders than when colliding with MeshColliders. This is due to a limitation in how PhysX handles Capsule/BoxCollider collisions.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ControllerColliderHit.point
member.summary: The impact point in world space.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ControllerColliderHit.rigidbody
member.summary: The rigidbody that was hit by the controller.
member.remarks: Null if we didn't touch a rigidbody but a static collider.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ControllerColliderHit.transform
member.summary: The transform that was hit by the controller.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Coroutine
member.summary: MonoBehaviour.StartCoroutine returns a Coroutine. Instances of this class are only used to reference these coroutines and do not hold any exposed properties or functions.
member.remarks: A coroutine is a function that can suspend its execution (yield) until the given given YieldInstruction finishes.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CrashReport
member.summary: Holds data for a single application crash event and provides access to all gathered crash reports.
member.remarks: If compiled with appropriate settings, Unity will try to gather useful information, like location and thread stack traces, when your application crashes. Upon the next application start, if the data gathering was successful, all crash information will be accessible using this API. To enable crash report generation open your generated Xcode project and edit trampoline file: Classes/CrashReporter.h. Change ENABLE_CUSTOM_CRASH_REPORTER define from 0 to 1. Note: this API currently is available only for iOS targets. CrashReport API requires Unity Pro license for target platform. See Also: CrashReport.reports.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CrashReport.lastReport
member.summary: Returns last crash report, or null if no reports are available.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.CrashReport.Remove
member.summary: Remove report from available reports list.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.CrashReport.RemoveAll
member.summary: Remove all reports from available reports list.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.CrashReport.reports
member.summary: Returns all currently available reports in a new array.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CrashReport.text
member.summary: Crash report data as formatted text.
member.remarks: NOTE: data provided and text format depends on the target platform.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Cubemap
member.summary: Class for handling cube maps, Use this to create or modify existing cube map assets.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cubemap.Apply
member.summary: Actually apply all previous SetPixel and SetPixels changes.
member.remarks: If updateMipmaps is true, the mipmap levels are recalculated as well, using the base level as a source. Usually you want to use true in all cases except when you've modified the mip levels yourself using SetPixels. This is a potentially expensive operation, so you'll want to change as many pixels as possible between Apply calls. See Also: SetPixel, SetPixels functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cubemap.Apply(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Actually apply all previous SetPixel and SetPixels changes.
member.remarks: If updateMipmaps is true, the mipmap levels are recalculated as well, using the base level as a source. Usually you want to use true in all cases except when you've modified the mip levels yourself using SetPixels. This is a potentially expensive operation, so you'll want to change as many pixels as possible between Apply calls. See Also: SetPixel, SetPixels functions.
member.param: Should all mipmap levels be updated?

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cubemap.Apply(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Actually apply all previous SetPixel and SetPixels changes.
member.remarks: If updateMipmaps is true, the mipmap levels are recalculated as well, using the base level as a source. Usually you want to use true in all cases except when you've modified the mip levels yourself using SetPixels. This is a potentially expensive operation, so you'll want to change as many pixels as possible between Apply calls. See Also: SetPixel, SetPixels functions.
member.param: Should all mipmap levels be updated?
Should the Cubemap texture data be readable/modifiable after changes are applied?

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Cubemap.format
member.summary: The format of the pixel data in the texture (Read Only).
member.remarks: Use this to determine the format of the texture.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cubemap.GetPixel(UnityEngine.CubemapFace,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns pixel color at coordinates (face, x, y).
member.remarks: If the pixel coordinates are out of bounds (larger than width/height or small than 0), they will be clamped or repeat based on the texture's wrap mode. The texture must have the Is Readable flag set in the import settings, otherwise this function will fail.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cubemap.GetPixels(UnityEngine.CubemapFace)
member.summary: Returns pixel colors of a cubemap face.
member.remarks: This function returns an array of pixel colors of the whole mip level of a cubemap face. The returned array is a flattened 2D array, where pixels are laid out right to left, top to bottom (i.e. row after row). Array size is width by height of the mip level used. The default mip level is zero (the base texture) in which case the size is just the size of the texture. In general case, mip level size is mipSize=max(1,width>>miplevel). The texture must have the Is Readable flag set in the import settings, otherwise this function will fail. Using GetPixels can be faster than calling GetPixel repeatedly, especially for large textures. In addition, GetPixels can access individual mipmap levels. See Also: SetPixels, mipmapCount.
member.param: The face from which pixel data is taken.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cubemap.GetPixels(UnityEngine.CubemapFace,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns pixel colors of a cubemap face.
member.remarks: This function returns an array of pixel colors of the whole mip level of a cubemap face. The returned array is a flattened 2D array, where pixels are laid out right to left, top to bottom (i.e. row after row). Array size is width by height of the mip level used. The default mip level is zero (the base texture) in which case the size is just the size of the texture. In general case, mip level size is mipSize=max(1,width>>miplevel). The texture must have the Is Readable flag set in the import settings, otherwise this function will fail. Using GetPixels can be faster than calling GetPixel repeatedly, especially for large textures. In addition, GetPixels can access individual mipmap levels. See Also: SetPixels, mipmapCount.
member.param: The face from which pixel data is taken.
Mipmap level for the chosen face.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cubemap.SetPixel(UnityEngine.CubemapFace,System.Int32,System.Int32,UnityEngine.Color)
member.summary: Sets pixel color at coordinates (face, x, y).
member.remarks: Call Apply to actually upload the changed pixels to the graphics card. Uploading is an expensive operation, so you'll want to change as many pixels as possible between Apply calls. This function works only on ARGB32, RGB24 and Alpha8 texture formats. For other formats SetPixel is ignored. See Also: Apply function.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cubemap.SetPixels(UnityEngine.Color[],UnityEngine.CubemapFace)
member.summary: Sets pixel colors of a cubemap face.
member.remarks: This function takes a color array and changes the pixel colors of the whole cubemap face. Call Apply to actually upload the changed pixels to the graphics card. The colors array is a flattened 2D array, where pixels are laid out right to left, top to bottom (i.e. row after row). Array size must be at least width by height of the mip level used. The default mip level is zero (the base texture) in which case the size is just the size of the texture. In general case, mip level size is mipSize=max(1,width>>miplevel). This function works only on ARGB32, RGB24 and Alpha8 texture formats. For other formats SetPixels is ignored. See Also: GetPixels, Apply, mipmapCount.
member.param: Pixel data for the Cubemap face.
The face to which the new data should be applied.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cubemap.SetPixels(UnityEngine.Color[],UnityEngine.CubemapFace,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets pixel colors of a cubemap face.
member.remarks: This function takes a color array and changes the pixel colors of the whole cubemap face. Call Apply to actually upload the changed pixels to the graphics card. The colors array is a flattened 2D array, where pixels are laid out right to left, top to bottom (i.e. row after row). Array size must be at least width by height of the mip level used. The default mip level is zero (the base texture) in which case the size is just the size of the texture. In general case, mip level size is mipSize=max(1,width>>miplevel). This function works only on ARGB32, RGB24 and Alpha8 texture formats. For other formats SetPixels is ignored. See Also: GetPixels, Apply, mipmapCount.
member.param: Pixel data for the Cubemap face.
The face to which the new data should be applied.
The mipmap level for the face.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cubemap.SmoothEdges
member.summary: Performs smoothing of near edge regions.
member.remarks: Helps to compensate lack of linear interpolation across the edges of cubemap in GPU. Usually you will want to call this function for the cubemap which is going to be used for glossy reflections.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cubemap.SmoothEdges(System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs smoothing of near edge regions.
member.remarks: Helps to compensate lack of linear interpolation across the edges of cubemap in GPU. Usually you will want to call this function for the cubemap which is going to be used for glossy reflections.
member.param: Pixel distance at edges over which to apply smoothing.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Cursor
member.summary: Cursor API for setting the cursor that is used for rendering.
member.remarks: Supports Hardware Cursors on OSX, Windows, Linux, and Flash falls back to software cursors on unsupported platforms. Textures used as cursors should be marked as such in their import settings. OSX Webplayer note: Due to sandboxing, Hardware Cursors can only be updated intermittently (when the cursor is moving) the best way to ensure correct behavior if to use OnMouseEnter and OnMouseExit to set the hardware cursors. This is not an issue for software cursors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Cursor.SetCursor(UnityEngine.Texture2D,UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.CursorMode)
member.summary: Change the mouse cursor to the set texture OnMouseEnter.Specify a custom cursor that you wish to use as a cursor.
member.param: The texture to use for the cursor.
The offset from the top left of the texture to use as the target point (must be within the bounds of the cursor).
Allow this cursor to render as a hardware cursor on supported platforms, or force software cursor.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.CursorMode
member.summary: How should the custom cursor be rendered.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CursorMode.Auto
member.summary: Use hardware cursors on supported platforms.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.CursorMode.ForceSoftware
member.summary: Force the use of software cursors.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Debug
member.summary: Class containing methods to ease debugging while developing a game.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Debug.Break
member.remarks: This is useful when you want to check certain values on the inspector and you are not able to pause it manually.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Debug.ClearDeveloperConsole
member.summary: Clears errors from the developer console.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Debug.DrawLine(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Draws a line between specified start and end points.
member.remarks: The line will be drawn in the scene view of the editor. If gizmo drawing is enabled in the game view, the line will also be drawn there. The duration is the time (in seconds) for which the line will be visible after it is first displayed. A duration of zero shows the line for just one frame. Note: This is for debugging playmode only. Editor gizmos should be drawn with Gizmos.Drawline or Handles.DrawLine instead.
member.param: Point in world space where the line should start.
Point in world space where the line should end.

Editor gizmos should be drawn with Gizmos.Drawline or Handles.DrawLine instead.
member.param: Point in world space where the line should start.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Debug.DrawRay(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Draws a line from start to start + dir in world coordinates.
member.remarks: The duration parameter determines how long the line will be visible after the frame it is drawn. If duration is 0 (the default) then the line is rendered 1 frame. If depthTest is set to true then the line will be obscured by other objects in the scene that are nearer to the camera. The line will be drawn in the scene view of the editor. If gizmo drawing is enabled in the game view, the line will also be drawn there.
member.param: Point in world space where the ray should start.
Direction and length of the ray.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Debug.isDebugBuild
member.summary: In the Build Settings dialog there is a check box called "Development Build".
member.remarks: If it is checked isDebugBuild will be true. In the editor isDebugBuild always returns true. It is recommended to remove all calls to Debug.Log when deploying a game, this way you can easily deploy beta builds with debug prints and final builds without.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Debug.Log(System.Object)
member.summary: Logs message to the Unity Console.
member.remarks: When you select the message in the console a connection to the context object will be drawn. This can be useful for locating the object on which an error occurs. When the message is a string, rich text markup can be used to add emphasis. See the manual page about rich text for details of the different markup tags available.
member.param: String or object to be converted to string representation for display.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.DepthTextureMode
member.summary: Depth texture generation mode for Camera.
member.remarks: The flags can be combined, so you can set a Camera to generate both a Depth and Depth+Normals texture if needed. See Also: Camera.depthTextureMode.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DepthTextureMode.Depth
member.remarks: Will generate a screen-space depth texture as seen from this camera. Texture will be in RenderTextureFormat.Depth format and will be set as _CameraDepthTexture global shader property. See Also: Camera.depthTextureMode.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DepthTextureMode.DepthNormals
member.remarks: Will generate a screen-space depth and view space normals texture as seen from this camera. Texture will be in RenderTextureFormat.ARGB32 format and will be set as _CameraDepthNormalsTexture global shader property. Depth and normals will be specially encoded, see Camera Depth Texture page for details. See Also: Camera.depthTextureMode.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.DetailPrototype
member.summary: Detail prototype used by the Terrain GameObject.
member.remarks: This can be grass, or a flower..

member.name: P:UnityEngine.DetailPrototype.maxHeight
member.summary: Maximum height of the grass billboards (if render mode is GrassBillboard).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.DetailPrototype.maxWidth
member.summary: Maximum width of the grass billboards (if render mode is GrassBillboard).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.DetailPrototype.minHeight
member.summary: Minimum height of the grass billboards (if render mode is GrassBillboard).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.DetailPrototype.minWidth
member.summary: Minimum width of the grass billboards (if render mode is GrassBillboard).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.DetailPrototype.noiseSpread
member.summary: How spread out is the noise for the DetailPrototype.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DetailRenderMode.Grass
member.summary: The detail prototype will use the grass shader.
member.remarks: When using custom meshes in this mode, control the wave amount by setting vertex color's alpha channel. Grass will take normals from terrain directly underneath it, so that the shading matches the terrain.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DetailRenderMode.GrassBillboard
member.summary: The detail prototype will be rendered as billboards that are always facing the camera.
member.remarks: Grass will take normals from terrain directly underneath it, so that the shading matches the terrain.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DetailRenderMode.VertexLit
member.summary: Will show the prototype using diffuse shading.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.DeviceOrientation
member.summary: Describes physical orientation of the device as determined by the OS.
member.remarks: If device is physically situated between discrete positions, as when (for example) rotated diagonally, system will report Unknown orientation.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DeviceOrientation.FaceDown
member.summary: The device is held parallel to the ground with the screen facing downwards.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DeviceOrientation.FaceUp
member.summary: The device is held parallel to the ground with the screen facing upwards.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DeviceOrientation.LandscapeLeft
member.summary: The device is in landscape mode, with the device held upright and the home button on the right side.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DeviceOrientation.LandscapeRight
member.summary: The device is in landscape mode, with the device held upright and the home button on the left side.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DeviceOrientation.Portrait
member.summary: The device is in portrait mode, with the device held upright and the home button at the bottom.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DeviceOrientation.PortraitUpsideDown
member.summary: The device is in portrait mode but upside down, with the device held upright and the home button at the top.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DeviceOrientation.Unknown
member.summary: The orientation of the device cannot be determined.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.DeviceType
member.summary: Enumeration for SystemInfo.deviceType, denotes a coarse grouping of kinds of devices.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DeviceType.Handheld
member.summary: A handheld device like mobile phone or a tablet.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.DeviceType.Unknown
member.summary: Device type is unknown. You should never see this in practice.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Display
member.summary: Provides access to a display / screen for rendering operations.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.Display.displays
member.summary: The list of currently connected Displays. Contains at least one (main) display.
member.remarks: It will be automatically updated should the display be connected/disconnected.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Display.SetRenderingResolution(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets Rendering resolution for the display.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.DistanceJoint2D
member.summary: Joint that keeps two Rigidbody2D objects a fixed distance apart.
member.remarks: Note that unlike the SpringJoint2D component, the distance separating the objects is truly fixed and does not allow for any stretching. See Also: HingeJoint2D class, SliderJoint2D class, SpringJoint2D class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.DistanceJoint2D.anchor
member.summary: The joint's anchor point on the object that has the DistanceJoint2D component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.DistanceJoint2D.connectedAnchor
member.summary: The joint's anchor point on the second object (ie, the one which doesn't have the component).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.DistanceJoint2D.distance
member.summary: The distance separating the two ends of the joint.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.EdgeCollider2D
member.summary: Collider for 2D physics representing an arbitrary set of connected edges (lines) defined by its vertices.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.EdgeCollider2D.edgeCount
member.remarks: This is one less than the number of points.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.EdgeCollider2D.pointCount
member.remarks: This cannot be less than two which will form a single edge.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.EdgeCollider2D.points
member.summary: Get or set the points defining multiple continuous edges.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.EdgeCollider2D.Reset
member.summary: Reset to a single edge consisting of two points.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Event
member.remarks: Events correspond to user input (key presses, mouse actions), or are UnityGUI layout or rendering events. For each event OnGUI is called in the scripts; so OnGUI is potentially called multiple times per frame. Event.current corresponds to "current" event inside OnGUI call. See Also: GUI Scripting Guide, EventType.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.alt
member.summary: Is Alt/Option key held down? (Read Only)
member.remarks: On Windows, this returns true if any Alt key is held down. On Mac, this returns true if any Option key is held down.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.button
member.remarks: 0 means left mouse button, 1 means right mouse button, 2 means middle mouse button. Used in EventType.MouseDown, EventType.MouseUp events.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.capsLock
member.remarks: Returns true if Caps Lock is switched on.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.character
member.remarks: Used in EventType.KeyDown event. Note that EventType.KeyUp events might not contain a character, only Event.keyCode. See Also: Event.keyCode.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.clickCount
member.summary: How many consecutive mouse clicks have we received.
member.remarks: Used in EventType.MouseDown event; use this to differentiate between a single and double clicks.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.command
member.summary: Is Command/Windows key held down? (Read Only)
member.remarks: On Windows, this returns true if any Windows key is held down. On Mac, this returns true if any Command key is held down.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.commandName
member.summary: The name of an ExecuteCommand or ValidateCommand Event.
member.remarks: "Copy", "Cut", "Paste", "Delete", "FrameSelected", "Duplicate", "SelectAll" and so on. Sent only in the editor.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.control
member.summary: Is Control key held down? (Read Only)
member.remarks: Returns true if any Control key is held down.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.current
member.summary: The current event that's being processed right now.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.delta
member.summary: The relative movement of the mouse compared to last event.
member.remarks: Used in EventType.MouseMove, EventType.MouseDrag, EventType.ScrollWheel events. See Also: Event.mousePosition.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.functionKey
member.summary: Is the current keypress a function key? (Read Only)
member.remarks: Returns true if the current keypress is an arrow key, page up, page down, backspace, etc. key. If this key needs special processing in order to work in text editing, functionKey is on.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Event.GetTypeForControl(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a filtered event type for a given control ID.
member.remarks: This function is used to implement mouse locking and keyboard focus. The controlID can be obtained from GUIUtilty.GetControlID (). See Also: EventType for the list of possible values.
member.param: The ID of the control you are querying from.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.isKey
member.summary: Is this event a keyboard event? (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.isMouse
member.summary: Is this event a mouse event? (Read Only)

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Event.KeyboardEvent(System.String)
member.remarks: This is useful when you need to check if a certain key has been pressed - possibly with modifiers. The syntax for the key string is a key name (same as in the Input Manager), optionally prefixed by any number of modifiers: & = Alternate, ^ = Control, % = Command/Windows key, # = Shift Examples: &f12 = Alternate + F12, "^[0]" = Control + keypad0.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.keyCode
member.summary: The raw key code for keyboard events.
member.remarks: Used in EventType.KeyDown and EventType.KeyUp events; this returns KeyCode value that matches the physical keyboard key. Use this for handling cursor keys, function keys etc. See Also: Event.character.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.modifiers
member.summary: Which modifier keys are held down.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.mousePosition
member.remarks: Used in EventType.MouseMove and EventType.MouseDrag events. See Also: Event.delta.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.numeric
member.summary: Is the current keypress on the numeric keyboard? (Read Only)
member.remarks: Use this flag to destinguish between main & numeric keys.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.shift
member.remarks: Returns true if any Shift key is held down.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Event.type
member.remarks: See Also: EventType, GUI Scripting Guide.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Event.Use
member.remarks: Call this method when you've used an event. The event's type will be set to EventType.Used, causing other GUI elements to ignore it.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.EventModifiers
member.summary: Types of modifier key that can be active during a keystroke event.
member.remarks: See Also: Event, GUI Scripting Guide.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.EventType
member.summary: Types of UnityGUI input and processing events.
member.remarks: See Also: Event.type, Event, GUI Scripting Guide.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.ContextClick
member.summary: User has right-clicked (or control-clicked on the mac).
member.remarks: Window should show a context menu if applicable. Sent only in the editor.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.DragExited
member.summary: Editor only: drag & drop operation exited.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.dragPerform
member.summary: Editor only: drag & drop operation performed.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.DragPerform
member.summary: Editor only: drag & drop operation performed.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.dragUpdated
member.summary: Editor only: drag & drop operation updated.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.DragUpdated
member.summary: Editor only: drag & drop operation updated.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.ExecuteCommand
member.summary: Execute a special command (eg. copy & paste).

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.ignore
member.remarks: This event is temporarily disabled and should be ignored.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.Ignore
member.remarks: This event is temporarily disabled and should be ignored.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.keyDown
member.remarks: Use Event.character to find out what has been typed. Use Event.keyCode to handle arrow, home/end or other function keys, or to find out which physical key has been pressed. This event is sent repeatedly depending on the end user's keyboard repeat settings. Note that key presses can come as separate events, one with valid Event.keyCode, and another with valid Event.character. In case of keyboard layouts with dead keys, multiple Event.keyCode events can generate a single Event.character event.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.KeyDown
member.remarks: Use Event.character to find out what has been typed. Use Event.keyCode to handle arrow, home/end or other function keys, or to find out which physical key has been pressed. This event is sent repeatedly depending on the end user's keyboard repeat settings. Note that key presses can come as separate events, one with valid Event.keyCode, and another with valid Event.character. In case of keyboard layouts with dead keys, multiple Event.keyCode events can generate a single Event.character event.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.keyUp
member.remarks: Use Event.keyCode to find which physical key was released. Note that depending on the system and keyboard layout, Event.character might not contain any character for a key release event.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.KeyUp
member.remarks: Use Event.keyCode to find which physical key was released. Note that depending on the system and keyboard layout, Event.character might not contain any character for a key release event.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.layout
member.remarks: This event is sent prior to anything else - this is a chance to perform any initialization. It is used by the automatic layout system.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.Layout
member.remarks: This event is sent prior to anything else - this is a chance to perform any initialization. It is used by the automatic layout system.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.mouseDown
member.remarks: This event gets sent when any mouse button is pressed. Use Event.button to determine which button was pressed down.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.MouseDown
member.remarks: This event gets sent when any mouse button is pressed. Use Event.button to determine which button was pressed down.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.mouseDrag
member.remarks: The mouse was moved with a button held down - a mouse drag. Use Event.mousePosition and Event.delta to determine mouse motion.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.MouseDrag
member.remarks: The mouse was moved with a button held down - a mouse drag. Use Event.mousePosition and Event.delta to determine mouse motion.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.mouseMove
member.remarks: The mouse was moved without any buttons being held down. Use Event.mousePosition and Event.delta to determine mouse motion. Note that this even is only sent in the Editor, for EditorWindow windows which have EditorWindow.wantsMouseMove set to true. Mouse move events are never sent in the games.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.MouseMove
member.remarks: The mouse was moved without any buttons being held down. Use Event.mousePosition and Event.delta to determine mouse motion. Note that this even is only sent in the Editor, for EditorWindow windows which have EditorWindow.wantsMouseMove set to true. Mouse move events are never sent in the games.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.mouseUp
member.remarks: This event gets sent when any mouse button is released. Use Event.button to determine which button was pressed down.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.MouseUp
member.remarks: This event gets sent when any mouse button is released. Use Event.button to determine which button was pressed down.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.EventType.repaint
member.summary: A repaint event. One is sent every frame.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ExecuteInEditMode
member.summary: Makes a script execute in edit mode.
member.remarks: By default, script components are only executed in play mode. By adding this attribute, each script component will also have its callback functions executed while the Editor is not in playmode. The functions are not called constantly like they are in play mode. - Update is only called when something in the scene changed. - OnGUI is called when the Game View recieves an Event. - OnRenderObject and the other rendering callback functions are called on every repaint of the Scene View or Game View.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.FFTWindow
member.remarks: Use this to reduce leakage of signals across frequency bands.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.FilterMode
member.summary: Filtering mode for textures. Corresponds to the settings in a texture inspector.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FilterMode.Bilinear
member.summary: Bilinear filtering - texture samples are averaged.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FilterMode.Point
member.summary: Point filtering - texture pixels become blocky up close.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FilterMode.Trilinear
member.summary: Trilinear filtering - texture samples are averaged and also blended between mipmap levels.
member.remarks: RenderTextures do not support mipmaps, so this setting reverts to Bilinear for those. See Also: Texture.filterMode, texture assets.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Font
member.remarks: You can use this class to dynamically switch fonts on GUI texts or Text Meshes. See Also: GUIText and TextMesh.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Font.characterInfo
member.summary: Access an array of all characters contained in the font texture.
member.remarks: You can read this if you want to render the font texture using custom generated Meshes, or you can set it when you want to build your own custom font assets from scripts (or modify existing ones). See Also: GetCharacterInfo.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Font.GetCharacterInfo(System.Char,UnityEngine.CharacterInfo@)
member.summary: Get rendering info for a specific character.
member.remarks: Note: You should only ever need to use this when you want to implement your own text rendering. If the character ch with the specified size and style is present in the font texture, then this method will return true, and info will contain the texture placement information for that character. If the character is not present, this method returns false. If size is zero, it will use the default size for the font. See Also: characterInfo.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Font.GetCharacterInfo(System.Char,UnityEngine.CharacterInfo@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get rendering info for a specific character.
member.remarks: Note: You should only ever need to use this when you want to implement your own text rendering. If the character ch with the specified size and style is present in the font texture, then this method will return true, and info will contain the texture placement information for that character. If the character is not present, this method returns false. If size is zero, it will use the default size for the font. See Also: characterInfo.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Font.GetCharacterInfo(System.Char,UnityEngine.CharacterInfo@,System.Int32,UnityEngine.FontStyle)
member.summary: Get rendering info for a specific character.
member.remarks: Note: You should only ever need to use this when you want to implement your own text rendering. If the character ch with the specified size and style is present in the font texture, then this method will return true, and info will contain the texture placement information for that character. If the character is not present, this method returns false. If size is zero, it will use the default size for the font. See Also: characterInfo.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Font.HasCharacter(System.Char)
member.summary: Does this font have a specific character?

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Font.material
member.summary: The material used for the font display.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Font.RequestCharactersInTexture(System.String)
member.summary: Request characters to be added to the font texture (dynamic fonts only).
member.remarks: Note: You should only ever need to use this when you want to implement your own text rendering. Call this function to request Unity to make sure all the characters in the string characters are available in the font's font texture (and it's characterInfo property). This is useful when you want to implement your own code to render dynamic fonts. You can supply a custom font size and style for the characters. If size is zero (the default), it will use the default size for that font. RequestCharactersInTexture may cause the font texture to be regenerated if it does not have space to add all the requested characters. If the font texture is regenerated it will only contain characters which have been used using Font.RequestCharactersInTexture, or using Unity's text rendering functions during the last frame. So it is advisable to always call RequestCharactersInTexture for any text on the screen you wish to render using custom font rendering functions, even if the characters are currently present in the texture, to make sure they don't get purged during texture rebuild. See Also: FontTextureRebuildCallback, GetCharacterInfo.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Font.RequestCharactersInTexture(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Request characters to be added to the font texture (dynamic fonts only).
member.remarks: Note: You should only ever need to use this when you want to implement your own text rendering. Call this function to request Unity to make sure all the characters in the string characters are available in the font's font texture (and it's characterInfo property). This is useful when you want to implement your own code to render dynamic fonts. You can supply a custom font size and style for the characters. If size is zero (the default), it will use the default size for that font. RequestCharactersInTexture may cause the font texture to be regenerated if it does not have space to add all the requested characters. If the font texture is regenerated it will only contain characters which have been used using Font.RequestCharactersInTexture, or using Unity's text rendering functions during the last frame. So it is advisable to always call RequestCharactersInTexture for any text on the screen you wish to render using custom font rendering functions, even if the characters are currently present in the texture, to make sure they don't get purged during texture rebuild. See Also: FontTextureRebuildCallback, GetCharacterInfo.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Font.RequestCharactersInTexture(System.String,System.Int32,UnityEngine.FontStyle)
member.summary: Request characters to be added to the font texture (dynamic fonts only).
member.remarks: Note: You should only ever need to use this when you want to implement your own text rendering. Call this function to request Unity to make sure all the characters in the string characters are available in the font's font texture (and it's characterInfo property). This is useful when you want to implement your own code to render dynamic fonts. You can supply a custom font size and style for the characters. If size is zero (the default), it will use the default size for that font. RequestCharactersInTexture may cause the font texture to be regenerated if it does not have space to add all the requested characters. If the font texture is regenerated it will only contain characters which have been used using Font.RequestCharactersInTexture, or using Unity's text rendering functions during the last frame. So it is advisable to always call RequestCharactersInTexture for any text on the screen you wish to render using custom font rendering functions, even if the characters are currently present in the texture, to make sure they don't get purged during texture rebuild. See Also: FontTextureRebuildCallback, GetCharacterInfo.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Font.textureRebuildCallback
member.summary: Set a function to be called when the dynamic font texture is rebuilt.
member.remarks: This lets you set a delegate function to be called when the dynamic font texture is rebuilt. This will happen when new characters added to the font no longer fit into the texture. The font texture will then be rebuilt to fit all needed characters. If you use custom meshes to render characters from the font, you will need to use the textureRebuildCallback to regenerate such meshes, as previous UV coordinates from the Font will no longer be valid.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FontStyle.BoldAndItalic

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FontStyle.Italic
member.summary: Italic style applied to your texts.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ForceMode
member.summary: Option for how to apply a force using Rigidbody.AddForce.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ForceMode.Acceleration
member.summary: Add a continuous acceleration to the rigidbody, ignoring its mass.
member.remarks: Apply the acceleration in each FixedUpdate over a duration of time. In contrast to ForceMode.Force, Acceleration will move every rigidbody the same way regardless of differences in mass. This mode is useful if you just want to control the acceleration of an object directly. In this mode, the unit of the force parameter is applied to the rigidbody as distance/time^2.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ForceMode.Force
member.summary: Add a continuous force to the rigidbody, using its mass.
member.remarks: Apply the force in each FixedUpdate over a duration of time. This mode depends on the mass of rigidbody so more force must be applied to push or twist higher-mass objects the same amount as lower-mass objects. This mode is useful for setting up realistic physics where it takes more force to move heavier objects. In this mode, the unit of the force parameter is applied to the rigidbody as mass*distance/time^2.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ForceMode.Impulse
member.summary: Add an instant force impulse to the rigidbody, using its mass.
member.remarks: Apply the impulse force instantly with a single function call. This mode depends on the mass of rigidbody so more force must be applied to push or twist higher-mass objects the same amount as lower-mass objects. This mode is useful for applying forces that happen instantly, such as forces from explosions or collisions. In this mode, the unit of the force parameter is applied to the rigidbody as mass*distance/time.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ForceMode.VelocityChange
member.summary: Add an instant velocity change to the rigidbody, ignoring its mass.
member.remarks: Apply the velocity change instantly with a single function call. In contrast to ForceMode.Impulse, VelocityChange will change the velocity of every rigidbody the same way regardless of differences in mass. This mode is useful for something like a fleet of differently-sized space ships that you want to control without accounting for differences in mass. In this mode, the unit of the force parameter is applied to the rigidbody as distance/time.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.FullScreenMovieControlMode
member.summary: Describes options for displaying movie playback controls.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FullScreenMovieControlMode.CancelOnInput
member.summary: Do not display any controls, but cancel movie playback if input occurs.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FullScreenMovieControlMode.Full
member.summary: Display the standard controls for controlling movie playback.
member.remarks: This includes play/pause controls, a volume slider, and a timeline control.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FullScreenMovieControlMode.Hidden
member.remarks: This mode prevents the user from controlling playback.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FullScreenMovieControlMode.Minimal
member.summary: Display minimal set of controls controlling movie playback.
member.remarks: The set of controls displayed might differ between OS versions.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.FullScreenMovieScalingMode
member.summary: Describes scaling modes for displaying movies.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FullScreenMovieScalingMode.AspectFill
member.summary: Scale the movie until the movie fills the entire screen.
member.remarks: Content at the edges of the larger of the two dimensions is clipped so that the other dimension fits the screen exactly. The aspect ratio of the movie is preserved.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FullScreenMovieScalingMode.AspectFit
member.summary: Scale the movie until one dimension fits on the screen exactly.
member.remarks: In the other dimension, the region between the edge of the movie and the edge of the screen is filled with a black bar. The aspect ratio of the movie is preserved.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.FullScreenMovieScalingMode.Fill
member.summary: Scale the movie until both dimensions fit the screen exactly.
member.remarks: The aspect ratio of the movie is not preserved.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.GameObject
member.summary: Base class for all entities in Unity scenes.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.GameObject.activeInHierarchy
member.summary: Is the GameObject active in the scene?
member.remarks: This lets you know if a gameObject is active in the game. That is the case if its GameObject.activeSelf property is enabled, as well as that of all it's parents. See Also: GameObject.SetActive, GameObject.activeSelf.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.GameObject.activeSelf
member.summary: The local active state of this GameObject. (Read Only)
member.remarks: This returns the local active state of this GameObject, which is set using GameObject.SetActive. Note that a GameObject may be inactive because a parent is not active, even if this returns true. This state will then be used once all parents are active. Use GameObject.activeInHierarchy if you want to check if the GameObject is actually treated as active in the scene. See Also: GameObject.SetActive, GameObject.activeInHierarchy.

member.param: The type of primitive object to create.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GameObject.Find(System.String)
member.summary: Finds a GameObject by name and returns it.
member.remarks: If no GameObject with name can be found, null is returned. If name contains a '/' character it will traverse the hierarchy like a path name. This function only returns active gameobjects. For performance reasons it is recommended to not use this function every frame Instead cache the result in a member variable at startup or use GameObject.FindWithTag.This function is most useful to automatically connect references to other objects at load time, eg. inside MonoBehaviour.Awake or MonoBehaviour.Start. You should avoid calling this function every frame eg. MonoBehaviour.Update for performance reasons. A common pattern is to assign a GameObject to a variable inside MonoBehaviour.Start. And use the variable in MonoBehaviour.Update.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GameObject.FindGameObjectsWithTag(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a list of active GameObjects tagged tag. Returns empty array if no GameObject was found.
member.remarks: Tags must be declared in the tag manager before using them. A UnityException will be thrown if the tag does not exist or an empty string or null is passed as the tag.Another example:Another example, testing for empty array:
member.param: The name of the tag to search GameObjects for.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GameObject.FindWithTag(System.String)
member.summary: Returns one active GameObject tagged tag. Returns null if no GameObject was found.
member.remarks: Tags must be declared in the tag manager before using them. A UnityException will be thrown if the tag does not exist or an empty string or null is passed as the tag.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GameObject.SampleAnimation(UnityEngine.AnimationClip,System.Single)
member.summary: Samples an animation at a given time for any animated properties.
member.remarks: It is recommended to use the Animation interface instead for performance reasons. This will sample animation at the given time. Any component properties that are animated in the clip will be replaced with the sampled value. Most of the time you want to use Animation.Play instead. SampleAnimation is useful when you need to jump between frames in an unordered way or based on some special input. See Also: Animation.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GameObject.SendMessage(System.String)
member.summary: Calls the method named methodName on every MonoBehaviour in this GameObject.
member.remarks: The receiving method can choose to ignore the argument by having zero parameters. If options is set to SendMessageOptions.RequireReceiver an error is printed if the message is not picked up by any component. Note that messages will not be sent to inactive objects (ie, those that have been deactivated in the editor or with the SetActive function).
member.param: The name of the method to call.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GameObject.SetActive(System.Boolean)
member.remarks: Note that a GameObject may be inactive because a parent is not active. In that case, calling SetActive() will not activate it, but only set the local state of the GameObject, which can be checked using GameObject.activeSelf. This state will then be used once all parents are active. See Also: GameObject.activeSelf, GameObject.activeInHierarchy.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.GameObject.tag

member.name: P:UnityEngine.GameObject.transform
member.summary: The Transform attached to this GameObject. (null if there is none attached).

member.name: T:UnityEngine.GeometryUtility
member.summary: Utility class for common geometric functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GeometryUtility.TestPlanesAABB(UnityEngine.Plane[],UnityEngine.Bounds)
member.summary: Returns true if bounds are inside the plane array.
member.remarks: Will return true if the bounding box is inside the planes or intersects any of the planes. The TestPlanesAABB function uses the Plane array to test whether a bounding box is in the frustum or not. You can use this function with CalculateFrustrumPlanes to test whether a camera's view contains an object regardless of whether it is rendered or not. See Also: GeometryUtility.CalculateFrustumPlanes.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Gizmos
member.summary: Gizmos are used to give visual debugging or setup aids in the scene view.
member.remarks: All gizmo drawing has to be done in either OnDrawGizmos or OnDrawGizmosSelected functions of the script. OnDrawGizmos is called every frame. All gizmos rendered within OnDrawGizmos are pickable. OnDrawGizmosSelected is called only if the object the script is attached to is selected.

Distance of the frustum's near plane.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Gizmos.DrawGUITexture(UnityEngine.Rect,UnityEngine.Texture)
member.summary: Draw a texture in the scene.
member.remarks: The chosen texture is drawn in 3D space on a "screen" defined by the XY plane (ie, the plane where the Z coordinate is zero). The values of the texture rectangle are given in scene units. The optional border values specify an inset from each edge within the rectangle in scene units; the texture is drawn inside the inset rectangle and the edge pixels are repeated outwards. This is a useful quick way to create a large background region around the main texture when its edges are of a single colour. This function can be useful for creating GUI backgrounds in conjunction with a camera pointing directly at the texture.
member.param: The size and position of the texture on the "screen" defined by the XY plane.

This is a useful quick way to create a large background region around the main texture when its edges are of a single colour. This function can be useful for creating GUI backgrounds in conjunction with a camera pointing directly at the texture.
member.param: The size and position of the texture on the "screen" defined by the XY plane.
An optional material to apply the texture.

member.summary: Draw an icon at a position in the scene view.
member.remarks: The image filename for the icon is specified with the name parameter while the center parameter denotes the location of the icon in world space and the allowScaling parameter determines if the icon is allowed to be scaled. member.name: T:UnityEngine.GL
member.remarks: Use this class to manipulate active transformation matrices, issue rendering commands similar to OpenGL's immediate mode and do other low-level graphics tasks. Note that in almost all cases using Graphics.DrawMesh is more efficient than using immediate mode drawing. GL immediate drawing functions use whatever is the "current material" set up right now. The material controls how the rendering is done (blending, textures, etc.), so unless you explicitly set it to something before using GL draw functions, the material can happen to be anything. Also, if you call any other drawing commands from inside GL drawing code, they can set material to something else, so make sure it's under control as well. GL drawing commands execute immediately. That means if you call them in Update(), they will be executed before the camera is rendered (and the camera will most likely clear the screen, making the GL drawing not visible). The usual place to call GL drawing is most often in OnPostRender() from a script attached to a cameraNote: This class is almost always used when you need to draw a couple of lines or triangles, and don't want to deal with meshes. If you want to avoid surprises the usage pattern is this:Where at the "// Draw your stuff" you should do SetPass() on some material previously declared, which will be used for drawing. If you dont call SetPass, then you'll get basically a random material (whatever was used before) which is not good. So do it.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.Begin(System.Int32)
member.remarks: In OpenGL this matches glBegin ; on other graphics APIs the same functionality is emulated. Between GL.Begin and GL.End it is valid to call GL.Vertex, GL.Color, GL.TexCoord and other immediate mode drawing functions. You should be careful about culling when drawing primitives yourself. The culling rules may be different depending on which graphics API the game is running. In most cases the safest way is to use Cull Off command in the shader. See Also: GL.End.
member.param: Primitives to draw: can be TRIANGLES, TRIANGLE_STRIP, QUADS or LINES.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.Clear(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,UnityEngine.Color)
member.remarks: This clears the screen or the active RenderTexture you are drawing into. In most other situations, some camera is drawing something somewhere, and probably is clearing already with the background color of the skybox. See Also: GL.ClearWithSkybox.
member.param: Should the depth buffer be cleared?
Should the color buffer be cleared?
The color to clear with, used only if clearColor is true.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.Clear(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,UnityEngine.Color,System.Single)
member.remarks: This clears the screen or the active RenderTexture you are drawing into. In most other situations, some camera is drawing something somewhere, and probably is clearing already with the background color of the skybox. See Also: GL.ClearWithSkybox.
member.param: Should the depth buffer be cleared?
Should the color buffer be cleared?
The color to clear with, used only if clearColor is true.
The depth to clear Z buffer with, used only if clearDepth is true.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.ClearWithSkybox(System.Boolean,UnityEngine.Camera)
member.summary: Clear the current render buffer with camera's skybox.
member.remarks: This draws skybox into the screen or the active RenderTexture. If the passed camera does not have custom Skybox component, the global skybox from RenderSettings will be used. See Also: GL.Clear.
member.param: Should the depth buffer be cleared?
Camera to get projection parameters and skybox from.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.Color(UnityEngine.Color)
member.remarks: In OpenGL this matches glColor4f(c.r,c.g,c.b,c.a) ; on other graphics APIs the same functionality is emulated. In order for per-vertex colors to work reliably across different hardware, you have to use a shader that binds in the color channel. See BindChannels documentation. This function can only be called between GL.Begin and GL.End functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.End
member.remarks: In OpenGL this matches glEnd ; on other graphics APIs the same functionality is emulated. See Also: GL.Begin.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.GetGPUProjectionMatrix(UnityEngine.Matrix4x4,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Compute GPU projection matrix from camera's projection matrix.
member.remarks: In Unity, projection matrices follow OpenGL convention. However on some platforms they have to be transformed a bit to match the native API requirements. Use this function to calculate how the final projection matrix will be like. The value will match what comes as UNITY_MATRIX_P matrix in a shader. The renderIntoTexture value should be set to true if you intend to render into a RenderTexture with this projection matrix. On some platforms it affects how the final matrix will look like.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.InvalidateState
member.remarks: This invalidates any cached renderstates tied to the GL context. If for example a (native) plugin alters the renderstate settings then Unity's rendering architecture must be made aware of that to not assume the GL context is preserved.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.IssuePluginEvent(System.Int32)
member.summary: Send a user-defined event to a native code plugin.
member.remarks: Rendering in Unity can be multithreaded if the platform and number of available CPUs will allow for it. When multithreaded rendering is used, the rendering API commands happen on a thread which is completely separate from the one that runs the scripts. Consequently, it is not possible for your plugin to start rendering immediately, since it might interfere with what the render thread is doing at the time. In order to do any rendering from the plugin, you should call GL.IssuePluginEvent from your script, which will cause your native plugin to be called from the render thread. For example, if you call GL.IssuePluginEvent from the camera's OnPostRender function, you'll get a plugin callback immediately after the camera has finished rendering. See Native Plugin Interface for more details and an example.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.GL.LINES
member.remarks: If you want to draw something 2D in screen space then probably you will want to use GL.LoadOrtho or GL.LoadPixelMatrix. If you want something in "3D", then probably you should consider using GL.LoadIdentity followed by GL.MultMatrix with the actual 3D transform you want your stuff to be in. See Also: GL.Begin, GL.End.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.LoadIdentity
member.summary: Load the identity matrix to the current modelview matrix.
member.remarks: This function overrides current camera's view parameters, so most often you want to save and restore matrix using GL.PushMatrix and GL.PopMatrix.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.LoadOrtho
member.summary: Helper function to set up an ortho perspective transform.
member.remarks: After calling LoadOrtho, the viewing frustum goes from (0,0,-1) to (1,1,100). LoadOrtho can be used for drawing primitives in 2D.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.LoadPixelMatrix
member.summary: Setup a matrix for pixel-correct rendering.Setup a matrix for pixel-correct rendering.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.LoadPixelMatrix(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Setup a matrix for pixel-correct rendering.Setup a matrix for pixel-correct rendering.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.LoadProjectionMatrix(UnityEngine.Matrix4x4)
member.summary: Load an arbitrary matrix to the current projection matrix.
member.remarks: This function overrides current camera's projection parameters, so most often you want to save and restore projection matrix using GL.PushMatrix and GL.PopMatrix.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.GL.modelview
member.remarks: Assigning to this variable is equivalent to glLoadMatrix(mat) in OpenGL; in other graphics APIs the corresponding functionality is emulated. Changing modelview matrix overrides current camera's view parameters, so most often you want to save and restore matrix using GL.PushMatrix and GL.PopMatrix. Reading this variable returns the current modelview matrix.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.MultiTexCoord(System.Int32,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Sets current texture coordinate (v.x,v.y,v.z) to the actual texture unit.
member.remarks: In OpenGL this matches glMultiTexCoord for the given texture unit if multi-texturing is available. On other graphics APIs the same functionality is emulated. The Z component is used only when: 1. You access a cubemap (which you access with a vector coordinate, hence x,y & z). 2. You do "projective texturing", where the X & Y coordinates are divided by Z to get the final coordinate. This would be mostly useful for water reflections and similar things. This function can only be called between GL.Begin and GL.End functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.MultiTexCoord2(System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets current texture coordinate (x,y) for the actual texture unit.
member.remarks: In OpenGL this matches glMultiTexCoord for the given texture unit if multi-texturing is available. On other graphics APIs the same functionality is emulated. This function can only be called between GL.Begin and GL.End functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.MultiTexCoord3(System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets current texture coordinate (x,y,z) to the actual texture unit.
member.remarks: In OpenGL this matches glMultiTexCoord for the given texture unit if multi-texturing is available. On other graphics APIs the same functionality is emulated. The Z component is used only when: 1. You access a cubemap (which you access with a vector coordinate, hence x,y & z). 2. You do "projective texturing", where the X & Y coordinates are divided by Z to get the final coordinate. This would be mostly useful for water reflections and similar things. This function can only be called between GL.Begin and GL.End functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.MultMatrix(UnityEngine.Matrix4x4)
member.summary: Multiplies the current modelview matrix with the one specified.
member.remarks: Equivalent to glMultMatrix(mat) in OpenGL; in other graphics APIs the corresponding functionality is emulated. Changing modelview matrix overrides current camera's view parameters, so most often you want to save and restore matrix using GL.PushMatrix and GL.PopMatrix.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.PopMatrix
member.summary: Restores both projection and modelview matrices off the top of the matrix stack.
member.remarks: Changing modelview or projection matrices overrides current camera's parameters. These matrices can be saved and restored using GL.PushMatrix and GL.PopMatrix. See Also: PushMatrix function.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.PushMatrix
member.summary: Saves both projection and modelview matrices to the matrix stack.
member.remarks: Changing modelview or projection matrices overrides current camera's parameters. These matrices can be saved and restored using GL.PushMatrix and GL.PopMatrix. See Also: PopMatrix function.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.GL.QUADS
member.remarks: If you want to draw something 2D in screen space then probably you will want to use GL.LoadOrtho or GL.LoadPixelMatrix. If you want something in "3D", then probably you should consider using GL.LoadIdentity followed by GL.MultMatrix with the actual 3D transform you want your stuff to be in. member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.SetRevertBackfacing(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Select whether to invert the backface culling (true) or not (false).
member.remarks: Unlike most other calls, this is not only related to stuff you draw via GL class. It changes culling of triangles globally. Major use case: rendering reflections for mirrors, water etc. Since virtual camera for rendering the reflection is mirrored, the culling order has to be inverted. You can see that the Water script in Pro Standard Assets does that.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.TexCoord(UnityEngine.Vector3)

member.remarks: In OpenGL this matches glMultiTexCoord for all texture units or glTexCoord when no multi-texturing is available. On other graphics APIs the same functionality is emulated. The Z component is used only when: 1. You access a cubemap (which you access with a vector coordinate, hence x,y & z). 2. You do "projective texturing", where the X & Y coordinates are divided by Z to get the final coordinate. This would be mostly useful for water reflections and similar things. This function can only be called between GL.Begin and GL.End functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.GL.Viewport(UnityEngine.Rect)
member.remarks: All rendering is constrained to be inside the passed pixelRect. If the Viewport is modified, all the rendered content inside of it gets stretched.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.GL.wireframe
member.summary: Should rendering be done in wireframe?
member.remarks: Turning on wireframe mode will affect all objects rendered after the call, until you turn wireframe back off. In the Unity editor, wireframe mode is always turned off before repainting any window. Note that some platforms, for example mobile (OpenGL ES) and Flash (Stage3D) do not support wireframe rendering.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Graphics
member.summary: Raw interface to Unity's drawing functions.
member.remarks: This is the high-level shortcut into the optimized mesh drawing functionality of Unity.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Graphics.Blit(UnityEngine.Texture,UnityEngine.Material)
member.summary: Copies source texture into destination render texture.
member.remarks: This is mostly used for implementing image effects, and requires Unity Pro. Blit sets dest to be active render texture, sets source as _MainTex property on the material, and draws a full-screen quad. See Also: Graphics.BlitMultiTap, image effects.
member.param: Material to use for copying. Material's shader could do some post-processing effect, for example.

member.summary: Copies source texture into destination render texture.

member.param: Destination RenderTexture, or null to blit directly to screen.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Graphics.Blit(UnityEngine.Texture,UnityEngine.Material,System.Int32)
