member.name: T:UnityEngine.ImageEffectOpaque
member.summary: Any Image Effect with this attribute will be rendered after opaque geometry but before transparent geometry.
member.remarks: This allows for effects which extensively use the depth buffer (SSAO ect) to only affect opaque pixels. This Attribute can be used to reduce the amount of visual artifacts in a scene with post processing.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ImageEffectTransformsToLDR
member.summary: When using HDR rendering it can sometime be desirable to switch to LDR rendering during ImageEffect rendering.
member.remarks: Using this Attribute on an image effect will cause the destination buffer to be an LDR buffer, and switch the rest of the Image Effect pipeline into LDR mode. It is the responsibility of the Image Effect that this Attribute is associated to ensure that the output is in the LDR range.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ImagePosition
member.summary: How image and text is placed inside GUIStyle.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ImagePosition.ImageLeft
member.summary: Image is to the left of the text.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.IMECompositionMode.Auto
member.summary: Enable IME input only when a text field is selected (default).

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Input
member.remarks: Use this class to read the axes set up in the Input Manager, and to access multi-touch/accelerometer data on mobile devices. To read an axis use Input.GetAxis with one of the following default axes: "Horizontal" and "Vertical" are mapped to joystick, A, W, S, D and the arrow keys. "Mouse X" and "Mouse Y" are mapped to the mouse delta. "Fire1", "Fire2" "Fire3" are mapped to Ctrl, Alt, Cmd keys and three mouse or joystick buttons. New input axes can be added in the Input Manager. If you are using input for any kind of movement behaviour use Input.GetAxis. It gives you smoothed and configurable input that can be mapped to keyboard, joystick or mouse. Use Input.GetButton for action like events only. Don't use it for movement, Input.GetAxis will make the script code smaller and simpler. Note also that the Input flags are not reset until "Update()", so its suggested you make all the Input Calls in the Update Loop. Mobile Devices: iOS and Android devices are capable of tracking multiple fingers touching the screen simultaneously. You can access data on the status of each finger touching screen during the last frame by accessing the Input.touches property array. As a device moves, its accelerometer hardware reports linear acceleration changes along the three primary axes in three-dimensional space. You can use this data to detect both the current orientation of the device (relative to the ground) and any immediate changes to that orientation. Acceleration along each axis is reported directly by the hardware as G-force values. A value of 1.0 represents a load of about +1g along a given axis while a value of -1.0 represents -1g. If you hold the device upright (with the home button at the bottom) in front of you, the X axis is positive along the right, the Y axis is positive directly up, and the Z axis is positive pointing toward you. You can read the Input.acceleration property to get the accelerometer reading. You can also use the Input.deviceOrientation property to get a discrete evaluation of the device's orientation in three-dimensional space. Detecting a change in orientation can be useful if you want to create game behaviors when the user rotates the device to hold it differently. Note that the accelerometer hardware can be polled more than once per frame. To access all accelerometer samples since the last frame, you can read the Input.accelerationEvents property array. This can be useful when reconstructing player motions, feeding acceleration data into a predictor, or implementing other precise motion analysis.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.acceleration
member.summary: Last measured linear acceleration of a device in three-dimensional space. (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.accelerationEventCount
member.summary: Number of acceleration measurements which occurred during last frame.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.accelerationEvents
member.summary: Returns list of acceleration measurements which occurred during the last frame. (Read Only) (Allocates temporary variables).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.anyKey
member.summary: Is any key or mouse button currently held down? (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.anyKeyDown
member.summary: Returns true the first frame the user hits any key or mouse button. (Read Only)
member.remarks: You should be polling this variable from the Update function, since the state gets reset each frame. It will not return true until the user has released all keys / buttons and pressed any key / buttons again.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.compass
member.summary: Property for accessing compass (handheld devices only). (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.compensateSensors
member.summary: This property controls if input sensors should be compensated for screen orientation.
member.remarks: Compensated sensors are accelerometer, compass, gyroscope. Note : currently it fully affects iOS platform and partially Android platform (on Android compensation can't be turned off at the moment).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.compositionCursorPos
member.summary: The current text input position used by IMEs to open windows.
member.remarks: Some language IMEs such as Japanese will open windows while the user is typing text, to aid the user in picking the correct input strings. These windows are expected to pop up at the current cursor position, so the IME needs to know where input is displayed. When using Unity's built in GUI system for text input, Unity will take care of setting the cursor position for the IME. However, if you wish to implement your own GUI for text input, you need to set this to the current text input position for IME windows to show up correctly. See Also: Input.imeCompositionMode, Input.compositionString.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.compositionString
member.summary: The current IME composition string being typed by the user.
member.remarks: In some languages such as Chinese, Japanese or Korean, text is input by typing multiple keys to generate one or multiple characters. These characters are visually composed on the screen as the user types. When using Unity's built in GUI system for text input, Unity will take care of displaying the composition strings as the users types. If you want to implement your own GUI, however, you need to take care of displaying the string at the current cursor position. The composition string is only updated when IME compositing is used. See Input.imeCompositionMode for more info. See Also: Input.imeCompositionMode, Input.compositionCursorPos.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.deviceOrientation
member.summary: Device physical orientation as reported by OS. (Read Only)

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetAccelerationEvent(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns specific acceleration measurement which occurred during last frame. (Does not allocate temporary variables).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetAxis(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the value of the virtual axis identified by axisName.
member.remarks: The value will be in the range -1...1 for keyboard and joystick input. If the axis is setup to be delta mouse movement, the mouse delta is multiplied by the axis sensitivity and the range is not -1...1. This is frame-rate independent; you do not need to be concerned about varying frame-rates when using this value.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetAxisRaw(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the value of the virtual axis identified by axisName with no smoothing filtering applied.
member.remarks: The value will be in the range -1...1 for keyboard and joystick input. Since input is not smoothed, keyboard input will always be either -1, 0 or 1. This is useful if you want to do all smoothing of keyboard input processing yourself.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetButton(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true while the virtual button identified by buttonName is held down.
member.remarks: Think auto fire - this will return true as long as the button is held down. Use this only when implementing action like events IE: shooting a weapon. Use Input.GetAxis for any kind of movement behaviour.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetButtonDown(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true during the frame the user pressed down the virtual button identified by buttonName.
member.remarks: You need to call this function from the Update function, since the state gets reset each frame. It will not return true until the user has released the key and pressed it again. Use this only when implementing action like events IE: shooting a weapon. Use Input.GetAxis for any kind of movement behaviour.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetButtonUp(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true the first frame the user releases the virtual button identified by buttonName.
member.remarks: You need to call this function from the Update function, since the state gets reset each frame. It will not return true until the user has pressed the button and released it again. Use this only when implementing action like events IE: shooting a weapon. Use Input.GetAxis for any kind of movement behaviour.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetJoystickNames
member.summary: Returns an array of strings describing the connected joysticks.
member.remarks: This can be useful in user input configuration screens - this way, instead of showing labels like "Joystick 1", you can show more meaningful names like "Logitech WingMan". To read values from different joysticks, you need to assign respective axes for the number of joysticks you want to support in the input manager.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetKey(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true while the user holds down the key identified by name. Think auto fire.Returns true while the user holds down the key identified by the key KeyCode enum parameter.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetKey(UnityEngine.KeyCode)
member.summary: Returns true while the user holds down the key identified by name. Think auto fire.Returns true while the user holds down the key identified by the key KeyCode enum parameter.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetKeyDown(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true during the frame the user starts pressing down the key identified by name.Returns true during the frame the user starts pressing down the key identified by the key KeyCode enum parameter.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetKeyDown(UnityEngine.KeyCode)
member.summary: Returns true during the frame the user starts pressing down the key identified by name.Returns true during the frame the user starts pressing down the key identified by the key KeyCode enum parameter.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetKeyUp(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true during the frame the user releases the key identified by name.Returns true during the frame the user releases the key identified by the key KeyCode enum parameter.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetKeyUp(UnityEngine.KeyCode)
member.summary: Returns true during the frame the user releases the key identified by name.Returns true during the frame the user releases the key identified by the key KeyCode enum parameter.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetMouseButton(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns whether the given mouse button is held down.
member.remarks: button values are 0 for left button, 1 for right button, 2 for the middle button.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetMouseButtonDown(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns true during the frame the user pressed the given mouse button.
member.remarks: You need to call this function from the Update function, since the state gets reset each frame. It will not return true until the user has released the mouse button and pressed it again. button values are 0 for left button, 1 for right button, 2 for the middle button.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetMouseButtonUp(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns true during the frame the user releases the given mouse button.
member.remarks: You need to call this function from the Update function, since the state gets reset each frame. It will not return true until the user has pressed the mouse button and released it again. button values are 0 for left button, 1 for right button, 2 for the middle button.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.GetTouch(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns object representing status of a specific touch. (Does not allocate temporary variables).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.imeCompositionMode
member.summary: Controls enabling and disabling of IME input composition.
member.remarks: Some languages use complex input methods which involve opening windows to insert characters. Typically, this is not desirable while playing a game, as games may just interpret key strokes as game input, not as text. By default, Unity will enable IME composition when in text fields, and disable it otherwise. However, when you want to implement your own input GUI, you may want to have control over this yourself, which is possible using the imeCompositionMode property. Set it to Auto for the default behavior, or On or Off to explicitly enable or disable IME composition.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.imeIsSelected
member.summary: Does the user have an IME keyboard input source selected?
member.remarks: This returns true if the users keyboard is currently configured for IME input, and false otherwise. Since users of asian languages can typically turn IME conversion on or off using a keystroke, it is useful to provide some visual indication of IME being enabled. This can be done by checking Input.imeIsSelected.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.inputString
member.summary: Returns the keyboard input entered this frame. (Read Only)
member.remarks: Only ASCII characters are contained in the inputString. The string can contain two special characters which should be handled: Character "\b" represents backspace. Character "\n" represents return or enter.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.location
member.summary: Property for accessing device location (handheld devices only). (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.mousePosition
member.summary: The current mouse position in pixel coordinates. (Read Only)
member.remarks: The bottom-left of the screen or window is at (0, 0). The top-right of the screen or window is at (Screen.width, Screen.height).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.multiTouchEnabled
member.summary: Property indicating whether the system handles multiple touches.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Input.ResetInputAxes
member.summary: Resets all input. After ResetInputAxes all axes return to 0 and all buttons return to 0 for one frame.
member.remarks: This can be useful when respawning the player and you don't want any input from keys that might still be held down.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.touchCount
member.summary: Number of touches. Guaranteed not to change throughout the frame. (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Input.touches
member.summary: Returns list of objects representing status of all touches during last frame. (Read Only) (Allocates temporary variables).
member.remarks: Each entry represents a status of a finger touching the screen.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth
member.summary: The InteractiveCloth component is used to simulate objects with cloth physics.
member.remarks: This is used together with the ClothRenderer component to visualize cloth objects in the scene.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.AddForceAtPosition(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Adds force force to all vertices of the cloth mesh which are with radius distance of position.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.AddForceAtPosition(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,UnityEngine.ForceMode)
member.summary: Adds force force to all vertices of the cloth mesh which are with radius distance of position.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.attachmentResponse
member.summary: How much force will be applied to attached rigidbodies?
member.remarks: The higher this value is, the greater the forces applied to attached rigidbodies are. It is recommended to start out with small values (like 0.2) for best results. Only has an affect for rigid bodies which have been attached with the twoWayInteraction parameter set. See Also: AttachToCollider function.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.attachmentTearFactor
member.summary: How far attached rigid bodies need to be stretched, before they will tear off.
member.remarks: Must be larger then zero. Larger values make the cloth stretch further without tearing. Only has an affect for rigid bodies which have been attached with the tearable parameter set. See Also: AttachToCollider function.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.AttachToCollider(UnityEngine.Collider)
member.summary: Attaches a collider to the cloth object.
member.remarks: Only has an effect if some vertices of the cloth are intersecting the collider. These vertices will then become static in their position with respect to the collider. If tearable is true, attachments can tear of, depending on the value of attachmentTearFactor. If twoWayInteraction is true, the cloth will apply forces back to the attached rigidbody, depending on the value of attachmentResponse. See Also: DetachFromCollider function.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.AttachToCollider(UnityEngine.Collider,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Attaches a collider to the cloth object.
member.remarks: Only has an effect if some vertices of the cloth are intersecting the collider. These vertices will then become static in their position with respect to the collider. If tearable is true, attachments can tear of, depending on the value of attachmentTearFactor. If twoWayInteraction is true, the cloth will apply forces back to the attached rigidbody, depending on the value of attachmentResponse. See Also: DetachFromCollider function.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.AttachToCollider(UnityEngine.Collider,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Attaches a collider to the cloth object.
member.remarks: Only has an effect if some vertices of the cloth are intersecting the collider. These vertices will then become static in their position with respect to the collider. If tearable is true, attachments can tear of, depending on the value of attachmentTearFactor. If twoWayInteraction is true, the cloth will apply forces back to the attached rigidbody, depending on the value of attachmentResponse. See Also: DetachFromCollider function.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.collisionResponse
member.summary: How much force will be applied to colliding rigidbodies?
member.remarks: If this is greater then zero, interaction of the cloth with colliding rigidbodies is enabled. The higher this value is, the greater the forces applied to rigidbodies are. It is recommended to start out with small values (like 0.2) for best results.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.density
member.remarks: This sets the mass of the cloth per area. Must be greater than zero. Changing this property causes the cloth simulation to reset.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.DetachFromCollider(UnityEngine.Collider)
member.summary: Detaches a collider from the cloth object.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.friction
member.remarks: Must be between zero and one.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.mesh
member.summary: The mesh used as base for the cloth object.
member.remarks: Changing this property causes the cloth simulation to reset. For best performance, pick a mesh which does not have UV or color seams (ie, duplicated vertices with the same position but two or more texture coordinates or color values), as this requires some additional vertex mapping to be performed when rendering the results of the cloth simulation.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.pressure
member.remarks: Pressure simulation only gives reasonable results for closed mesh shapes. Pressure simulation is disabled when this value is set to zero. When it is set to values greater then zero, the cloth is simulated to be a closed shape containing air. A value of 1 sets the air pressure to be the same as the atmosphere outside the cloth mesh. Values smaller then one make the cloth shape contract, values larger then one make it expand.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.InteractiveCloth.tearFactor
member.summary: How far cloth vertices need to be stretched, before the cloth will tear.
member.remarks: If this is set to zero, tearing is disabled. For values greater than zero, larger values make the cloth stretch further without tearing. This property can be changed dynamically, but turning it on or off completely (by setting it to zero or non-zero), will cause the cloth simulation to reset. See Also: isTeared variable.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.iOSActivityIndicatorStyle.Gray
member.summary: The standard gray style of indicator (UIActivityIndicatorViewStyleGray).

member.name: F:UnityEngine.iOSActivityIndicatorStyle.White
member.summary: The standard white style of indicator (UIActivityIndicatorViewStyleWhite).

member.name: F:UnityEngine.iOSActivityIndicatorStyle.WhiteLarge
member.summary: The large white style of indicator (UIActivityIndicatorViewStyleWhiteLarge).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.iPhone.generation
member.summary: The generation of the device. (Read Only)
member.remarks: See iPhoneGeneration enumeration for possible return values.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.iPhone.ResetNoBackupFlag(System.String)
member.summary: Reset "no backup" file flag: file will be synced with iCloud/iTunes backup and can be deleted by OS in low storage situations.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.iPhone.SetNoBackupFlag(System.String)
member.summary: Set file flag to be excluded from iCloud/iTunes backup.
member.remarks: As a side-effect, if it was located in Caches folder, it won't be deleted by OS.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Joint
member.summary: Joint is the base class for all joints.
member.remarks: See Also: CharacterJoint, HingeJoint, SpringJoint, FixedJoint, ConfigurableJoint.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Joint.anchor
member.summary: The Position of the anchor around which the joints motion is constrained.
member.remarks: The Position is defined in local space.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Joint.autoConfigureConnectedAnchor
member.summary: Should the connectedAnchor be calculated automatically?
member.remarks: If this is enabled, then the connectedAnchor property will be calculated automatically to match the global position of the anchor property. This is the default behavior. If this is disabled, you can configure the position of the connected anchor using the connectedAnchor property.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Joint.axis
member.summary: The Direction of the axis around which the body is constrained.
member.remarks: The Axis is defined in local space.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Joint.breakForce
member.summary: The force that needs to be applied for this joint to break.
member.remarks: The force might come from collisions with other objects, forces applied with rigidbody.AddTorque or from other joints. See Also: Joint.OnJointBreak.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Joint.breakTorque
member.summary: The torque that needs to be applied for this joint to break.
member.remarks: The torque might come from collisions with other objects, forces applied with rigidbody.AddTorque or from other joints. See Also: Joint.OnJointBreak.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Joint.connectedAnchor
member.summary: Position of the anchor relative to the connected Rigidbody.
member.remarks: If /Joint.autoConfigureConnectedAnchor/ is not enabled, then this will be used to set the position of the anchor on the connected rigidbody. The position is given in local coordinates of the connected rigidbody, or in world coordinates if there is no connected rigidbody.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Joint.connectedBody
member.summary: A reference to another rigidbody this joint connects to.
member.remarks: If not set, the joint connects the object to the world.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Joint2D
member.summary: Parent class for joints to connect Rigidbody2D objects.
member.remarks: See Also: DistanceJoint2D class, HingeJoint2D class, SliderJoint2D class, SpringJoint2D class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Joint2D.collideConnected
member.summary: Can the joint collide with the other Rigidbody2D object to which it is attached?

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Joint2D.connectedBody
member.summary: The Rigidbody2D object to which the other end of the joint is attached (ie, the object without the joint component).
member.remarks: If this property is set to null then the joint attaches to a fixed point in space rather than another Rigidbody2D. See Also: Rigidbody2D class, collideConnected.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.JointAngleLimits2D
member.summary: Angular limits on the rotation of a Rigidbody2D object around a HingeJoint2D.
member.remarks: See Also: Rigidbody2D class, HingeJoint2D class.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.JointDrive
member.summary: How the joint's movement will behave along its local X axis.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointDrive.maximumForce
member.summary: Amount of force applied to push the object toward the defined direction.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointDrive.mode
member.summary: Whether the drive should attempt to reach position, velocity, both or nothing.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointDrive.positionDamper
member.summary: Resistance strength against the Position Spring. Only used if mode includes Position.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointDrive.positionSpring
member.summary: Strength of a rubber-band pull toward the defined direction. Only used if mode includes Position.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.JointDriveMode
member.summary: The ConfigurableJoint attempts to attain position / velocity targets based on this flag.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.JointDriveMode.None
member.summary: Don't apply any forces to reach the target.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.JointDriveMode.Position
member.summary: Try to reach the specified target position.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.JointDriveMode.PositionAndVelocity
member.summary: Try to reach the specified target position and velocity.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.JointDriveMode.Velocity
member.summary: Try to reach the specified target velocity.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.JointLimits
member.summary: JointLimits is used by the HingeJoint to limit the joints angle.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointLimits.max
member.summary: The upper limit of the joint.
member.remarks: When the joint angle or position is above it, the joint will excert forces to constrain it.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointLimits.maxBounce
member.summary: The bounciness of the joint when hitting the upper limit of the joint.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointLimits.min
member.summary: The lower limit of the joint.
member.remarks: When the joint angle or position is below it, the joint will excert forces to constrain it.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointLimits.minBounce
member.summary: The bounciness of the joint when hitting the lower limit of the joint.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.JointMotor
member.summary: The JointMotor is used to motorize a joint.
member.remarks: For example the HingeJoint can be told to rotate at a given speed and force. The joint will then attempt to reach the velocity with the given maximum force. See Also: HingeJoint.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointMotor.force
member.summary: The motor will apply a force.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointMotor.freeSpin
member.summary: If freeSpin is enabled the motor will only accelerate but never slow down.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointMotor.targetVelocity
member.summary: The motor will apply a force up to force to achieve targetVelocity.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.JointMotor2D
member.summary: Parameters for the optional motor force applied to a Joint2D.
member.remarks: See Also: HingeJoint2D class, SliderJoint class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointMotor2D.maxMotorTorque
member.summary: The maximum force that can be applied to the Rigidbody2D at the joint to attain the target speed.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointMotor2D.motorSpeed
member.summary: The desired speed for the Rigidbody2D to reach as it moves with the joint.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.JointProjectionMode
member.summary: Determines how to snap physics joints back to its constrained position when it drifts off too much.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.JointSpring
member.summary: JointSpring is used add a spring force to HingeJoint and PhysicMaterial.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.JointSpring.damper
member.summary: The damper force uses to dampen the spring.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.JointSpring.spring
member.summary: The spring forces used to reach the target position.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.JointSpring.targetPosition
member.summary: The target position the joint attempts to reach.
member.remarks: In the case of a HingeJoint the target position is the target angle in degrees.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.JointTranslationLimits2D
member.summary: Motion limits of a Rigidbody2D object along a SliderJoint2D.
member.remarks: See Also: Rigidbody2D class, SliderJoint2D class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointTranslationLimits2D.max
member.summary: Maximum distance the Rigidbody2D object can move from the Slider Joint's anchor.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.JointTranslationLimits2D.min
member.summary: Minimum distance the Rigidbody2D object can move from the Slider Joint's anchor.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.KeyCode
member.summary: Key codes returned by Event.keyCode. These map directly to a physical key on the keyboard.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.KeyCode.Alpha0
member.summary: The '0' key on the top of the alphanumeric keyboard.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.KeyCode.Alpha1
member.summary: The '1' key on the top of the alphanumeric keyboard.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.KeyCode.Alpha2
member.summary: The '2' key on the top of the alphanumeric keyboard.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.KeyCode.Alpha3
member.summary: The '3' key on the top of the alphanumeric keyboard.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.KeyCode.Alpha4
member.summary: The '4' key on the top of the alphanumeric keyboard.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.KeyCode.Alpha5
member.summary: The '5' key on the top of the alphanumeric keyboard.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.KeyCode.Alpha6
member.summary: The '6' key on the top of the alphanumeric keyboard.

member.summary: The '7' key on the top of the alphanumeric keyboard.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.KeyCode.None

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Keyframe
member.summary: A single keyframe that can be injected into an animation curve.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Keyframe.inTangent
member.summary: Describes the tangent when approaching this point from the previous point in the curve.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Keyframe.outTangent
member.summary: Describes the tangent when leaving this point towards the next point in the curve.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Keyframe.time
member.remarks: In a 2D graph you could think of this as the x-value. See Also: value.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Keyframe.value
member.summary: The value of the curve at keyframe.
member.remarks: In a 2D graph you could think of this as the y-value. See Also: time.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.LayerMask
member.summary: LayerMask allow you to display the LayerMask popup menu in the inspector.
member.remarks: Similar to those in the camera.cullingMask. Layer masks can be used selectively filter GameObjects for example when casting rays.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.LayerMask.LayerToName(System.Int32)
member.summary: Given a layer number, returns the name of the layer as defined in either a Builtin or a User Layer in the Tag Manager.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.LayerMask.NameToLayer(System.String)
member.summary: Given a layer name, returns the layer index as defined by either a Builtin or a User Layer in the Tag Manager.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LayerMask.value
member.summary: Converts a layer mask value to an integer value.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.LensFlare
member.summary: Script interface for a Lens flare component.
member.remarks: This allows you to change the brightness and color of lens flares at runtime.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LensFlare.brightness
member.remarks: This controls the size and brightness of the flare elements. See Also: Lens flare component, flare assets.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LensFlare.color
member.remarks: This controls the color of some flare elements (the ones that have use light color enabled). See Also: Lens flare component, flare assets.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LensFlare.fadeSpeed
member.summary: The fade speed of the flare.
member.remarks: See Also: Lens flare component, flare assets.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LensFlare.flare
member.remarks: See Also: Lens flare component, flare assets.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Light
member.remarks: Use this to control all aspects of Unity's lights. The properties are an exact match for the values shown in the Inspector. Usually lights are just created in the editor but sometimes you want to create a light from a script:

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.alreadyLightmapped
member.summary: Has the light already been lightmapped.
member.remarks: When manually assembling a lightmapped scene set this property appropriately, so that the light doesn't affect lightmapped objects twice, but at the same time affects dynamic objects. See Also: Light component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.areaSize
member.summary: The size of the area light. Editor only.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.color
member.remarks: To modify the light intensity you change light's color luminance. Lights always add illumination, so a light with a black color is the same as no light at all. See Also: Light component .Another example:

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.cookie
member.summary: The cookie texture projected by the light.
member.remarks: If the cookie is a cube map, the light will become a Point light. Note that cookies are only displayed for pixel lights. See Also: Light component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.cookieSize
member.summary: The size of a directional light's cookie.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.cullingMask
member.summary: This is used to light certain objects in the scene selectively.
member.remarks: A GameObject will only be illuminated by a light if that light's cullingMask includes the layer chosen for the GameObject (ie, the mask bit for the layer must be set to 1 for the object to receive any light). See Layers for more information about layer masking. See Also: Light component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.flare
member.summary: The flare asset to use for this light.
member.remarks: See Also: LensFlare.flare, Light component and flare asset.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.intensity
member.summary: The Intensity of a light is multiplied with the Light color.
member.remarks: The value can be between 0 and 8. This allows you to create over bright lights.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.renderMode
member.remarks: This can be LightRenderMode.Auto, LightRenderMode.ForceVertex or LightRenderMode.ForcePixel. Pixel lights render slower but look better, especially on not very highly tesselated geometry. Some effects (e.g. bumpmapping) are only displayed for pixel lights. See Also: Light component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.shadows
member.remarks: See Also: LightShadows, shadowStrength property, Renderer.castShadows, Renderer.receiveShadows.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.shadowSoftness
member.summary: Softness of directional light's soft shadows.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.shadowSoftnessFade
member.summary: Fadeout speed of directional light's soft shadows.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.shadowStrength
member.remarks: See Also: shadows property, Renderer.castShadows, Renderer.receiveShadows.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.spotAngle
member.summary: The angle of the light's spotlight cone in degrees.
member.remarks: This is used primarily for Spot lights and has no effect for Point lights See Also: Light component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Light.type
member.remarks: Can be LightType.Spot, LightType.Directional, LightType.Point.See Also: Light component.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.LightmapData
member.remarks: A scene can have several lightmaps stored in it, and Renderer components can use those lightmaps. This makes it possible to use the same material on multiple objects, while each object can refer to a different lightmap or different portion of the same lightmap. See Also: LightmapSettings class, Renderer.lightmapIndex property.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LightmapData.lightmapFar
member.summary: Lightmap storing the full incoming light.
member.remarks: See Also: LightmapSettings class, Renderer.lightmapIndex property.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LightmapData.lightmapNear
member.summary: Lightmap storing only the indirect incoming light.
member.remarks: See Also: LightmapSettings class, Renderer.lightmapIndex property.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.LightmapSettings
member.remarks: A scene can have several lightmaps stored in it, and Renderer components can use those lightmaps. This makes it possible to use the same material on multiple objects, while each object can refer to a different lightmap or different portion of the same lightmap. See Also: LightmapData class, Renderer.lightmapIndex property.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LightmapSettings.lightmaps
member.remarks: See Also: LightmapData class, Renderer.lightmapIndex property.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LightmapSettings.lightmapsMode
member.summary: Single, Dual or Directional lightmaps rendering mode.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LightmapSettings.lightProbes
member.summary: Holds all data needed by the light probes.
member.remarks: It can be swapped to a different pre-baked one at runtime.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.LightmapsMode
member.summary: Single, dual, or directional lightmaps rendering mode.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LightProbeGroup.probePositions
member.summary: Editor only function to access and modify probe positions.
member.remarks: Probe positions are specified in local space relative to the parent object. At runtime this function will return an empty Vector3 array and setting it will have no effect.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.LightProbes
member.summary: Stores light probes for the scene.
member.remarks: The baked data includes: probe positions, SH coefficients and the tetrahedral tesselation. You can modify the coefficients at runtime. You can also swap the entire LightProbes object to a different pre-baked one using LightmapSettings.lightProbes. See Also: LightmapSettings class, Renderer.useLightProbes property.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LightProbes.cellCount
member.summary: The number of cells (tetrahedra + outer cells) the space is divided to.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LightProbes.coefficients
member.summary: Coefficients of the baked light probes. The coefficients represent a 3-band RGB spherical harmonics probe, with a total of 27 floats per light probe, laid out: rgbrgbrgb...

member.name: M:UnityEngine.LightProbes.GetInterpolatedLightProbe(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Renderer,System.Single[])
member.summary: Returns spherical harmonics coefficients of a light probe at the given position. The light probe is interpolated from the light probes baked.
member.remarks: For the scene. The coefficients represent a 3-band RGB spherical harmonics probe, with a total of 27 floats laid out: rgbrgbrgb... Renderer is only needed to speed up the search for the current tetrahedron, as it caches the index of the tetrahedron it was in the last frame.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LightProbes.positions

member.name: T:UnityEngine.LocalNotification
member.summary: LocalNotification is a wrapper around the UILocalNotification class found in the Apple UIKit framework and is only available on iPhoneiPadiPod Touch.
member.remarks: It represents notifications that an application can schedule for presentation to its user at specific dates and times. The operating system is responsible for delivering the notification at the specified time. Local notifications are similar to remote notifications but are scheduled and delivered locally and do not require connection with remote servers. Local notifications are scheduled and handled using NotificationServices class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LocationService.isEnabledByUser
member.summary: Specifies whether location service is enabled in user settings.
member.remarks: You should check this property before starting location updates to determine if the user has location services enabled for the current device. On iOS, if this property is false and you start location updates anyway, the CoreLocation framework prompts the user with a confirmation panel asking whether location services should be reenabled. The user can enable or disable location services altogether from the Settings application by toggling the switch in Settings>General>LocationServices.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.LocationService.lastData
member.remarks: Before accessing this property, make sure location service was started via Input.location.Start().

member.name: M:UnityEngine.LocationService.Start
member.summary: Starts location service updates. Last location coordinates could be.
member.remarks: Retrieved via Input.location.lastData. Service does not start to send location data immediately. Code should check Input.location.status for current service status. desiredAccuracyInMeters - desired service accuracy in meters. Using higher value like 500 usually does not require to turn GPS chip on and thus saves battery power. Values like 5-10 could be used for getting best accuracy. Default value is 10 meters. updateDistanceInMeters - the minimum distance (measured in meters) a device must move laterally before Input.location property is updated. Higher values like 500 imply less overhead. Default is 10 meters.

Higher values like 500 imply less overhead. Default is 10 meters.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.MasterServer
member.summary: The Master Server is used to make matchmaking between servers and clients easy.
member.remarks: You can advertise game hosts or fetch host lists for you game type. The functions here are used to communicate with the Master Server itself which resides on a separate server. If necessary the server itself can be customized. For an overview of the Master Server as well as a technical description see the Master Server manual page.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MasterServer.ClearHostList
member.summary: Clear the host list which was received by MasterServer.PollHostList.
member.remarks: Useful if you want to update the list and want to make sure you don't use the older data.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MasterServer.dedicatedServer
member.summary: Report this machine as a dedicated server.
member.remarks: If running as a server the connection count defines the player count and this is reported when registering on the master server. By default the master server assumes this instance is not a dedicated server and thus the player count is incremented by one (to account for the \"client\" running on the server). If this is not desired this variable can be set to false and then only the connection count is reported in the host data as the player count.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MasterServer.ipAddress
member.summary: The IP address of the master server.
member.remarks: By default this is a server run by Unity Technologies.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MasterServer.PollHostList
member.summary: Check for the latest host list received by using MasterServer.RequestHostList.
member.remarks: You can clear the current host list with MasterServer.ClearHostList. That way you can be sure that the list returned by is up to date.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MasterServer.port
member.summary: The connection port of the master server.
member.remarks: By default this is a server run by Unity Technologies.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MasterServer.RegisterHost(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Register this server on the master server.
member.remarks: If the master server address information has not been changed the default Unity master server will be used.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MasterServer.RegisterHost(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Register this server on the master server.
member.remarks: If the master server address information has not been changed the default Unity master server will be used.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MasterServer.RequestHostList(System.String)
member.summary: Request a host list from the master server.
member.remarks: The list is available through MasterServer.PollHostList when it has arrived.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MasterServer.UnregisterHost
member.summary: Unregister this server from the master server.
member.remarks: Does nothing if the server is not registered or has already unregistered.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MasterServer.updateRate
member.summary: Set the minimum update rate for master server host information update.
member.remarks: Normally host updates are only sent if something in the host information has changed (like connected players). The update rate defines the minimum amount of time which may elapse between host updates. The default value is 60 seconds minimum update rate (where a check is made for changes). So if one host update is sent and then some field changes 10 seconds later then the update will possibly sent 50 seconds later (at the next change check). If this is set to 0 then no updates are sent, only initial registration information.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.MasterServerEvent
member.summary: Describes status messages from the master server as returned in OnMasterServerEvent.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.MasterServerEvent.HostListReceived
member.summary: Received a host list from the master server.

member.summary: Registration failed because an empty game name was given.

member.summary: Registration failed because no server is running.

member.summary: Registration to master server succeeded, received confirmation.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Material
member.remarks: This class exposes all properties from a material, allowing you to animate them. You can also use it to set custom shader properties that can't be accessed through the inspector (e.g. matrices). In order to get the material used by an object, use the Renderer.material property: See Also: Materials, ShaderLab documentation.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Material.GetColor(System.Int32)
member.remarks: Many shaders use more than one color. Use GetColor to get the propertyName color. Common color names used by Unity's builtin shaders: "_Color" is the main color of a material. This can also be accessed via color property. "_SpecColor" is the specular color of a material (used in specular glossy vertexlit shaders). "_Emission" is the emissive color of a material (used in vertexlit shaders). "_ReflectColor" is the reflection color of the material (used in reflective shaders). See Also: color property, SetColor, Shader.PropertyToID.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Material.GetColor(System.String)
member.remarks: Many shaders use more than one color. Use GetColor to get the propertyName color. Common color names used by Unity's builtin shaders: "_Color" is the main color of a material. This can also be accessed via color property. "_SpecColor" is the specular color of a material (used in specular glossy vertexlit shaders). "_Emission" is the emissive color of a material (used in vertexlit shaders). "_ReflectColor" is the reflection color of the material (used in reflective shaders). See Also: color property, SetColor, Shader.PropertyToID.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Material.GetMatrix(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a named matrix value from the shader.
member.remarks: This is mostly used with custom shaders that need extra matrix parameters. Matrix parameters are not exposed in the material inspector, but can be set and queried with SetMatrix and GetMatrix from scripts. See Also: SetMatrix, Materials, ShaderLab documentation, Shader.PropertyToID.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Material.GetMatrix(System.String)
member.summary: Get a named matrix value from the shader.
member.remarks: This is mostly used with custom shaders that need extra matrix parameters. Matrix parameters are not exposed in the material inspector, but can be set and queried with SetMatrix and GetMatrix from scripts. See Also: SetMatrix, Materials, ShaderLab documentation, Shader.PropertyToID.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Material.GetTag(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Get the value of material's shader tag.
member.remarks: If the material's shader does not define the tag, defaultValue is returned. If searchFallbacks is true then this function will look for tag in all subshaders and all fallbacks. If seachFallbacks is false then only the currently used subshader will be queried for the tag. Using GetTag without searching through fallbacks makes it possible to detect which subshader is currently being used: add a custom tag to each subshader with different value, and query the value at run time. For example, Unity Pro's water uses this function to detect when the shader falls back to non-reflective one, and turns off reflection camera in that case.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Material.GetTag(System.String,System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Get the value of material's shader tag.
member.remarks: If the material's shader does not define the tag, defaultValue is returned. If searchFallbacks is true then this function will look for tag in all subshaders and all fallbacks. If seachFallbacks is false then only the currently used subshader will be queried for the tag. Using GetTag without searching through fallbacks makes it possible to detect which subshader is currently being used: add a custom tag to each subshader with different value, and query the value at run time. For example, Unity Pro's water uses this function to detect when the shader falls back to non-reflective one, and turns off reflection camera in that case.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Material.GetTexture(System.Int32)
member.remarks: Many shaders use more than one texture. Use GetTexture to get the propertyName texture. Common texture names used by Unity's builtin shaders: "_MainTex" is the main diffuse texture. This can also be accessed via mainTexture property. "_BumpMap" is the normal map. "_Cube" is the reflection cubemap. See Also: mainTexture property, SetTexture, Shader.PropertyToID.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Material.Lerp(UnityEngine.Material,UnityEngine.Material,System.Single)
member.remarks: Makes all color and float values of a material be interpolated from start to end, based on t. When t is 0, all values are taken from start. When t is 1, all values are taken from end. Most often you want the materials that are interpolated between to be the same (use the same shaders and textures) except for colors and floats. Then you use Lerp to blend between them. See Also: Materials.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Material.passCount
member.summary: How many passes are in this material (Read Only).
member.remarks: This is mostly used in direct drawing code using GL class. For example, Image Effects use materials for implementing screen post-processing. For each pass in the material they activate the pass (see SetPass ) and draw a fullscreen quad. Here is an example of a full image effect that inverts the colors. Add this script to the camera and see it in play mode.See Also: SetPass function, GL class, ShaderLab documentation.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Material.renderQueue
member.remarks: By default materials use render queue of the shader it uses. You can override the render queue used using this variable. Note that once render queue is set on the material, it stays at that value, even if shader is later changed to be different. Render queue number should be positive to work properly. See Also: Shader.renderQueue, RenderQueue tag.

"_Emission" is the emissive color of a material (used in vertexlit shaders). "_ReflectColor" is the reflection color of the material (used in reflective shaders). See Also: color property, GetColor, Shader.PropertyToID.

"_Emission" is the emissive color of a material (used in vertexlit shaders). "_ReflectColor" is the reflection color of the material (used in reflective shaders). member.name: M:UnityEngine.Material.SetPass(System.Int32)
member.summary: Activate the given pass for rendering.
member.remarks: Pass indices start from zero and go up to (but not including) passCount. This is mostly used in direct drawing code using GL class. For example, Image Effects use materials for implementing screen post-processing. For each pass in the material they activate the pass and draw a fullscreen quad. If SetPass returns false, you should not render anything. Here is an example of a full image effect that inverts the colors. Add this script to the camera and see it in play mode.See Also: passCount property, GL class, ShaderLab documentation.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.MaterialPropertyBlock
member.summary: A block of material values to apply.
member.remarks: MaterialPropertyBlock is used by Graphics.DrawMesh and Renderer.SetPropertyBlock. Use it in situations where you want to draw multiple objects with the same material, but slightly different properties. For example, if you want to slightly change the color of each mesh drawn. Unity's terrain engine uses MaterialPropertyBlock to draw trees; all of them use the same material, but each tree has different color, scale & wind factor. The block passed to Graphics.DrawMesh or Renderer.SetPropertyBlock is copied, so the most efficient way of using it is to create one block and reuse it for all DrawMesh calls. Use Clear to clear block's values, and AddFloat, AddVector, AddColor, AddMatrix to add values. See Also: Graphics.DrawMesh, Material.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mathf.PerlinNoise(System.Single,System.Single)
member.remarks: Perlin noise is a pseudo-random pattern of float values generated across a 2D plane (although the technique does generalise to three or more dimensions, this is not implemented in Unity). The noise does not contain a completely random value at each point but rather consists of "waves" whose values gradually increase and decrease across the pattern. The noise can be used as the basis for texture effects but also for animation, generating terrain heightmaps and many other things.Although the noise plane is two-dimensional, it is easy to use just a single one-dimensional line through the pattern, say for animation effects.

member.summary: Loops the value t, so that it is never larger than length and never smaller than 0.
member.remarks: This is similar to the modulo operator but it works with floating point numbers. For example, using 3.0 for t and 2.5 for length, the result would be 0.5. With t = 5 and length = 2.5, the result would be 0.0. Note, however, that the behaviour is not defined for negative numbers as it is for the modulo operator.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4
member.remarks: A transformation matrix can perform arbitrary linear 3D transformations (i.e. translation, rotation, scale, shear etc.) and perspective transformations using homogenous coordinates. You rarely use matrices in scripts; most often using Vector3 s, Quaternion s and functionality of Transform class is more straightforward. Plain matrices are used in special cases like setting up nonstandard camera projection. Consult any graphics textbook for in depth explanation of transformation matrices. In Unity, Matrix4x4 is used by several Transform, Camera, Material and GL functions. Matrices in unity are column major. Data is accessed as: row + (column*4). Matrices can be indexed like 2D arrays but in an expression like mat[a, b], a refers to the row index, while b refers to the column index (note that this is the opposite way round to Cartesian coordinates).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4.GetColumn(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a column of the matrix.
member.remarks: The i-th column is returned as a Vector4. i must be from 0 to 3 inclusive. See Also: SetColumn.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4.GetRow(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a row of the matrix.
member.remarks: The i-th row is returned as a Vector4. i must be from 0 to 3 inclusive. See Also: SetRow.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4.identity
member.remarks: This is a matrix that effectively does nothing when applied. It has 1s in the main diagonal and 0s in all other elements:See Also: zero variable.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4.inverse
member.summary: The inverse of this matrix (Read Only).
member.remarks: Inverted matrix is such that if multiplied by the original would result in identity matrix. If some matrix transforms vectors in a particular way, then the inverse matrix can transform them back. For example, Transform's worldToLocalMatrix and localToWorldMatrix are inverses of each other.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4.Inverse(UnityEngine.Matrix4x4)
member.summary: The inverse of this matrix (Read Only).
member.remarks: Inverted matrix is such that if multiplied by the original would result in identity matrix. If some matrix transforms vectors in a particular way, then the inverse matrix can transform them back. For example, Transform's worldToLocalMatrix and localToWorldMatrix are inverses of each other.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4.MultiplyPoint(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Transforms a position by this matrix (generic).
member.remarks: Returns a position v transformed by the current fully arbitrary matrix. If the matrix is a regular 3D transformation matrix, it is much faster to use MultiplyPoint3x4 instead. MultiplyPoint is slower, but can handle projective transformations as well. See Also: MultiplyPoint3x4, MultiplyVector.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4.MultiplyPoint3x4(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Transforms a position by this matrix (fast).
member.remarks: Returns a position v transformed by the current transformation matrix. This function is a faster version of MultiplyPoint ; but it can only handle regular 3D transformations. MultiplyPoint is slower, but can handle projective transformations as well. See Also: MultiplyPoint, MultiplyVector.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4.MultiplyVector(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Transforms a direction by this matrix.
member.remarks: This function is similar to MultiplyPoint ; but it transforms directions and not positions. When transforming a direction, only the rotation part of the matrix is taken into account. See Also: MultiplyPoint, MultiplyPoint3x4.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4.Ortho(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.remarks: The returned matrix is such that views left to right, bottom to top area, with zNear and zFar depth clipping planes. If you want to use orthogonal for pixel-correct rendering, it is better to use GL.LoadPixelMatrix, as that would apply proper half-texel offsets for Direct3D renderer. See Also: GL.LoadPixelMatrix, GL.LoadProjectionMatrix, GUI.matrix.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4.Perspective(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.remarks: fov is the vertical field-of-view in degrees of the perspective matrix, aspect is the aspect ratio (width divided by height). zNear and zFar set up the depth clipping planes. See Also: GL.LoadPixelMatrix, GL.LoadProjectionMatrix, GUI.matrix.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Matrix4x4.Scale(UnityEngine.Vector3)
