member.name: T:UnityEngine.Mesh
member.summary: A class that allows creating or modifying meshes from scripts.
member.remarks: Meshes contain vertices and multiple triangle arrays. See the Procedural example project for examples of using the mesh interface. The triangle arrays are simply indices into the vertex arrays; three indices for each triangle. For every vertex there can be a normal, two texture coordinates, color and tangent. These are optional though and can be removed at will. All vertex information is stored in separate arrays of the same size, so if your mesh has 10 vertices, you would also have 10-size arrays for normals and other attributes. There are probably 3 things you might want to use the modifyable mesh interface for: 1. Building a mesh from scratch : should always be done in the following order: 1) assign vertices 2) assign triangles .2. Modifying vertex attributes every frame : 1) get vertices, 2) modify them, 3) assign them back to the mesh.3. Continously changing the mesh triangles and vertices : 1) call Clear to start fresh, 2) assign vertices and other attributes, 3) assign triangle indices. It is important to call Clear before assigning new vertices or triangles. Unity always checks the supplied triangle indices whether they don't reference out of bounds vertices. Calling Clear then assigning vertices then triangles makes sure you never have out of bounds data.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.bindposes
member.summary: The bind poses. The bind pose at each index refers to the bone with the same index.
member.remarks: The bind pose is the inverse of inverse transformation matrix of the bone, when the bone is in the bind pose.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.blendShapeCount
member.summary: Returns BlendShape count on this mesh.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.boneWeights
member.summary: The bone weights of each vertex.
member.remarks: The size of the array is either the same as vertexCount or empty. Each vertex can be affected by up to 4 different bones. All 4 bone weights should sum up to 1.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.bounds
member.summary: The bounding volume of the mesh.
member.remarks: This is the axis-aligned bounding box of the mesh in its local space (that is, not affected by the transform). See also Renderer.bounds property that returns bounds in world space. See Also: Bounds class, Renderer.bounds property.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.Clear
member.summary: Clears all vertex data and all triangle indices.
member.remarks: You should call this function before rebuilding triangles array.Default behaviour of this function keeps the existing vertex layout: if the mesh had tangent vectors and vertex colors, for example, then the tangents and colors will be part of mesh data once you fill in new vertex data. If you want to completely clear the mesh and start with an empty vertex layout, pass false for keepVertexLayout parameter. Alternatively, assigning an empty array to any mesh component will also remove it from the vertex layout.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.Clear(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Clears all vertex data and all triangle indices.
member.remarks: You should call this function before rebuilding triangles array.Default behaviour of this function keeps the existing vertex layout: if the mesh had tangent vectors and vertex colors, for example, then the tangents and colors will be part of mesh data once you fill in new vertex data. If you want to completely clear the mesh and start with an empty vertex layout, pass false for keepVertexLayout parameter. Alternatively, assigning an empty array to any mesh component will also remove it from the vertex layout.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.colors
member.remarks: If no vertex colors are available an empty array will be returned.For performance reasons, consider using colors32 instead. This will avoid byte-to-float conversions in colors, as well as use less temporary memory.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.colors32
member.remarks: Same as colors, except using Color32 structure which is better for performance.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.CombineMeshes(UnityEngine.CombineInstance[])
member.summary: Combines several meshes into this mesh.
member.remarks: Combining meshes is useful for performance optimization. If mergeSubMeshes is true, all the meshes will be combined to a single submesh. Otherwise each mesh will go into a different submesh. If all meshes share the same material, set this to true. If useMatrices is false, the transform matrices in CombineInstance structs will be ignored.
member.param: Descriptions of the meshes to combine.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.CombineMeshes(UnityEngine.CombineInstance[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Combines several meshes into this mesh.
member.remarks: Combining meshes is useful for performance optimization. If mergeSubMeshes is true, all the meshes will be combined to a single submesh. Otherwise each mesh will go into a different submesh. If all meshes share the same material, set this to true. If useMatrices is false, the transform matrices in CombineInstance structs will be ignored.
member.param: Descriptions of the meshes to combine.
Should all meshes be combined into a single submesh?

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.CombineMeshes(UnityEngine.CombineInstance[],System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Combines several meshes into this mesh.
member.remarks: Combining meshes is useful for performance optimization. If mergeSubMeshes is true, all the meshes will be combined to a single submesh. Otherwise each mesh will go into a different submesh. If all meshes share the same material, set this to true. If useMatrices is false, the transform matrices in CombineInstance structs will be ignored.
member.param: Descriptions of the meshes to combine.
Should all meshes be combined into a single submesh?
Should the transforms supplied in the CombineInstance array be used or ignored?

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.GetBlendShapeName(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns name of BlendShape by given index.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.GetIndices(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the index buffer for the submesh.
member.remarks: The layout of indices depends on the topology of a submesh, for example for triangular mesh each triangle will result in three indices. See Also: subMeshCount, GetTopology, MeshTopology enum.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.GetTopology(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the topology of a submesh.
member.remarks: See Also: MeshTopology enum, SetIndices function.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.GetTriangles(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the triangle list for the submesh.
member.remarks: A submesh is simply a separate triangle list. When the mesh renderer uses multiple materials, you should ensure that there are as many submeshes as materials. See Also: subMeshCount.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.isReadable
member.summary: Returns state of the Read/Write Enabled checkbox when model was imported.
member.remarks: For a dynamic Mesh created from script, always returns true. Meshes not marked readable will throw an error on accessing any data arrays from script at runtime. Access is allowed in Unity's editor outside of the game and rendering loop.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.MarkDynamic
member.remarks: Call this before assigning vertices to get better performance when continually updating mesh.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.normals
member.remarks: If the mesh contains no normals an empty array will be returned.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.Optimize
member.remarks: This operation might take a while but will make the geometry displayed be faster. You should use it if you generate a mesh from scratch procedurally and you want to trade better runtime performance against higher load time. Internally it optimizes the triangles for vertex cache locality. For imported models you should never call this as the import pipeline already does it for you.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.RecalculateBounds
member.summary: Recalculate the bounding volume of the mesh from the vertices.
member.remarks: After modifying vertices you should call this function to ensure the bounding volume is correct. Assigning triangles will automatically Recalculate the bounding volume.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.RecalculateNormals
member.summary: Recalculates the normals of the mesh from the triangles and vertices.
member.remarks: After modifying the vertices it is often useful to update the normals to reflect the change. Normals are calculated from all shared vertices. Imported meshes sometimes don't share all vertices. For example a vertex at a uv seam will be split into two vertices. Thus the RecalculateNormals function will create normals that are not smooth at the uv seam. Also note that RecalculateNormals does not generate tangents automatically thus bumpmap shaders will not work with the mesh after calling RecalculateNormals. You can provide your own tangents however.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.SetIndices(System.Int32[],UnityEngine.MeshTopology,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the index buffer for the submesh.
member.remarks: A submesh is simply a separate indices array. When the mesh renderer uses multiple materials, you should ensure that there are as many submeshes as materials. SetTriangles and ::triangles always make the mesh be composed of triangles faces. Using SetIndices you can create a mesh that's made out of lines or points, see MeshTopology enum. See Also: subMeshCount, MeshTopology enum.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Mesh.SetTriangles(System.Int32[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the triangle list for the submesh.
member.remarks: A submesh is simply a separate triangle list. When the mesh renderer uses multiple materials, you should ensure that there are as many submeshes as materials. It is recommended to assign a the triangle array after assigning the vertex array in order to avoid out of bounds errors. See Also: subMeshCount.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.subMeshCount
member.summary: The number of submeshes. Every material has a separate triangle list.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.tangents
member.remarks: Tangents are mostly used in bump-mapped shaders. A tangent is a unit length vector that follows mesh surface along horizontal (U) texture direction. Tangents in Unity are represented as Vector4, with x,y,z components defining the vector, and w used to flip the binormal if needed. Unity calculates the other surface vector (binormal) by taking a cross product between normal and tangent, and multiplying result by tangent.w. Thus w should always be 1 or -1. You should calculate tangents yourself if you plan to use bump-mapped shaders on the mesh. Assign tangents after assigning normals or using RecalculateNormals.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.triangles
member.summary: An array containing all triangles in the mesh.
member.remarks: The array is a list of triangles that contains indices into the vertex array. The size of the triangle array must always be a multiple of 3. Vertices can be shared by simply indexing into the same vertex. If the mesh contains multiple sub meshes (materials) the triangle list will contain all triangles of all submeshes. When you assign triangle array, subMeshCount is set to 1. If you want to have multiple sub meshes, use subMeshCount and SetTriangles. It is recommended to assign a the triangle array after assigning the vertex array in order to avoid out of bounds errors.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.uv
member.summary: The base texture coordinates of the mesh.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.uv2
member.summary: The second texture coordinate set of the mesh, if present.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.vertexCount
member.summary: Returns the number of vertices in the mesh (Read Only).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Mesh.vertices
member.summary: Returns a copy of the vertex positions or assigns a new vertex positions array.
member.remarks: The number of vertices in the mesh is changed by assigning a vertex array with a different number of vertices. Note that if you resize the vertex array then all other vertex attributes (normals, colors, tangents, UVs) will be automatically resized too. RecalculateBounds will automatically be invoked if no vertices have been assigned to the mesh when setting the vertices.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.MeshCollider
member.summary: A mesh collider allows you to do collision detection between meshes and primitives.
member.remarks: See Also: BoxCollider, CapsuleCollider, PhysicMaterial, Rigidbody.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MeshCollider.convex
member.summary: Use a convex collider from the mesh.
member.remarks: This means that if you have this set to true, your mesh collider wont have Holes or entrances. Convex meshes can collide with other convex colliders and non-convex meshes. Thus convex mesh colliders are suitable on rigidibodies, if you really need more detailed colliders than what the primitive colliders provide you with.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MeshCollider.sharedMesh
member.summary: The mesh object used for collision detection.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MeshCollider.smoothSphereCollisions
member.summary: Uses interpolated normals for sphere collisions instead of flat polygonal normals.
member.remarks: This smoothes out bumps for sphere's rolling over smooth surfaces. The downside is that rolling over steep corners can behave really strangely and appears like it is pulling the sphere in some direction.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.MeshFilter
member.summary: A class to access the Mesh of the mesh filter.
member.remarks: Use this with a procedural mesh interface. See Also: Mesh class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MeshFilter.mesh
member.summary: Returns the instantiated Mesh assigned to the mesh filter.
member.remarks: If no mesh is assigned to the mesh filter a new mesh will be created and assigned. If a mesh is assigned to the mesh filter already, then first query of mesh property will create a duplicate of it, and this copy will be returned. Further queries of mesh property will return this duplicated mesh instance. If you want to avoid this automatic mesh duplication, use MeshFilter.sharedMesh instead. By using mesh property you can modify the mesh for a single object only. The other objects that used the same mesh will not be modified.See Also: Mesh class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MeshFilter.sharedMesh
member.summary: Returns the shared mesh of the mesh filter.
member.remarks: It is recommended to use this function only for reading mesh data and not for writing, since you might modify imported assets and all objects that use this mesh will be affected. Also, be aware that is not possible to undo the changes done to this mesh.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.MeshRenderer
member.summary: Renders meshes inserted by the MeshFilter or TextMesh.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.MeshTopology
member.remarks: Normally meshes are composed of triangles (three vertex indices per face), but in some cases you might want to render complex things that are made up from lines or points. Creating a Mesh with that topology and using it to render is usually the most efficient way. See Also: Mesh.SetIndices function.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.MeshTopology.Lines
member.remarks: Each two indices in the mesh index buffer form a line. See Also: Mesh.SetIndices function.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.MeshTopology.LineStrip
member.remarks: First two indices form a line, and then each new index connects a new vertex to the existing line strip. See Also: Mesh.SetIndices function.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.MeshTopology.Points
member.remarks: In most of use cases, mesh index buffer should be "indendity": 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, ... See Also: Mesh.SetIndices function.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.MeshTopology.Quads
member.remarks: Each four indices in the mesh index buffer form a quadrangular face. Note that quad topology is emulated on many platforms, so it's more efficient to use a triangular mesh. Unless you really need quads, for example if using DirectX 11 tessellation shaders that operate on quad patches. See Also: Mesh.SetIndices function.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.MeshTopology.Triangles
member.remarks: Each three indices in the mesh index buffer form a triangular face. See Also: Mesh.SetIndices function.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Microphone
member.summary: Use this class to record to an AudioClip using a connected microphone.
member.remarks: You can get a list of connected microphone(s) from the devices property and then use the Start and End functions to start or end a recording session using one of the available devices.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Microphone.devices
member.summary: A list of available microphone devices, identified by name.
member.remarks: You can use the name with the Start and End functions to specify which microphone you wish to start/stop recording.See Also: Start, End, IsRecording.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Microphone.End(System.String)
member.remarks: If you pass a null or empty string for the device name then the default microphone will be used. You can get a list of available microphone devices from the devices property.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Microphone.GetDeviceCaps(System.String,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Get the frequency capabilities of a device.
member.remarks: Passing null or an empty string for the device name will select the default device. You can use the devices property to get a list of all available microphones. When a value of zero is returned in the minFreq and maxFreq parameters, this indicates that the device supports any frequency.
member.param: Returns the minimum sampling frequency of the device.
Returns the maximum sampling frequency of the device.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Microphone.GetPosition(System.String)
member.summary: Get the position in samples of the recording.
member.remarks: If you pass a null or empty string for the device name then the default microphone will be used. You can get a list of available microphone devices from the devices property. You can use this to control latency. If you want a 30ms latency, poll getRecordPosition() until 30ms (in samples) has gone and then start the audio.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Microphone.IsRecording(System.String)
member.summary: Query if a device is currently recording.
member.remarks: If you pass a null or empty string for the device name then the default microphone will be used. You can get a list of available microphone devices from the devices property.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Microphone.Start(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.returns: The function returns null if the recording fails to start.
member.remarks: If you pass a null or empty string for the device name then the default microphone will be used. You can get a list of available microphone devices from the devices property. You can find the range of sample rates supported by a microphone using the GetDeviceCaps property. Note that if you want to use the Microphone class in the web player, you need to get the user's permission to do so. Call Application.RequestUserAuthorization before calling any Microphone methods.
member.param: Indicates whether the recording should continue recording if lengthSec is reached, and wrap around and record from the beginning of the AudioClip.
Is the length of the AudioClip produced by the recording.
The sample rate of the AudioClip produced by the recording.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour
member.summary: MonoBehaviour is the base class every script derives from.
member.remarks: Using Javascript every script automatically derives from MonoBehaviour. When using C# or Boo you have to explicitly derive from MonoBehaviour. Note: The checkbox for disabling a MonoBehavior (on the editor) will only prevent Start(), Awake(), Update(), FixedUpdate(), and OnGUI() from executing. If none of these functions are present, the checkbox is not displayed. See Also: The chapter on scripting in the manual.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.CancelInvoke
member.summary: Cancels all Invoke calls on this MonoBehaviour.Cancels all Invoke calls with name methodName on this behaviour.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.CancelInvoke(System.String)
member.summary: Cancels all Invoke calls on this MonoBehaviour.Cancels all Invoke calls with name methodName on this behaviour.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.Invoke(System.String,System.Single)
member.summary: Invokes the method methodName in time seconds.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.InvokeRepeating(System.String,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Invokes the method methodName in time seconds.
member.remarks: After the first invocation repeats calling that function every repeatRate seconds.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.IsInvoking
member.summary: Is any invoke on methodName pending?Is any invoke pending on this MonoBehaviour?

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.IsInvoking(System.String)
member.summary: Is any invoke on methodName pending?Is any invoke pending on this MonoBehaviour?

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.print(System.Object)
member.summary: Logs message to the Unity Console. This function is identical to Debug.Log.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.StartCoroutine(System.Collections.IEnumerator)
member.summary: Starts a coroutine.Starts a coroutine named methodName.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.StartCoroutine(System.String)
member.summary: Starts a coroutine.Starts a coroutine named methodName.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.StartCoroutine(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts a coroutine.Starts a coroutine named methodName.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.StopAllCoroutines
member.summary: Stops all coroutines running on this behaviour.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.StopCoroutine(System.String)
member.summary: Stops all coroutines named methodName running on this behaviour.
member.remarks: Please note that only StartCoroutine using a string method name can be stopped using StopCoroutine.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MonoBehaviour.useGUILayout
member.summary: Disabling this lets you skip the GUI layout phase.
member.remarks: It can only be used if you do not use GUI.Window and GUILayout inside of this OnGUI call.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.MovieTexture
member.summary: Movie Textures (Pro only) are textures onto which movies are played back.
member.remarks: They can be used for cutscene movie sequences, or to render movies into the scene itself.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MovieTexture.audioClip
member.summary: Returns the AudioClip belonging to the MovieTexture.
member.remarks: Note that this is a special AudioClip which will always play its audio synchronized to the movie. If you attach a Movie's audioClip to a source in the editor, it will start playing automatically when the movie is playing, Otherwise you'll have to start it manually when you start the movie. The clip can only be attached to one single AudioSource. See Also: Play, WWW.movie.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MovieTexture.duration
member.summary: The time, in seconds, that the movie takes to play back completely.
member.remarks: Note that duration is only available once the movie has started. Until then duration will return -1. If you need to know the duration of a movie before it is played, consider extracting this information offline and creating a text asset. You can then look up the duration given the movie name.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MovieTexture.isPlaying
member.summary: Returns whether the movie is playing or not.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MovieTexture.isReadyToPlay
member.summary: If the movie is downloading from a web site, this returns if enough data has been downloaded so playback should be able to start without interruptions.
member.remarks: For movies not associated with a web stream, this value always returns true.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.MovieTexture.loop
member.summary: Set this to true to make the movie loop.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MovieTexture.Play
member.remarks: Note that a running MovieTexture will use a lot of CPU power, and it will continue running until it is manually stopped or a new level is loaded. Also note that MovieTextures does not behave exactly the same as for example audio clips. When you call the Play() method on a MovieTexture, it is the Asset that will start playing, and not a particular instance of the movie. This means that if you have for example several planes in your scene, all having the same MovieTexture set as their materials texture, when you call Play() on one of them, every instance of the Movie will start playing. MovieTextures are a pro-only feature. See Also: Stop, audioClip.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.MovieTexture.Stop
member.summary: Stops playing the movie, and rewinds it to the beginning.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.MultilineAttribute
member.summary: Attribute to make a string be edited with a multi-line textfield.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMesh.CalculatePath(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Int32,UnityEngine.NavMeshPath)
member.summary: Calculate a path between two points and store the resulting path.
member.returns: True if a path is found.
member.remarks: This function can be used to plan a path ahead of time to avoid a delay in gameplay when the path is needed. Another use is to check if a target position is reachable before moving the agent.
member.param: The initial postion of the path requested.
The final position of the path requested.
A mask specifying which NavMesh layers can be passed when calculating a path.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMesh.CalculateTriangulation
member.remarks: Calculates and returns a simple triangulation of the current navmesh - containing the vertices, triangle indices and navmesh layers.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMesh.FindClosestEdge(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.NavMeshHit@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Locate the closest NavMesh edge from a point on the NavMesh.
member.returns: True if a nearest edge is found.
member.remarks: The returned NavMeshHit object contains the position and details of the nearest point on the nearest edge of the navmesh. Since an edge typically corresponds to a wall or other large object, this could be used to make a character take cover as close to the wall as possible.
member.param: The origin of the distance query.
Holds the properties of the resulting location.
A mask specifying which NavMesh layers can be passed when finding the nearest edge.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMesh.GetLayerCost(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the cost for traversing over geometry of the layer type on all agents.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMesh.GetNavMeshLayerFromName(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the layer index for a named layer.
member.remarks: If the named layer does not exist returns -1.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMesh.Raycast(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.NavMeshHit@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Trace a line between two points on the NavMesh.
member.returns: True if the ray is terminated before reaching target position. Otherwise returns false.
member.remarks: This function follows the path of a "ray" between the specified source and target positions on the navmesh. If an obstruction is encountered along the line then a true value is returned and the position and other details of the obstructing object are stored in the hit parameter. This can be used to check if there is a clear shot or line of sight between a character and a target object. This function is preferable to the similar Physics .Raycast because the line tracing is performed in a simpler way using the navmesh and has a lower processing overhead.
member.param: Holds the properties of the ray cast resulting location.
A mask specifying which NavMesh layers can be passed when tracing the ray.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMesh.SamplePosition(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.NavMeshHit@,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sample the NavMesh closest to the point specified.
member.returns: True if a nearest point is found.
member.param: The origin of the sample query.
Holds the properties of the resulting location.
Sample within this distance from sourcePosition.
A mask specifying which NavMesh layers are allowed when finding the nearest point.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMesh.SetLayerCost(System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the cost for traversing over geometry of the layer type on all agents.
member.remarks: This will replace any custom layer costs on all agents.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent
member.remarks: This component is attached to a mobile character in the game to allow it to navigate the scene using the NavMesh. See the NavMesh and Pathfinding section of the manual for further details.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.acceleration
member.summary: The maximum acceleration of an agent as it follows a path, given in units / sec^2.
member.remarks: An agent does not follow precisely the line segments of the path calculated by the navigation system but rather uses the waypoints along the path as intermediate destinations. This value is the maximum amount by which the agent can accelerate while moving towards the next waypoint.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.ActivateCurrentOffMeshLink(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables the current off-mesh link.
member.remarks: This function activates or deactivates the off-mesh link where the agent is currently waiting. This is useful for granting access to newly discovered areas of the game world or simulating the creation or removal of an obstacle to an area.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.angularSpeed
member.summary: Maximum turning speed in (deg/s) while following a path.
member.remarks: This is the maximum rate at which the agent can turn as it rounds the "corner" defined by a waypoint. The actual turning circle is also influenced by the speed of the agent on approach and also the maximum acceleration. See Also: acceleration, velocity.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.autoBraking
member.summary: Should the agent brake automatically to avoid overshooting the destination point?
member.remarks: If the agent needs to land close to the destination point then it will typically need to brake to avoid overshooting or endless "orbiting" around the target zone. If this property is set to true, the agent will brake automatically as it nears the destination.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.autoRepath
member.summary: Should the agent attempt to acquire a new path if the existing path becomes invalid?
member.remarks: A new path calculation is also attempted aquired if the agent reaches the end of a partial and stale path.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.autoTraverseOffMeshLink
member.summary: Should the agent move via OffMeshLinks automatically?
member.remarks: Off-mesh links are used to connect disjoint regions of the NavMesh. Usually, a character should be able to pass through or traverse a link automatically, which will happen if this property is set to true. However, it can also be set to false in cases where a link represents a door or other obstacle that a character needs "permission" to cross. See Also: CompleteOffMeshLink.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.avoidancePriority
member.remarks: When the agent is performing avoidance, agents of lower priority are ignored. The valid range is from 0 to 99 where: Most important = 0. Least important = 99. Default = 50.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.baseOffset
member.summary: The relative vertical displacement of the owning GameObject.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.CalculatePath(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.NavMeshPath)
member.summary: Calculate a path to a specified point and store the resulting path.
member.returns: True if a path is found.
member.remarks: This function can be used to plan a path ahead of time to avoid a delay in gameplay when the path is needed. Another use is to check if a target position is reachable before moving the agent.
member.param: The final position of the path requested.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.CompleteOffMeshLink
member.remarks: When the autoTraverseOffMeshLink property is switched off an agent will pause at an off-mesh link until this function is called to let it pass. This can be used to allow characters access selectively (eg, to simulate openable doors or obstacles that only certain characters can pass, etc).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.currentOffMeshLinkData
member.remarks: In the case that this agent is not on an OffMeshLink the OffMeshLinkData is marked as invalid. See also isOnOffMeshLink

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.desiredVelocity
member.summary: The desired velocity of the agent including any potential contribution from avoidance. (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.destination
member.summary: Destination point for the agent to navigate towards.
member.remarks: When the value of this property is set, the effect is much the same as using the SetDestination function - a path will be plotted to the newly set destination and by default, the agent will start to move toward it. The destination point can also be read while the agent is moving.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.FindClosestEdge(UnityEngine.NavMeshHit@)
member.returns: True if a nearest edge is found.
member.remarks: The returned NavMeshHit object contains the position and details of the nearest point on the nearest edge of the Navmesh. Since an edge typically corresponds to a wall or other large object, this could be used to make a character take cover as close to the wall as possible.
member.param: Holds the properties of the resulting location.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.GetLayerCost(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the cost for crossing ground of a particular type.
member.remarks: The cost of a path is the amount of "difficulty" involved in following it - the shortest path may not be the quickest if it passes over difficult ground, such as mud, snow, etc. Different types of ground are denoted by navmesh layers in Unity. The cost of a particular layer is given in cost units per distance unit. Note that the cost of a path applies to the pathfinding only and does not automatically affect the movement speed of the agent when following the path. Indeed, the path's cost may denote other factors such as danger (safe but long path through a minefield) or visibility (long path that keeps a character in the shadows).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.hasPath
member.summary: Does the agent currently have a path? (Read Only)
member.remarks: This property will be true if the agent has a path calculated to the desired destination and false otherwise. See Also: pathPending.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.height
member.summary: The height of the agent for purposes of passing under obstacles, etc.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.isOnOffMeshLink
member.summary: Is the agent currently positioned on an OffMeshLink? (Read Only)
member.remarks: This property is used when autoTraverseOffMeshLink is false and the script is making its own decision about letting the agent cross the link. See CompleteOffMeshLInk for an example that uses this property to allow only certain agents to cross a link.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.isPathStale
member.summary: Is the current path stale. (Read Only)
member.remarks: When true, the path may no longer be valid or optimal. This flag will be set if: there are any changes to the walkableMask, if any OffMeshLink is enabled or disabled, or if the costs for the NavMeshLayers have been changed.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.Move(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Apply relative movement to current position.
member.remarks: If the agent has a path it will be adjusted.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.nextOffMeshLinkData
member.summary: The next OffMeshLinkData on the current path.
member.remarks: In the case that the current path does not contain an OffMeshLink the OffMeshLinkData is marked as invalid.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.nextPosition
member.summary: The next position on the path.
member.remarks: A path consists of waypoints that are aimed for in succession by the agent as it navigates. This property contains the position of the waypoint the agent is currently heading for. When this point is reached, the target will be advanced to the next waypoint, and so on until the agent lands at the destination point.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.obstacleAvoidanceType
member.summary: The level of quality of avoidance.
member.remarks: This property lets you trade off the precision of obstacle avoidance againt the processor load required to achieve it. The exact quality/performance values will depend heavily on the complexity of the scene but as a general rule, faster performance can be achieved at the cost of quality and vice versa.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.path
member.summary: Property to get and set the current path.
member.remarks: This property can be useful for GUI, debugging and other purposes to get the points of the path calculated by the navigation system. Additionally, a path created from user code can be set for the agent to follow in the usual way. An example of this might be a patrol route designed for coverage rather than optimal distance between two points.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.pathPending
member.summary: Is a path in the process of being computed but not yet ready? (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.pathStatus
member.summary: The status of the current path (complete, partial or invalid).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.radius
member.summary: The avoidance radius for the agent.
member.remarks: This is the agent's "personal space" within which obstacles and other agents should not pass.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.Raycast(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.NavMeshHit@)
member.summary: Trace a straight path towards a target postion in the NavMesh without moving the agent.
member.returns: True if there is an obstacle between the agent and the target position, otherwise false.
member.remarks: This function follows the path of a "ray" between the agent's position and the specified target position. If an obstruction is encountered along the line then a true value is returned and the position and other details of the obstructing object are stored in the hit parameter. This can be used to check if there is a clear shot or line of sight between a character and a target object. This function is preferable to the similar Physics .Raycast because the line tracing is performed in a simpler way using the navmesh and has a lower processing overhead.
member.param: The desired end position of movement.
Properties of the obstacle detected by the ray (if any).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.remainingDistance
member.summary: The distance between the agent's position and the destination on the current path. (Read Only)
member.remarks: If the remaining distance is unknown then this will have a value of infinity.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.ResetPath
member.remarks: When the path is cleared, the agent will not start looking for a new path until SetDestination is called. Note that if the agent is on an OffMeshLink when this function is called, it will complete the link immediately.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.Resume
member.summary: Resumes the movement along the current path after a pause.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.SamplePathPosition(System.Int32,System.Single,UnityEngine.NavMeshHit@)
member.summary: Sample a position along the current path.
member.returns: True if terminated before reaching the position at maxDistance, false otherwise.
member.remarks: This function looks ahead a specified distance along the current path. Details of the mesh at that position are then returned in a NavMeshHit object. This could be used, for example, to check the type of surface that lies ahead before the character gets there - a character could raise his gun above his head if he is about to wade through water, say.
member.param: A mask specifying which NavMesh layers can be passed when tracing the path.
Terminate scanning the path at this distance.
Holds the properties of the resulting location.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.SetDestination(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Sets or updates the destination thus triggering the calculation for a new path.
member.remarks: Note that the path may not become available until after a few frames later. While the path is being computed, pathPending will be true. If a valid path becomes available then the agent will resume movement.
member.param: The target point to navigate to.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.SetLayerCost(System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the cost for traversing over geometry of the layer type.
member.remarks: If you enable or disable the agent then the cost will be reset to the default layer cost.
member.param: New cost for the specified layer.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.SetPath(UnityEngine.NavMeshPath)
member.summary: Assign a new path to this agent.
member.returns: True if the path is succesfully assigned.
member.remarks: If the path is succesfully assigned the agent will resume movement toward the new target. If the path cannot be assigned the path will be cleared (see ResetPath ).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.speed
member.summary: Maximum movement speed when following a path.
member.remarks: An agent will typically need to speed up and slow down as it follows a path (eg, it will slow down to make a tight turn). The speed is often limited by the length of a path segment and the time taken to accelerate and brake, but the speed will not exceed the value set by this property even on a long, straight path. See Also: desiredVelocity.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.steeringTarget
member.summary: The current steering target - usually the next corner or end point of the current path. (Read Only)

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.Stop
member.summary: Stop movement of this agent along its current path.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.Stop(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Stop movement of this agent along its current path.
member.param: If true, the GameObject is stopped immediately and not affected by the avoidance system. If false, the NavMeshAgent controls the deceleration.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.stoppingDistance
member.summary: Stop within this distance from the target position.
member.remarks: It is seldom possible to land exactly at the target point, so this property can be used to set an acceptable radius within which the agent should stop. A larger stopping distance will give the agent more room for manoeuvre at the end of the path and might avoid sudden braking, turning or other unconvincing AI behaviour.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.updatePosition
member.summary: Should the agent update the transform position?

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.updateRotation
member.summary: Should the agent update the transform orientation?

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.velocity
member.summary: The current velocity of the NavMeshAgent component.
member.remarks: Setting the velocity is not constrained by the maximum acceleration.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.walkableMask
member.summary: Specifies which NavMesh layers are passable (bitfield). Changing walkableMask will make the path stale (see isPathStale).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshAgent.Warp(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Warps agent to the provided position.
member.remarks: Returns true if successful, otherwise returns false.
member.param: New position to warp the agent to.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshHit.distance
member.summary: Distance to the point of hit.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshHit.mask
member.summary: Mask specifying NavMeshLayers at point of hit.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshHit.normal
member.summary: Normal at the point of hit.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.NavMeshObstacle
member.summary: An obstacle for NavMeshAgents to avoid.
member.remarks: A NavMeshObstacle is cylindrical in shape and can move around the surface of the NavMesh with a specified velocity. By default, the obstacle will only affect the agent's avoidance behaviour rather than the pathfinding. This means that the agent will ignore the obstacle when plotting a path but will sidestep around it while moving along the path. If carving is enabled, the obstacle will create a temporary "hole" in the NavMesh. The hole will be recognised by the pathfinding, so paths will be plotted to avoid the obstacle. This means that if, say, an obstacle blocks a narrow gap, the pathfinding will seek an alternative route to the target. Without carving, the agent will head for the gap but won't be able to pass until the obstacle is clear. See Also: NavMeshAgent.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshObstacle.carving
member.summary: Should this obstacle make a cut-out in the navmesh.
member.remarks: When enabled, this changes the navmesh by cutting out a hole. The shape of the hole is based on the bounding volume of the NavMeshObstacle and the navmesh bake settings for radius and height. When the obstacle moves, the carved hole will also move but to reduce CPU overhead the hole is only recalculated when the obstacle is a certain distance from its previous position.- the carvingMoveThreshold property sets this distance.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshObstacle.carvingMoveThreshold
member.summary: Threshold distance for updating a moving carved hole (when carving is enabled).
member.remarks: If the NavMeshObstacle has moved a distance shorter than the threshold since last carving then the navmesh will not be updated. See Also: carving.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshObstacle.height
member.summary: Height of the obstacle's cylinder shape.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshObstacle.radius
member.summary: Radius of the obstacle's cylinder shape.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshObstacle.velocity
member.summary: Velocity at which the obstacle moves around the NavMesh.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.NavMeshPath
member.summary: A path as calculated by the navigation system.
member.remarks: The path is represented as a list of waypoints stored in the corners array. These points are not set directly from user scripts but a NavMeshPath with points correctly assigned is returned by the NavMesh.CalculatePath function and the NavMeshAgent.path property.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.NavMeshPath.ClearCorners
member.summary: Erase all corner points from path.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshPath.corners
member.summary: Corner points of the path. (Read Only)
member.remarks: Also known as "waypoints", the corners define the places along a path where it changes direction (ie, the path consists of a number of straight-line moves between corners).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NavMeshPath.status
member.remarks: This reports whether the path reaches to the target, partway to the target or is completely invalid.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.NavMeshPathStatus.PathComplete
member.summary: The path terminates at the destination.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.NavMeshPathStatus.PathPartial
member.summary: The path cannot reach the destination.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.NavMeshTriangulation
member.summary: Contains data describing a triangulation of a navmesh.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.NavMeshTriangulation.indices
member.summary: Triangle indices for the navmesh triangulation.
member.remarks: Contains 3 integers for each triangle. These integers refer to the vertices array.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.NavMeshTriangulation.layers
member.summary: NavMeshLayer values for the navmesh triangulation.
member.remarks: Contains one element for each triangle.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.NavMeshTriangulation.vertices
member.remarks: Vertices are referenced by the indices.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Network
member.summary: The network class is at the heart of the network implementation and provides the core functions.
member.remarks: This class configures the network interface and all the network parameters. You use it to set up a server or connect to one and have a row of helper functions to help you with those tasks. For more information on what is exposed in the editor see the Network Manger component reference.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.AllocateViewID
member.summary: Query for the next available network view ID number and allocate it (reserve).
member.remarks: This number can then be assigned to the network view of an instantiated object. The example below demonstrates a simple method to do this. Note that for this to work there must be a NetworkView attached to the object which has this script and it must have the script as its observed property. There must be a Cube prefab present also with a NetworkView which watches something (like the Transform of the Cube). The cubePrefab variable in the script must be set to that cube prefab. This is the simplest method of using AllocateViewID intelligently. This get more complicated if there were more than one NetworkView attached to the Cube which is to be instantiated.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.CloseConnection(UnityEngine.NetworkPlayer,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Close the connection to another system.
member.remarks: target defines which system to close the connection to. If we are a client the only possible connection to close is the server connection, if we are a server the target player will be kicked off. sendDisconnectionNotification, enables or disables notifications being sent to the other end. If disabled the connection is dropped, if not a disconnect notification is reliably sent to the remote party and there after the connection is dropped.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.DestroyPlayerObjects(UnityEngine.NetworkPlayer)
member.summary: Destroy all the objects based on view IDs belonging to this player.
member.remarks: This should only be called when running as a server. It is, for example, meant to to clean up networked objects left by a disconnected player.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.Disconnect
member.summary: Close all open connections and shuts down the network interface.
member.remarks: The timeout parameter indicates how much time in milliseconds the network interface gets to signal to others that it is disconnecting. The network state, like security and password, is also reset. Note that if you set the timeout to 0 the network interface will shut down before the disconnect notification can be sent to the remote party. For a client this could mean he cannot reconnect to the server as the server thinks he is still connected (after a certain interval the connection will be detected as dropped).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.Disconnect(System.Int32)
member.summary: Close all open connections and shuts down the network interface.

The network state, like security and password, is also reset. Note that if you set the timeout to 0 the network interface will shut down before the disconnect notification can be sent to the remote party. For a client this could mean he cannot reconnect to the server as the server thinks he is still connected (after a certain interval the connection will be detected as dropped).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.HavePublicAddress
member.summary: Check if this machine has a public IP address.
member.remarks: It checks all the network interfaces for IPv4 public addresses and returns true if one address is found.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.incomingPassword
member.summary: Set the password for the server (for incoming connections).
member.remarks: This must be matched in the Network.Connect routine on the clients. Pass "" to specify no password (this is default).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.InitializeSecurity
member.remarks: You need to call this function on the server before calling Network.InitializeServer. Don't call this function on the client. Once your online game reaches a certain popularity people will try to cheat. You will need to account for this both at the game layer and at the network layer. Unity handles the network layer by providing secure connections if you wish to use them. * Uses AES encryption. Prevents unauthorized reads and blocks replay attacks * Adds CRCs so that data tampering can be detected. * Uses randomized, encrypted SYNCookies to prevent unauthorized logins. * Uses RSA encryption to protect the AES key. Most games will want to use secure connections. However, they add up to 15 bytes per packet and take time to compute so you may wish to limit usage to deployed games only.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.InitializeServer(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.remarks: connections is the number of allowed incoming connections (note that this is generally not the same as the number of players). listenPort is the port number we want to listen to. useNat sets the NAT punchthrough functionality. If you want this server to be able to accept connections using NAT punchthrough, using the facilitator, set this to true.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.InitializeServer(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.remarks: connections is the number of allowed incoming connections (note that this is generally not the same as the number of players). listenPort is the port number we want to listen to. useNat sets the NAT punchthrough functionality. If you want this server to be able to accept connections using NAT punchthrough, using the facilitator, set this to true.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.Instantiate(UnityEngine.Object,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Quaternion,System.Int32)
member.remarks: The given prefab will be instanted on all clients in the game. Synchronization is automatically set up so there is no extra work involved. The position, rotation and network group number are given as parameters. Note that in the example below there must be something set to the playerPrefab in the Editor. You can read more about instantiations in the object reference Object.Instantiate. Internally this is a buffered RPC call. You can use Network.RemoveRPCs is with the group number to remove the call from the buffer. Alternatively you can call Network.RemoveRPCs on the first NetworkViewID in the instantiated prefab. When the instantiation occurs internally the buffered RPC message is linked to the first NetworkView of the prefab which makes this possible.Example of removing an instantiation from the RPC buffer:

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.isClient
member.summary: Returns true if your peer type is client.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.isMessageQueueRunning
member.summary: Enable or disable the processing of network messages.
member.remarks: If this is disabled no RPC call execution or network view synchronization takes place. The Network level loading page has an example of how to use this function.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.isServer
member.summary: Returns true if your peer type is server.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.logLevel
member.summary: Set the log level for network messages (default is Off).
member.remarks: For a description of the different log levels have a look at the NetworkLogLevel enum.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.maxConnections
member.summary: Set the maximum amount of connections/players allowed.
member.remarks: Setting it to 0 means no new connections can be made but the existing ones stay connected. Setting it to -1 means the maximum connections count is set to the same number of current open connections. In that case, if a players drops then the slot is still open for him. This cannot be set higher than the connection count given in Network.InitializeServer.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.minimumAllocatableViewIDs
member.summary: Get or set the minimum number of ViewID numbers in the ViewID pool given to clients by the server.
member.remarks: The ViewID pools are given to each player as he connects and are refreshed with new numbers if the player runs out. The server and clients should be in sync regarding this value. Setting this higher only on the server has the effect that he sends more view ID numbers to clients, than they really want. Setting this higher only on clients means they request more view IDs more often, for example twice in a row, as the pools received from the server don't contain enough numbers. The default value is 100. If a game instantiates a lot of new objects over the network on each client, like more than 100 network intantiations per minute, then this value should be set higher.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.natFacilitatorIP
member.summary: The IP address of the NAT punchthrough facilitator.
member.remarks: Usually this is the same as the Master Server.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.natFacilitatorPort
member.summary: The port of the NAT punchthrough facilitator.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.peerType
member.summary: The status of the peer type, i.e. if it is disconnected, connecting, server or client.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.proxyIP
member.summary: The IP address of the proxy server.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.proxyPassword
member.remarks: It is possible to make your own custom proxy server. In that case you might want to password protect it and then your Unity players must set this value appropriately.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.proxyPort
member.summary: The port of the proxy server.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.SetLevelPrefix(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the level prefix which will then be prefixed to all network ViewID numbers.
member.remarks: This offers protection to prevent old network updates from straying from into a new level from the previous level. This can be set to any number and then incremented with each new level load. This doesn't add overhead to network traffic but just diminishes the pool of network ViewID numbers a little bit. The Network level loading page has an example of how to use this function.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.SetReceivingEnabled(UnityEngine.NetworkPlayer,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enable or disables the reception of messages in a specific group number from a specific player.
member.remarks: You can use the when you do not want any network messages coming in for processing at the moment, and then enable it later when you are ready. This is useful to stop network messages until a level is loaded, for example.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.SetSendingEnabled(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables transmission of messages and RPC calls on a specific network group number.Enable or disable transmission of messages and RPC calls based on target network player as well as the network group.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.SetSendingEnabled(UnityEngine.NetworkPlayer,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables transmission of messages and RPC calls on a specific network group number.Enable or disable transmission of messages and RPC calls based on target network player as well as the network group.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.TestConnection
member.remarks: Two types of tests are performed depending on if the machine has a public IP address present or if it only has a private address (or addresses). The public IP address test is primarily for when running a server as no tests are needed for clients with public addresses. In order for the public IP test to succeed a server instance must be started. A test server will try to connect to the IP and port of the local server and thus it is shown in the server is connectable. If not then a firewall is most likely blocking the server port. A server instance needs to be running so that the test server has something to connect to. The other test is for checking NAT punchthrough capabilities. This is a valid test for both servers and clients and can be performed without any prior setup. There are 4 types of NAT test results (see ConnectionTesterStatus ): Full Cone Address Restricted Cone Port restricted Symmetric First two types offer full NAT punchthrough support and can connect to any type. Port restricted type cannot connect to or receive a connection from symmetric type. Symmetric if worst and cannot connect to other symmetric types or port restricted type. The latter two are labelled as offering limited NAT punchthrough support. This function is asynchronous and might not return a valid result right away because the tests needs some time to complete (1-2 seconds). After test completion the test result is only returned when the function is called again, a full network test is not redone. That way it is safe to poll the function frequently. If another test is desired, like if the network connection has been altered, then the forceTest parameter should be passed as true. The function returns a ConnectionTesterStatus enum.If you know both server and client NAT types you could use the following function to determine if the client can connect to the server or not.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.TestConnection(System.Boolean)
member.remarks: Two types of tests are performed depending on if the machine has a public IP address present or if it only has a private address (or addresses). The public IP address test is primarily for when running a server as no tests are needed for clients with public addresses. In order for the public IP test to succeed a server instance must be started. A test server will try to connect to the IP and port of the local server and thus it is shown in the server is connectable. If not then a firewall is most likely blocking the server port. A server instance needs to be running so that the test server has something to connect to. The other test is for checking NAT punchthrough capabilities. This is a valid test for both servers and clients and can be performed without any prior setup. There are 4 types of NAT test results (see ConnectionTesterStatus ): Full Cone Address Restricted Cone Port restricted Symmetric First two types offer full NAT punchthrough support and can connect to any type. Port restricted type cannot connect to or receive a connection from symmetric type. Symmetric if worst and cannot connect to other symmetric types or port restricted type. The latter two are labelled as offering limited NAT punchthrough support. This function is asynchronous and might not return a valid result right away because the tests needs some time to complete (1-2 seconds). After test completion the test result is only returned when the function is called again, a full network test is not redone. That way it is safe to poll the function frequently. If another test is desired, like if the network connection has been altered, then the forceTest parameter should be passed as true. The function returns a ConnectionTesterStatus enum.If you know both server and client NAT types you could use the following function to determine if the client can connect to the server or not.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.TestConnectionNAT
member.summary: Test the connecction specifically for NAT punchthrough connectivity.
member.remarks: This is like Network.TestConnection except that a NAT punchthrough test is forced, even through the machine does not have a NAT address (private IP address) but a public address. See Network.TestConnection example code.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Network.TestConnectionNAT(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Test the connecction specifically for NAT punchthrough connectivity.
member.remarks: This is like Network.TestConnection except that a NAT punchthrough test is forced, even through the machine does not have a NAT address (private IP address) but a public address. See Network.TestConnection example code.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.time
member.remarks: This can, for example, be used to compare with the time returned in NetworkMessageInfo. The example script needs to be attached to an object with a network view and have the network view observe the script. It measures the time it took to send a message which synchronizes the X postion value of the objects transform.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Network.useProxy
member.summary: Indicate if proxy support is needed, in which case traffic is relayed through the proxy server.
member.remarks: The proxy server is a solution to connectivity problems with servers as well as clients. When a machine has an non NAT punchthrough capable router his connectivity options are limited. A game cannot be hosted as nobody external can connect to him (only clients on the local network can). By using the proxy server the machine can be fully connectable but with the extra cost of having all traffic relayed through another server. A non NAT punchthrough capable client can connect to any server through the proxy server, as long as the proxy server is set up properly. Unity Technologies does not provide a proxy server for public use, so to use this feature you will need to set up your own proxy server. Of course it is advisable to set up a proxy server with a public IP address and a lot of available bandwidth. When running as a client, just enabling Network.useProxy is all you have to do. Connect to the server as usual with Network.Connect(). All traffic will be relayed through the proxy server. The servers external IP and internal IP still work as usual. So clients can connect to him directly without the proxy in case they are located on the same network. When running as a server OnServerInitialized(NetworkPlayer) returns a NetworkPlayer structure which indicates what the game servers relayed IP/port is, i.e. what port the proxy server allocated to the game server. This is the IP/port others can use to connect to. When connecting to the server, the clients don't treat the server any differently than other servers. Technically speaking, they don't need to know at all that the game server is getting help from a proxy server. When using the master server you can no longer only rely on the IP/port he registers for servers when using proxy support. The proxy server IP address and port which the server is using can be placed in the comment field of the data sent to the master server. A client which received host information from the master server can peek into the comment field and find out if he can use an alternative IP/port for that host. IMPORTANT: You should never enable proxy support for both the server and the client connecting to him. Unexpected things are bound to happen.

member.summary: This data structure contains information on a message just received from the network.
member.remarks: It reveals where it came from, what time it was send and what network view sent it.

member.summary: The NetworkView who sent this message.

member.summary: The player who sent this network message (owner).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.NetworkMessageInfo.timestamp
member.summary: The time stamp when the Message was sent in seconds.
member.remarks: Timestamps can be used to implement interpolation or extrapolation of continous streams of packets The timestamp is passed as a double to avoid overflow when a game is running for a long time. Internally timestamps are sent as 32 bit integers with millisecond accuracy to save bandwidth. Timestamps are automatically adjusted to be relative to Network.time. Thus Network.time - messageInfo.timeStamp is the time the packet spent in transit.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.NetworkStateSynchronization
member.summary: Different types of synchronization for the NetworkView component.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.NetworkStateSynchronization.Off
member.summary: No state data will be synchronized.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.NetworkStateSynchronization.ReliableDeltaCompressed
member.summary: All packets are sent reliable and ordered.
member.remarks: Delta compression is used to send only the difference between the last sent state and the current state. For example if you synchronize a Transform. Scale x, y, z is most likely going to keep the same value. Unity compares the state received by the client to the new state, if it is changed 1 bit and the data will be sent. If it didn't change only a single bit will be sent. When Unity detects that nothing has changed since the last state, no data will be sent at all.

member.remarks: With this you can define exactly what is to be synchronized over the network and how it should be done. GameObjects can have NetworkView components which can be configured to watch other components for the object. For more information see the Network View manual page and the component reference page.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Object
member.summary: Base class for all objects Unity can reference.
member.remarks: Any public variable you make that derives from Object gets shown in the inspector as a drop target, allowing you to set the value from the GUI.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Object.Destroy(UnityEngine.Object)
member.summary: Removes a gameobject, component or asset.
member.remarks: The object obj will be destroyed now or if a time is specified t seconds from now. If obj is a Component it will remove the component from the GameObject and destroy it. If obj is a GameObject it will destroy the GameObject, all its components and all transform children of the GameObject. Actual object destruction is always delayed until after the current Update loop, but will always be done before rendering.Destroy is inherited from the UnityEngine.Object base class. Javascript users should consider making a call to UnityEngine.Object.Destroy, rather than Object.Destroy to avoid references being resolved to the .Net System.Object class.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Object.Destroy(UnityEngine.Object,System.Single)
member.summary: Removes a gameobject, component or asset.
member.remarks: The object obj will be destroyed now or if a time is specified t seconds from now. If obj is a Component it will remove the component from the GameObject and destroy it. If obj is a GameObject it will destroy the GameObject, all its components and all transform children of the GameObject. Actual object destruction is always delayed until after the current Update loop, but will always be done before rendering.Destroy is inherited from the UnityEngine.Object base class. Javascript users should consider making a call to UnityEngine.Object.Destroy, rather than Object.Destroy to avoid references being resolved to the .Net System.Object class.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Object.DestroyImmediate(UnityEngine.Object)
member.summary: Destroys the object obj immediately. You are strongly recommended to use Destroy instead.
member.remarks: This function should only be used when writing editor code since the delayed destruction will never be invoked in edit mode. In game code you should use Object.Destroy instead. Destroy is always delayed (but executed within the same frame). Use this function with care since it can destroy assets permanently! Also note that you should never iterate through arrays and destroy the elements you are iterating over. This will cause serious problems (as a general programming practice, not just in Unity).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Object.DestroyImmediate(UnityEngine.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Destroys the object obj immediately. You are strongly recommended to use Destroy instead.
member.remarks: This function should only be used when writing editor code since the delayed destruction will never be invoked in edit mode. In game code you should use Object.Destroy instead. Destroy is always delayed (but executed within the same frame). Use this function with care since it can destroy assets permanently! Also note that you should never iterate through arrays and destroy the elements you are iterating over. This will cause serious problems (as a general programming practice, not just in Unity).
member.param: Set to true to allow assets to be destoyed.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Object.DontDestroyOnLoad(UnityEngine.Object)
member.summary: Makes the object target not be destroyed automatically when loading a new scene.
member.remarks: When loading a new level all objects in the scene are destroyed, then the objects in the new level are loaded. In order to preserve an object during level loading call DontDestroyOnLoad on it. If the object is a component or GameObject then its entire transform hierarchy will not be destroyed either.

member.remarks: Please note that this function is very slow. It is not recommended to use this function every frame. In most cases you can use the singleton pattern instead. See Also: Object.FindObjectsOfType.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Object.FindObjectsOfType(System.Type)
member.summary: Returns a list of all active loaded objects of Type type.
member.remarks: It will return no assets (meshes, textures, prefabs, ...) or inactive objects. Please note that this function is very slow. It is not recommended to use this function every frame. In most cases you can use the singleton pattern instead.
