Particles with energy of zero or less will be killed when assigning the particles. Thus when creating a complete new particle array, you need to set the energy of all particles explicitly.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleEmitter.rndAngularVelocity
member.summary: A random angular velocity modifier for new particles.
member.remarks: A random value in the range of [-rndAngularVelocity, rndAngularVelocity] will be applied to all new particles, in addition to ParticleEmitter.angularVelocity See Also: angularVelocity.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleEmitter.rndRotation
member.summary: If enabled, the particles will be spawned with random rotations.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleEmitter.rndVelocity
member.summary: A random speed along X, Y, and Z that is added to the velocity.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleEmitter.Simulate(System.Single)
member.summary: Advance particle simulation by given time.
member.remarks: This is useful for pre-warming particle emitters.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleEmitter.useWorldSpace
member.summary: If enabled, the particles don't move when the emitter moves. If false, when you move the emitter, the particles follow it around.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleEmitter.worldVelocity
member.summary: The starting speed of particles in world space, along X, Y, and Z.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ParticleRenderer
member.summary: (Legacy Particles) Renders particles on to the screen.
member.remarks: This class is a script interface for a particle renderer component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleRenderer.cameraVelocityScale
member.summary: How much are the particles strected depending on the Camera's speed.
member.remarks: Use this to make particles become large if the viewing camera has a large speed.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleRenderer.lengthScale
member.summary: How much are the particles stretched in their direction of motion.
member.remarks: Use this to make particles always be longer than they are wide.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleRenderer.maxParticleSize
member.remarks: Particles can become very heavy on fillrate. Use this setting to make sure they don't use too much perfomance when up close to the viewer.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleRenderer.velocityScale
member.summary: How much are the particles strectched depending on "how fast they move".
member.remarks: Use this to make particles get longer as their speed increases.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ParticleRenderMode
member.summary: The rendering mode for legacy particles.
member.remarks: This is used by the ParticleRenderer to determine how to render the particles.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ParticleRenderMode.Billboard
member.summary: Render the particles as billboards facing the player. (Default)

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ParticleRenderMode.HorizontalBillboard
member.summary: Render the particles as billboards always facing up along the y-Axis.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ParticleRenderMode.SortedBillboard
member.summary: Sort the particles back-to-front and render as billboards.
member.remarks: This looks better with blended particle shaders, but is slower because of the sorting.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ParticleRenderMode.Stretch
member.summary: Stretch particles in the direction of motion.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ParticleRenderMode.VerticalBillboard
member.summary: Render the particles as billboards always facing the player, but not pitching along the x-Axis.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.Clear
member.summary: Remove all particles in the particle system.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.Clear(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Remove all particles in the particle system.
member.param: Clear all child particle systems as well.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.duration
member.summary: The duration of the particle system in seconds (Read Only).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.Emit(System.Int32)
member.summary: Emit count particles immediately.Emit a single particle with given parameters.Emit a single particle.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.Emit(UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+Particle)
member.summary: Emit count particles immediately.Emit a single particle with given parameters.Emit a single particle.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.Emit(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,System.Single,UnityEngine.Color32)
member.summary: Emit count particles immediately.Emit a single particle with given parameters.Emit a single particle.
member.param: The remaining lifetime of the particle.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.enableEmission
member.summary: When set to false, the particle system will not emit particles.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.GetCollisionEvents(UnityEngine.GameObject,UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+CollisionEvent[])
member.summary: Get the particle collision events for a GameObject. Returns the number of events written to the array.
member.remarks: This method is typically called from MonoBehaviour.OnParticleCollision in response to a collision callback. If the array used is too short events may be truncated. To avoid this use ParticleSystem.safeCollisionEventSize to determine an appropriate array size prior the call. See Also: MonoBehaviour.OnParticleCollision.
member.param: The GameObject for which to retrieve collision events.
Array to write collision events to.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.GetParticles(UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+Particle[])
member.summary: Get the particles of this particle system. Returns the number of particles written to the input particle array.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.gravityModifier
member.summary: Scale being applied to the gravity defined by Physics.gravity.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.IsAlive
member.summary: Does the system have any live particles (or will produce more)?
member.returns: True if the particle system is still "alive", false if the particle system is done emitting particles and all particles are dead.
member.example: // Auto destruct script that can be added to the root particle system // of a particle effect. It will destroy the gameobject and its children. using UnityEngine; public class AutoDestructParticleSystem : MonoBehaviour { void LateUpdate () { if (!particleSystem.IsAlive()) Object.Destroy (this.gameObject); } }

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.IsAlive(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Does the system have any live particles (or will produce more)?
member.returns: True if the particle system is still "alive", false if the particle system is done emitting particles and all particles are dead.
member.example: // Auto destruct script that can be added to the root particle system // of a particle effect. It will destroy the gameobject and its children. using UnityEngine; public class AutoDestructParticleSystem : MonoBehaviour { void LateUpdate () { if (!particleSystem.IsAlive()) Object.Destroy (this.gameObject); } }
member.param: Check all child particle systems as well.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.isPaused
member.summary: Is the particle system paused right now ?

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.isPlaying
member.summary: Is the particle system playing right now ?

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.isStopped
member.summary: Is the particle system stopped right now ?

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.loop
member.remarks: If you disable looping on a playing particle system, it will stop after the end of the current loop.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.maxParticles
member.summary: The maximum number of particles to emit.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.particleCount
member.summary: The current number of particles (Read Only).

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.Pause(System.Boolean)
member.param: Pause all child particle systems as well.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.Play(System.Boolean)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.playbackSpeed
member.summary: The playback speed of the particle system. 1 is normal playback speed.
member.remarks: A negative playback speed is not supported.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.playOnAwake
member.summary: If set to true, the particle system will automatically start playing on startup.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.randomSeed
member.summary: Random seed used for the particle system emission. If set to 0, it will be assigned a random value on awake.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.safeCollisionEventSize
member.summary: Safe array size for use with ParticleSystem.GetCollisionEvents.
member.remarks: This is guaranteed to be large enough to use with ParticleSystem.GetCollisionEvents for the current frame. GetCollisionEvents may return fewer elements for some GameObjects though.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.SetParticles(UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+Particle[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the particles of this particle system. size is the number of particles that is set.
member.remarks: Setting the lifetime of a particle to a negative value will result in Shuriken removing the particle. See Also: GetParticles.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.Simulate(System.Single)

member.summary: Fastforwards the particle system by simulating particles over given period of time, then pauses it.

Fastforward all child particle systems as well.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.simulationSpace
member.summary: This selects the space in which to simulate particles. It can be either world or local space.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.startColor
member.summary: The initial color of particles when emitted.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.startDelay
member.remarks: Use this to delay when the playback starts on the system.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.startLifetime
member.summary: The total lifetime in seconds that particles will have when emitted. When using curves, this values acts as a scale on the curve. This value is set in the particle when it is create by the particle system.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.startRotation
member.summary: The initial rotation of particles when emitted. When using curves, this values acts as a scale on the curve.
member.remarks: Note that the value should be given in radians.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.startSize
member.summary: The initial size of particles when emitted. When using curves, this values acts as a scale on the curve.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.startSpeed
member.summary: The initial speed of particles when emitted. When using curves, this values acts as a scale on the curve.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.Stop(System.Boolean)
member.param: Stop all child particle systems as well.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem.time
member.remarks: Use this to read current playback time or to seek to a new playback time.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+CollisionEvent.collider
member.summary: The Collider for the GameObject struck by the particles.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+CollisionEvent.intersection
member.summary: Intersection point of the collision in world coordinates.
member.remarks: The intersection point is reported in world coordinates regardless of whether the particle system is simulated in local coordinates.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+CollisionEvent.normal
member.summary: Geometry normal at the intersection point of the collision.
member.remarks: The normal is reported in world coordinates regardless of whether the particle system is simulated in local coordinates.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+CollisionEvent.velocity
member.summary: Incident velocity at the intersection point of the collision.
member.remarks: The velocity is reported in world coordinates regardless of whether the particle system is simulated in local coordinates.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+Particle.angularVelocity
member.summary: The angular velocity of the particle.
member.remarks: This is particle's angular velocity in degrees per second.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+Particle.color
member.summary: The initial color of the particle. The current color of the particle is calculated procedurally based on this value and the active color modules.
member.remarks: Alpha channel of the color is used to fade out particles.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+Particle.lifetime
member.remarks: This is the time in seconds for how long this particle will remain alive. When the lifetime drops below zero the Particle will be killed.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+Particle.randomSeed
member.summary: The random seed of the particle.
member.remarks: This is used to create the value used to interpolate between the two curves when random between curves is used.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+Particle.rotation
member.remarks: This is particle's rotation in degrees.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+Particle.size
member.summary: The initial size of the particle. The current size of the particle is calculated procedurally based on this value and the active size modules.
member.remarks: This is particle's size in meters in world space.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+Particle.startLifetime
member.summary: The starting lifetime of the particle.
member.remarks: This is the total lifetime of this particle in seconds. It is set by the particle system when creating the particle.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystem+Particle.velocity
member.remarks: The particle will move by the velocity every frame. The velocity is also used by the ParticleSystemRenderer if Stretch Particles is set to ParticleSystemRenderMode.Stretch.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystemRenderer.maxParticleSize
member.remarks: Particles can become very heavy on fillrate. Use this setting to make sure they don't use too much perfomance when up close to the viewer.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystemRenderer.mesh
member.summary: Mesh used as particle instead of billboarded texture.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ParticleSystemRenderer.velocityScale
member.summary: How much are the particles strectched depending on "how fast they move".
member.remarks: Use this to make particles get longer as their speed increases.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ParticleSystemRenderMode
member.summary: The rendering mode for particle systems (Shuriken).
member.remarks: This is used by the ParticleSystemRenderer to determine how to render the particles.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ParticleSystemRenderMode.Billboard
member.summary: Render particles as billboards facing the player. (Default)

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ParticleSystemRenderMode.HorizontalBillboard
member.summary: Render particles as billboards always facing up along the y-Axis.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ParticleSystemRenderMode.Stretch
member.summary: Stretch particles in the direction of motion.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ParticleSystemRenderMode.VerticalBillboard
member.summary: Render particles as billboards always facing the player, but not pitching along the x-Axis.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ParticleSystemSimulationSpace
member.summary: The space to simulate particles in.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterial
member.summary: Physics material describes how to handle colliding objects (friction, bounciness).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterial.bounceCombine
member.summary: Determines how the bounciness is combined.
member.remarks: Traditionally bounciness properties are dependent on the combination of the two materials in contact. This is however impractical in a game. Instead you can use the combine mode to tune how the bounciness values of two materials are combined.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterial.bounciness
member.summary: How bouncy is the surface? A value of 0 will not bounce. A value of 1 will bounce without any loss of energy.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterial.dynamicFriction
member.summary: The friction used when already moving. This value has to be between 0 and 1.
member.remarks: A value of 0 feels like ice, 1 feels like rubber.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterial.dynamicFriction2
member.summary: If anisotropic friction is enabled, dynamicFriction2 will be applied along frictionDirection2.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterial.frictionCombine
member.summary: Determines how the friction is combined.
member.remarks: Traditionally friction properties are dependent on the combination of the two materials in contact. This is however impractical in a game. Instead you can use the combine mode to tune how the friction values of two materials are combined.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterial.frictionDirection2
member.summary: The direction of anisotropy. Anisotropic friction is enabled if the vector is not zero.
member.remarks: DynamicFriction2 and staticFriction2 will be applied along frictionDirection2. The direction of anisotropy is relative to the colliders local coordinate system.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterial.staticFriction
member.summary: The friction coefficient used when an object is lying on a surface.
member.remarks: Must be >= 0. Natural materials will usually have a friction coefficient between 0 (no friction at all, like slippy ice) and 1 (full friction, like rubber). Values larger then 1 are possible, and may be realistic for sticky materials.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterial.staticFriction2
member.summary: If anisotropic friction is enabled, staticFriction2 will be applied along frictionDirection2.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterialCombine
member.summary: Describes how physic materials of colliding objects are combined.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterialCombine.Average
member.summary: Averages the friction/bounce of the two colliding materials.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterialCombine.Maximum
member.summary: Uses the larger friction/bounce of the two colliding materials.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterialCombine.Minimum
member.summary: Uses the smaller friction/bounce of the two colliding materials.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.PhysicMaterialCombine.Multiply
member.summary: Multiplies the friction/bounce of the two colliding materials.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Physics
member.summary: Global physics properties and helper methods.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.Physics.AllLayers
member.summary: Layer mask constant to select all layers.
member.remarks: This can be used in the layermask field of Physics.Raycast and other methods to select all layers. See Also: Physics.DefaultLayers, Physics.IgnoreRaycastLayer.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Physics.bounceThreshold
member.summary: Two colliding objects with a relative velocity below this will not bounce (default 2). Must be positive.
member.remarks: This value is usually changed in Edit->Project Settings->Physics inspector instead of from scripts.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.CapsuleCast(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Casts a capsule against all colliders in the scene and returns detailed information on what was hit.
member.returns: True when the capsule sweep intersects any collider, otherwise false.
member.remarks: The capsule is defined by the two spheres with radius around point1 and point2, which form the two ends of the capsule. Hits are returned for the first collider which would collide against this capsule if the capsule was moved along direction. This is useful when a Raycast does not give enough precision, because you want to find out if an object of a specific size, such as a character, will be able to move somewhere without colliding with anything on the way. Note: If you move colliders from scripting or by animation, there needs to be at least one FixedUpdate executed so that the physics library can update it's data structures, before a CapsuleCast will hit the collider at it's new position. See Also: Physics.SphereCast, Physics.CapsuleCastAll, Physics.Raycast, Rigidbody.SweepTest.
member.param: The direction into which to sweep the capsule.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.CapsuleCast(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Casts a capsule against all colliders in the scene and returns detailed information on what was hit.
member.returns: True when the capsule sweep intersects any collider, otherwise false.

See Also: Physics.SphereCast, Physics.CapsuleCastAll, Physics.Raycast, Rigidbody.SweepTest.
member.param: The direction into which to sweep the capsule.

member.summary: Casts a capsule against all colliders in the scene and returns detailed information on what was hit.
member.returns: True when the capsule sweep intersects any collider, otherwise false.

This is useful when a Raycast does not give enough precision, because you want to find out if an object of a specific size, such as a character, will be able to move somewhere without colliding with anything on the way. member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.CapsuleCastAll(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Like Physics.CapsuleCast, but this function will return all hits the capsule sweep intersects.
member.returns: An array of all colliders hit in the sweep.
member.remarks: Casts a capsule against all colliders in the scene and returns detailed information on each collider which was hit. The capsule is defined by the two spheres with radius around point1 and point2, which form the two ends of the capsule. Hits are returned all colliders which would collide against this capsule if the capsule was moved along direction. This is useful when a Raycast does not give enough precision, because you want to find out if an object of a specific size, such as a character, will be able to move somewhere without colliding with anything on the way. Notes: The capsule cast does not work against colliders configured as triggers. If you move colliders from scripting or by animation, there needs to be at least one FixedUpdate executed so that the physics library can update it's data structures, before a capsule cast will hit the collider at it's new position. See Also: Physics.SphereCast, Physics.CapsuleCast, Physics.Raycast, Rigidbody.SweepTest.
member.param: The direction into which to sweep the capsule.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.CapsuleCastAll(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)

member.param: The direction into which to sweep the capsule.

Notes: The capsule cast does not work against colliders configured as triggers. If you move colliders from scripting or by animation, there needs to be at least one FixedUpdate executed so that the physics library can update it's data structures, before a capsule cast will hit the collider at it's new position. See Also: Physics.SphereCast, Physics.CapsuleCast, Physics.Raycast, Rigidbody.SweepTest.
member.param: The direction into which to sweep the capsule.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.CheckCapsule(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Returns true if there are any colliders overlapping the capsule defined by the axis going from start and end and having radius in world coordinates.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.CheckCapsule(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns true if there are any colliders overlapping the capsule defined by the axis going from start and end and having radius in world coordinates.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.CheckSphere(UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Returns true if there are any colliders overlapping the sphere defined by position and radius in world coordinates.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.CheckSphere(UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns true if there are any colliders overlapping the sphere defined by position and radius in world coordinates.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.Physics.DefaultRaycastLayers
member.summary: Layer mask constant to select default raycast layers.
member.remarks: This can be used in the layermask field of Physics.Raycast and other methods to select the default raycast layers. The default layers are all layers execpt for the ignore raycast layer. See Also: Physics.AllLayers, Physics.IgnoreRaycastLayer.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.GetIgnoreLayerCollision(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Are collisions between layer1 and layer2 being ignored?
member.remarks: Returns the value set by Physics.IgnoreLayerCollision or in the Physics inspector.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Physics.gravity
member.summary: The gravity applied to all rigid bodies in the scene.
member.remarks: Gravity can be turned off for an individual rigidbody using its useGravity property.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.IgnoreCollision(UnityEngine.Collider,UnityEngine.Collider)
member.summary: Makes the collision detection system ignore all collisions between collider1 and collider2.
member.remarks: This is most useful for making eg. projectiles not collide with the object shooting them. IgnoreCollision has a few limitations: 1) It is not persistent. This means ignore collision state will not be stored in the editor when saving a scene. 2) You can only apply the ignore collision to colliders in active GameObjects. When deactivating the collider or attached rigidbody the IgnoreCollision state will be lost and you have to call Physics.IgnoreCollision again. See Also: Physics.IgnoreLayerCollision.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.IgnoreCollision(UnityEngine.Collider,UnityEngine.Collider,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes the collision detection system ignore all collisions between collider1 and collider2.
member.remarks: This is most useful for making eg. projectiles not collide with the object shooting them. IgnoreCollision has a few limitations: 1) It is not persistent. This means ignore collision state will not be stored in the editor when saving a scene. 2) You can only apply the ignore collision to colliders in active GameObjects. When deactivating the collider or attached rigidbody the IgnoreCollision state will be lost and you have to call Physics.IgnoreCollision again. See Also: Physics.IgnoreLayerCollision.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.IgnoreLayerCollision(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Makes the collision detection system ignore all collisions between any collider in layer1 and any collider in layer2.
member.remarks: You can set the default values for your project for any layer combinations in the Physics inspector. See Also: Physics.GetIgnoreLayerCollision, Physics.IgnoreCollision.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.IgnoreLayerCollision(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes the collision detection system ignore all collisions between any collider in layer1 and any collider in layer2.
member.remarks: You can set the default values for your project for any layer combinations in the Physics inspector. See Also: Physics.GetIgnoreLayerCollision, Physics.IgnoreCollision.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.Physics.IgnoreRaycastLayer
member.summary: Layer mask constant to select ignore raycast layer.
member.remarks: This can be used in the layermask field of Physics.Raycast and other methods to select the "ignore raycast" layer (which does not receive raycasts by default). See Also: Physics.AllLayers, Physics.DefaultLayers.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Physics.maxAngularVelocity
member.summary: The default maximum angular velocity permitted for any rigid bodies (default 7). Must be positive.
member.remarks: The angular velocity of rigidbodies is clamped to maxAngularVelocity to avoid numerical instability with fast rotating bodies. Because this may prevent intentional fast rotations on objects such as wheels, you can override this value per rigidbody using Rigidbody.maxAngularVelocity. This value is usually changed in Edit->Project Settings->Physics inspector instead of from scripts.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Physics.minPenetrationForPenalty
member.summary: The minimum contact penetration value in order to apply a penalty force (default 0.05). Must be positive.
member.remarks: This value is usually changed in Edit->Project Settings->Physics inspector instead of from scripts.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics.RaycastAll(UnityEngine.Ray)
member.summary: Casts a ray through the scene and returns all hits. Note that order is not guaranteed.
member.remarks: Notes: This function will return false if you cast a ray from inside a sphere to the outside; this in an intended behaviour. If you move colliders from scripting or by animation, there needs to be at least one FixedUpdate executed so that the physics library can update it's data structures, before a Raycast will hit the collider at it's new position.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Physics.sleepAngularVelocity
member.summary: The default angular velocity, below which objects start sleeping (default 0.14). Must be positive.
member.remarks: See Rigidbody Sleeping for more information. This can be overridden per rigidbody using Rigidbody.sleepAngularVelocity. This value is usually changed in Edit->Project Settings->Physics inspector instead of from scripts.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Physics.sleepVelocity
member.summary: The default linear velocity, below which objects start going to sleep (default 0.15). Must be positive.
member.remarks: See Rigidbody Sleeping for more information. This value can be overridden per rigidbody using Rigidbody.sleepVelocity. This value is usually changed in Edit->Project Settings->Physics inspector instead of from scripts.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Physics.solverIterationCount
member.summary: The default solver iteration count permitted for any rigid bodies (default 7). Must be positive.
member.remarks: The solverIterationCount determines how accurately joints and contacts are resolved. If you are having trouble with connected bodies oscillating and behaving erratically setting a higher solver iteration count may improve their stability (but is slower). Usually a value of 7 works very well for almost all situations. This value is usually changed in Edit->Project Settings->Physics inspector instead of from scripts.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Physics2D
member.summary: Global settings and helpers for 2D physics.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.Physics2D.AllLayers
member.summary: Layer mask constant that includes all layers.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.Physics2D.DefaultRaycastLayers
member.summary: Layer mask constant that includes all layers participating in raycasts by default.
member.remarks: The value of the mask is the bitwise complement of the IgnoreRaycastLayer mask. See Also: Raycast, IgnoreRaycastLayer, AllLayers.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.GetIgnoreLayerCollision(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Should collisions between the specified layers be ignored?

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.GetRayIntersection(UnityEngine.Ray)
member.summary: Cast a 3D ray against the colliders in the scene returning the first collider along the ray.
member.remarks: This is useful for finding colliders intersecting an arbitrary 3D ray. Note that this function will allocate memory for the returned RaycastHit2D object. You can use GetRayIntersectionNonAlloc to avoid this overhead if you need to make such calls frequently. Additionally that this function is a 3D intersection test therefore any collision normals returned in the RaycastHit2D will be zero.
member.param: The 3D ray defining origin and direction to test.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.GetRayIntersectionNonAlloc(UnityEngine.Ray,UnityEngine.RaycastHit2D[])
member.summary: Cast a 3D ray against the colliders in the scene returning the colliders along the ray.
member.remarks: This is useful for finding colliders intersecting an arbitrary 3D ray. This function is similar to the GetRayIntersectionAll function except that the results are returned in the supplied array. The integer return value is the number of objects that intersect the ray (possibly zero) but the results array will not be resized if it doesn't contain enough elements to report all the results. The significance of this is that no memory is allocated for the results and so garbage collection performance is improved when such calls are performed frequently. The colliders will be placed in the returned array in order of distance from the start of the ray. Note that this function will allocate memory for the returned RaycastHit2D array. You can use GetRayIntersectionNonAlloc to avoid this overhead if you need to make such calls frequently. Additionally this function is a 3D intersection test therefore any collision normals returned in the RaycastHit2D will be zero.
member.param: The 3D ray defining origin and direction to test.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.Physics2D.IgnoreRaycastLayer
member.summary: Layer mask constant for the default layer that ignores raycasts.
member.remarks: The value of the mask is the bitwise complement of the DefaultRaycastLayers mask. See Also: Raycast, DefaultRaycastLayers, AllLayers.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.Linecast(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Casts a line against colliders in the scene.
member.remarks: A linecast is an imaginary line between two points in world space. Any object making contact with the beam can be detected and reported. This differs from the similar raycast in that raycasting specifies the line using an origin and directtion. This function returns a RaycastHit2D object when the line contacts a Collider in the scene. The layerMask can be used to detect objects selectively only on certain layers (this allows you to apply the detection only to enemy characters, for example). The direction of the line is assumed to extend from the start point to the end point. Only the first collider encountered in that direction will be reported. Although the Z axis is not relevant for rendering or collisions in 2D, you can use the minDepth and maxDepth parameters to filter objects based on their Z coordinate. Linecasts are useful for determining lines of sight, targets hit by gunfire and for many other purposes in gameplay. Note that this function will allocate memory for the returned RaycastHit2D object. You can use LinecastNonAlloc to avoid this overhead if you need to make linecasts frequently. Additionally, this will also detect Collider(s) at the start of the line. In this case the line is starting inside the Collider and doesn't intersect the Collider surface. This means that the collision normal cannot be calculated in which case the collision normal returned is set to the inverse of the line vector being tested. This can easily be detected because such results are always at a RaycastHit2D fraction of zero. See Also: LayerMask::ref:: class, RaycastHit2D::ref:: class, LinecastAll, LinecastNonAlloc, defaultRaycastLayers, ignoreRaycastLayer, raycastsHitTriggers.
member.param: The start point of the line in world space.
The end point of the line in world space.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.LinecastNonAlloc(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.RaycastHit2D[])
member.summary: Casts a line against colliders in the scene.
member.remarks: A linecast is an imaginary line between two points in world space. Any object making contact with the beam can be detected and reported. This differs from the similar raycast in that the raycast specifies the line using an origin and directtion. This function is similar to the LinecastAll function except that the results are returned in the supplied array. The integer return value is the number of objects that intersect the line (possibly zero) but the results array will not be resized if it doesn't contain enough elements to report all the results. The significance of this is that no memory is allocated for the results and so garbage collection performance is improved when linecasts are performed frequently. The line is assumed to run from its start point to its end point; colliders will be placed in the returned array in order of distance from the start of the line. Additionally, this will also detect Collider(s) at the start of the line. In this case the line is starting inside the Collider and doesn't intersect the Collider surface. This means that the collision normal cannot be calculated in which case the collision normal returned is set to the inverse of the line vector being tested. member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.OverlapArea(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Check if a collider falls within a rectangular area.
member.remarks: The rectangle is defined by two diagonally opposite corner coordinates in world space. You can think of these as top-left and bottom-right but the test will still work if the ordering of the points is reversed. The optional layerMask allows the test to check only for objects on specific layers. Although the Z axis is not relevant for rendering or collisions in 2D, you can use the minDepth and maxDepth parameters to filter objects based on their Z coordinate. If more than one collider falls within the area then the one returned will be the one with the lowest Z coordinate value. Null is returned if there are no colliders in the area. Note that this function will allocate memory for the returned Collider2D object. You can use OverlapAreaNonAlloc to avoid this overhead if you need to make the check frequently. See Also: OverlapCircle, OverlapPoint, OverlapCircleAll, OverlapAreaNonAlloc.
member.param: Diagonally opposite corner of the rectangle.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.OverlapArea(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,System.Int32)

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.OverlapArea(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Check if a collider falls within a rectangular area.
member.remarks: The rectangle is defined by two diagonally opposite corner coordinates in world space. You can think of these as top-left and bottom-right but the test will still work if the ordering of the points is reversed. The optional layerMask allows the test to check only for objects on specific layers. Although the Z axis is not relevant for rendering or collisions in 2D, you can use the minDepth and maxDepth parameters to filter objects based on their Z coordinate. If more than one collider falls within the area then the one returned will be the one with the lowest Z coordinate value. Null is returned if there are no colliders in the area. Note that this function will allocate memory for the returned Collider2D object. You can use OverlapAreaNonAlloc to avoid this overhead if you need to make the check frequently. See Also: OverlapCircle, OverlapPoint, OverlapCircleAll, OverlapAreaNonAlloc.
member.param: Diagonally opposite corner of the rectangle.
Filter to check objects only on specific layers.
Only include objects with a Z coordinate (depth) greater than this value.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.OverlapArea(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single)

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.OverlapAreaAll(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Get a list of all colliders that fall within a rectangular area.
member.remarks: This function is similar to OverlapArea except that all colliders that fall within the area are returned. The colliders in the returned array are sorted in order of increasing Z coordinate. An empty array is returned if there are no colliders within the area. Note that this function will allocate memory for the returned Collider2D array. You can use OverlapAreaNonAlloc to avoid this overhead if you need to make the check frequently. See Also: OverlapArea, OverlapAreaNonAlloc.
member.param: Diagonally opposite corner of the rectangle.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.OverlapAreaNonAlloc(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Collider2D[])
member.summary: Get a list of all colliders that fall within a specified area.
member.remarks: This function is similar to OverlapAreaAll except that the results are returned in the supplied array. The integer return value is the number of objects that fall within the area (possibly zero) but the results array will not be resized if it doesn't contain enough elements to report all the results. The significance of this is that no memory is allocated for the results and so garbage collection performance is improved when the check is performed frequently. See Also: OverlapArea, OverlapAreaAll.
member.param: Diagonally opposite corner of the rectangle.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.OverlapCircle(UnityEngine.Vector2,System.Single)
member.summary: Check if a collider falls within a circular area.
member.remarks: The circle is defined by its centre coordinate in world space and by its radius. The optional layerMask allows the test to check only for objects on specific layers. Although the Z axis is not relevant for rendering or collisions in 2D, you can use the minDepth and maxDepth parameters to filter objects based on their Z coordinate. If more than one collider falls within the circle then the one returned will be the one with the lowest Z coordinate value. Null is returned if there are no colliders in the circle. Note that this function will allocate memory for the returned Collider2D object. You can use OverlapCircleNonAlloc to avoid this overhead if you need to make the check frequently. See Also: OverlapArea, OverlapPoint, OverlapCircleAll, OverlapCircleNonAlloc.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.OverlapPoint(UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Check if a collider overlaps a point in space.
member.remarks: The optional layerMask allows the test to check only for objects on specific layers. Although the Z axis is not relevant for rendering or collisions in 2D, you can use the minDepth and maxDepth parameters to filter objects based on their Z coordinate. If more than one collider overlaps the point then the one returned will be the one with the lowest Z coordinate value. Null is returned if there are no colliders over the point. Note that this function will allocate memory for the returned Collider2D object. You can use OverlapPointNonAlloc to avoid this overhead if you need to make the check frequently. See Also: OverlapArea, OverlapCircle, OverlapPointAll, OverlapPointNonAlloc.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Physics2D.positionIterations
member.summary: The number of iterations of the physics solver when considering objects' positions.
member.remarks: A higher number of interations will improve accuracy at the expense of processing overhead. See Also: velocityIterations.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.Raycast(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Casts a ray against colliders in the scene.
member.remarks: A raycast is conceptually like a laser beam that is fired from a point in space along a particular direction. Any object making contact with the beam can be detected and reported. This function returns a RaycastHit object when a collider is hit by the ray or null otherwise. The layerMask can be used to detect objects selectively only on certain layers (this allows you to apply the detection only to enemy characters, for example). Raycasts are useful for determining lines of sight, targets hit by gunfire and for many other purposes in gameplay. Additionally, this will also detect Collider(s) at the start of the ray. In this case the ray is starting inside the Collider and doesn't intersect the Collider surface. This means that the collision normal cannot be calculated in which case the collision normal returned is set to the inverse of the ray vector being tested. This can easily be detected because such results are always at a RaycastHit2D fraction of zero. See Also: LayerMask::ref:: class, RaycastHit2D::ref:: class, RaycastAll, Linecast, defaultRaycastLayers, ignoreRaycastLayer, raycastsHitTriggers.
member.param: The point in 2D space where the ray originates.
Vector representing the direction of the ray.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.Raycast(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,System.Single)
member.summary: Casts a ray against colliders in the scene.
member.remarks: A raycast is conceptually like a laser beam that is fired from a point in space along a particular direction. Any object making contact with the beam can be detected and reported. This function returns a RaycastHit object when a collider is hit by the ray or null otherwise. The layerMask can be used to detect objects selectively only on certain layers (this allows you to apply the detection only to enemy characters, for example). Raycasts are useful for determining lines of sight, targets hit by gunfire and for many other purposes in gameplay. Additionally, this will also detect Collider(s) at the start of the ray. In this case the ray is starting inside the Collider and doesn't intersect the Collider surface. This means that the collision normal cannot be calculated in which case the collision normal returned is set to the inverse of the ray vector being tested. This can easily be detected because such results are always at a RaycastHit2D fraction of zero. See Also: LayerMask::ref:: class, RaycastHit2D::ref:: class, RaycastAll, Linecast, defaultRaycastLayers, ignoreRaycastLayer, raycastsHitTriggers.
member.param: The point in 2D space where the ray originates.
Vector representing the direction of the ray.
Maximum distance over which to cast the ray.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.RaycastAll(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Casts a ray against colliders in the scene, returning all colliders that contact with it.
member.remarks: A raycast is conceptually like a laser beam that is fired from a point in space along a particular direction. Any object making contact with the beam can be detected and reported. This function is similar to the Raycast function but instead of detecting just the first collider that is hit, an array of all colliders along the path of the ray is returned. The colliders in the array are sorted in order of distance from the origin point. The layerMask can be used to detect objects selectively only on certain layers (this allows you to apply the detection only to enemy characters, for example). Raycasts are useful for determining lines of sight, targets hit by gunfire and for many other purposes in gameplay. Additionally, this will also detect Collider(s) at the start of the ray. In this case the ray is starting inside the Collider and doesn't intersect the Collider surface. This means that the collision normal cannot be calculated in which case the collision normal returned is set to the inverse of the ray vector being tested. This can easily be detected because such results are always at a RaycastHit2D fraction of zero. See Also: LayerMask::ref:: class, RaycastHit2D::ref:: class, Raycast, Linecast, defaultRaycastLayers, ignoreRaycastLayer, raycastsHitTriggers.
member.param: The point in 2D space where the ray originates.
Vector representing the direction of the ray.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Physics2D.RaycastNonAlloc(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.RaycastHit2D[])
member.summary: Casts a ray into the scene.
member.remarks: This function is similar to the RaycastAll function except that the results are returned in the supplied array. The integer return value is the number of objects that intersect the line (possibly zero) but the results array will not be resized if it doesn't contain enough elements to report all the results. The significance of this is that no memory is allocated for the results and so garbage collection performance is improved when raycasts are performed frequently. Additionally, this will also detect Collider(s) at the start of the ray. In this case the ray is starting inside the Collider and doesn't intersect the Collider surface. This means that the collision normal cannot be calculated in which case the collision normal returned is set to the inverse of the ray vector being tested. This can easily be detected because such results are always at a RaycastHit2D fraction of zero. See Also: LayerMask::ref:: class, RaycastHit2D::ref:: class, Raycast, Linecast, defaultRaycastLayers, ignoreRaycastLayer, raycastsHitTriggers.
member.param: The point in 2D space where the ray originates.
Vector representing the direction of the ray.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Physics2D.raycastsHitTriggers
member.summary: Do raycasts detect Colliders configured as triggers?
member.remarks: A Collider can be set up to act as a trigger which will detect other Colliders entering its volume but won't physically collide with them. Often, it is desirable to avoid detecting trigger Colliders with raycasts because they don't represent solid objects. This property lets you choose whether or not raycasts should detect triggers. See Also: Collider2D.isTrigger, Raycast.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Physics2D.velocityIterations
member.summary: The number of iterations of the physics solver when considering objects' velocities.
member.remarks: A higher number of interations will improve accuracy at the expense of processing overhead. See Also: positionIterations.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.PhysicsMaterial2D
member.summary: Asset type that defines the surface properties of a Collider2D.
member.remarks: Note: the 3D equivalent of this class is spelt as "PhysicMaterial" with no S, but this class is spelt "Physic s Material" with an S. See Also: PhysicMaterial::ref:: class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.PhysicsMaterial2D.bounciness
member.summary: The degree of elasticity during collisions.
member.remarks: A value of zero indicates no elasticity (ie, no bounce at all) while a value of one indicates perfect elasticity. See Also: PhysicMaterial.bounciness.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.PhysicsMaterial2D.friction
member.remarks: A value of zero indicates a surface with no friction while a value of 1 indicates maximum friction (eg, rubber). See Also: PhysicMaterial.staticFriction.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Ping
member.summary: Ping any given IP address (given in dot notation).
member.remarks: The ping operation is asynchronous and a ping object can be polled for status using Ping.isDone. When a response is received it is in Ping.time.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Ping.ip
member.summary: The IP target of the ping.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Ping.time
member.summary: This property contains the ping time result after isDone returns true.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Plane
member.summary: Representation of a plane in 3D space.
member.remarks: A plane is an infinitely large, flat surface that exists in 3D space and divides the space into two halves known as half-spaces. It is easy to determine which of the two half-spaces a particular point is in and also how far the point is from the plane. Walls, floors and other flat surfaces are common in games, so a plane is sometimes useful for mathematical calculations with these objects. Also, there are cases where a real surface does not exist but it is useful to imagine that one is there. For example, in sports, a goal line or out-of-bounds line is often assumed to extend into the air, effectively defining a plane. When a plane passes through the point in world space, it is defined simply by a normal vector that determines which way it faces. It is easy to visualise this if you imagine looking at the plane edge-on.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Plane.distance
member.summary: Distance from the origin to the plane.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Plane.GetDistanceToPoint(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns a signed distance from plane to point.
member.remarks: The value returned is positive if the point is on the side of the plane into which the plane's normal is facing, and negative otherwise.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Plane.GetSide(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Is a point on the positive side of the plane?

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Plane.Raycast(UnityEngine.Ray,System.Single@)
member.summary: Intersects a ray with the plane.
member.remarks: This function sets enter to the distance along the ray, where it intersects the plane. If the ray is parallel to the plane, function returns false and sets enter to zero. If the ray is pointing in the opposite direction than the plane, function returns false and sets enter to the distance along the ray (negative value).See Also: Physics.Raycast.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Plane.SameSide(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Are two points on the same side of the plane?

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Plane.Set3Points(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Sets a plane using three points that lie within it. The points go around clockwise as you look down on the top surface of the plane.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Plane.SetNormalAndPosition(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Sets a plane using a point that lies within it along with a normal to orient it.
member.remarks: Note that the normal must be a normalised vector.See Also: Set3Points.
member.param: A point that lies on the plane.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs
member.summary: Stores and accesses player preferences between game sessions.
member.remarks: Editor/Standalone On Mac OS X PlayerPrefs are stored in ~ Library Preferences folder, in a file named unity.[company name].[product name].plist, where company and product names are the names set up in Project Settings. The same .plist file is used for both Projects run in the Editor and standalone players. On Windows, PlayerPrefs are stored in the registry under HKCU\Software\[company name]\[product name] key, where company and product names are the names set up in Project Settings. On Linux, PlayerPrefs can be found in ~/.config unity3d [CompanyName]/[ProductName] again using the company and product names specified in the Project Settings. WebPlayer On Web players, PlayerPrefs are stored in binary files in the following locations: Mac OS X: ~ Library Preferences Unity WebPlayerPrefs Windows: %APPDATA%\Unity\WebPlayerPrefs There is one preference file per Web player URL and the file size is limited to 1 megabyte. If this limit is exceeded, SetInt, SetFloat and SetString will not store the value and throw a PlayerPrefsException.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.DeleteAll
member.summary: Removes all keys and values from the preferences. Use with caution.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.DeleteKey(System.String)
member.summary: Removes key and its corresponding value from the preferences.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.GetFloat(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the value corresponding to key in the preference file if it exists.
member.remarks: If it doesn't exist, it will return defaultValue.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.GetFloat(System.String,System.Single)
member.summary: Returns the value corresponding to key in the preference file if it exists.
member.remarks: If it doesn't exist, it will return defaultValue.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.GetInt(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the value corresponding to key in the preference file if it exists.
member.remarks: If it doesn't exist, it will return defaultValue.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.GetInt(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the value corresponding to key in the preference file if it exists.
member.remarks: If it doesn't exist, it will return defaultValue.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.GetString(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the value corresponding to key in the preference file if it exists.
member.remarks: If it doesn't exist, it will return defaultValue.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.GetString(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Returns the value corresponding to key in the preference file if it exists.
member.remarks: If it doesn't exist, it will return defaultValue.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.HasKey(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if key exists in the preferences.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.Save
member.summary: Writes all modified preferences to disk.
member.remarks: By default Unity writes preferences to disk on Application Quit. In case when the game crashes or otherwise prematuraly exits, you might want to write the PlayerPrefs at sensible 'checkpoints' in your game. This function will write to disk potentially causing a small hiccup, therefore it is not recommended to call during actual gameplay.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.SetFloat(System.String,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the value of the preference identified by key.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.SetInt(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the value of the preference identified by key.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefs.SetString(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Sets the value of the preference identified by key.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.PlayerPrefsException
member.summary: An exception thrown by the PlayerPrefs class in a web player build.
member.remarks: The exception is thrown when writing to a preference file exceeds the allotted storage space. The storage space is 1MB for a web player. This exception is not thrown on other platforms.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.PlayMode.StopAll
member.summary: Will stop all animations that were started with this component before playing.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.PlayMode.StopSameLayer
member.summary: Will stop all animations that were started in the same layer. This is the default when playing animations.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.PolygonCollider2D
member.summary: Collider for 2D physics representing an arbitrary polygon defined by its vertices.
member.remarks: See Also: BoxCollider2D class, CircleCollider2D class.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PolygonCollider2D.CreatePrimitive(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates as regular primitive polygon with the specified number of sides.
member.param: The number of sides in the polygon. This must be greater than two.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PolygonCollider2D.CreatePrimitive(System.Int32,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Creates as regular primitive polygon with the specified number of sides.
member.param: The number of sides in the polygon. This must be greater than two.
The X/Y scale of the polygon. These must be greater than zero.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PolygonCollider2D.CreatePrimitive(System.Int32,UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Creates as regular primitive polygon with the specified number of sides.
member.param: The number of sides in the polygon. This must be greater than two.
The X/Y scale of the polygon. These must be greater than zero.
The X/Y offset of the polygon.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PolygonCollider2D.GetPath(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a path from the polygon by its index.
member.remarks: A path is cyclic sequence of line segments between points that define the outline of the polygon. Since the polygon can have holes and discontinuous parts, its shape is not necessarily defined by a single path. The returned value is an ordered array of the points in the path. See Also: pathCount, SetPath.
member.param: The index of the path to retrieve.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.PolygonCollider2D.GetTotalPointCount
member.summary: Return the total number of points in the polygon in all paths.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.PolygonCollider2D.pathCount

member.remarks: A path is cyclic sequence of line segments between points that define the outline of the polygon. Since the polygon can have holes and discontinuous parts, its shape is not necessarily defined by a single path. See Also: pathCount, GetPath.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ProceduralCacheSize
member.remarks: This also affects the amount of working memory for the generation of the ProceduralMaterial.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ProceduralCacheSize.Heavy
member.summary: A limit of 512MB for the cache or the working memory.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ProceduralCacheSize.Medium
member.summary: A limit of 256MB for the cache or the working memory.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ProceduralCacheSize.NoLimit
member.summary: No limit for the cache or the working memory.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ProceduralCacheSize.Tiny

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ProceduralLoadingBehavior.BakeAndDiscard
member.summary: Bake the textures to speed up loading and discard the ProceduralMaterial data (default on unsupported platform).

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ProceduralLoadingBehavior.BakeAndKeep
member.summary: Bake the textures to speed up loading and keep the ProceduralMaterial data so that it can still be tweaked and regenerated later on.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ProceduralLoadingBehavior.Cache
member.summary: Generate the textures when loading and cache them to disk/flash to speed up subsequent game/application startups.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ProceduralLoadingBehavior.DoNothing
member.summary: Do not generate the textures. RebuildTextures() or RebuildTexturesImmediately() must be called to generate the textures.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.ProceduralLoadingBehavior.Generate
member.summary: Generate the textures when loading to favor application's size (default on supported platform).

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ProceduralMaterial
member.remarks: A reference to a ProceduralMaterial is usually assigned using "renderer.sharedMaterial as ProceduralMaterial".Note that accessing a ProceduralMaterial via renderer.material will create a runtime clone of the original ProceduralMaterial and can negatively impact performance.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ProceduralMaterial.animationUpdateRate
member.summary: Set or get the update rate in millisecond of the animated substance.
member.remarks: An animated substance is a ProceduralMaterial containing a $time input which is automatically generated.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ProceduralMaterial.CacheProceduralProperty(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Specifies if a named ProceduralProperty should be cached for efficient runtime tweaking.
member.remarks: Set this to true for all properties that you expect to be tweaking. It will take effect the next time the textures are rebuild, so call RebuildTextures after setting up these flags in order to prepare the cache. The fewer properties have caching enabled, the more efficient rebuilding the textures will be so consider carefully which properties are actually going to be changed. While modified properties are automatically cached for the next rebuild, this cache flag is persistent. See Also: IsProceduralPropertyCached, ClearCache.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.ProceduralMaterial.cacheSize
member.summary: Set or get the Procedural cache budget.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ProceduralMaterial.ClearCache
member.remarks: This frees up all memory used by the cache and sets all properties to not be cached anymore. Use this when you don't expect to make anymore changes to the ProceduralProperties for now. See Also: CacheProceduralProperty.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.ProceduralMaterial.GetGeneratedTexture(System.String)
member.summary: This allows to get a reference to a ProceduralTexture generated by a ProceduralMaterial using its name.
member.param: The name of the ProceduralTexture to get.

member.remarks: If enabled, the ProceduralMaterial will be generated when the scene loads. If disabled, the ProceduralMaterial will not be generated until RebuildTextures or RebuildTexturesImmediately is called. See Also: RebuildTextures, RebuildTexturesImmediately.
