member.name: P:UnityEngine.TextMesh.fontSize
member.summary: The font size to use (for dynamic fonts).
member.remarks: If this is set to a non-zero value, the font size specified in the font importer is overriden with a custom size. This is only supported for fonts set to use dynamic font rendering. Other fonts will always use the default font size.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TextMesh.fontStyle
member.summary: The font style to use (for dynamic fonts).
member.remarks: If this is set to a value other then normal, the font style set in the font importer is overriden with a custom style. This is only supported for fonts set to use dynamic font rendering. Other fonts will always render in normal style.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TextMesh.lineSpacing
member.summary: How much space will be in-between lines of text.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TextMesh.offsetZ
member.summary: How far should the text be offset from the transform.position.z when drawing.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TextMesh.richText
member.summary: Enable HTML-style tags for Text Formatting Markup.
member.remarks: Supported tags are: <color="htmlcolor">colored text</color>, where "htmlcolor" is a html color string, like "#ff0000" or "red". <b>bold text</b> <i>italic text</i> <size=20>sized text</size> <material=1>render using custom material index</material> <quad material=1 size=20 x=0.1 y=0.1 width=0.5 height=0.5/>, to render a single quad using the given material and UVs, used for embedding images in text. These are only supported for fonts set to use dynamic font rendering, except for the 'color', 'material' and 'quad' tags.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TextMesh.tabSize
member.summary: How much space will be inserted for a tab '\t' character. This is a multiplum of the 'spacebar' character offset.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Texture
member.summary: Base class for texture handling. Contains functionality that is common to both Texture2D and RenderTexture classes.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Texture.anisoLevel
member.summary: Anisotropic filtering level of the texture.
member.remarks: Anisotropic filtering makes textures look better when viewed at a shallow angle, but comes at a performance cost in the graphics hardware. Usually you use it on floor, ground or road textures to make them look better. The value range of this variable goes from 1 to 9, where 1 equals no filtering applied and 9 equals full filtering applied. As the value gets bigger, the texture is clearer at shallow angles. Lower values mean the texture will be more blurry at shallow angles. See Also: texture assets.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture.GetNativeTextureID
member.summary: Retrieve native ('hardware') handle to a texture.
member.remarks: Use this function to retrieve an ID/handle corresponding to a particular texture as it is represented on the native graphics device level. This can be used to enable texture manipulation from native code plugins. This function is only supported on OpenGL-like devices; for a better cross-platform approach use GetNativeTexturePtr. See Also: GetNativeTexturePtr function, Native code plugins.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture.GetNativeTexturePtr
member.summary: Retrieve native ('hardware') pointer to a texture.
member.remarks: Use this function to retrieve a pointer/handle corresponding to a particular texture as it is represented on the native graphics device level. This can be used to enable texture manipulation from native code plugins. On Direct3D-like devices this returns a pointer to the base texture type (IDirect3DBaseTexture9 on D3D9, ID3D11Resource on D3D11). On OpenGL-like devices the texture "name" is returned; cast the pointer to integer type to get it. On platforms that do not support native code plugins, this function always returns NULL. Note that calling this function when using multi-threaded rendering will synchronize with the rendering thread (a slow operation), so best practice is to set up needed texture pointers only at initialization time. See Also: Native code plugins.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Texture.height
member.summary: Height of the texture in pixels. (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Texture.mipMapBias
member.summary: Mip map bias of the texture.
member.remarks: A positive bias makes a texture appear extra blurry, while a negative bias sharpens the texture. Note that using large negative bias can reduce performance, so it's not recommended to use more than -0.5 negative bias. In most cases better sharpening of the texture can be achieved by using anisotropic filtering. See Also: Texture.anisoLevel, texture assets.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture.SetGlobalAnisotropicFilteringLimits(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.remarks: ForcedMin value controls the minimal anisotropy level set when Anisotropy is forced. globalMax value controls the max possible anisotropy level. set any to -1 to use default values.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Texture.width
member.summary: Width of the texture in pixels. (Read Only)

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Texture.wrapMode
member.summary: Wrap mode (Repeat or Clamp) of the texture.
member.remarks: Set the texture to clamp at the borders to avoid warping artifacts with TextureWrapMode.Clamp. Or tile the texture with TextureWrapMode.Repeat. See Also: Texture.wrapMode, texture assets.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Texture2D
member.summary: Class for texture handling. Use this to create textures on the fly or to modify existing texture assets.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.Apply
member.summary: Actually apply all previous SetPixel and SetPixels changes.
member.remarks: If updateMipmaps is true, the mipmap levels are recalculated as well, using the base level as a source. Usually you want to use true in all cases except when you've modified the mip levels yourself using SetPixels. By default updateMipmaps is set to true. If makeNoLongerReadable is true, texture will be marked as no longer readable and memory will be freed after uploading to GPU. By default makeNoLongerReadable is set to false. This is a potentially expensive operation, so you'll want to change as many pixels as possible between Apply calls. The texture has to have Is Readable flag set in the import settings.See Also: SetPixel, SetPixels functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.Apply(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Actually apply all previous SetPixel and SetPixels changes.
member.remarks: If updateMipmaps is true, the mipmap levels are recalculated as well, using the base level as a source. Usually you want to use true in all cases except when you've modified the mip levels yourself using SetPixels. By default updateMipmaps is set to true. If makeNoLongerReadable is true, texture will be marked as no longer readable and memory will be freed after uploading to GPU. By default makeNoLongerReadable is set to false. This is a potentially expensive operation, so you'll want to change as many pixels as possible between Apply calls. The texture has to have Is Readable flag set in the import settings.See Also: SetPixel, SetPixels functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.Apply(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Actually apply all previous SetPixel and SetPixels changes.
member.remarks: If updateMipmaps is true, the mipmap levels are recalculated as well, using the base level as a source. Usually you want to use true in all cases except when you've modified the mip levels yourself using SetPixels. By default updateMipmaps is set to true. If makeNoLongerReadable is true, texture will be marked as no longer readable and memory will be freed after uploading to GPU. By default makeNoLongerReadable is set to false. This is a potentially expensive operation, so you'll want to change as many pixels as possible between Apply calls. The texture has to have Is Readable flag set in the import settings.See Also: SetPixel, SetPixels functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.Compress(System.Boolean)
member.remarks: Use this to compress textures generated at runtime. Compressed textures use less graphics memory and are faster to render. After compression, texture will be in DXT1 format if the original texture had no alpha channel, and in DXT5 format if it had alpha channel. Passing true for highQuality parameter will dither the source texture during compression, which helps to reduce compression artifacts but is slightly slower. If the graphics card does not support compression or the texture is already in compressed format, then Compress will do nothing. In the Editor scripts, you probably want to use EditorUtility.CompressTexture, which will compress using slower, but higher quality DXT compression. See Also: SetPixels function, EditorUtility.CompressTexture.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.CreateExternalTexture(System.Int32,System.Int32,UnityEngine.TextureFormat,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Creates Unity Texture on top of already inited native texture object.
member.remarks: You should make sure that params specified here are the same as the ones used for creation of native texture. Native texture object on Direct3D-like devices is a pointer to the base type, from which a texture can be created (IDirect3DBaseTexture9 on D3D9, ID3D11ShaderResourceView on D3D11). On OpenGL/OpenGL ES it is GLuint.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.EncodeToPNG
member.summary: Encodes this texture into PNG format.
member.remarks: The returned byte array is the PNG "file". You can write them to disk to get the PNG file, send them over the network, etc. This function works only on ARGB32 and RGB24 texture formats. The texture also has to have Is Readable flag set in the import settings. The encoded PNG data will contain alpha channel for ARGB32 textures, and no alpha channel for RGB24 textures. PNG data will not contain gamma correction or color profile information.See Also: ReadPixels, WaitForEndOfFrame, LoadImage.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Texture2D.format
member.summary: The format of the pixel data in the texture (Read Only).
member.remarks: Use this to determine the format of the texture.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.GetPixel(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns pixel color at coordinates (x, y).
member.remarks: If the pixel coordinates are out of bounds (larger than width/height or small than 0), they will be clamped or repeat based on the texture's wrap mode. If you are reading a large block of pixels from the texture, it may be faster to use GetPixels which returns a whole block of pixel colors. The texture must have the Read/Write Enabled flag set in the import settings, otherwise this function will fail. See Also: GetPixels, SetPixel, GetPixelBilinear.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.GetPixelBilinear(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Returns filtered pixel color at normalized coordinates (u, v).
member.remarks: Coordinates u and v go from 0.0 to 1.0, just like UV coordinates in meshes. If coordinates are out of bounds (larger than 1.0 or smaller than 0.0), they will be clamped or repeated based on the texture's wrap mode. Returned pixel color is bilinearly filtered. The texture must have the Read/Write Enabled flag set in the import settings, otherwise this function will fail.See Also: GetPixel.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.GetPixels
member.summary: Get a block of pixel colors.Get a block of pixel colors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.GetPixels(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a block of pixel colors.Get a block of pixel colors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.GetPixels(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a block of pixel colors.Get a block of pixel colors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.GetPixels(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a block of pixel colors.Get a block of pixel colors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.GetPixels32
member.summary: Get a block of pixel colors in Color32 format.
member.remarks: This function returns an array of pixel colors of the whole mip level of the texture. The returned array is a flattened 2D array, where pixels are laid out left to right, bottom to top (i.e. row after row). Array size is width by height of the mip level used. The default mip level is zero (the base texture) in which case the size is just the size of the texture. In general case, mip level size is mipWidth=max(1,width>>miplevel) and similarly for height. The texture must have the Read/Write Enabled flag set in the import settings, otherwise this function will fail. Using GetPixels32 can be faster than calling GetPixel repeatedly, especially for large textures. In addition, GetPixels32 can access individual mipmap levels.See Also: SetPixels, mipmapCount.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.GetPixels32(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a block of pixel colors in Color32 format.
member.remarks: This function returns an array of pixel colors of the whole mip level of the texture. The returned array is a flattened 2D array, where pixels are laid out left to right, bottom to top (i.e. row after row). Array size is width by height of the mip level used. The default mip level is zero (the base texture) in which case the size is just the size of the texture. In general case, mip level size is mipWidth=max(1,width>>miplevel) and similarly for height. The texture must have the Read/Write Enabled flag set in the import settings, otherwise this function will fail. Using GetPixels32 can be faster than calling GetPixel repeatedly, especially for large textures. In addition, GetPixels32 can access individual mipmap levels.See Also: SetPixels, mipmapCount.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.LoadImage(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Loads an image from a byte array.
member.remarks: This function loads a JPG or PNG image from raw byte[] array.This function replaces texture contents with new image data. After LoadImage, texture size and format might change. JPG files are loaded into RGB24 format, PNG files are loaded into ARGB32 format. If texture format before calling LoadImage is DXT1 or DXT5, then the loaded image will be DXT-compressed (into DXT1 for JPG images and DXT5 for PNG images). See Also: EncodeToPNG function.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Texture2D.mipmapCount
member.summary: How many mipmap levels are in this texture (Read Only).
member.remarks: The returned value includes the base level as well, so it is always 1 or more. Mipmap count is used if you use GetPixels or SetPixels to fetch or modify the different mip levels. For example, you could change a texture so that each mip level is tinted in a different color - then in the game you'd see which mip levels are actually visible. See Also: GetPixels function, SetPixels function.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.PackTextures(UnityEngine.Texture2D[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Packs multiple Textures into a texture atlas.
member.returns: An array of rectangles containing the UV coordinates in the atlas for each input texture, or null if packing fails.
member.remarks: This function will replace the current texture with the atlas made from the supplied textures. The size, format and mipmaps of any of the textures can change after packing. The resulting texture atlas will be as large as needed to fit all input textures but only up to maximumAtlasSize in each dimension. If the input textures can't all fit into a texture atlas of the desired size then they will be scaled down to fit. The atlas will have DXT1 format if all input textures are DXT1 compressed. If all input textures are compressed in DXT1 or DXT5 formats then the atlas will be in DXT5 format. If any input texture is not compressed then the atlas will be in ARGB32 uncompressed format. If none of the input textures have mipmaps then the atlas will also have no mipmaps. If you use non-zero padding and the atlas is compressed and has mipmaps then the lower-level mipmaps might not be exactly the same as in the original texture due to compression restrictions. If makeNoLongerReadable is true then the texture will be marked as no longer readable and memory will be freed after uploading to the GPU. By default makeNoLongerReadable is set to false.
member.param: Array of textures to pack into the atlas.
Padding in pixels between the packed textures.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.PackTextures(UnityEngine.Texture2D[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Packs multiple Textures into a texture atlas.
member.returns: An array of rectangles containing the UV coordinates in the atlas for each input texture, or null if packing fails.
member.remarks: This function will replace the current texture with the atlas made from the supplied textures. The size, format and mipmaps of any of the textures can change after packing. The resulting texture atlas will be as large as needed to fit all input textures but only up to maximumAtlasSize in each dimension. If all input textures are compressed in DXT1 or DXT5 formats then the atlas will be in DXT5 format. If any input texture is not compressed then the atlas will be in ARGB32 uncompressed format. If none of the input textures have mipmaps then the atlas will also have no mipmaps. If you use non-zero padding and the atlas is compressed and has mipmaps then the lower-level mipmaps might not be exactly the same as in the original texture due to compression restrictions. If makeNoLongerReadable is true then the texture will be marked as no longer readable and memory will be freed after uploading to the GPU. By default makeNoLongerReadable is set to false.
member.param: Array of textures to pack into the atlas.
Padding in pixels between the packed textures.
Maximum size of the resulting texture.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.ReadPixels(UnityEngine.Rect,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Read screen pixels into the saved texture data.
member.remarks: This will copy a rectangular pixel area from the currently active RenderTexture or the view (specified by the source parameter) into the position defined by destX and destY. Both coordinates use pixel space - (0,0) is lower left. If recalculateMipMaps is set to true, the mip maps of the texture will also be updated. If recalculateMipMaps is set to false, you must call Apply to recalculate them. This function works only on ARGB32 and RGB24 texture formats. The texture also has to have Read/Write Enabled flag set in the import settings. ReadPixels is unsupported on Flash.See Also: EncodeToPNG.
member.param: Rectangular region of the view to read from.
Horizontal pixel position in the texture to place the pixels that are read.
Vertical pixel position in the texture to place the pixels that are read.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.ReadPixels(UnityEngine.Rect,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Read screen pixels into the saved texture data.
member.remarks: This will copy a rectangular pixel area from the currently active RenderTexture or the view (specified by the source parameter) into the position defined by destX and destY. Both coordinates use pixel space - (0,0) is lower left. If recalculateMipMaps is set to true, the mip maps of the texture will also be updated. If recalculateMipMaps is set to false, you must call Apply to recalculate them. This function works only on ARGB32 and RGB24 texture formats. The texture also has to have Read/Write Enabled flag set in the import settings. ReadPixels is unsupported on Flash.See Also: EncodeToPNG.
member.param: Rectangular region of the view to read from.
Horizontal pixel position in the texture to place the pixels that are read.
Vertical pixel position in the texture to place the pixels that are read.
Should the texture's mipmaps be recalculated after reading?

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.SetPixel(System.Int32,System.Int32,UnityEngine.Color)
member.remarks: Call Apply to actually upload the changed pixels to the graphics card. Uploading is an expensive operation, so you'll want to change as many pixels as possible between Apply calls. If you're constantly regenerating a texture at runtime, it may be faster to generate an array of pixel colors and set all of them at once with SetPixels. This function works only on ARGB32, RGB24 and Alpha8 texture formats. For other formats SetPixel is ignored. The texture also has to have Read/Write Enabled flag set in the import settings. See Also: SetPixels, GetPixel, Apply.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.SetPixels32(UnityEngine.Color32[])
member.summary: Set a block of pixel colors.
member.remarks: This function takes a Color32 array and changes the pixel colors of the whole mip level of the texture. Call Apply to actually upload the changed pixels to the graphics card. The colors array is a flattened 2D array, where pixels are laid out left to right, bottom to top (i.e. row after row). Array size must be at least width by height of the mip level used. The default mip level is zero (the base texture) in which case the size is just the size of the texture. In general case, mip level size is mipWidth=max(1,width>>miplevel) and similarly for height. This function works only on ARGB32 texture formats. For other formats SetPixels32 is ignored. The texture also has to have Is Readable flag set in the import settings. Using SetPixels32 is faster than calling SetPixels. See Also: SetPixels, GetPixels32, GetPixels, Apply, mipmapCount.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.SetPixels32(UnityEngine.Color32[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Set a block of pixel colors.
member.remarks: This function takes a Color32 array and changes the pixel colors of the whole mip level of the texture. Call Apply to actually upload the changed pixels to the graphics card. The colors array is a flattened 2D array, where pixels are laid out left to right, bottom to top (i.e. row after row). Array size must be at least width by height of the mip level used. The default mip level is zero (the base texture) in which case the size is just the size of the texture. In general case, mip level size is mipWidth=max(1,width>>miplevel) and similarly for height. This function works only on ARGB32 texture formats. For other formats SetPixels32 is ignored. The texture also has to have Is Readable flag set in the import settings. Using SetPixels32 is faster than calling SetPixels. See Also: SetPixels, GetPixels32, GetPixels, Apply, mipmapCount.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture2D.UpdateExternalTexture(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Updates Unity Texture to use different native texture object.
member.remarks: Native texture object on Direct3D-like devices is a pointer to the base type, from which a texture can be created (IDirect3DBaseTexture9 on D3D9, ID3D11ShaderResourceView on D3D11). On OpenGL/OpenGL ES it is GLuint.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Texture3D
member.summary: Class for handling 3D Textures, Use this to create 3D texture assets.
member.remarks: 3D textures are commonly used as lookup tables by shaders.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture3D.Apply
member.summary: Actually apply all previous SetPixels changes.
member.remarks: If updateMipmaps is true, the mipmap levels are recalculated as well, using the base level as a source. Usually you want to use true in all cases except when you've modified the mip levels yourself using SetPixels. This is a potentially expensive operation, so you'll want to change as many pixels as possible between Apply calls. See Also: SetPixels functions.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Texture3D.Apply(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Actually apply all previous SetPixels changes.
member.remarks: If updateMipmaps is true, the mipmap levels are recalculated as well, using the base level as a source. Usually you want to use true in all cases except when you've modified the mip levels yourself using SetPixels. This is a potentially expensive operation, so you'll want to change as many pixels as possible between Apply calls. See Also: SetPixels functions.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Texture3D.format

member.remarks: Use this to determine the format of the texture.

member.summary: This function returns an array of pixel colors representing one mip level of the 3D texture.
member.remarks: Call Apply to actually upload the changed.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.TextureWrapMode
member.summary: Wrap mode for textures. Corresponds to the settings in a texture inspector.
member.remarks: You can either Tile the texture (Repeat) or map a single texture on the object (Clamp) See Also: Texture.wrapMode, texture assets.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.TextureWrapMode.Clamp
member.summary: Clamps the texture to the last pixel at the border.
member.remarks: This is useful for preventing wrapping artifacts when mapping an image onto an object and you don't want the texture to tile. UV coordinates will be clamped to the range 0...1. When UVs are larger than 1 or smaller than 0, the last pixel at the border will be used. See Also: Texture.wrapMode, texture assets.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.TextureWrapMode.Repeat
member.summary: Tiles the texture, creating a repeating pattern.
member.remarks: When UVs are outside of the 0...1 range, the integer part will be ignored, thus creating a repeating pattern. See Also: Texture.wrapMode, texture assets.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.ThreadPriority
member.remarks: Lower priority means a background operation will run less often and will take up less time, but will progress more slowly. See Also: Application.backgroundLoadingPriority, WWW.threadPriority.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Time
member.summary: The interface to get time information from Unity.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Time.captureFramerate
member.summary: Slows game playback time to allow screenshots to be saved between frames.
member.remarks: If this property has a non-zero value then frame update will occur at an interval of (1.0 / captureFramerate) regardless of real time and the time required to render a frame. This is useful if you want to capture a movie where you need a constant frame rate and leave enough time between frames to save screen images.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Time.deltaTime
member.summary: The time in seconds it took to complete the last frame (Read Only).
member.remarks: Use this function to make your game frame rate independent. If you add or subtract to a value every frame chances are you should multiply with Time.deltaTime. When you multiply with Time.deltaTime you essentially express: I want to move this object 10 meters per second instead of 10 meters per frame. When called from inside MonoBehaviour's FixedUpdate, returns the fixed framerate delta time. Note that you should not rely on Time.deltaTime from inside OnGUI since OnGUI can be called multiple times per frame and deltaTime would hold the same value each call, until next frame where it would be updated again.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Time.fixedDeltaTime
member.summary: The interval in seconds at which physics and other fixed frame rate updates (like MonoBehaviour's FixedUpdate) are performed.
member.remarks: For reading the delta time it is recommended to use Time.deltaTime instead because it automatically returns the right delta time if you are inside a FixedUpdate function or Update function. Note that the fixedDeltaTime interval is with respect to the in-game time affected by timeScale.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Time.fixedTime
member.summary: The time the latest FixedUpdate has started (Read Only). This is the time in seconds since the start of the game.
member.remarks: Fixed time is updated in regular intervals (equal to fixedDeltaTime ) until time property is reached.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Time.frameCount
member.summary: The total number of frames that have passed (Read Only).

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Time.maximumDeltaTime
member.summary: The maximum time a frame can take. Physics and other fixed frame rate updates (like MonoBehaviour's FixedUpdate).
member.remarks: Will be performed only for this duration of time per frame. Use this function to avoid low frame rate spikes occurring due to combination of GarbageCollector and expensive physics or other fixed frame rate updates. If frame will take longer than specified value, then less physics and other fixed frame rate updates will be performed. That will temporarily slow down the gameplay, but will allow frame rate to catchup avoiding nasty stuttering. It is advisable to keep maximum time for frame between 1/10th and 1/3th of a second.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Time.realtimeSinceStartup
member.summary: The real time in seconds since the game started (Read Only).
member.remarks: In almost all cases you can and should use Time.time instead. realtimeSinceStartup returns the time since startup, not affected by Time.timeScale. realtimeSinceStartup also keeps increasing while the player is paused (in the background). Using realtimeSinceStartup is useful when you want to pause the game by setting Time.timeScale to zero, but still want to be able to measure time somehow. Note that realtimeSinceStartup returns time as reported by system timer. Depending on the platform and the hardware, it may report the same time even in several consecutive frames. If you're dividing something by time difference, take this into account (time difference may become zero!).Another example:

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Time.time
member.summary: The time this frame has started (Read Only). This is the time in seconds since the start of the game.
member.remarks: When called from inside MonoBehaviour's FixedUpdate, returns fixedTime property.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Time.timeScale
member.summary: The scale at which the time is passing. This can be used for slow motion effects.
member.remarks: When timeScale is 1.0 the time is passing as fast as realtime. When timeScale is 0.5 the time is passing 2x slower than realtime. When timeScale is set to zero the game is basically paused if all your functions are frame rate independent. Except for realtimeSinceStartup, timeScale affects all the time and delta time measuring variables of the Time class. If you lower timeScale it is recommended to also lower Time.fixedDeltaTime by the same amount. FixedUpdate functions will not be called when timeScale is set to zero.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Time.timeSinceLevelLoad
member.summary: The time this frame has started (Read Only). This is the time in seconds since the last level has been loaded.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Touch
member.summary: Structure describing the status of a finger touching the screen.
member.remarks: Devices can track a number of different pieces of data about a touch on a touchscreen, including its phase (ie, whether it has just started, ended or moved), its position and whether the touch was a single contact or several taps. Furthermore, the continuity of a touch between frame updates can be detected by the device, so a consistent ID number can be reported across frames and used to determine how a particular finger is moving. The Touch struct is used by Unity to store data relating to a single touch instance and is returned by the Input.GetTouch function. Fresh calls to GetTouch will be required on each frame update to obtain the latest touch information from the device but the fingerID property can be used to identify the same touch between frames. See Also: Input.GetTouch, TouchPhase enum.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Touch.deltaPosition
member.summary: The position delta since last change.
member.remarks: The absolute position of the touch is recorded periodically and available in the position property. The deltaPosition value is a Vector2 that represents the difference between the touch position recorded on the most recent update and that recorded on the previous update. The deltaTime value gives the time that elapsed between the previous and current updates; you can calculate the touch's speed of motion by dividing deltaPosition.magnitude by deltaTime. See Also: deltaTime.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Touch.deltaTime
member.summary: Amount of time that has passed since the last recorded change in Touch values.
member.remarks: Values for the various touch properties are updated periodically. The deltaTime value is simply the amount of time that elapsed between the previous update and the current one. This is primarily useful for determining the movement speed of the touch position with reference to deltaPosition. See Also: deltaPosition.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Touch.fingerId
member.summary: The unique index for the touch.
member.remarks: All current touches are reported in the Input.touches array or by using the Input.GetTouch function with the equivalent array index. However, the array index is not guaranteed to be the same from one frame to the next. The fingerID value, however, consistently refers to the same touch across frames. This ID value is very useful when analysing gestures and is more reliable than identifying fingers by their proximity to previous position, etc.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Touch.phase
member.summary: Describes the phase of the touch.
member.remarks: The touch phase refers to the action the finger has taken on the most recent frame update. Since a touch is tracked over its "lifetime" by the device, the start and end of a touch and movements in between can be reported on the frames they occur. The phase property can be used as the basis of a "switch' statement or as part of a more sophisitcated state handling system.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Touch.position
member.summary: The position of the touch in pixel coordinates.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Touch.tapCount
member.remarks: This is intended as a way to detect "double-clicks", etc, from the finger in a particular position. In some circumstances, two fingers may be tapped alternately and this may incorrectly register as a single finger tapping and simultaneously moving.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.TouchPhase
member.summary: Describes phase of a finger touch.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.TouchPhase.Canceled
member.summary: The system cancelled tracking for the touch.
member.remarks: This might happen if, for example, the user puts the device to her face or simultaneously applies more touches than the system can track (the exact number varies with different platforms). This is the final phase of a touch.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.TouchPhase.Ended
member.summary: A finger was lifted from the screen. This is the final phase of a touch.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.TouchPhase.Moved
member.summary: A finger moved on the screen.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.TouchPhase.Stationary
member.summary: A finger is touching the screen but hasn't moved.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.TouchScreenKeyboard
member.summary: Interface into the native iPhone and Android on-screen keyboards - it is not available on other platforms.
member.remarks: This interface allows to display different types of the keyboard: ASCII, Numbers, URL, Email, and others. Because the appearance of the keyboard has the potential to obscure portions of your user interface, it is up to you to make sure that parts of your user interface are not obscured when the keyboard is being displayed. TouchScreenKeyboard.visible and TouchScreenKeyboard.area should be used to determine if the keyboard is being shown (activated) and what portion of the screen is using.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TouchScreenKeyboard.active
member.summary: Is the keyboard visible or sliding into the position on the screen?
member.remarks: Use this property to bring previously hidden keyboard back on the screen.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TouchScreenKeyboard.area
member.summary: Returns portion of the screen which is covered by the keyboard.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TouchScreenKeyboard.done
member.summary: Specifies if input process was finished. (Read Only)
member.remarks: Keyboard input process can be finished either by user tapping "Done" button or script setting active property to false. Note that keyboard might be temporarily inactive (either by sliding in/out due to orientation change or by appearance of another keyboard), however it's input process might still be not finished and will be resumed automatically.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TouchScreenKeyboard.hideInput
member.summary: Will text input field above the keyboard be hidden when the keyboard is on screen?
member.remarks: This property is applicable for single line text fields that have assigned keyboard with alphanumeric keys. Number-only keyboards will show text input field no matter if this flag is set to true or false.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.TouchScreenKeyboard.Open(System.String)
member.summary: Opens the native keyboard provided by OS on the screen.
member.remarks: The autocorrection determines whether the input tracks unknown words and suggests a more suitable replacement candidate to the user, replacing the typed text automatically unless the user explicitly overrides the action. The multiline determines if user can input more than one line of text. The secure identifies whether the keyboard is used for password. Text in the input field will be hidden from the user except the recently typed character. The keyboard can be opened in the alert mode too. The placeholder string will be displayed when there is no other text in the input field of the keyboard.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.TouchScreenKeyboard.Open(System.String,UnityEngine.TouchScreenKeyboardType)

member.remarks: The autocorrection determines whether the input tracks unknown words and suggests a more suitable replacement candidate to the user, replacing the typed text automatically unless the user explicitly overrides the action. The multiline determines if user can input more than one line of text. The secure identifies whether the keyboard is used for password. Text in the input field will be hidden from the user except the recently typed character. The keyboard can be opened in the alert mode too. The placeholder string will be displayed when there is no other text in the input field of the keyboard.
member.param: Type of keyboard (eg, any text, numbers only, etc).

member.name: T:UnityEngine.TrailRenderer
member.summary: The trail renderer is used to make trails behind objects in the scene as they move about.
member.remarks: This class is a script interface for a trail renderer component.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TrailRenderer.autodestruct
member.summary: Does the GameObject of this trail renderer auto destructs?
member.remarks: When set to true, the GameObject will be destroyed when it is not moving anymore.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TrailRenderer.endWidth
member.summary: The width of the trail at the end of the trail.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TrailRenderer.startWidth
member.summary: The width of the trail at the spawning point.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.TrailRenderer.time
member.summary: How long does the trail take to fade out.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Transform
member.summary: Position, rotation and scale of an object.
member.remarks: Every object in a scene has a Transform. It's used to store and manipulate the position, rotation and scale of the object. Every Transform can have a parent, which allows you to apply position, rotation and scale hierarchically. This is the hierarchy seen in the Hierarchy pane. They also support enumerators so you can loop through children using:See Also: The component reference, Physics class.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Transform.childCount
member.summary: The number of children the Transform has.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Transform.DetachChildren
member.remarks: Useful if you want to destroy the root of a hierarchy without destroying the children.See Also: Transform.parent to detach/change the parent of a single transform.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Transform.eulerAngles
member.summary: The rotation as Euler angles in degrees.
member.remarks: The x, y, and z angles represent a rotation z degrees around the z axis, x degrees around the x axis, and y degrees around the y axis (in that order). Only use this variable to read and set the angles to absolute values. Don't increment them, as it will fail when the angle exceeds 360 degrees. Use Transform.Rotate instead.Do not set one of the eulerAngles axis separately (eg. eulerAngles.x = 10; ) since this will lead to drift and undesired rotations. When setting them to a new value set them all at once as shown above. Unity will convert the angles to and from the rotation stored in Transform.rotation.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Transform.Find(System.String)
member.summary: Finds a child by name and returns it.
member.remarks: If no child with name can be found, null is returned. If name contains a '/' character it will traverse the hierarchy like a path name.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Transform.forward
member.summary: The blue axis of the transform in world space.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Transform.GetChild(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a transform child by index.
member.param: Index of the child transform to return. Must be smaller then Transform.childCount.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Transform.hasChanged
member.summary: Has the transform changed since the last time the flag was set to 'false'?
member.remarks: A change to the transform can be anything that can cause its matrix to be recalculated: any adjustment to its position, rotation or scale. Note that operations which can change the transform will not actually check if the old and new value are different before setting this flag. So setting, for instance, transform.position will always set hasChanged on the transform, regardless of there being any actual change.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Transform.InverseTransformDirection(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Transforms a direction from world space to local space. The opposite of Transform.TransformDirection.Transforms the direction x, y, z from world space to local space. The opposite of Transform.TransformDirection.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Transform.InverseTransformDirection(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Transforms a direction from world space to local space. The opposite of Transform.TransformDirection.Transforms the direction x, y, z from world space to local space. The opposite of Transform.TransformDirection.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Transform.InverseTransformPoint(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Transforms position from world space to local space. The opposite of Transform.TransformPoint.Transforms the position x, y, z from world space to local space. The opposite of Transform.TransformPoint.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Transform.InverseTransformPoint(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Transforms position from world space to local space. The opposite of Transform.TransformPoint.Transforms the position x, y, z from world space to local space. The opposite of Transform.TransformPoint.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Transform.IsChildOf(UnityEngine.Transform)
member.summary: Is this transform a child of parent?
member.remarks: Returns a boolean value that indicates whether the transform is a child of a given transform. true if this transform is a child, deep child (child of a child) or identical to this transform, otherwise false.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Transform.localEulerAngles
member.summary: The rotation as Euler angles in degrees relative to the parent transform's rotation.
member.remarks: The x, y, and z angles represent a rotation z degrees around the z axis, x degrees around the x axis, and y degrees around the y axis (in that order). Only use this variable to read and set the angles to absolute values. Don't increment them, as it will fail when the angle exceeds 360 degrees. Use Transform.Rotate instead.Unity automatically converts the angles to and from the rotation stored in Transform.localRotation.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Transform.localPosition
member.summary: Position of the transform relative to the parent transform.
member.remarks: If the transform has no parent, it is the same as Transform.position.Note that the parent transform's world rotation and scale are applied to the local position when calculating the world position. This means that while 1 unit in Transform.position is always 1 unit, 1 unit in Transform.localPosition will get scaled by the scale of all ancestors.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Transform.localRotation
member.summary: The rotation of the transform relative to the parent transform's rotation.
member.remarks: Unity stores rotations as Quaternions internally. To rotate an object, use Transform.Rotate. Use Transform.localEulerAngles for modifying the rotation as euler angles.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Transform.localScale
member.summary: The scale of the transform relative to the parent.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Transform.localToWorldMatrix
member.summary: Matrix that transforms a point from local space into world space (Read Only).
member.remarks: If you're not familiar with using matrices for coordinate transformations, use Transform.TransformPoint instead. IMPORTANT: If you're setting shader parameters you MUST use Renderer.localToWorldMatrix instead.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Transform.lossyScale
member.summary: The global scale of the object (Read Only).
member.remarks: Please note that if you have a parent transform with scale and a child that is arbitrarily rotated, the scale will be skewed. Thus scale can not be represented correctly in a 3 component vector but only a 3x3 matrix. Such a representation is quite inconvenient to work with however. lossyScale is a convenience property that attempts to match the actual world scale as much as it can. If your objects are not skewed the value will be completely correct and most likely the value will not be very different if it contains skew too.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.TransparencySortMode
member.summary: Transparent object sorting mode of a Camera.
member.remarks: By default, perspective cameras sort objects based on distance from camera position to the object center; and orthographic cameras sort based on distance along the view direction. If you're making a 2D game with a perspective camera, you might want to use TransparencySortMode.Orthographic sort mode so that objects are sorted based on distance along the camera's view. See Also: Camera.transparencySortMode.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.TransparencySortMode.Orthographic
member.remarks: Transparent objects will be sorted based on distance along the camera's view. See Also: Camera.transparencySortMode.

member.name: F:UnityEngine.TransparencySortMode.Perspective
member.remarks: Transparent objects will be sorted based on distance from camera position to the object center. See Also: Camera.transparencySortMode.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Vector2
member.remarks: This structure is used in some places to represent 2D positions and vectors (e.g. texture coordinates in a Mesh or texture offsets in Material ). In the majority of other cases a Vector3 is used.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector2.Angle(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Returns the angle in degrees between from and to.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector2.ClampMagnitude(UnityEngine.Vector2,System.Single)
member.summary: Returns a copy of vector with its magnitude clamped to maxLength.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector2.Distance(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Returns the distance between a and b.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector2.Dot(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.remarks: Returns lhs . rhs. For normalized vectors Dot returns 1 if they point in exactly the same direction; -1 if they point in completely opposite directions; and a number in between for other cases (e.g. Dot returns zero if vectors are perpendicular). For vectors of arbitrary length the Dot return values are similar: they get larger when the angle between vectors decreases.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector2.Lerp(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,System.Single)
member.remarks: Interpolates between from and to by amount t. t is clamped between [0...1]. When t = 0 returns from. When t = 1 returns to. When t = 0.5 returns the average of from and to.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Vector2.magnitude
member.summary: Returns the length of this vector (Read Only).
member.remarks: The length of the vector is square root of (x*x+y*y). If you only need to compare magnitudes of some vectors, you can compare squared magnitudes of them using sqrMagnitude (computing squared magnitudes is faster). See Also: sqrMagnitude.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector2.Max(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Returns a vector that is made from the largest components of two vectors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector2.Min(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Returns a vector that is made from the smallest components of two vectors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector2.MoveTowards(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,System.Single)
member.summary: Moves a point current towards target.
member.remarks: This is essentially the same as Vector2.Lerp but instead the function will ensure that the speed never exceeds maxDistanceDelta. Negative values of maxDistanceDelta pushes the vector away from target.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector2.Normalize
member.summary: Makes this vector have a magnitude of 1.
member.remarks: When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is 1.0. Note that this function will change the current vector. If you want to keep the current vector unchanged, use normalized variable. If this vector is too small to be normalized it will be set to zero. See Also: normalized variable.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Vector2.normalized
member.summary: Returns this vector with a magnitude of 1 (Read Only).
member.remarks: When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is 1.0. Note that the current vector is unchanged and a new normalized vector is returned. If you want to normalize the current vector, use Normalize function. If the vector is too small to be normalized a zero vector will be returned. See Also: Normalize function.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector2.Scale(UnityEngine.Vector2)
member.summary: Multiplies two vectors component-wise.Multiplies every component of this vector by the same component of scale.

member.summary: Multiplies two vectors component-wise.Multiplies every component of this vector by the same component of scale.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.Vector3
member.remarks: This structure is used throughout Unity to pass 3D positions and directions around. It also contains functions for doing common vector operations. Besides the functions listed below, other classes can be used to manipulate vectors and points as well. For example the Quaternion and the Matrix4x4 classes are useful for rotating or transforming vectors and points.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Angle(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns the angle in degrees between from and to.
member.remarks: The angle returned is always the acute angle between the two vector (ie, the smaller of the two possible angles between them and never greater than 180 degrees).
member.param: The angle extends round from this vector.
The angle extends round to this vector.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.ClampMagnitude(UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Returns a copy of vector with its magnitude clamped to maxLength.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Cross(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.remarks: The cross product of two vectors results in a third vector which is perpendicular to the two input vectors. The result's magnitude is equal to the magnitudes of the two inputs multiplied together and then multiplied by the sine of the angle between the inputs. You can determine the direction of the result vector using the "left hand rule".

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Distance(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns the distance between a and b.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Dot(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.remarks: The dot product is a float value equal to the magnitudes of the two vectors multiplied together and then multiplied by the cosine of the angle between them. For normalized vectors Dot returns 1 if they point in exactly the same direction, -1 if they point in completely opposite directions and zero if the vectors are perpendicular.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Lerp(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.remarks: Interpolates between from and to by the fraction t. This is most commonly used to find a point some fraction of the way along a line between two endpoints (eg, to move an object gradually between those points). This fraction is clamped to the range [0...1]. When t = 0 returns from. When t = 1 returns to. When t = 0.5 returns the point midway between from and to.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Vector3.magnitude
member.summary: Returns the length of this vector (Read Only).
member.remarks: The length of the vector is square root of (x*x+y*y+z*z). If you only need to compare magnitudes of some vectors, you can compare squared magnitudes of them using sqrMagnitude (computing squared magnitudes is faster). See Also: sqrMagnitude.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Magnitude(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns the length of this vector (Read Only).
member.remarks: The length of the vector is square root of (x*x+y*y+z*z). If you only need to compare magnitudes of some vectors, you can compare squared magnitudes of them using sqrMagnitude (computing squared magnitudes is faster). See Also: sqrMagnitude.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Max(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns a vector that is made from the largest components of two vectors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Min(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns a vector that is made from the smallest components of two vectors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.MoveTowards(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary: Moves a point current in a straight line towards a target point.
member.remarks: The value returned by this function is a point maxDistanceDelta units closer to a target point along a line between current and target. If the target is closer than maxDistanceDelta then the returned value will be equal to target (ie, the movement will not overshoot the target). Negative values of maxDistanceDelta can be used to push the point away from the target.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Normalize
member.summary: Makes this vector have a magnitude of 1.
member.remarks: When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is 1.0. Note that this function will change the current vector. If you want to keep the current vector unchanged, use normalized variable. If this vector is too small to be normalized it will be set to zero. See Also: normalized variable.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Normalize(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Makes this vector have a magnitude of 1.
member.remarks: When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is 1.0. Note that this function will change the current vector. If you want to keep the current vector unchanged, use normalized variable. If this vector is too small to be normalized it will be set to zero. See Also: normalized variable.

If you want to normalize the current vector, use Normalize function. If the vector is too small to be normalized a zero vector will be returned. See Also: Normalize function.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.OrthoNormalize(UnityEngine.Vector3@,UnityEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Makes vectors normalized and orthogonal to each other.Makes vectors normalized and orthogonal to each other.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.OrthoNormalize(UnityEngine.Vector3@,UnityEngine.Vector3@,UnityEngine.Vector3@)
member.summary: Makes vectors normalized and orthogonal to each other.Makes vectors normalized and orthogonal to each other.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Project(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Projects a vector onto another vector.
member.remarks: To understand vector projection, imagine that onNormal is resting on a line pointing in its direction. Somewhere along that line will be the nearest point to the tip of vector. The projection is just onNormal rescaled so that it reaches that point on the line.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Reflect(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Reflects a vector off the plane defined by a normal.
member.remarks: The inNormal vector defines a plane (a plane's normal is the vector that is perpendicular to its surface). the inDirection vector is treated as a directional arrow coming in to the plane. The returned value is a vector of equal magnitude to inDirection but with its direction reflected.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.RotateTowards(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Rotates a vector current towards target.
member.remarks: This function is similar to MoveTowards except that the vector is treated as a direction rather than a position. The current vector will be rotated round toward the target direction by an angle of maxRadiansDelta, although it will land exactly on the target rather than overshoot. If the magnitudes of current and target are different then the magnitude of the result will be linearly interpolated during the rotation. If a negative value is used for maxRadiansDelta, the vector will rotate away from target until it is pointing in exactly the opposite direction, then stop.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Scale(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Multiplies two vectors component-wise.Multiplies every component of this vector by the same component of scale.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Scale(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Multiplies two vectors component-wise.Multiplies every component of this vector by the same component of scale.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Set(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Set x, y and z components of an existing Vector3.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.Slerp(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,System.Single)
member.remarks: Interpolates between from and to by amount t. The difference between this and linear interpolation (aka, "lerp") is that the vectors are treated as directions rather than points in space. The direction of the returned vector is interpolated by the angle and its magnitude is interpolated between the magnitudes of from and to. t is clamped between [0...1]. See Also: Lerp function.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.SmoothDamp(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3@,System.Single)
member.summary: Gradually changes a vector towards a desired goal over time.
member.remarks: The vector is smoothed by some spring-damper like function, which will never overshoot. The most common use is for smoothing a follow camera.
member.param: The position we are trying to reach.
The current velocity, this value is modified by the function every time you call it.
Approximately the time it will take to reach the target. A smaller value will reach the target faster.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.SmoothDamp(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3@,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Gradually changes a vector towards a desired goal over time.
member.remarks: The vector is smoothed by some spring-damper like function, which will never overshoot. The most common use is for smoothing a follow camera.
member.param: The position we are trying to reach.
The current velocity, this value is modified by the function every time you call it.
Approximately the time it will take to reach the target. A smaller value will reach the target faster.
Optionally allows you to clamp the maximum speed.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.SmoothDamp(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3@,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Gradually changes a vector towards a desired goal over time.
member.remarks: The vector is smoothed by some spring-damper like function, which will never overshoot. The most common use is for smoothing a follow camera.
member.param: The position we are trying to reach.
The current velocity, this value is modified by the function every time you call it.
Approximately the time it will take to reach the target. A smaller value will reach the target faster.
Optionally allows you to clamp the maximum speed.
The time since the last call to this function. By default Time.deltaTime.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.Vector3.sqrMagnitude
member.summary: Returns the squared length of this vector (Read Only).
member.remarks: The magnitude of a vector v is calculated as Mathf.Sqrt(Vector3.Dot(v, v)). However, the Sqrt calculation is quite complicated and takes longer to execute than the normal arithmetic operations. Calculating the squared magnitude instead of using the magnitude property is much faster - the calculation is basically the same only without the slow Sqrt call. If you are using magnitudes simply to compare distances, then you can just as well compare squared magnitudes against the squares of distances since the comparison will give the same result. See Also: magnitude.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.Vector3.SqrMagnitude(UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns the squared length of this vector (Read Only).
member.remarks: The magnitude of a vector v is calculated as Mathf.Sqrt(Vector3.Dot(v, v)). However, the Sqrt calculation is quite complicated and takes longer to execute than the normal arithmetic operations. Calculating the squared magnitude instead of using the magnitude property is much faster - the calculation is basically the same only without the slow Sqrt call. If you are using magnitudes simply to compare distances, then you can just as well compare squared magnitudes against the squares of distances since the comparison will give the same result. See Also: magnitude.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.WebCamTexture

member.name: P:UnityEngine.WebCamTexture.deviceName

member.remarks: This only has an effect when set while the camera is not running.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.WebCamTexture.devices
member.summary: Return a list of available devices.
member.remarks: This queries the system for the list of devices connected and it can be slow. You should cache this value by keeping a copy of the result if you want to use it repeatedly.

member.name: P:UnityEngine.WebCamTexture.didUpdateThisFrame
member.summary: Did the video buffer update this frame?
member.remarks: Use this to check if the video buffer has changed since the last frame. When setting a low frame rate, it is likely that the video updates slower then the game, so it does not make sense to do expensive video processing in each Update call, so check this value before doing any processing.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.WebCamTexture.GetPixel(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns pixel color at coordinates (x, y).
member.remarks: If the pixel coordinates are out of bounds (larger than width/height or small than 0), they will be clamped or repeat based on the texture's wrap mode. If you are reading a large block of pixels from the texture, it may be faster to use GetPixels which returns a whole block of pixel colors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.WebCamTexture.GetPixels
member.summary: Get a block of pixel colors.Get a block of pixel colors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.WebCamTexture.GetPixels(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a block of pixel colors.Get a block of pixel colors.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.WebCamTexture.GetPixels32
member.summary: Returns the pixels data in raw format.
member.remarks: This can be faster then calling GetPixels, as pixel data does not have to be converted to color structs, so you may want to use it if you need to do continuous processing on the video feed. You can optionally pass in an array of Color32s to use in colors to avoid allocating new memory each frame, which is faster when you are continuously reading data from the camera. The array needs to be initialized to a length matching width * height of the texture. If you don't pass an array, GetPixels32 will allocate one for you and return it.

member.name: M:UnityEngine.WebCamTexture.GetPixels32(UnityEngine.Color32[])

You can optionally pass in an array of Color32s to use in colors to avoid allocating new memory each frame, which is faster when you are continuously reading data from the camera. The array needs to be initialized to a length matching width * height of the texture. If you don't pass an array, GetPixels32 will allocate one for you and return it.
